universal_emergency_number.description: A universal emergency number for reporting unlawful detention. Can be used to gain immediate help as well as long term support for the detainees and their families.
universal_emergency_number.creator: 7fca212600e8b5fb31005b23071188e8

comments.text: Rashmi! Thank you for your contribution. We really appreciate how much thought and time you put into this concept. And particularly liked your insights around how to support unlawful detainees after release. Thank you.
Appreciating the straightforward simplicity of this 911 for unlawful detention!
I agree with Vincent. Simple yet efficient!

Hi Rashmi,yesterday I was talking with a friend who works for Unicef and worked 5 years in Congo. Her husband works for the UN in Congo as well and it seems that a year ago he did a project with Vodaphone and a local NGO to start an emergency number that people can contact if they see robbers or other dangerous people in a village. People most often send an SMS to this number. According to her, this has been very useful. I thought I'll share the story with you. cheers, al
Thanks for sharing the story Anne. This system can definitely be adapted for many such purposes. Is there a website or any info that we can read online about their project ?

Hi Rashmi, the friend I talked to did not of a website. I'll ask her husband who implemented. Yet he's currently in Kinshasa and with the elections things are quite "busy". I'll let you know if I find more.
I meant did not know of a website...

Hi Rashmi, there is no website on that particular project of emergency network which had been implemented  with mobile phones. Yet, here is a related project: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15173291
Hi, I found an article on the emergency network I was referring to :-) http://www.refugeesinternational.org/policy/field-report/drc-support-community-based-tools-monusco

Rashmi, this idea of Universal Emergency Number is very similar to the idea of ChildLine - a tele-helpline for children in India that has been running very successfully.In 1996, Jeroo Billmoria (a social entrepreneur) from India launched CHILDLINE (Dial 1098 Ten-Nine-Eight), India's first toll-free tele-helpline for street children in distress. As of March 2011, total of 21 Million calls since inception have been serviced by CHILDLINE service and operates in 172 cities/districts in 30 States and UTs through its network of 415 partner organisations across India.http://www.childlineindia.org.in/And yes, this model is scalable across geographies and cultures too. After Childline's success, Jeroo went further and founded Child Helpline International (http://www.childhelplineinternational.org/) - an initiative that runs similar children helplines in more than 150 countries across the world and responds to 14-18 million calls annually.To learn more about ChildLine, I would suggest you to go through these resources:1) Video - An Introduction to ChildLine Indiahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_P8pmSfI6Y2) Book - How Childline 1098 started and how it works (Pages 8 to 24)http://www.childlineindia.org.in/pdf/CHILDLINE-Day-Night.pdf3) Jeroo Billimoria's talk at TEDx Hamburghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l8ppaYLGtEkSome more facts:- ChildLine started as an independent initiative, but eventually government started supporting and funding the Childline and other nonprofits who provide support to the children.- Childline partners with several allies and NGOs to help provide support to children in far off locations.- Depending on the urgency of the situation, after a child calls, a local representative reaches the child within 60 minutes to 1 week from the time the call was made to the helpline.

Yatin, Thanks for sharing about Childline. I will be updating my post with examples like these where the concept has been successfully implemented. The success of this system lies in the fact that it can be used by anyone without the hassle of having to download an app or using specifically modified phones hardwares. All you need is access to a phone - could be a cell phone, a landline or a simple payphone. A friend of mine works at Childline and I am trying to get more info from him regarding this.

Simple and straightforward - and makes so much sense.Here in Oz we use 000 instead oif 911 (and in UK it used to be 999) -in addition we have specific numbers for suicide prevention services and depression support services etcI can see this service being administered in a similar fashion with volunteers trained to gain vital information quickly and efficiently.I also saw this concvept as complementary to Anne's PACT where individual numbers could be registered for pre-arranged responses.Calls from pre-registered numbers to this number would trigger specific actions. General calls to the number would be processed as originally envisaged.I'm sure all support and emergency numbers get hoax calls and suffer from various mistakes - no design can make them perfect but each call becomes a chance to learn about pitfalls and improve the service.

I was updating my concept to add a helpline feature for suicide prevention services and depression support when you posted your suggestions! Telepathy is it ?? :P Great to see someone thinking on similar lines :)For volunteering, maybe NGOs can also train the detainees and their families (after they are being released) for say consulting or call monitoring. It will serve as - 1. a moral booster for the callers to learn from experiences from the ones who have successfully managed to come out of such situations.  2. a work opportunity for the detainees.. and chance for a fresh start

I was watching the interview of a young guy - Syed Imran Khan, a BTech student in Hyderabad, India who was acccused of being responsible for a bomb blast in India at the age of 22.. After a prolonged legal battle which lasted for 18 months, his innocence was finally proven. However, his real struggle began after he returned to the society. His community refused to accept him, his family was outcasted and attacked, his sister was asked to leave the school, his father got demoted, he was not allowed to complete his education, no one was ready to give him a job. Syed was emotionally so shattered and felt so helpless that we that he became suicidal.Syed's story made me wonder how we could provide support for people like him. Our efforts should not just concentrate on reporting detainment, providing legal information, getting support for families during the crisis but it should also continue after the detainee is released in order to help him find his much deserved place in the society. The Universal Emergency number could also cater as a helpline to provide consultations on depression or suicide prevention. Something similar to Child Helpline International (http://www.childhelplineinternational.org). After Syeds interview aired on the television, a company tracked him through facebook and offered him a job.   I am sure there are many such companies, schools, training institutes who would be ready to support the detainees by giving them a chance to get back on their feet. NGOs can team up with such organizations and the related information can be shared through the helpline service.

The Wells College Innovation Lab has been searching ideas and we thought yours was very interesting! We began to brainstorm ideas that could possible help this or just be put out there. We came up with a walkie talkie add on for the phone that is similar to the universal emergency number. This could also be a device built into the phone already much like nextel already has for one of their phones on the market. Instead of using the number, you could press a button and talk to a call center run by interns organized by Amnesty International. If the center was run by interns it would be more economically viable for everyone since they don't need to be paid. The reason we are using this kind of technology is because it's quicker to just talk to someone instantaneously than send a text or find a number to call. (Rachel, Hannah, Forrest, Richard, Giavarna)

Hi Rachel, I do like the idea of having a shortcut rather than finding and dialing the whole number.. Few questions however,- how feasible is it to get this technology in phones other than nextel. - is it possible to adapt this technology to maybe send a video or a picture .. like click a picture and press a button to directly send it to the call center. :P .. just trying to think aloud - can we look for options like assigning the number to "1-touch dialing" key already on the phone.

We were wondering how a detainee would have time to send a text message or take pictures of the situation without the use of an application? Is there a preset button or other activation for this? I think time is of the essence in this type of situation...

I have tried to keep the concept limited to just a "number" so that the user-1. can make a call with a landline phone or a payphone where installing such app or button is not an option.2. does not have to install a specific app, a data connection or a particular hardware modification in his cellphone...It will be similar to and as simple as calling 911 ..Also it can be used not just by the detainee but by anyone who wants to report an unlawful detainment. Also in many parts of the world people do not have the resources or even the knowledge to download and use apps. For example in India people are much more comfortable dialing a number or sending an sms than using an app.. most of the phone used are not even compatible for running any apps.

another "global" concept, I would like to hear more about this, Amnesty and individual organisations can only ever do so much in terms of a problem this huge, how do we share responsibility, what would happen with the information, how would we avoid raising expectations? what would we all do with the information coming in and how might we stop it being corrupted, sorry for all the questions, thinking aloud really but I love the simplicity and old school nature of this concept,.thanks s

The role of the local organizations can be to educate the local communities through schools, colleges, offices and raise a local army of trusthworthy volunteers  .. There can be various teams locally that can share the responsibility. I think the families would turn for support from their friends, neighbours... someone around them rather than going directly to a human rights org... and local volunteers can really play a key role in such situations.I have updated the illustration with responsibilities divided between the national orgs, local orgs, communities and volunteers. Let me know if you have any suggestions.

Hi Rashmi, Ushahidi came across similar issues of responsibility and how to best network with aid organizations on the ground when their platform was deployed to locate victims and direct emergency services in Haiti: http://www.ushahidi.com/They were able to set up an international SMS line and map the incidents so that emergency services could be efficiently disbursed to clusters of reports, rather than one by one. They've also been working on developing ways of verifying and mapping real-time data.  It's always important to think of ways to triangulate your data and make sure that your platform isn't 'gamed' or leaky.Best of luck!
Thanks Adriana. Ushahidi is a great platform and there is certainly so much to learn from all their projects. I think their Crowdmap tool would be really helpful for many concepts in this challenge.

I co-teach at course called CRISIS NETWORKS at Parsons/NewSchool that may be helpful in your design/research refinement process: http://crisisnetworks.tumblr.com/One of my students designed a program called MSAADA, an Ushahidi-based emergency response app that builds on virtual and local volunteer networks to coordinate rescue efforts: http://hirumianajones.tumblr.com/post/2146777192/last-hopefully-iteration-for-the-msaada-appOur class Tumblr has more proposed design interventions and resources that may be of help too!
Nice one, Adriana  cheers for weighing in! And perhaps your students might be interested in joining in refinement conversations too.
Great idea Meena - I'll ask them to chime in!

Great stuff, Adriana! You might also be interested to check out this post about OpenIDEO + the classroom: http://www.openideo.com/fieldnotes/openideo-team-notes/openideouniversity We're always excited to have fresh hearts and minds join our collaborative community.

Hello Rashmi, thank you for your great idea. The expert panel has short-listed your concept for the next phase of the Amnesty challenge. The team liked the simplicity of your concept, and was wondering if youd be willing to push the idea further. What is the feasibility of pulling off a universal emergency number? How would we pull it off? Who might respond? Is it a phone number? The universal access is a compelling aspect of this idea, how would maintenance work?

To pull off a universal emergency number we will have to work with telephone service providers like Vodafone, T-mobile, AT&T, etc. Since they already have their IT systems in place in so many countries, they can help us build network trees down the line. Also, they can help us with personalising the number to suit our needs. For example - We can have a 10 digit phone number or a simple 3-4 digit number or a toll free number as per our need. During the concepting phase, we discussed many options for the number like 111 based on Jason's symbol, 3733 Anne's Shift Freedom concept, etc. However, many of these numbers are already being used by the service providers for customer care or other similar services (111 is the customer care number for Vodafone in India) . So these service providers would be the best guides while selecting a universal number and then practically implementing it. Another option could be working in collaboration with Google.org . The Google Voice service could be adapted to fit our needs. Currently, with Google Voice you get a personalised number for a $10 fee. All the calls, sms, mms to this number are then forwarded to a web-based application similar to gmail. This can be very helpful to keep a record of all the cases and will be easy for maintenance too. It even has a feature which allows all the calls to be transcripted in English. However, Google Voice is not yet available in all the countries so we might even want to look at other similar services out there. I am sure the openIDEO community will have more suggestions on this.
I alwais love the simply way

Very nice idea indeed. Simple but could be very effective indeed like 911 (see inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/9-1-1).I guess the issue would be to make sure that the number "sticks".I also think it'll be nice if somehow you could like it to Jason's universal symbol: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-universal-unlawfully-detained-symbol-to-spread-in-case-of-emergency/His symbol has 3 "bars". It's a triple number... I think that building on each other, the concepts could be stronger or reinforce their power and stick better in people's memory.

I am working on some options to link it to Jason's symbol.. Also linking it to Anne's Shift Freedom concept, I think that  something like #3733 which you get by typing "FREE" on the phone keypad could work. It will be easy to remember and relate as well.

Great! Looking forward to the evolution. Anne in a comment on the Universal symbol suggested 111 as the symbolic number. It could also become the universal emergency number: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-universal-unlawfully-detained-symbol-to-spread-in-case-of-emergencyUsing the Shift freedom campaign is a good idea ... It'll be great to make people aware of them...

Hey Rashmi this is totally great; and if we can combine it with the various Shift Freedom campaigns and the Universal Symbol, I think we'll be on to something really powerful. I'm going to try to synthesize some of these in an update to my concept. Nice work!
Great! looking forward to your update :)
This is a good idea! I would love to see how these resources come together and collaborate for such a great cause!
I like the simplicity of this. And also that it takes into account that information sharing needs to be made as easy as possible, and as accessible as possible. Great concept!
Loving your illustration here, Rashmi!
Thanks Meena. Tried to create an illustration as simple and easily relatable as the concept itself.

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

comments.text: I'm glad you've given us an opportunity to think truly low-tech.I was hoping to throw in a resource  for low tech distance communication: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_telecommunication#TimelinesThe thing that stood out most for me was heliographs (think mirror + sun=light morse code) which various countries used to communicate in the battlefield till as late as 1975. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heliograph

This is really great David. It's easy (at least for me) to get seduced by the word "technology" in the brief, but as everyone's already expressed we'll have to be extra limber when concepting. Thanks for this!

I think that it is incredibly important to think of ideas that aknowledge the issue of internet shutdown and ones that don't depend on a particular device that is easily confiscated, destroyed, or that can lose battery life in a short period of time. I also think it is extremely beneficial to think of the term "technology" as encompassing tools outside of contemporary, high-tech options and to expand the term to include more possiblities.

Hi David,I love the fact that you're trying to explore what could we do "without the internet". I think it is particularly important in the context of this challenge where many people who are unlawfully detained as well as their families and friends might not have access to the internet. This is going to be important to keep in mind in the concepting phase.It also made me reflect on the origins of a notion of "the public" and the "public sphere" (and the political consciousness associated to it). Philosophers and sociologists like Habermas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Habermas) and historians like Eisenstein (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Eisenstein) relate the emergence of a public sphere to the invention of the press, the development of books and newspapers which allowed the circulation of ideas... cheers,al
also I like to think of the horse as a technology: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/social-epidemics-paul-revere-and-its-famous-nocturnal-ride/:-)
A great provocation to all to think widely across hi-tech and lo-tech solutions. Looking forward to hearing more in the upcoming Conception phase!

comments.text: Ana Im so sad we didnt get to the final 16 :( .. I really liked your concept! But well done girl!

Ana, I remembered this installation by Hansen and Rubin for "Native Land" an exhibition in Paris and I thought it was quite inspiring and aligned with your concept: http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xb76ef_exit-remittances-sending-money-home_creation?start=21#from=embediframe

hi Anne-Laure, thanks for thinking of me and the concept. It's an interesting visualization, and one I hadn't imagined yet. I like how the artists describe it as :  "sharing his nostalgia about the magnitude of the world, about its scale ", a thought shared by me too with regards to this challenge and the human rights issues always affecting our vast population. I'd like to show the world the magnitude and scale of this problem too, in a precise and professional way. Thank u! :)

Small update: Today Bloomberg launched their new Company website, which is a live stream of infographics relating to them, with an infinite scroll page property: http://www.bloomberg.com/company/# I think it's pretty neat visually, and although it is interactive, it's not very visual in terms of the way it displays its data ( majority is in numbers) but I still really like the visual style. We could insert on this platform a sharing capability of each piece of data displayed, and even be able to customize the dashboard with data you are interested in following.

wow!  I was too busy to hang out here and looked what I missed!  Thought I would check in one more time before the "concepting" is over.  if the Amnesty challenge is How can technology help people working to uphold human rights in the face of unlawful detention?what is the goal?  is the goal to prevent unlawful detention by early detection of fear through risk analysis; find, watch over and free those detained, using information from insiders, family, casual observers; identify the source of power causing the unlawful acts and prevent future acts of human rights violation; increase global awareness to put pressure on governments and gain global support (financial and data providers ...)...? how can data help with these and other goals?  data can help with everything.  time, patterns, location...time: at what point does the criticality of the situation demand an Amber Alert type system?  when is it too late, demanding a shift in the type of operation?early alerts and hunches, like the globalpulse folks have implemented at hunchworks, can be used to drive human intervention - early intervention, with the goal of prevention. with pattern analysis many things can be determined, including where the hot spots are.  location clustering of reports can be used for rescue missions and reporting... I'm sorry but I haven't had the time to read through all the wonderful inspirations and concepts to contribute fully here.  Data collection and visualization can be used to tell many stories.  What is the story you are looking for in this data?  http://book.flowingdata.com/  In the video, flowingdata says "first you need the data".  I would say, first you need the question or problem.  Then, what data will help you answer that question or contribute to the story around that question or problem.  Then how will this data be collected, stored, tagged, structured, curated ....? How will relationships between the data elements be defined?  How will the context be established?  What type of analysis of the data is most effective to answer the question or tell the story? How will the quality be determined? .... some things to inspire (post inspiration phase) from Brainpickings/Maria Popova and Google1. To aid in the visualization of the data- 7 essential books on data visualization and computational art http://www.brainpickings.org/index.php/2011/06/30/best-books-data-visualization-computational-art/ 2. visual storytelling: New Language for the Information Age http://www.brainpickings.org/index.php/2011/10/25/visual-storytelling-gestalten/ and 3. Data from Google http://www.thinkwithgoogle.co.uk/quarterly/data/top-10-simon-rogers.html4.  Dirty Data - This is a very important consideration before visualizing any data.  GIGO - Garbage In Garbage Out.  I ran into this one today http://ideaexchange.quarry.com/2011/09/the-impact-of-dirty-data-and-what-one-marketer-did-about-it/  Sorry I can't read through all of the comments and contribute more specifically ....time is always a problem...hope this adds something to the conversation.  Good Luck... I will check back in as soon as I can.

Hi Marnie !Wow, thanks for your super kind contribution. I'm very happy you stopped by my concept again, and made me re-think things again. I really like the Google's Think Quarterly previous Data Issue. So as you pointed out, data can help with everything, and it is a current trend these days, as there is so much data out there, there is a huge demand for people who can interpret it. And I think we could do it here too... I also agree with 1st having a question/problem to solve, then 2nd find relevant sources and information to feed and collect the data. I think what still needs some defining here is how to store, collect and curate the data, in terms of logistics and technology. However I do think there is loads of tools and sources out there for us to begin planning this platform ! Thanks Marnie for your valuable words and collaboration.

Hi Ana, Glad you found it helpful.  I had that old and marked up  Think Quarterly on my desk for another project with a deadline of today!  As I was flipping thru it, I thought it might help this challenge as well.  Convergence of thought, in time and concept.   This is all standard Data Science.  Although it is a very new field and experts are in high demand and short supply, people have done projects like this one, very successfully, many times.  Please look at the Global Pulse link  that I posted somewhere.  They have done what you are "concepting" here.  They are among the most experienced Data Scientists on the planet.  They have a team of designers and developers that are top of the field.  To re-invent the wheel, so to speak, would be prohibitive,  both in terms of cost and time.  They key, imho, as with all great projects is to collaborate.  In this case, collaborate with the global pulse team and build on their experience, platform and design investment.  Like jumping on a trampoline vs jumping on the ground - you'll go faster, higher and have more fun:)  I love these projects so much that I cannot resist the temptation to "concept" with OpenIDEO, but I must get back to work now!!

Hi Anna,(Felicitaciones) Congratulations I loved the concept! Infographics is a powerful tool!..Anne-Laure sent me a link with your concept and Im sure we can join forces to pull something very interesting. have a look to my concept and tell me if you would like to build something together ;) ...

Gracias Nayda ! Thanks for your words.. I will check your concept like you said!Yes, I believe data is the new oil, the new rich raw materials that we can use to empower us, so that is why I believe in this concept. Absolutely, I'm really open to everyone suggesting ways fo collaborating and improving on this concept. :)

Very well thought out and cohesive. Platforms that allow for a number of different inputs and interactions are most effective because information and circumstances in detainee situations can be so varied. This allows gives everyone an opportunity to view and share information in whatever form they may have a available. Great concept!

Hi Abbey ! Thanks for your comment. This platform would like you say allow a number of different inputs (Still yet to be defined) and output into empowering and understandable visual data, regarding human rights and unlawful detentions occurring in the world. You mention a last point which hadn't yet been too emphasized which is regarding 'sharing information', maybe we could make this a central point with each visual interpretation of data: easy to share. So it makes the circle complete, anyone can: input info (contribute data + stories) + output the visual interpretations of it. Thanks Abbey !

Hi Anna,I love the idea! In fact I was thinking of exploring this weekend the 2 inspirations that I'm referring to below. Great to see you starting the conversation.It can be very powerful and there's been a lot of work on data visualization (from Tufte's work to more recently books like Information is Beautiful).Two inspirations you might want to check:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/infographics-a-call-to-action/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/making-policy-public/I love the idea of having "live representations of data". While I'm not an expert, what I know from data visualization and infographics makes me wonder how this is possible. These beautiful infographics that we see are based on data analysis and these are hard to update regularly (let's not say live). It might be possible (as I said I'm not an expert) but I think it will require a lot of resources.Maybe an option is to have a team designed the infographics based on the analysis of a certain set of data (provided by the sources you referred to) and then you could may be "feed" the system. I remember an add for an online bank and they had an interesting data visualization based on customers' feedback. I'll try to find the reference.

It is indeed possible Anne-Laure!  That is what the UN Global Pulse folks and others with open platforms like http://www.ushahidi.com/ Ushahidi (interactive mapping, info collection and vizualization) aim to achieve.  For example, they can plot information coming in from mobile phones and other sources to determine clusters and other things.  They all capture the data in both real time and in the background and send it to beautiful applications, like the maps of ushahidi, and custom built infographics.  Hans Rosling http://www.ted.com/talks/hans_rosling_on_global_population_growth.html is a spectacular example of telling a powerful story in a visual way with otherwise meaningless data.  In this example, he does not capture his data real-time, but from a big data set.  The technology in this field is changing rapidly, with more tools constantly becoming available - hardware, software to develop platforms, open source platforms and commercial tools.

Thanks Marnie for the expertise. This is great news. I guess the question then became what are the resources needed to make this concept possible. We also need to explore the low-tech options but Ana has already started thinking of the options.
I would suggest, low tech and high tech for the capture of the data, but high tech for the storage, analysis, aggregation, visualization and retrieval.....

Hi again, I've just checked the ushahidi website and in fact it is a great mapping tool. In fact, I passed the information to Julian for his map of freedom concept. Cross-pollination! :-)I know the work of Hans Rosling http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jbkSRLYSojo&feature=player_embedded#!. It's great. Yet, in this case there's a lot of work - in terms of analysis, design and production. I guessed that's what I had in mind when I thought of data visualization and that's why I was wondering how much real-time / live data visualization one could do.

some resources to consider:  data scientists to design and write the algorithms and heuristics, designers to map the data onto beautiful story telling visualizations, computer scientists to build robust back ends and select tools to build and open source to build upon, business analysts to determine the requirements ... (not in any specific order).  sounds prohibitive, but it can be crowdsourced, with excellent leadership.  So the key is in the leadership, imho.  with the tools available today, a lot can be done very quickly.

I should add here that by collaborating with the UN Global Pulse team, you get to build on the work that they have already done.   that paves the way for simple add ons to accomplish unique features, specific to this project.  they have all of the resources listed above and have done a lot of the design and requirements work already.

Hello to Anne-Laure and Marnie!Thanks for the great conversation been ushered by this concept, it's so exciting see you both so engaged!Anne Laure:Thanks so much for the both inspiration's you linked to. The second one by Meena has a very interesting Summary, which includes a very important word I missed here ( Accessible ) : this should be an "accessible, meaningful and shared" experience. I look forward to your concept after this weekend :) Data visualization in itself has been a huge trend, and it would be interesting to see how it could work for this case. Communication design is so important as is the information being produced, so if we combine both I believe we could makes something powerful! The Ushuahidi project has a Product called Crowdmap ( http://www.ushahidi.com/products/crowdmap ) that could possible be outsourced or bought to be included in this new platform, that would gain greater momentum, power and respect in the eyes of the world, if it were sponsored by Amnesty International, for example. And I love The Information is Beautiful Book! I have a copy myself, and I thought of taking pictures of some of it's pages and post here...Actually I might just update my entry and do that (if I don't infringe any copyright laws) thanks for the inspiration!Marnie:Great  information you are sharing, thanks so much! It's great to see your view on this. Hans Rosling's talks are indeed very interesting and add great stimulation to this concept. It also reminds me of National Geographic's recent video '7 Billion and Counting', a very visual and impactful way to explain the population boom and put it into context: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4B2xOvKFFz4I agree with you that a lot of the technology is out there already. I am studying at a Digital school and we get bombarded with a lot of news and new technologies that are being used to simplify the way we communicate. Using API's from Twitter and Facebook alone, a lot of information can be quickly translated into data immediately, for example. Here are a couple links of people doing great work on data visualization: - http://flowingdata.com/- http://jess3.com/I also list some more on my Delicious page: http://www.delicious.com/anaceciliaboman/dataThanks for the great collaboration AL & Marnie!

Hi Ana,there's indeed been a lot of discussion.I love Information is beautiful too. I like the picture!I agree that looking into using Crowdmap from Ushuahidi could be a good idea. Yet (to build upon Amanda's point), you need to choose what kind of data. This is open for you to define in Ushahidi product.I think building upon data collected and produced by other platforms as you suggested in your description is a good idea.BTW you might also want to check: http://www.ushahidi.com/products/crowdmap )

Hi Anne -L!Thanks :) You and Amanda are very correct - choosing what data to display is VERY important. I think this concept would greatly benefit also with input & perspectives from people that have been involved in problematic situations or have tried to share information about a cause they have been affected by. Like this I could try and understand what it is EXACTLY people share the MOST in these high-risk situations. I need more real insights from the people that are being affected to improve this too. I think I'll do some research on this and try and get closer to people in the unfortunate inside of these problems. I recently went to see the premier of this documentary here in Stockholm, it was about real stories of people involved in the Arab Uprising, and in the premier night some of the actors ( real people ) were there for a Q&A and it was really interesting:  http://www.zerosilence.org/ It's a beautiful and emotional story. The husband of one of the directors has worked at my school, I could try and ask him some questions and thoughts on this kind of service. At this moment, some of the data I see visualize with this service could be:- Specific to Region ( like Amanda said in her latest comment above)- Specific to Media Usage ( if people are sharing this info via e-mail, mobile (sms) Tweets, Facebook etc)- Specific to Words ( e.g. Arab Uprising: Fear; Help; Unlawful etc) However as I said I think this needs some input from someone that has been in a situation like this, do you agree ?The Crowdmap is great, I had mentioned it in my post above your last one, and I think we could definitely deploy it on our website : http://crowdmap.com/

Hi,yes, you did mention the crowdmap and I was confirming that it'll be great to use it but my point is that it is a tool that requires you to define (at least from what I understand) what data you want... I guess you have two options: the first one, which I thought was your original idea - to get data from other platforms and interpret them and visualize them; the second one, to get your own data - if you were to implement crowdmap in your platform.Regarding talking with people who have been in a situation looking for data, that is indeed (and always :-) ) an excellent idea to take an "ethnographic" type of approach. It's always hard to build scenarios from what we believe are the needs.The type of person you want to interview highlights the interactive nature of the website: someone who is involved in a situation and wants to share the information... Definitely important to get insights from these "users" as it'll be key to think about the features of your platform. This leads me to another question: who would be the main users / audience of this platform?   From you concept description "To produce and display real-time infographics to improve the communication of a movement's messages and data surrounding them that is being produced all over the world." I felt your aim was to increase public awareness, but also provide more specific information to some NGOs and policy makers... I also felt that the aim was mostly "represent" (in an interactive, meaningful, lively way) and share information about unlawful detention. Yet, I'm not completely sure... Can you clarify? all works but I've just realized that maybe I was unclear.still thinking here :-)

Hi Anne-Laure!Such great questions and issues you bring up, that is what I need to re-define this concept, I understand it might not sound very clear as I should have thought about the smaller details before posting it! But, let me try and answer ure' questions so this becomes clearer! 1- The Aim: "To produce and display real-time infographics to improve the communication of a movement's messages and data surrounding being produced all over the world." I think I am missing a second aim, which is to inform anyone out there being affected by a movement or problem, with free and understandable data, instead of having to search on news channels about what is going on. This platform would crowd source it for you, from the real people being affected, with real info.  2- Where does the info come from: For this question I wanted to integrate the other concepts mentioned as I thought they had great potential to partner with this concept. The Crowdmap could be our second partner of info gathering, and maybe focus on TWO types of visual data we offer: 1 from the crowd map, 2. from texts, tweets emails, videos etc being sent in via the other 3 concepts' channels.3- Who is the audience? (This is how I see it) 1: Someone being affected by a human rights issue; or a friend or family member or someone being affected; who HAVE access to technology to stay up-to date about what is being said about it. For ex ppl being affected by a cause but can't participate in a relevant rally being held, they can accompany the live flow of info coming in, videos, tweets, regional specific info etc. 2: Organizations that combat human rights issues, like NGO's & Policy Makers that you mention, could use this as a tool to access and supervise what current problems are being reported on the 'radar' of this live data feed, that maybe are not appearing in the Media. I know anonymity is a big issue, as has been discussed in Vincent's Amnesty Observer App, so maybe we could come up with a solution to this that also protects users from 'trolling' like Manuel mentioned above.What do you think? I think I need to redefine the concept a bit further with the great conversations that've been flowing on here! Thank u :)

Hey Anne-Laure and Ana!I'm switching to this thread (as opposed to the one I started) for two reasons, the first is that I've been doing some thinking as to what a helpful infographic might entail and I have some additional thoughts for you, and the second is that I want to respond specifically to your most recent comment Ana.  Thank you for clarifying some of your goals for this concept!  It was very helpful in terms of giving me a brainstorming direction to go in :)So, here are my thoughts.  I was looking at the Mashable link that Marnie posted and thought one of the websites held particular promise in terms of addressing some of your goals Ana.I came at this from the perspective of finding a way to get friends and family affected by detainment a way to stay up-to-date on the most recent news by developing an infographic that would incorporate the different types of immediate data from the 3 different concepts mentioned.Here is a link to the website you can refer to because I'll be referencing it in order to explain my thoughts (you'll notice I've already programmed in a map):http://www.trulia.com/for_sale/x_map/resale,new_homes_lt/Memphis,TN/So, first you'll notice that this map has a very simple Google-maps (ish) interface.  I think this is ideal because of its simplicity and ease of understanding.  If there is location data captured within the data that would be coming in from all 3 concepts, this interface would be ideal because it would allow that location info to be mapped.If you refer to the link, where the real estate website has the balloons on the map labeled by price, I think the balloons could be labeled based on the date or time uploaded.  Additionally, you'll notice that if you move your mouse cursor over an individual balloon a street view of the house for sale appears.  In the context of this concept, I see the original posting appearing.  So, in the videos coming from my concept a miniature frame of the video would appear along with the title (much like the information displayed in a YouTube listing.  With a tweet the tweet itself and the author of the tweet's picture and profile link might appear, and so on.  So this map could track all incoming information from the 3 concepts all in on map, and all for one region.I'd also like to point out that since everything would be based on location information, anything uploaded (i.e., video) should be in the language of that region so there wouldn't be any translation issues.Finally, what this graphic has that is really neat is the ability to search *within the map*.  (You can see that little checkbox right underneath the location information in the search bar on the left.)  The implications of such a "search within the map" feature, would be the ability of family members, say, to search a particular date to try to find information about their loved one.  Or to search a particular source of data, i.e., Twitter.  Or perhaps even as specific as name.  Or maybe they want to narrow it down to headlines so that they can try to follow the most recent news about the protests...I can see how such a map might have profound implications for family and friends trying to stay on top of the most recent information.  Since I'm not sure exactly what you're looking for, I don't know if this helps, but hopefully it'll at least give you food for thought! :)

Hi Amanda!Thanks for this SUPER post, with great and rich info ! I glad my clarification helped, I think it might have been a bitty foggy in the beginning ... I think you're exactly on the right track of my mind-frame for this idea too, I especially liked your focus, which i think is one of the most important ones with this concept: "finding a way to get friends and family affected by detainment a way to stay up-to-date on the most recent news by developing an infographic that would incorporate the different types of immediate data from the 3 different concepts mentioned." Your map example with the Real estate is simple yet very straightforward. I was thinking something similar too, using Google Maps API, which is rally simple. What we must not forget though, regarding Map systems is that we could use Crowdmap service by Ushahidi for this which already maps a lot of info for us : http://crowdmap.com/ However i'm not sure it collects videos too but i assume so! But I think you are right, a map does have a great emphasis and is so easy to recognize search with by region. With regards to translating languages that is interesting, maybe we could offer the local source language, and a translation in English too so Amnesty staff or policy makers could keep track of what is being said! Like you say the family members/friends of a detainee might want to narrow information down from the infographic website in different ways, so this would be a particular area to investigate for this concept - in what visual ways would they prefer to search and see searchable info ?In terms of the 'hovering mouse' over details like you showed with your map, I've seen very interesting HTML5 experiments this year, using great visuals using the new  element, and I particularly like the way the Tweets are displayed when you hover a circle on this website, check it out: http://9elements.com/io/projects/html5/canvas/ Thanks for everything you said, it is great food for thought, and in fact this week I am going to try and VISUALIZE my concept better in the form of an experience diagram, in flow chart kind of way , so it is easier to explain and understand!Thanks Amanda, so inspiring to 'collaborate' with you :)

Hi Ana,I've loved reading through the discussion of this concept, there are a ton of great ideas for how we can visualize this data. Crowdmap seems like a great resource and a good way to give structure to data collection as well.Another tool to check out is IBM's Many Eyes: http://www-958.ibm.com/ where you can create simple data visualizations quickly. This may be a good way to prototype different kinds of data to see what's most visually insightful, particularly for data is that not map-based. For example, you could see what kind of data could be gleaned from twitter (popular phrases, locations, or names associated with human rights hotspots) and try plotting it a couple different ways: word cloud, over time, geographically, etc.Hopefully, this kind of testing could help you figure out what the most powerful data will look like before an event happens (and the demand for information is immediate), to shape data collection.
Congrats on being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Wow what an honour! Thank you so much. I need to refine this concept after such great inputs I got from the collaborators below! :)
and looking forward to see the concept evolve and hopefully help in the process. Congrats Ana!
Congrats Ana, very cool!  Like A-L, I too am looking forward to seeing your concept evolve.  Looking forward to your updates :)

Hi Amanda and A-L! Thanks for the kind words. Absolutely, I think there is loads you and everyone else can still contribute to help refine this, and I still want to devise a visual flow diagram of how info would be 'fed' and outputted... hopefully next week I'll have some time to sit down and update everything! Keep up the wonderful help :) much appreciated ! Thank u!
Fab discussion guys. This really exemplifies our notion of 'better together' at OpenIDEO. Keep conversing & building!

Hey Ana, I love the idea, but I have question for you:How can you control the quality of info produced? I mean a lot of 'trolling' can be done, and bad inputs that don't really make any sense, eg. imagine someone playing around with it: 'Let me put on the Human Rights app that I am going to 'spank' my GF so hard that she needs help.'  - Therefore the 'all involved' parameter needs to be reviewed IMHO.

Hi Manuel! Thanks for the great input. You bring up a very important point that I hope the community can help with too, as I don't have a definite answer to.In my view, we could use some Game Mechanics reward system for the people submitting information through various channels :1- people could sign in via Twitter, Facebook or create a completely new profile (similar to how OpenIDEO profiles work)2- with each submitted peace of info, a rating could system could be enforced, before the info is evaluated, and turned into a visual interpretation. Similar to how Couch Surfing works - u never know how to trust the person you're contacting, apart from the reviews and the 'Vouching' gesture included for each user. Maybe points could be awarded for each piece of info shared. I know this would make the data interpretation longer and take away the immediate value of this platform : Fast and Real Time info of Amnesty related issues at one time...but it is one possibility!However, it will always be hard to control 'trolling', as it can be present anywhere, ever on this platform we are communicating right now. My optimistic hope is that this platform would only reach individuals wanting to help a cause, a person, a friend or just someone who cares about sharing information that can help someone else, but you're right the 'all involved parameter' can be a limitation too. Do you have any suggestions how to still make this a valuable and safe platform while not excluding possible contributors?Thanks :)

Hi Ana, I'm glad to see my post inspired you :)  I am a data geek, so I love the idea of using infographics!!  I especially like the idea of using infographics as a way to encourage intranational social responsibility (yup, I made that phrase up, but that's what it seems like you're getting at).  Could you be a little more specific on the types of data you would like to collect and how they would be displayed?  For instance, would you combine multiple types of data into one infograph?  Or would you have separate infographs for varying types of information?  What patterns are you hoping to capture/picture are you trying to convey?

Hi Amanda!Thanks for your comment, and GREAT questions, I think that's what I needed from everyone else now, in order to refine the concept. I am still learning from data, I collect a lot of research on it but it is not the area I know most about, so maybe you could add ure expertise!1. I think it would be more valuable and interesting to have separate infographics for different types of information. Like that it would also hopefully me more interesting and accurate to pinpoint what is happening and being said.2. The patterns we would try and convey would be for example: my region (geographic location); by issue (unlawful detention; rally; demonstration of violence etc)3. Possibly there would be a section to deliver 140 Tweet characters, and possible information generated by those could be extracted and evaluated by number of times the word #violence is used or #Free Libya for example.I think this is an area where I need input and help from everyone else. I think the idea of real time news is very opportunistic - people need and want information as fast, easiest and understandable as possible. This would be the aim of this platform with the help of other information gathering systems too! What do you think ? What patterns do you see need capturing from what you've seen in this Challenge?Thanks :)

I think that one of the issues with detention are the political circumstances in place that allow it to occur.  I think something like an infograph could be used to combat that.  As you said, statistics are harder to argue with.Something I think would be cool to see would be a visual aid kind of like Hans Rosling's or the inspiration Visualising Social Media's.  The context of the infograph could be region specific, in other words each region would get its own infograph.  You could have the circles' colors represent various political groups in the region.  Each political group would get a cluster of circles, one circle for each type of human rights violations.  The size of the circles could be determined by the number of instances of violations.  Finally, you would need to figure out how to plot them within space.  I think it might be interesting to plot them in terms of where that group operates in the region.  So, the Y axis might be N-S, and the X would be W-E.  Of course, these are just my initial thoughts, but it should give you some food for thought!An effort like this would be aimed at the source of detention, rather than the immediate antecedents.  Still, I think that those sources are an important aspect to consider.  In terms of infographics that display more immediate types of information, I'll need to think about it!  I'll get back to you on that one :)

Yes, I like the idea of this platform acting as a 'visual aid', like you mention. Maybe it could start simple, with the help of Amnesty International (they most probably have a lot of immediate knowledge of abusive human rights issues happening a.t.m.) and in the future propagate into something more info specific.  Like you say, I think Region Specific data is always important + interesting to look at. Like i've mentioned in this comment thread before, there are a lot of API's we could use to extract data, in this case Google Maps would be great. (I'm not very knowledgable in tech, but I hope this is correct!) You pick up on something very interesting at the end: Immediate Antecedents vs. Source of Detention. Maybe that is also a way to differentiate data in our platform? Active Detentions/Rallys vs Immediate Antecedents of Rallys.. or something related to that.Great thoughts Amanda Thank You :) Keep them coming!
16 awesome data visualization tools from mashable: http://mashable.com/2007/05/15/16-awesome-data-visualization-tools/

restricted_freedom.description: I hurt my left foot and it prevented me from doing the things I love to do. I could not move freely as I used to. This restricted freedom made me feel trapped and powerless.
restricted_freedom.creator: 2f7e4493c5853c18e7fd0ef83dd30d7f

comments.text: Welcome, Phuc  and thanks for sharing your insightful recollection about the frustration of being immobilised. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!

restricted_freedom.title: Restricted Freedom

google_hangouts_helps_dalai_lama_desmond.description: The Dalai Lama planned to visit fellow Nobel Peace prize laureate Desmond Tutu for his 80th birthday. But, South Africa refused to issue a visa, perhaps pressured by key trading partner China. So, they used Google+ Hangouts to meet & broadcast live.
google_hangouts_helps_dalai_lama_desmond.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Brilliant example of technology being leveraged in a positive, solution-focused way. Certainly echoing the core principles of our OpenIDEO endeavors. Way to go Vincent!

Great Inspiration Vincent! As we keep hearing about the merging btw the physical and the virtual worlds, this is a great to build upon this merging.I love the humor and the great informality... wonderful use of technology to build a shared space and have a conversation.Of course, we discussed cases where there might be technological constraints. We might need to keep them in mind but there is clearly some potential! and this is clearly a great way to raise public awareness.thanks for sharing,al

Fab inspiration, Vincent!We're looking to do a live video stream with some of the Amnesty team in the next few weeks, to answer questions about this challenge topic. Wonder if google+ hangouts or ustream would be better suited.

google_hangouts_helps_dalai_lama_desmond.title: Google+ Hangouts helps Dalai Lama & Desmond Tutu overcome Government restriction to meet

amnesty_international_iii_shift_van_.description: A mobile van to provide knowledge and advice, create connections and create (global) awareness on unlawful detentions. Because of its mobility, it will allow people in remote areas to access information and internet access.
amnesty_international_iii_shift_van_.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: Hello Anne-Laure! Thank you for your great contribution to this challenge. The Amnesty team felt your idea would be a nice awareness building tool. We really appreciate all of your hard work. Thank you!
Thank you. I had a wonderful team on this one and I learnt a lot about during this last phase about the technical possibilities, constraints and other projects on the field. al
Great to see you're the lead on this fantastic concept AL!
Thanks Tom. It was a lot of fun and learning to work on this. al

Hi, just updated my concept by adding a reference to a project I heard about on Thursday and went to see today at the Design with the 90%other cities: Digital drums. It is a great innovation developed by UNICEF that reflects this need and allow children and youth to have access to information across areas of health, education, job training, and protection from violence and abuse:http://www.unicefusa.org/news/releases/unicefs-digital-drum-chosen.htmlThis clearly highlight the need to provide access to information. In Uganda as only about 10% of Ugandans currently use the Internet. The van could clearly provide access through its journey, but also by installing mesh networks and living computers or tablets.Another option could be that the van will help distribute the drums and the van staff will build upon this knowledge, still providing internet access and training.
The drums are pre-loaded but you could imagine that if the vans could help develop internet access, these drums could provide internet access.

Sounds exciting to learn of more complementary projects. The development of mesh networks (also called 'village telcos') has huge potential for low (or no) cost communication in remote communities (utilising solar power sources and batteries). Depending on the range involved they also mean possible communication with the van without actually physically visiting it.

Hi Paul, I was also excited by learning about these projects and it made me really envision the van as helping building capacities. Although once the networks are installed, you could imagine the local communities communicating with the van, I believe that the van would probably need to keep its route in order to help with potential technical issues as well as with training. Yet, its role will evolve.thanks for all your insights and feedback.
I wonder if it might be possible to create a digital walk-thru of the van--agree with Paul that reaching people who can't take part live is vital.

Hi Emily, I'm not sure what you mean by a digital walk through of the van? My understanding of Paul's comment was that once the mesh networks / village telcos are set up, it allows the local communities to be in touch with the staff of the van for advice, training and technical support once they are not in their village. thanks,

Hi Anne-Laure,I tried to create a google doc of part transcript from the radio program on the mesh networking that inspired my concept but my dialup internet connection has defeated me.Here is a link, some snippets and some references:http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/futuretense/communication-access-and-equality/3612658phone system he's helped develop, and which is currently being trialled in East Timor, is all about giving poor people in the developing world access to the sort of communication that we in the West take for granted. As you'll hear, the project is simple, clever and based on altruism...The box on your roof talks to the boxes of your neighbours' roofs and the roofs down the road, and they form what's called a mesh network. So your neighbours help relay your phone calls out and around the village or through the city or even further if you have some sort of infrastructure linking it long distance, like an internet connection.......the whole system uses internet protocols as the underlying mechanism for it to work, so it's just the voices relayed on top of that. So as you deploy these mesh networks you also get an internet backbone that can be used for internet traffic as well. We see voice as the killer application because in cases where people are illiterate most people can use and dial a telephone, but maybe the next generation can use it for internet access...This is something that's built from the community level up. It can be very small, as small as two units, connecting a couple of homes in a village, and it can scale up to many thousands of units......one of the things that I think we've got right is handle the ability for local guys to come up to speed, to train and repair. When we did rain on the system we spent about 90% of our time on finding and how to fix it, and we made the thing as simple as we could. Switch it on, put it up in the air, set one number, the phone number of the unit, and then you can start making phone calls.There has been too many projects, well meaning people from the first world who've gone there but with technology that's too complex for local guys to maintain, and we've seen that time and time again. So the trick here is we've tried to come up with something that can grow by itself once we put a tiny amount of initial training in. Now we've incidences in Timor of second or third generation training. So guys that I trained have trained other trainers who are training other people to install the system now.Serval is the name of the second project we're focussing on today, and its founder is also from South Australia, he's Dr Paul Gardner-Stephen, a researcher at Flinders University.Paul Gardner-Stephen: At the moment we are using the wi-fi radio in the phone, so very, very similar to the Mesh Potatoes made by Village Telco. And we simply construct a mesh network from that. So my phone might want to ring your phone and there might be two or three phones along the way in between, and the call will basically hop across those to your phone at the far end. It doesn't rely on anything other than the phones itself.Antony Funnell: Range is a problem still at the moment, isn't it. How do you get around that, particularly if you are thinking of using this system in a disaster situation? Paul Gardner-Stephen: You're quite right, the range with wi-fi is quite limiting and it's something that we are actively working to deal with. We are also looking at, from a more pragmatic end, reusing the radio that is already in a mobile phone that would normally talk to a phone tower on an unlicensed band quite close to the mobile phone frequencies. And that would give us probably something like 20 times or more of the range of wi-fi. So without any phones in between you would probably be able to contact half a kilometre to a kilometre in an urban area, and in open country or in fact in a disaster situation where there is no background interference, the range again can be potentially several times that.Sorry for such a long post - its only a small part of the whole article - I just felt convergence and collaboration on these technologies and things like the drums has huge and exciting potential on which a range of services, including Amnesty initiatives could be built.

The Serval link was posted in the inspiration phase and the Village Telco link in my concept but here they are again if anyone would like to look at them:http://www.servalproject.org/http://villagetelco.org/

A couple of other interesting links out of the Serval site:A Human Right ( http://ahumanright.org/ )  is a project which believes communication is, indeed, a human right. They have been unfailingly supportive and are going to make fantastic ongoing collaborators in ensuring the world manages to make access to communications a fairer & attainable proposition for everyone. Kostas Grammatis gave a talk in Athens at TEDx ( http://www.ted.com/tedx/events/1098 )Kosta Grammatis is a visiting researcher at the MIT Media labs and the founder of ahumanright.org  an organization charged with bringing low cost internet access to the world. Kosta was the lead scientist for the video camera enabled prosthetic eye called the eyeborg project. and was awarded TIME Magazines best invention of 2009 for his work. He worked for Space Exploration Technologies and was the lead engineer of a satellite that is now currently in orbit. He likes big ideas.

Hi Anne Laure!Wonderful to see a very well thought and packaged concept.I'm glad to see my Vending Machine / Hub as an inspiration.I really like how you tell us how it could have two uses, and it seems that makes it very adaptable : I see both my concept and the campaigning/raising public awareness solution work very well together. I just had a small idea to promote the Shift Van in the Developed countries, before it reaches an impoverished community. It's inspired by the 'I am Precious Bike' ( http://yesiamprecious.com/ ) that together with it's driver, cycled across America to raise money for Livestrong. The bike had an 'on-board device that captured all of it's experiences, combined with a cloud-based system that analyzes those experiences. ' These experiences were outputs such as Tweets about how the bike was so tired, and needed to rest, etc etc. So my idea would be: If the Van's journey started in Europe, and it's Aim was to reach Iran for example, we could implement a technology similar to Precious, that would document the Van's journey, how many KM travelled, and share videos of the Amnesty team on board and their preparations for their 1st mission, on a website. (Of course money should be raised prior to it's departure from Europe, with the help of some marketing) The Van could then keep raising money while on the road and while helping the communities in the Middle East. I know this might be an expensive idea... but I just like the 'community' kind of feel of raising the funds for the Van, while also raising awareness of the issues it will tackle. Anne posted a concept about Facebook Groups - I told her that we could use your Van as a vehicle of education and propagating her Facebook Group, and that we could name the VENDING MACHINE + VAN + FACEBOOK GROUP = Shift. aAd include the symbol Jason created as a vehicle to turn them into reality ! Ok thinking pretty huge scale here, but that's what connecting concepts and ideas does to me :)

Hi Sara, thanks for your feedback. Security was raised by Amanda in terms of being recognizable based on my comparison with Doctors without Borders' white jeeps. To Amanda's point, the work and status of Doctors without borders and Amnesty differ. I've addressed this point by having a note:"Note on the van for scenario 1: Reading an article about Doctors without borders and how recognizable (in a positive way) their white Toyota with their label has become, I thought that we could try to have a unified look and design and that this would help create a sense of trust and positive awareness about Amnesty International involvement with local communities. Yet, as noted by Amanda in one of her comments (a well-taken point, that others also highlighted), it might be better to make the van less visible. I guess this would have to be discussed with Amnesty International's experts and other local NGOs, and might vary depending on the areas."In some cases, using local vehicles could also help making the van less visible.As for other security issues, I thought of and which were raised by some in a workshop at NYU-Poly on Friday, they will concern people going to the van being seen as going to complain. We discuss the possibility of making the van more of a wifi access provider and downplaying the unlawful detention aspect. We also suggested having a variety of services, access to online platforms and information related to unlawful detention being only one of a broader offering.This is how I address it in the concept:"Security was raised as an issue: Offering a variety of services (like internet connection "in general", sms services, scribe, etc.) could make it less "suspicious" to go to the Shift van. Also I guess that security issues will vary depending on the area the van will be visiting. It is difficult to decide upfront. However, it seems that the van would have a stronger impact if it was offering more than just information about unlawful detention and collecting stories.  You can imagine specific services (on how to create a business, selling crafts, postal services, letter writing workshop, etc.) depending of the local needs and the skills of the people driving the van."I saw on your profile that you are campaign manager for Amnesty International's Security with Human Rights campaign. Any specific thoughts on issues related to security and maybe ways they could be addressed. thanks.al

Hi Anne-Laure,Reading your scenarios I am uncertain if you envisage the vans being deployed in 'at risk' communities, but I think you probably do. I have looked at the 'Ground Control' site and note their broad range of dishes. I have made a general enquiry of http://www.dishcamo.com on the feasibility of incorporating one of their covers into the superstructure of a van (say a Ford Transit or similar). This could provide both additional weather-proofing and concealment (at least attracting less attention).I also wondered, with respect to information, if it would be appropriate to use on-board sources of commonly accessed information on hard drive or usb connected storage (I'm sure it could be suitably encrypted if required) - that way the communication overhead could be reduced and bandwidth be conserved for more critical aspects of the operation. Maybe even Amanda's matching database could be deployed locally with overnight updates between vans and/or base-stations.It seems to me there is no urgent imperative to distribute new stories immediately, the time involved in collecting them would probably be greater than adding them to the collection.A little more controversially the vans might also be used to set up local mesh networks:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/open-network-mesh-cans-be-on-when-they-turn-off-every-thing-/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/network-startegically-using-mesh-potato-networking/This could be overt or covert, and perhaps only in areas where the van's presence has become accepted. Then the van could be used as a backup hub for connection between the mesh and satellite networks. There are all sorts of possible configurations to suit a range of circumstances.Finally (for now) I see the technology being suggested to protect 'at risk'  individuals (or similar technology) being used to protect (monitor) van staff, and even the van itself. Any such deployment could be extended to other organisations upholding human rights (Doctors Without Borders, Red Cross etc.)
