A-L, looked over your update and overall it looks good!  I like that you too are addressing some of the technical aspects in more detail.  I have three suggestions for you.  The first is in terms of generators.  Rather than a bio-fuel generator, why not a solar-powered generator?  That is a completely renewable resource that would be available most places.  Though perhaps a bio-fuel generator might be a better choice during the rainy season (if there is one, depending on the region).  Also, in terms of services, you might also address technology training.  If people need the van to access technology, they may not know how to use it.  Finally, I like the idea of a standardized truck, but I think it would depend on the area in which the truck is operating.  I think the reason Doctor's Without Borders can do that is because they're kind of like the Red Cross, medicine transcends political motives, etc.  While Amnesty is more pro-human-rights and less anti-regime, I think they could easily be perceived as anti-regime by the regime.  Which means making the truck so recognizable would be like painting a bulls-eye on it.  If the area is particularly volatile, it may be a better idea to blend in than stand out.  Out of sight, out of mind...

Thanks Amanda. I'll check out the solar panel option and maybe suggest the possibility of having both. I need to check some of the options suggested by Alan. As for training, I completely agree. I assumed that the people working in the van will help people to access the data, but maybe more intentional training should be involved. I'll add training as a service. I think that depending on the areas and the skills, you could imagine training sessions, or training the trainer that will allow people in the community to share with others.Good point about the van being recognizable. I guess that it will depend on the location and the situation. This is a question for Amnesty to decide upon.thanks again,
Hey A-L.  Glad to see you in the Refinement Phase!!  Congrats!
thanks! glad to see creating connections in the refinement phase as well!

Hi Anne-Laure, congratulations on your concept making it to the short list. We really like the potential of this idea not only to spread information but also to spread network access around a city. Our expert panel wonders if its possible to extend this idea into the direction of providing wifi access, especially in countries where this kind of access may not be readily available.

Thank you very much. I believe providing wifi access is clearly an option, one that I mentioned - although maybe not clearly enough: people coming to the van would be able to access internet and the various platforms. I'll clarify this part and explore also technical options for this (Hopefully with the help of others). I have had many great suggestions in the conception phase and I'm sure I'll get some more in the refinement phase. thanks!

Hi Anne-Laure,Super concept! Love this in conjunction with the other incorporated concepts. Also love Angeliki's extension for musical entertainment which would be crowd drawing and provide justification in some circumstances.You have extensively covered benefits and possible draw backs in the major scenarios too.Great work!
Hi, inspired by Yen's mobile letter writing workshops, I've clarified the 2 scenarios: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/mobile-letter-writing-workshops/thanks Yen!

Nice! There are many things I like about this, beginning with your phrase "connect and collect stories". So many of the concepts require people affected by detention to seek out the technology. This proactive way of reaching those in need is a great addition. You also raised a great point regarding those people who may be totally unaware that their rights had been violated. This concept definitely addresses that need.I also think it's a great way to spread the Universal Symbol!! Moreover, pairing that symbol with the public good the van offers is a nice little boost of positive reinforcement.Incorporating Ana's vending machine is also a nice touch. If the van can incorporate some form of legal skype or internet access to publish stories or petitions, then it's a perfect blend of high and low-tech. You addressed my one concern regarding safety. But I think even if it simply provided information it would be a valuable service.I can definitely help draw up a van, but be forewarned, my sketching may turn it into something more akin to the ScoobyDoo Van!

Thanks Jason. Indeed I believe that it is important to go and offer opportunities to people. I also believe that not everyone might realize that they have "rights", even less than they have been violated. I think that the van by providing internet access and people who can help accessing the different platforms discussed could potentially provide (better) access to the technology. We could even imagine local people (which will have a cell phone which could text the van if there was some update needed or urgent information requested). This is if we want to think of this as creating long-term support structures in the communities. I also believe (per your comment on public good) that it'll be a nice way to share positive and creative solutions - particularly in "developing countries" to move beyond empathy and potentially trigger action (remember Ashley's inspiration one empathy:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-limits-of-empathy/It will be indeed great to share the universal symbol... btw per one of my comments on your concept, I think it'll be great to "name" it so that we can refer to it... SOS for example is visual and "verbal" / discursive. As for the van, I'd love one that looks like the ScoobyDoo Van! Yet, I can also try to find a nice photo or work on my drawing skills. :-)
That's a perfect van! It'll be fun to get creative with the message and icons on the van itself...and I totally agree the symbol needs a name. If my symbol sticks, maybe something like "the triplet"?

thanks for the compliment on the van... I was inspired by your comment and went back to ScoobyDoo's van for inspiration... :-)the triplet is a good one... I also posted a comment on your concept suggesting to use the analogy between "free" and three... I agree on the being creative with the message and icons... You want to help? :-)
I thought it looked familiar :0) - Can't wait to help!

Thanks Jason. Any suggestion on the icons and message are welcome... I think playing with Shift and your universal symbol (which still needs to be named) would be great... Shift III or III Shift with the icon for your symbol rather than III. Verbally, it could be Triple shift, Shift Triplet, Shift free ... any other idea?

Great concept, it can be easily implemented. As you mentioned, it is indeed for both low-tech and high-tech situation. People can "build" the van based on different situations to serve different purposes.

Thanks Lei. Indeed, what I thought was that this concept could be "interpreted" differently in different contexts. Hence, if you think of the petitions centers discussed in Vincent's concept, you could imagine the bus supporting the petition process.

Yes! And it's easy to duplicate. You can have several of them, if it's a success. In Europe or the US for example, you could have 1 (or more) that are especially equipped to show stories and sign up supporters in events. A more PR related version.

Thanks Arjan. Yes, my idea was to have several of them. It could be implemented at a very local level -a region, both urban and rural zones, in particular if it offers access to internet and advice. It has to be coming back on a "regular" basis. Yes in Europe and in the US, it will be more about campaigning.  a more PR related version of it... although you could imagine a way of also implementing something in the spirit of the Ghana Think Tank: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/thinktanks/
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks for featuring the shift III van and also thanks for all the great comments it got.

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

comments.text: Thanks for sharing this. There are numerous Facebook groups as well that people have created to keep the conversation alive surrounding his captivity. Facebook and other social media tools are a great way to continue to rally support for similar cases.

Gilad's is a very moving story  thanks so much for sharing it Avi. We've found what appears to be a version of the video with English subtitles http://bit.ly/qRBzGc for others who want to check it out. On a related note, it might be helpful to share a reminder for everyone to check out our challenge Guiding Principles ( http://bit.ly/riHUU2 ), where we briefly discuss ethics, risk and directly naming people who have been or are currently detained unlawfully. Gilad's story is well-documented, but for other cases it's important that we consider the potential impact of naming someone publicly. Let us know if you have any questions  and keep up the great inspirations!

make_a_change_app.description: Technology and the growing use of apps on devices such as iPhones are increasingly popular among today's population. Something that features stories of unlawful detainees and tips on how to make a change from 1,000 miles away is as easy as just clicking on this app.  -Wells College Innovation Lab (Rachel, Hannah, Forrest, Giavarna, Richard)
make_a_change_app.creator: cbb1245231a4edac48fcd2c539c523af

comments.text: Thank you for the feedback! we are trying to add more to our concept as we speak. this was just a preliminary for our innovation class

I love this idea. Sharing the true stories is always a good method to encourage people. Through these featured stories, people could experience and learn how to face it. And it's also a good way to collect the full solutions of unlawful detention from people who use this app.

What a great idea here Rachel, Hannah, Forrest, Giavarna, and Richard! It's terrific to see your team from the Wells College Innovation Lab participate in this Challenge. I'm looking forward to seeing where this concept goes.(and for folks who aren't familiar with the Wells College Innovation Lab, check the Field Notes post we shared on Tracy Brandenburg, who leads their efforts: http://bit.ly/otUP6Q)

I think the app could also collaborate with GPS Service and Voice Control Services. It could work in this way: When a smart phone holder is in danger, he/she could say something like 'ONE', which has already been set when he/she install the app. That might mean 'call 911'. This is also a trigger for the GPS service which helps police locate. I know the voice control is definitely feasible since I have an app on my phone, which helps me to find the phone when I forget where I put it. The only thing I need to do is to say 'where are you'. And the phone will make some noise. The instruction is the one I set already, and it could be anything.

I like the one stop shop concept behind this idea, being able to take action and share information fast is essential in these situations, there would be some restrictions in certain parts of the world where technology is less available but in India for example the use of social media is increasing all the time. In our campaign on the unlawful detentions of juveniles in Jammu and Kashmir for example we had a significant and effective increase in the number of young people sharing information on twitter in recent months, and we achieved change with one case in particular encouraging direct response from a government representative and the young man in question was freed within days....
Great job, Rachel, Hannah, Forrest, Giavarna, and Richard!

Great stuff guys! Hoping as the Concepting phase continues that you might consider creating a few mock images of what this might feature  images are a brilliant way to engage people. Also you might want to outline a few imagined scenarios to explain how the app could be used in different contexts. eg. Scenario One: Protestor at Occupy Wall St, NYC. Scenario Two: Chinese Dissident Blogger, Beijing. Scenario Three: ?? You'd need to a bit of research into various contexts but this could go a long way to show how your app could be used (and useful ;^) in various situations.

fifty_people_one_question.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: Yes, I think that a "campaign" like this could unify many diverse experiences and create connections cross-culturally.
Hi al, How about we make the question more personal. For example, "who is the person that you would most object to be unlawfully detained?"

Hi Tayfun, more personal and more concrete I think is always a great idea. Yet, I'm not sure about asking "who is the person you would most object" but maybe it's because I would not know what to reply. Yet, maybe that will work. It could also be a "what question"? or "who do you think of when you think of someone unlawfully detained"?...It's interesting as it's a bit like writing the "right" brief... I guess the people who started this project would have some ideas...

Hi al, In that case we should at least try to get some input from them. I think in the concepting case, we (I can do that but don't know anyone from Deltree and Crush + Lovely) can send an e-mail to learn more about which question (s) can have more impact. Yet, if we invite them to the discussion, they may even be very much involved and help with the concept if it is chosen.

Hi Tayfun, indeed if we wanted to explore this idea or build upon this inspiration in the concepting phase, we could / should contact them. We could also brainstorm a few questions and "try them" / prototype. al

amnesty_international_unlawful_detention.description:
As I was reading all the posts I realized that I needed to see the entire problem so I put short overview together that would help me see the entire problem at a glance. I thought I should post it for everyone to see.

This can help me ideate better and I hope it can help you too!

For an young generation of activists, games may represent a resource for engaging young people with the political process and heightening their awareness of social issues like unlawful detention. 

What might it mean to empower young people to create their own games to reflect their perceptions of the world around them?

In what ways do young people use the online societies constructed in multiplayer games to rehearse and refine skills at citizenship?

Can we imagine games as a medium that encourages public awareness and citizenship?
amnesty_international_unlawful_detention.creator: 1d6938247df828016cda2465c1c9de17

comments.text: Interesting idea Ardy & cheers for the break down graphic! Would be great for you to discuss with others here ways in which the engagement by gaming could be transformed into awareness building for the real world. Perhaps you'd like to outline a scenario (or two) to convey this  I think that would really help folks engage with your ideas here.

Of Course Meena. Thank you for your the feedback.For an young generation of activists, games may represent a resource for engaging young people with the political process and heightening their awareness of social issues like unlawful detention. What might it mean to empower young people to create their own games to reflect their perceptions of the world around them?In what ways do young people use the online societies constructed in multiplayer games to rehearse and refine skills at citizenship?Can we imagine games as a medium that encourages public awareness and citizenship?Such game representations may be immensely influential, allowing us to engage with social, economic, political and even moral complexity in potentially new ways. This type of thinking can allow us to imagine alternatives to our current practices and to see how particular choices and outcomes are shaped by rules or principles of organization that can be changed or re-imagined.I have added an great example to the main post.

I agree, thanks for the break down graphic!  Also, I really like the idea of using gaming to engage young people.  It can be a powerful way to reach a large segment of that population.Meena, your comment makes me think of the concept "metacognition" in education -- how do we teach children to think about their thought process so that they can formalize the lessons they've learned from Topic A in order to translate them to other parts of their lives?  I think research has shown that if you create a structured process for this, then students are much more likely to translate those lessons (otherwise we assume it happens but it doesn't!)  Building off that, I wonder if there is a way to build a "metacognition" process into the games to draw direct links to unlawful detention?A "sacrificial" thought (just intended to get the brainstorm ball rolling) - what if, in the example detailed above, gamers somehow experienced two scenarios -- one where they operated in an "open" society and one where the local Police (or other institutions) enacted human rights violations -- a sort of compare/contrast that creates space for reflection on the impact of unlawful detention on the outcome of the game?  I'm sure there are other ways to do it, just throwing ideas around!

amnesty_international_unlawful_detention.title: Amnesty International Unlawful Detention - overview

crisis_tracker_leveraging_remote_communi.creator: 319041f17c1a62e49a7a2d44a767bbb9

comments.text: Nice example of melding high tech & appropriate tech.
Indeed.
Wow  what a super comprehensive effort! Much to be learnt from this rigorous approach  especially in regards to coordination between NGO's, etc.

I love the NGO coordination, and I do think that's a SUPER important part of why this is successful.  I'm so interested in the thought process behind their early warning radio - I need to dive more into how they coordinate and alert: who's driving the process on the ground? How do they coordinate it? How do they validate the attack report? SO MANY QUESTIONS. Here's a video about it (additionally, love the thought process behind these information pieces, so well done): http://www.lracrisistracker.com/media/video/early-warning-radio-network
Agreed  it really seems exceptionally well pulled together.

This is really nice as there are even ratings for accuracy, different type of incidence, etc... Well, I think this could be easily used with few changes in this challenge such as adding detention information (who detained, whom), trust worthiness of the person who states the detention, etc...
I agree, that's a great idea.  This idea I think could be very easily customized into everything you mapped out above! Great thoughs.

crisis_tracker_leveraging_remote_communi.title: Crisis Tracker: Leveraging remote communities and far-reaching technology

the_human_rights_graphic_narrative_platf.description: An easy to use, drag-and-drop software platform, that lets anyone create a short graphic narrative about an illegal detention, or other human rights abuse.  Rather than text-heavy alerts, this platform will allow for more graphic interest, human focus, and a narrative sense to really pull in an audience
the_human_rights_graphic_narrative_platf.creator: 12b9dacb49b9ae47466c07204f630baa

comments.text: http://www.articlesfield.com/

Love this idea (and the comments made) as someone still in the dialup world (and there are a lot of us) I have to think very hard about whether downloading video will be worth the effort. Sometimes in-page graphics are a challenge too but mostly modern low resolution graphics are quite sufficient for this sort of thing and for me a picture is still worth many words.

I like this idea very similar, but exploring a different medium, than the streetplay toolkit: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/street-plays-a-video-tool-kit-for-unlawful-detention/ It makes things simpler for people, increasing the chance of involvement.

I love this concept!  I've been thinking about two different approaches to storytelling in the media -- newspapers vs. magazines, and how the intentional attention to graphics that is displayed in magazines can enrich the narrative experience for viewers, and this concept provides an easy way for just about anybody to do that!  I wonder if some simple guidelines or suggestions for creating high impact graphics (or ways to interweave text with graphics) would be helpful, with samples for users to view?

I really like this concept.  And I agree that video is far more difficult in some country's where bandwidth is a problem.  This provides a wonderful solution for those with limited exposure to storytelling in the virtual world.  Nicely done!

Hi Margaret, Great idea. And nice illustrations too!I agree that text heavy is less appealing and poweful, than great imagery. I really see potential in combining/integrating your concept with my Interactive Infographic Platform concept : http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/an-interactive-infographic-platform-fueled-by-the-whole-network-of-supporters-/ where I imagine gathering information and alerts coming in through various channels (The Amnesty App and other sources) and translating this into neat real-time infographics, for anyone to share and understand what is happening regarding human rights issues, in real time. This would be a website, maybe an app later.Maybe your concept could be woven into the platform so people can create their personalized feed of infographics, tailored to their interest, and maybe have it as a widget on their personal website, or something... I really like the 'DIY', personalization approach. What do you think? (This is not the idea of a low-tech version of course :) ) Great work!

Nice one Margaret! You might want to connect this idea to your earlier Inspirations on this topic plus posts by others who are keen on graphic engagement. Hit the Update button on the right of your post, then scroll down to Build Upon. Search terms like 'infographics' your own posts and drag anything relevant over to your Build Upon field. Keep up the great work!
One more thing you might like to consider under "resources" is a Community Manager. As someone who plays this role on OpenIDEO, I guess I see it as pretty important for online platforms ;^)
Thanks Mena, I agree -- Community Managers add so much :D!

Great job evolving this from your original inspiration, Margaret! There's definitely value in providing an easy way to create engaging stories for unlawful detention campaigns.In this case, even more important than software engineering resources, is thoughtful design of the platform so that's it's truly simple to use and  naturally guides people to create compelling narratives.
Thanks -- that's true.  The platform should be simple, easy, quick!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

the_human_rights_graphic_narrative_platf.title: The Human Rights Graphic Narrative Platform

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Well spotted, Tom! Also highlights the rise of citizen journalism & how readily available relevant technology is to many of us these days.
Agreed - it made me think how unprepared I would be if I did find myself in a critical situation even though I carry so many devices...
Yes, great fodder for concepting. There are plenty of simple things that we could do to "always be prepared" to make the best use of our mobile devices in such situations.

Yesterday, I overheard someone saying that they always carry extra batteries for each of their devices, especially if they knew they were coming to a large event. Wifi, widgets and background tools always consume a lot of power so it helps to have a backup power supply.
nice simple move...

comments.text: Always like it when people want to think about taking away the cause in stead of solely focusing on battling the symptoms. Thanks for inspiring us to think about that, too.

Hi Christian, I really like the idea of looking at the cause, rather than the symptom. As you said it does not take away the need to address the symptoms, but this might also be an opportunity to think more deeply of the causes. Thanks for the inspiration!
Really interesting thoughts here Christian - you've definitely made me stop and ponder :) I'll look forward to you continuing to explore these questions throughout the Inspiration phase!

how_the_great_firewall_of_china_works.description: Finding out a way to bypass internet censorship and to allow information flow in and out will play a huge role to support those held in or at risk of secret detention.
how_the_great_firewall_of_china_works.creator: dc88a3b12e2251eb1327bd6d71c40230

comments.text: I use a VPN everytime I visit China since its hard to keep in touch with people without it because of the firewall. I read a lot about the different VPN services available and searched for one that satisfied my requirements (speed, reliability, duration of plan etc.) and got an account in  http://highspeedvpn.info/  It worked well..

The truth is you really need a VPN if you stay in China for more than a couple of days, most good sites are blocked there. The block on Facebook is the most annoying one, and also my gMail account didn`t work every time (without VPN I mean).Anyway, I used http://www.sunvpn.com/ while there, worked like a charm every time.
Great information. I have personally used Opera + Tor to bypass my universities internet filters when I was living on campus.
Thanks Lei for sharing. It is important to keep local contexts and possibility of censorship in mind when we think of developing technologies in the concepting phase.

It is true. In China, people can not log in facebook or twitter or many oversea websites, even if the outcome of search engineer, was filtrated by the government also. It is very ridiculous. In nowadays, people need fair opportunities to get information, and i think its one of humans rights. Everyone should have opportunities to choose what information they need from internet, as the lowest standard. That's why more and more people use VPN or similar tools to bypass. It's like the power to flight for own rights. BTW, I enjoy the translation of this video. It's amusing. :P
Thanks for another informative inspiration Lei! The video provides a decent introduction.

how_the_great_firewall_of_china_works.title: How The Great Firewall of China Works

emotional_engagement.description: Protesting against unlawful detentions needs social awareness. The real story of detainees merged with online petitions and protesting networks will engage the users emotionally and make them feel responsible for detainees lives.
emotional_engagement.creator: 9b55afd48a8fce4ab24bf903d6009eec

comments.text: What an emotional inspiration, Maryam - thanks for sharing this. You're so right that we need to find a way to personalize and "add spirit" to these campaigns to make them real. Your post brings up an important question for me, though, around confidentiality and risk, particularly around sharing personal details about detainees and others. How might we share these stories in inspiring and meaningful ways, without disclosing information about human rights defenders or detainees that might actually put them more at risk? We talk about this a bit in our Guiding Principles doc http://bit.ly/riHUU2 - if you haven't checked it out yet, perhaps it'll spark some further insights for you. Nice work!

About sharing personal details, am strongly against disclosing them in such a system which detain even the human right defenders. I can remember the days that we, as protestors, hid our faces behind masks! No way sharing the personal details :)But I believe that the communities such as Defenders of Human Rights Center should talk about their missions and what their members are engaged with, to aware the public. Not a personal story but maybe a symbolic provoking one, to make me engaged with the defenders mission.
Regarding Iran case, I reckon sustaining an emotional engaging is pretty harder than raising it. Unfortunately governments know that and by killing the time they always pass tough situation safely.

Definitely you are right! and am so interested if any examples of sustaining emotional engagement is available,,,In this case, social awareness is about causing a behavior to occur, as an example make the public to sign a petition.Emotional engagement is just a motivation for public to sign the petition. The rest factors to cause the behavior occur are available at: http://www.behaviormodel.org/

emotional_engagement.title: Emotional Engagement

remeber_me_necklace.description: A necklace to be safely distributed to families of unlawfully detained individuals. This necklace would serve as a touch point for honoring the loved one, connecting families with aid and other families with their situation.
remeber_me_necklace.creator: 25fe45ecadb74c8eb883da8d652df61a

comments.text: Hi Henken,nice concept. It reminded me of one of Ashley's inspirations: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/be-a-whistleblower-for-peace/I can see the emotional point regarding having the photo of the loved one. I'm wondering if there could not be a way to expand your concept where it will become more symbolic (using Jason's symbol for example) and that everyone could wear it. You could imagine that for family members, there would be a way of personalizing it, if wanted / possible.

Yes, I think one thing about this concept that weakens it is that it straddles two areas: one public and one private. To Vincent's point - it could be dangerous to wear the necklace in certain areas to attract attention to oneself, which could have been the exact reason the family member was detained. But it also would be a very visual and easy way to unite those who are in the same situation if worn in public in a safe area. On the private side I see this as more of a intimate tool: one that says there are others out there in your situation and there is a group of people that cares for your family: something that could be kept in private for remembrance, honor, and education. One thing that is different about the Falling Whistle campaign is the circulation on money in the process. In purchasing a whistle, one is supporting a cause monetarily and makes a very public statement. I wonder if there could be a public extension of a private system where anonymous versions of the necklaces are sold as part of a larger campaign to help sustain the project and support the families. On the private level, more personalization is a wonderful idea, I think there may be a way of incorporating a storytelling aspect to the creation of the necklace (if desired) that could help to honor the individuality of the detainee and deepen the emotional connection of the family to the support network.

Hi Henken, I agree re. the potential risk of making some statements public. I guess there could be 2 related concepts (as you suggest in your updated version). The public version of it might be offered for purchase in places and by people who are not directly "at risk" and who want to make a public statement.
I agree, I think there is union in keeping them as one "campaign" but two different strains of the same idea.
Great job of connecting your thoughts to various conversations, Henken!
Thanks Meena, I feel like this is one of the strongest aspects of this site: the potentiality for collaboration.

Nice one Henken! Can see how this would help honor a loved one, connect with others facing similar situations, and perhaps solicit help from others who might know something about what happened/is happening.One concern is whether this would attract unwanted attention of repressive authorities in some instances.

Yes, I do see that danger, which is why I think this could serve multiple purposes: "worn by family members, if in a safe community, or displayed inside one's house" or potentially also dropped off at a safe-spot as a memorial "safe drop-off spot for the necklaces which display long-term detainee information." But I agree with you and have the same concern if worn in public in the wrong spot... It would be a sort of token of honor to be used however the recipient felt safe.

remeber_me_necklace.title: Remeber Me Necklace

You also said no and that was clear enough, and strong enough, that they left. It highlights an important issue about how often in these situations, we end up forgetting that we can say no!
Wow, Ashwin thanks so much for sharing such a personal story with us! Even in a short paragraph, you've helped all of us understand this feeling of powerlessness in a very real way.

a_story_stuck_behind_bars.description: Create a viral street art campaign, where stories of illegally detained prisoners are stuck between all sorts of bars in an urban setting.
a_story_stuck_behind_bars.creator: 046c14ccc821e094ab37859494deeacc

comments.text: I really like your idea. You think on a good point, how to integrate the ressources that Amnesty has and the things in wich they are the best to cause impact.-

I really like this idea...the symbolism of putting the story within the bars is a really cool concept. It reminds me of 9/11 when they put pictures, stories, flowers...anything, on the fence/gates/bars of the church near the site...maybe this viral campaign can provoke emotion and support for people who are victims of detainment just like it did after 9/11!
Great interactive thinking, Anne!

Hi Anne,I'm really excited by the simplicity and the powerfulness of this concept. It reminds me of Candy Chang's 'Before I die' neighborhood project. ( http://candychang.com/before-i-die-in-nola/ )Maybe this could be seen also as an educational campaign as well as raising awareness of unlawful detention. It would also be interesting to investigate the digital aspect of contributing with your interpreted story, ex: Geo Tagging your Tweet of PDF on a specified Amnesty location site for the viral campaign, then you could track all the installation locations, and see the digital and the physical messages people left. Love it, great work!

Nice concept indeed and indeed it reminds me of the "before I die" installation. There's one instantiation of it just nearby our campus (NYU-Poly, Brooklyn). I thought that it would be nice to have something interactive like "If I were detained, I will miss..." or sth along these lines but just the story telling aspect makes sense.It could be part of the museum of memories of Luz: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/memories-museum-for-the-unlawful-detention/

what_can_we_learn_from_the_media_s_rush_.description: This Monday when Amanda Knox was released from prison, many media & journalists wrongly Tweeted and live reported that she was guilty, only later to apologize for this. Meanwhile, lots of people re-tweeted & spread their wrong message.
what_can_we_learn_from_the_media_s_rush_.creator: 890278307fec5590e0f5982a2de58e38

comments.text: This is an important point on the message of the media. Certainly it is important for the media to be fair and balanced when reporting the news because it can sway public opinion.

Hi Fernanda thanks for your comment!Yes, that is also very interesting. Again in that case we saw the urge and hunger of the media to feed us whatever information they want, of course.It is a very interesting debate, and let's see if it fuels a concept in the next phase!

Very good point! It comes to mind the case of the iranian girl, Neda, that was killed in 2009. The media just took the photo from the wrong facebook and suddenly a girl that was alive was being persecuted by Iranian forces and she even had to migrate to Germany. And the "right" Neda and martyr was being portrayed with the photo of another girl... Sad case...

what_can_we_learn_from_the_media_s_rush_.title: What can we learn from the media's rush to publish first online, example: Knox verdict?

Hey Kerry,So, you have unwittingly tapped into one of my other loves.  I am a Threadless junkie!!!  So, I love this concept.  My hope would be that Amesty would partner with Threadless in the realization of this concept.  They have a very successful, already set-up network of designers and manufacturers that would fit this concept well.What might be an interesting addition to your post, would be building off the clothing initiative http://www.krochetkids.org/Something like krochetkids.org could fit in well with Anne-Laure's concept, http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/give-the-a-voice-shifting-stories-of-powerlessness-to-empowerment./#c-18a1c0767f94321c420cf1112531fc17 , in terms of enabling wives of detainees to empower themselves.  Wouldn't have to be hats, but I like the idea of having them make something that could also be sold as part of this initiative...Glad to be on your virtual team :-)

awareness_supports_public_pressure.description: If folks know about laws and rulings, they can provide support through public pressure – even in far flung locations.
awareness_supports_public_pressure.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Meena,I really like this story not only because it is easy to feel the sense of powerlessness but also because it recalls me 2 other inspirations where Ashwin (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/held-by-the-nypd/) and Avi (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/resistance-starts-with-saying-no/) were able to say no, and get out of the situation.I think what your story is pointing at is how sometimes it is difficult to say no, but that if people felt "supported" - through awareness and knowledge of the laws - they will easily start resisting. The power of the others which can sometimes lead to silence, can also lead to resistance: you need only one to change the balance...thanks for inspiring.al

Exactly, I think that this is the next the of saying "no". I believe that people who misuse power don't have a sense of consequences and when they are made aware of the existence of possible repercussions, they eventually back off. For a redacted example, even a bully may stand down if you make him believe that you will "tell" on him with sufficient proof as witnesses or resources such as proximity to those in power. But not so much if your claims are vague. But I don't think that it will be applicable to everyone who are illegally detained and if done improperly, might worsen the condition.

Great story...Go Meena =). Finding ways to empower people to effectively say no can do wonders!At the same time, I think a key point hinted at by Ashwin is, it's not just about saying "no", but picking the right moment to say "no". In relatively low risk situations, the answer is clear.However, in high risk situations, you have to weigh the potential harm against the potential good. Otherwise, in certain situations, you could literally sacrifice yourself & others for naught, when it might have been wiser to live & fight another day on a bigger battlefield.

Hi Vincent, you're right: it's not only about saying no, but finding the opportunity to say no (or sometimes just having the opportunity). Meena in her story suggests a way of creating for ourselves a space to say no. Yet, I agree, even this might not be possible.Yesterday, I was talking with someone about how it is easy to wonder why people are not resisting or acting, but how in some cases, it is very difficult because of political contexts and the risks associated to the action.thanks for raising this point, al

Meena - brilliantly-written story.  Thanks for sharing this.While it's perhaps slightly tangential to your story, I'm not mulling over the question of how we can encourage prisoners to recognize their unity.  Independently, people will feel powerless, but cohesion is a potent force.
Not = now :)

It would be great if you can elaborate more on how you felt after proving to yourself and to others you are right. Not because of personal reasons but I think it should feel great to be part of a greater morale and apply it to life. Thinking of it, not saying no (there are lots of pressures for not saying it) when we have the power is a violation of human dignity. Being silent (there are situations where we shouldn't talk but at least we should feel opposed in our hearts) in front of injustice is unjust. So maybe we should find a way to remind that ourselves as often as possible so we can act when situation arises.

To be honest, the good feeling I got at the tail end of this story was not about coming off as 'right' but rather from having a sense of being supported by others who felt it too difficult to voice their concerns. Collectively we had a stronger voice. It reminds me of our OpenIDEO 'better together' tagline!

Thanks for elaborating. I was looking to put those feelings in a tangible format. 'better together' is already a great line that captures the essence. Maybe "be their voice" or something along that line could also be used.

awareness_supports_public_pressure.title: Awareness Supports Public Pressure

evaa_emergency_voice_activated_app.description: The concept is to use an app like SIRI to implement a series of tasks.  This app will be available but not limited to multiple platforms such as the Iphone, Android and Windows phones.  VOICE ACTIVATION is the catalyst for the system.  The use of smartphones is key because of the multi-functionality of the system.  The main advantage to the voice app is that it is very quick to activate.  Furthermore, most people always carry their phone close to them but even “if“ in the case of an abduction and the phone is separated from one's person the emergency app can be activated with a shout.
evaa_emergency_voice_activated_app.creator: c70aff42f46ebc1626f18e00f5c58825

comments.text: Great Thoughts are sharing,thankshttp://www.evincetech.com/eCommerce-application.html

The idea is really great and these app would be like must have apps for everyone. Technology should be used in a such a way that it helps in safe guarding us. On that note these kinds of emergency based apps are really good and provides great help. Mobile apps are waving flag in almost all the sectors like entertainment, educating as well as for official pupose. Find here more interesting and useful apps as mentioned here.http://www.contus.com/android-application-development.php

Interesting thoughts, guys  hope others will chip in to help develop ideas here. Keep in mind our Tips for Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips discussion on how tracking devices can work for and against detainees  might be good to evolve your thoughts with that in mind.If you've got any questions you'd like to ask the Amnesty team to help you and others understand that challenge more deeply so you can propose relevant solutions  come ask them here: http://bit.ly/ask_amnesty

Thanks for your thoughts. We would like to take this opportunity to clarify the GPS aspect of our concept for you.   Cell phones are ubiquitous and we are assuming that a detaining does not realize that they are going to be a detainee and are using their cell phone as usual. We realize that the GPS aspect can be used for negative purposes and actually work against detainees.  However, we included the GPS aspect in our concept because it is assumed that your phone is already being used for negative purposes when you are detained. Here are a couple links that illustrate this point: http://www.legalaffairs.org/issues/July-August-2003/feature_koerner_julaug03.msp  Also there is a device that can track cell phone locations as listed as a Stingray in a Wall Street Journal Article: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424053111904194604576583112723197574.html.  Also network spoofing can be used to track phones and this is done even in Europe as illustrated by http://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/london-police-buy-surveillance-tech-to-track-and-spy-on-cell-phone-users/.  Given these issues, why not use the technology then for a positive purpose like the one intended in our concept?  However, the main point of concept is the ease of use in Voice Activation and if it is deemed that using GPS signal is not suitable for the project then this feature can most certainly be foregone.

evaa_emergency_voice_activated_app.title: EVAA - Emergency Voice Activated App

proven_guilty.description: Guilt is a hypothesis that must be proven.
proven_guilty.creator: 7a5f9dd2ee07e3ea9a9265ac9109fafe

comments.text: In just a couple of sentences, you've managed to share something very thought-provoking Claire! :) If you're curious to explore more about how guilt/innocence plays into our work in this challenge, check out our Guiding Principles page http://bit.ly/riHUU2. As you've pointed out, guilt is often a hypothesis to be proven  but for our purposes here, we're hoping to create solutions that support individuals and families affected by unlawful or secret detention, no matter their presumed guilt or innocence.

Thank you, Ashley.  I get it completely.  I think I had the idea of assumed guilt, or a disregard for proving guilt, collapsed with a disregard for upholding human rights.  Your response had me drill down deeper into the issue. I am now in this inquiry with myself about why I am resisting taking guilt and innocence out of the equation. Definitely something to examine.

proven_guilty.title: PROVEN Guilty

comments.text: Thanks Kelly for sharing. Per Meena suggestion, it'll be great to start thinking about how dropbox as a technology could help people who are unlawfully detained or members of their families and relatives.I guess you could imagine it as a PO box where you could "drop" messages for your family and friends and if they see that you don't drop anything, they might  realize that something happen to you...It could also be use as a service where you would have information regarding the laws, customs and mores of a country if you needed some help like in the case of Vincent: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/fleeing-the-police/or Rathin: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/you-cannot-board-the-flight..-you-dont-have-enough-money../You might know about an example where dropbox was used in a situation of unlawful detention or situations related to human rights in a similar way that google+ hangout was used by the Dalai Lama: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/google-hangouts-helps-dalai-lama-desmond-tutu-overcome-government-restriction-to-meet/It will be great if you could develop this example. It is easy to edit and update your inspiration.thanks,al

Interesting Kelly. Would be great if you'd like to add some insights on how a great service like DropBox could help people supporting human rights int he face of unlawful detention. By expanding on this example you're more likely to attract others to join a conversation  which could be fruitful in translating these insights here to our upcoming Concepting phase.

frank_warren_postsecret.description: People mail Frank Warren postcards with their secrets. How can postcards convey more than what they say?
frank_warren_postsecret.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: Hi Avi, this is a great inspiration showing that giving people a space to post things anonymously online grants a huge sense of freedom and solidarity. It would be interesting in the concepting phase to consider if an anonymous site could be created for people to anonymously report an unlawful detention (in the UK this exists for crime http://www.crimestoppers-uk.org/). Perhaps someone saw something but was too scared to step in at the time, or cannot give evidence or information for fear of reprisal to themselves or family - online anonymity may alleviate some of these fears of passing information on.

I wonder if the postcard could say "If I am missing, please check for me in these places.  Also, x is likely behind this."  Could a message like this, in an online environment, prevent the detention from happening in the first place?

the_question_box_provides_answers_in_unr.description: The Question Box, an initiative and tool that is spreading across India, installs live telephone 'question boxes' in remote villages where access to information is low through which villagers can connect to operators who can help them find answers.

comments.text: This is really amazing. Its such an easy way to share knowledge and educate poeple who have limited access to technology. Its surprising but as you mentioned in your earlier comment about the cellular network reaching almost all the rural parts of India, this also is a fact that illeterate people in rural India also have started using cellphones for their basic functions. This proves that technology can reach the farthest and seemingly impossible parts of the world if given a right channel.As I can see it, the barrier or the gap between uneducated people and technology is diminishing soon which can prove to be very useful for our common cause of spreading the information and getting more and more people aware of important things like their legal rights. Its majorly possible because of simplified forms of technology and a user friendly interface, of which, QB is an excellent example.

Question Box is such a great example of inclusivity & spreading information, Imran! If anyone is keen to check out the link they can do so here: http://questionbox.org/ And Imran  you might like to check out tips like how to add direct links to your post over on our New Users Forum: http://bit.ly/oi_link

Thanks, Meena! I just noticed from the ThinkTank inspiration that we 'double-posted' on Question Box - sorry about that :) I came across Question Box this past summer when working with Lend-A-Hand India (LAHI) in Pune. The organizations partner together as LAHI's work concentrates on some of the most rural areas in India and QB was a practical, low-tech way of getting information to these parts that don't have the luxury of broadband coverage. Interestingly, mobile coverage is fantastic in many of the remote areas but little is being done (at least where I was) to integrate the tool into learning. Anyways, this is off topic but I thought I'd share. Thanks again for the comment and nice meeting you!
Great inspiration. Thanks for sharing. You might also want to check the Ghana Think Tank inspiration which in a similar spirit: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/thinktanks/
What a cool, innovative idea. Community empowerment efforts like this one can be really powerful. Thanks for sharing, Anne!

amnesty_workshops_in_police_academy.description: This concept targets the policemen who decide and perform an unlawful detention (or not). These people act possibly under their superior's commands or by themselves. They need information about what is unlawful detention and what are the consequences for the victim and what they can do instead and  they  also need reassurance that even if they act against their superior's commands they won't lose their job.

Great idea nonetheless!Hannah, Wells College Innovation Lab

comments.text: Great inspiration!What do you think of this adaptation?"The Map of Freedom"Amnesty International could build a section on their website to track collective data of each missed person (with a generated profile number (Amnesty International ID) in the way your example suggests.Any individual can submit a profile for a missing person online, with picture, age, sex, what was the person up do do next, etc. AND the last position and time the person had been seen marked on a Google-like map.With other people starting (anonymously) entering their coordinates of encounter with the missed person that will track and show the spots and times the person had been seen by others. A red string of movement of the person will build up and may give first evidence on what could have happened and where to start searching.This can be supported my other technology such as mobiles, apps, email, text messages.But surely a basic way should be good old paper.Missed persons are shown publicly on posters with their Amnesty International ID.Locally adapted one page form sheets provided by Amnesty International can be filled in and sent to Amnesty International by post or handed in directly at trusted places. There the data will be transferred to the online file.The form can be printed and is widely available at anonymous places such as toilet-cabins, churches, hospitals.The form is set up with fields one only has to tick (like lottery tickets):-Amnesty International ID of person-time last seen-seen in: good condition / bad condition-mark the spot on the regional mapInvolving in "The Map of Freedom" will be advertised as a means to helping build freedom for everybody: "Please help! This time it may be a stranger, but next time it may be you or a loved one!"
I gave it a try and made it my first concept.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Thank you!

Thanks Arjan. This is an interesting idea to explore the story-telling aspect discussed. I'm wondering if it would not be also something to explore with Shawn's idea of check-in updates (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/check-in-updates/)Something that might be problematic would be "access". It might not always possible to log in but this is where others could do it for the person in detention.al

Tip: If you add links without brackets in your comments, they'll show up as live, active links. Hope that helpful as I notice you've been so thoughtful in cross-pollinating posts across a number of Inspirations. Thanks for being such an active collaborator & community champion!
Thanks Meena for the kind words and the tip! I was wondering how to do this! :-)

Yes, access is an issue. And a solution has to design for that. It's both access to the phone, which can be addressed as you said by allowing people to report on others, but also access to mobile internet. It has to be easy to send a story. Through an app on a smartphone, a website, text-message (SMS) but maybe even a postcard.

A system like this one could be implemented to record kidnaps, or unofficial arrests, as well as official ones. This could add a real dimension to the "official" data provided by governments, involve community on watching and keeping safe each other.
That would be a good translation/conversion of this app!

i_am_here.description:
"I am here!" is a concept inspired by the age old conventional method of a 'roll call'. Let's assume that the entire world is like one classroom full of people who register themselves because they fear that they may be detained unlawfully.  A open web portal and ballot boxes (for low tech situations) would be at the heart of this solution. Considering that the ratio of human rights' activists to victims will always be skewed, if the latter can be provided with a medium so they may reach out and let the former know about their well being, it could enable organizations like Amnesty to focus on people who go missing rather than spending a lot of time, money and energy just to identify these people who need help. 

Motivation: I am not being an optimist when I say that society on the whole is noble and that transparency in any system usually yields one that is more efficient than a closed and secretive system.
i_am_here.creator: 293d4a74831874d6c5317eee51abb0e0

comments.text: I like this idea, and I would add a couple of possibilities.  It seem ideally suited to a text/sms world, which is much more flexible and widely available than the internet, so you wouldn't need the e-ballot boxes.  Second. I think it's also an opportunity for "micro-human rights" workers in the same way as micro finance lenders get engaged.  Rather than have Amnesty be the immediate central monitoring system for these "pings", you essentially pair up each person registered with someone on the other end who commits to monitoring.  This has the dual effect of accomplishing the "I am here" goal, and also getting people engaged in a real way in taking care of their fellow human being.
Your micro-worker concept is a powerful addition to Sharad's initial concept. I am working on an idea that builds on these. Hope to get it in the few days

Hi Sharad, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know if you face any problems. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

That way the people who wrote them will get email notifications and are likely to come and join the great conversation you've started here as well. Looking forward to collaborative discussion!

comments.text: Interesting example. Though one thing I've been struggling with is, how do you implement this type of art projects in countries with limited resources. Is there an equivalent community driven project that could raise awareness through imagery and art?

Hi Aviya, thanks for your comment and question. I guess one answer would be that these projects would aim to increase public awareness in developed countries, such as the US or European countries. comments.text: Hi Aina, sounds like an interesting program. But it also sounds like a good concept. Does it already exist, or is this a way you think could help solve the issue at hand. If it is the latter, please remember to also contribute it during the concepting phase!

Thank you Arjan!  It was something that I came up with by looking at the challenge and the Amnesty International website. I have never been to the site before and I was shocked by all of the injustices that exist globally on a daily basis to men women and children.  I thought if they branded "Human Rights" in a way that would resonate better with the world they could raise more awareness. It would be great if they could build something like a portal that members could access anytime, anywhere. It is important for everyone to feel safe as they move around the world and AI has the opportunity to design something that solves the problem of unlawfully being withheld. Thanks again for your comment and I will make sure I contribute this to the concept phase. This is my first time on this site so I am learning how it works.

Welcome onboard Aina! Glad you've joined in and you've got a great idea here. Like Arjan's suggested, definitely hold on to it for Concepting as I'm sure some folks would love to help you work on it! In the meantime, as you're finding your way around, you might want to check out the New Users Forum: http://bit.ly/new_users for OpenIDEO tips, tricks and answers.
Thank you Ashley. I will check out the new users forum. :-)

I think this is something similar to how NGO's in the UK support their lone workers who are working in jobs which it is deemed to place them at 'risk'.  There are systems that are set up and I could provide a couple of ideas of the systems that could be looked at.  Essentially what it means is a 24 hour check in system and a range of other tools such as personal alarms, coded SMS from mobile phones, satelite tracking chips etc.  Might be interesting to try something similar for HRDs and individuals at risk.... This issue is that there would need to be some sort of selection process.  Let's think about links to PBI and how we can learn from the referrals processes they have for this kind of thing.
That would be great Jenny....we would need to set up systems that could work for this. I agree that there needs t be a selection process. Thanks for the ideas and help. I appreciate it.

I really like the use of icons in this program.  I think that icons are certainly appreciated in the design world, but they are underused.  I think that one of the things about icons that is not appreciated is their inherent resonance.  There's a kind of direct wire from the perception of an icon to the human mind and it's tough to achieve that in any other way.The use of icons also emphasizes that Amnesty International is just that...international.  Most people aren't very clear about what AI is and I would suppose that most people aren't terribly interested.  The way to cut through that confusion is to tell people what AI actually DOES.  And this program is a clear reminder of what they do.Great work.  This is also a terrific candidate for an app that uses geo location to allow someone to "check in" with their location using the secure database that you mentioned above.
Thank you Chris.
