scratch_patch_.description:
An Amnesty training program on micro-expressions via online software which incorporates hostage scenarios. 

A micro-expression is a brief, involuntary facial expression shown on the face of humans according to emotions experienced. They usually occur in high-stakes situations, where people have something to lose or gain. Unlike regular facial expressions, it is difficult to fake micro-expressions. Micro-expressions express the seven universal emotions: disgust, anger, fear, sadness, happiness, surprise, and contempt.
(Wikipedia)
scratch_patch_.creator: 0be607cde2914e7c2f509b60548accca

comments.text: This micro-expressions training could be helpful within other training concepts like the Vending Machine / Info Hub (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-vending-machine-info-hub/) or WikiAm (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/-201c-wikiam-201d-the-wiki-amnesty/) Very cool!

I really appreciate this idea because I am also I big fan of the work of Paul Ekman and the series Lie To Me. I think training to detect mirco expressions can be used as a helpful tool to give insight to the truth in questionable situations. This new technology needs to be explored and put into effect and this is a great way to start doing so.

Hi Meena, thank you for your feedback. Yes I do agree that tracking devices are very risky hence I have changed it Micro-Expression Training. This topic is an upcoming phenomena and I am sure if incorporated with the right training tools will help out detainees immensely during a hostage situation.
Way to go on your agile ideating, Melanie!

Interesting idea, Melanie! You might like to check out our Tips on Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking devices could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. Even if they are concealed as in your idea, we need to consider the consequences if information gets into the wrong hands or potential for punishment if they are discovered. Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

scratch_patch_.title: F.A.C.E it (Micro-Expressions)

_rolling_away_from_unlawful_detention.description: Lengthy reports, interviews, and surveys are often ineffective and inefficient in reporting and monitoring cases of unlawful detention.  By using code wheels (see picture), friends / family  members can slide the wheel's moving parts in order to create an accurate description of when/how their loved-one was detained, and then text the corresponding code to an sms-database.  The codes can then be analyzed for trends and patterns to help Amnesty International better understand risk factors, center their prevention efforts around those most at risk, or work to discover the best way to help those who have been detained and their families.
_rolling_away_from_unlawful_detention.creator: 18cb8bb9368f4ceeca1d011aff1b0986

comments.text: Brilliantt concept! Having read further I see my 'photographic' suggestion is superfluous. The wheel represents a clever short-form census tool for use in a myriad of situations.On further reflection there might be a role for photographic collection where a wheel needed to use pictures or symbols to represent required information.

I love the low- tech nature of this idea, as well as how it compacts a lot of important information for clarity. My only question is how much does it rely on the users to be able to text thier information to the database? is there any other way this data could be collected and recorded? Relying on cell phone technology can get risky and honestly, it can be limiting as well. However, the idea is developed well enough that I am sure that there are plenty of other options to be thought of!Kathryn, Wells College Innovation Lab

I'm only just beginning to look at the mechanics of the concept so I'm speculating a bit but it occurs to me that a photographic record of wheel settings would allow collecting and collating results quickly and put the wheels back into the field almost immediately. The photos could be included in the database and provide for further analysis at any time.

This is a very neat concept!!  I like the simplicity of it, and the low-tech aspect.  I would love to see this concept expand into providing information to friends/family members, as well as collecting it.  For instance, I could see a similar wheel where you could line up who in your family was detained, what technology you have access to, whether or not you have children, how long the family member has been detained, etc. At which point the friend/family member would be assigned a corresponding code.  Just as you described, the friend/family member would send an SMS text with that corresponding code.  And, in this case, an automated response would be sent as a reply (based on the original code) listing the most appropriate means of support.  Whether that is the universal emergency number, the detainee support net, the local advice wiki, my voice, etc.http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/universal-emergency-number/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-detainee-support-net-financial-legal-moral/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/local-advice-wiki/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/my-voice/

Very nice concept! I like how it provides a low-tech way to collect information. I can see how the data could be linked with both Ana's and Ashwin's concepts: Ana: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/an-interactive-infographic-platform-fueled-by-the-whole-network-of-supporters-/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/secure-network-to-provide-customized-real-time-solution./I can also see providing inputs for Sonic Planet http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/sonic-planet-the-voices-of-the-unheards/or Alan's cube: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/world-s-largest-3d-led-cube.-inspiring-awareness-by-combining-information-art-and-designIn terms of distribution, Ana's vending machine,  letter writing workshop and the Shift III van would be great way to share the wheels but also educate people, and even help them entering the information in the database.http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-vending-machine-info-hubhttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-iii-shift-van-/
Great Inspiration from the Root Change initiative!

_rolling_away_from_unlawful_detention.title: "Rolling" away from unlawful detention

Great consideration of the stress the family, friends and supporters of detainees here, Avivya. And I wonder if as we move on the the Concepting phase if we might think what other services might help this audience? comments.text: Hi Peter, I did not know about this book but you made me curious so I just went to read a summary online and ended up buying it on Amazon.For those who like me do not know about this book, here is the New Yorker review (posted on amazon):Through the story of one mans experience after Hurricane Katrina, Eggers draws an indelible picture of Bush-era crisis management. Abdulrahman Zeitoun, a successful Syrian-born painting contractor, decides to stay in New Orleans and protect his property while his family flees. After the levees break, he uses a small canoe to rescue people, before being arrested by an armed squad and swept powerlessly into a vortex of bureaucratic brutality. When a guard accuses him of being a member of Al Qaeda, he sees that race and culture may explain his predicament. Eggers, compiling his account from interviews, sensibly resists rhetorical grandstanding, letting injustices speak for themselves. His skill is most evident in how closely he involves the reader in Zeitouns thoughts. Thrown into one of a series of wire cages, Zeitoun speculates, with a contractors practicality, that construction of his prison must have begun within a day or so of the hurricane. thanks!al

When I tell people about this book, I never want to blow where the actual story goes; it kind of starts off as this power-of-the-human-spirit story during Katrina but then gets REALLY crazy.Reading the book and realizing that something like that could happen here to US citizens blew my mind. We need story tellers like him to find these stories and then tell them soberly, without adornment, to show plain as day that injustice happens all day, everyday. Hopefully with that knowledge we as the motivated, creative, idealistic people we are can try to change the conditions that lead to injustice. Vai la.

amnesty_needed_at_home.title: Amnesty Needed At Home

comments.text: interesting Arjan! It reminds me of an exhibition I went to many years ago in Paris which aimed to make the visitors experience the feeling of being visually impaired. All was dark, you were given a white stick and the guides were visually impaired. This was an amazing experience of powerlessness for those who usually see but also showed us all the other senses that we were "missing"... I think it is still "touring": http://www.dialogtickets.com/
Interesting connection. I've also heard there's a restaurant in Paris like this. Staff (waiters) are blind, restaurant is pitch dark so guests can't see and experience blindness in a way.

comments.text: Disclaimer: I do not intend this to be a technique for guilty individuals to use. But I believe that Polygraph machines are highly inaccurate, yet widely used. The results can be easily tampered by environmental factors like temperature, health condition, personality, context and emotion. Therefore, if we know techniques to calm ourselves, perhaps we can prevent unlawful and inaccurate "evidence" which may lead to detention.

access_art.description:
Art is a universal tool that can spread both political and opinion based ideas non violently. If we can distribute art materials to people who do not have access to them, we are supplying them with an opportunity to express their ideas publicly. 
-Wells College Innovation Lab (Kelly, Ethan, Corey, Zach, Anastasia)
access_art.creator: 181cdff156814f6a39ce167d13f7d8e0

comments.text: Utilizing art as therapy for family and networks of those detained could provide significant healing / process of emotions. And given permission, some of this artwork could be distributed on other channels. Relevant example: I recently visited a native american reservation and found that one of the most moving things I experienced there was a book of children's drawings on their life on the reservation. They were compiled years later - i.e. not created for publication. But the honesty and simple messages really struck home - more than any higher end / glossy publication.Maybe, along with the art supplies, descriptions of how to use art for the people directly effected to process and express their experiences would be powerful - and/or training local people to facilitate this.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_therapy

Low-tech is probably the easiest and most efficient way for detainees and protestors to speak. Internet isn't readily accessible to masses of people, especially in other countries where unlawful arrests are prominent. Artwork is a very powerful tool that can reach a lot of people. I love this concept!! -Molly Heslin, Friendly neighborhood Wells College Innovation Lab.

Interesting thoughts, guys. Do you have any ideas on how you could encourage the art materials to be used for the purposes you're suggesting? Might be relevant to consider support tools which could help focus the use of the materials on the intended goal?

the_embassy_app.description:
Unlawful detention is a matter of being in the wrong place at the wrong time and as well meeting the wrong type of people.  One way to avoid the possibility of unlawful detention is through prevention.

There are already great concepts by the community that can create the right platform for prevention and the EMBASSY App is bringing all the good points of those ideas under one umbrella.

People's embassies are where they can get the most help and support in this situation and are in most countries in the world.  It makes sense that the United Nations, Amnesty International and Countries of the world collaborate under one umbrella to stop "unlawful detention"
the_embassy_app.creator: 9f72fde7a469c28d5a17e9f050da02b2

The opportunity and ability to communicate and share updates between detainees and their families is definitely something we need to consider in Concepting.

job_search.creator: 7905b5813c35371a21bcc668945f61d5

comments.text: Alix!! Fancy seeing you here! :D Like you and so many others, I'm def in the same boat. Going on 4 months now.. Oy. It's not schadenfreude, but I'm glad to know I'm not alone. And that's definitely relevant to how many detainees feel, I'm sure. Brilliant!
Ha, so funny! Good to see you again! It's crazy to see the response behind this, definitely shows that there are a lot of people in this boat.
OMG Alix I feel your pain, every line of it. And it's been 4 months already :(

I really get what you are saying. I've been job searching for quite some time as well and the day to day act of staying motivated is very tiring. I'm reminded of swimming in any large body of water and feeling a sense of being alone and yet flying over a huge abyss of unknown hoping that I don't sink or something doesn't come from below to swallow me whole.I think that communication is definitely a huge piece to this challenge.

Wow, great personal insight. And I think that it is very important to highlight the personal drama of stories to make people care. The situation you're describing will sound familiar to many of us (it does to me), and from there it is easier to imagine how powerless people must feel when they are persecuted unjustly. And that makes it easier for people to care and act on it.
Thanks Arjan!
Wonderful example Alix  and I couldn't have offered any praise better than what Arjan just said. You've done a great job of thinking through powerlessness with an eye toward empathy!
Okay, okay, the "Featured Inspiration" thing makes me feel powerful too ; ) Ha, thanks Ashley.
Happy to do what I can :)

Alix, as said by Arjan and Ashley, this is a very "powerful" story about feeling powerless. It also reminds you how many situations (that might not necessarily appear "dramatic") can make you feel powerless. On the commonalities of powerlessness, I think that the uncertainty - in all its variations - is a key element. I would add in some cases, like immigration, power differences.al

Yes, I think uncertainty is definitely a big one. In Nathan's tandem skydiving post, he mentions that the consistent instructions and process helped him with the powerlessness of the experience. Perhaps this could be addressed by providing a training course for at-risk people. It could explain human rights and maybe carry out simulations to teach people what to do in case they're unlawfully detained.

comments.text: Hi Simon, very interesting inspiration. It reminded me a comment made on the article linked to Dan's inspiration on Liu Xiaobo: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/a-chinese-story-liu-xiaobo-and-the-river-crabs/It was said that his wife since last October (when he was put in jail) has not been seen and that "her twitter account has gone silent since then".Also in the post about 9/11, Shoshana stopped twitting: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/detainments-on-9-11-11/One could imagine that these "silences" could be visualized in a similar way and with a similar symbolic power, that Liu's Nobel Prize award was placed on an empty chair in Oslo. Another option could also be to explore the idea of "bringing them back to life" as in the campaign you refer to.I can see a lot of options for the concepting phase. Looking forward to it,al

Thanks for building the connections across posts!I agree - lots of interesting visualization opportunities depicting silence and activity. Might be compelling to some how add other layers of information as well - e.g., other indicators of political liberty or a region's human rights track record.

Great example of turning contemporary conventions inside out, Simon.I notice that the link you've posted is not active. Tip: You can add a link directly to text (eg. you could add your link to "Read more" at the end of your last paragraph) To do this, hit the Update Entry button on the right of your post and then use the rich formatting bar above the Description field. To make a link, highlight the text you want linked & use the icon which has a chain link with a '+' sign on it. Hope that helps.
Thanks Meena! the link should be working now.

amnesty_international_invites_music_star.description: Musicians and volunteers start a road trip around the world! In each destination they collect stories, give information and raise awareness during the day; during the night they give concerts to raise funds for the campaign.
amnesty_international_invites_music_star.creator: 4b0ecd5a3a5c4881c323c18fe46b2ad1

comments.text: This is a lovely idea! The musicians themselves would be greatly inspired by hearing stories and lives of people in danger of detention.

Hi Angeliki,Love this idea especially as an extension of Anne-Laura's Shift lll Van incorporating mobility for lots of other concepts.I envisage mabye two complementary tours going on at the same time:One touring affluent areas where concerts could support costs for both and predominantly involved in spreading awareness; and The other touring places where direct support and action may be required.Put them in touch with one another so that as stories are collected or situations observed and documented they can be fed into the awareness campaign. At the same time those in need of support could discover first hand how their stories are being shared with the rest of the world.A second pair of tours could see teams reversed and so on building experience across the greater team.

Hi Angeliki,that would be nice indeed to go on the road in a van... If only I were a musician! :-)Seriously, I think this is an interesting concept that could clearly be an interesting campaign.It also made me think of Playing for change:http://playingforchange.com/episodes/38/Imaginehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cI_0Hyn57Lk&feature=artistand I think we could keep the Shift name created by Anne and it could be the Shift music tour...

I just saw 'playing for change' and it's a very idealistic idea that seems to work..I also tracked back to Anne's inspiration to understand why you chose the name 'Shift' for the van, so I'll rename the concept to Shift Music Tour :)
glad you liked playing for change. and nice to see Anne's shift inspiration kept alive :-)
I like weaving ideas together..I think it's the key in this whole process :)
Great collaborative ideating  and loving the conversations triggered here!
oh  I did I mention how awesome your illustration is on this???!
Thank you so much! Observing illustrations for other concepts in OPENIDEO is so helpful :)

Hi Angeliki!Great idea, and I really like the way you've managed to interwind and connect many concepts into one! Good job.I think the Shift Van is a great vehicle (in this case could be Shift Trucks :) ) and my Interactive Infographic Platform is a great way to use it here, to digitally and technically share to the world what is happening on the tour, and the idea of educating through the Shift Vans. One thing that came to mind was regarding your statement: "the volunteers are responsible for organizing the concert but also for inviting people to share their stories and informing people" with regards to inviting ppl to share their stories, and informing ppl, I imagine this is with regards to human rights issues I imagine, Maybe we could turn this into the big focus of some of the vans, but if the van arrives to a concert location in Venezuela let's say, we would need local knowledge or contacts, to get in touch with local families affected by HR violations, so they can join us at the concert, to share their problems, as maybe they won't be aware of this concert or big event, if they are leading a more secluded and low profile life since being affected by this serious issue in life. Using famous people or celebrities are always a good way to get attention to important issues. I don't have much experience in PR, but I was just wondering this could be quite an expensive project to plan. But either way is a great idea. Well done !

Thank you very much for your feedback! Yes, that would be indeed an issue; how could the affected families get in touch with Amnesty? How can we make sure that all people -and especially the affected ones that as you said live a more secluded life - participate? That's why I think there should be some local volunteers, who will know their way in the cities, the local language, the 'ghettos' etc. If you have any ideas how could we reach those people, you are more than welcome to share! :) However, I think that an event taking place in their area and volunteers speaking their language supported also by an online platform is already a quite direct approach (compared to a standalone website).

comments.text: Great illustration of what's at stake Owen, and how missteps can have huge costs! Definitely something to keep in mind during concepting & evaluation.

Hi Owen, You are right on the audacious hairy goal. Actually such grandiose goals "paralyze" people. There are two books that I am familiar which focus on small wins and progress. Little bets by Peter Sims http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1439170428/bobsutton-20Progress Principle by Amabile and Kramer http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/142219857X/bobsutton-20Related to unlawful detention, if we can decrease the detentions by 1 person at a time, that's a small and big win and if we can show progress (one more person not unlawfully detained or some other measure that show progress), that is also very motivating.

Thank you Meena, I am big follower of Bob Sutton (even the links for the books are from his site!), so he is a great resource in organizational management

protest_party_pack_education_service_equ.description: This concept targets the portion of unlawfully detained individuals by way of protests or rallys. It's an education service deployed in the middle of protests to offer information about individual rights, check-in's for tracking services, and any other product designed to keep participants safe.
protest_party_pack_education_service_equ.creator: 2935218c6249f6d941ddaac700aa391d

comments.text: Thanks to some great suggestions and dialogue within other concepts I've updated the Party Pack to include a new low-tech tracking service, the Shift Freedom Glasses and Shift III Van service.

Excellent in many ways (low-tech, easy to carry, easy to respond to if found, etc.), but could be useless if the detainee can't tear-off the bit (or, worse, if the detainers find the remaining piece of the paper, might get more violent with the detainee and try to find the piece back).
Excellent point and a valid scenario Sarah. Hopefully through some refinement we can address them!

Maybe a seperate piece of paper/plastic/stone/coin can be used, with an identifying number. This would also mean that a list has to be kept somewhere that connects the numbers and the people, but that could be taken care of in some secure way, I believe. Especially with people that are most at risk for being unlawfully detained for a longer period. It reminds me a bit of those things you can get for luggage or keys, that have a number on them, and a central return adress. If found, please send to... Pre-registration is required, but that could also happen on the spot.

This is a really interesting idea Arjan...low-tech tracking. It makes me think, maybe each card has two tear-off strips, with the same numerical code, as you mentioned. The first is completed with the activist's name (and any identifying information they would like to divulge) then torn off and stored with the P.P. volunteers. The second piece only has the numerical code and can be dropped as a breadcrumb. It also adds a nice bit of privacy. Nice job!

Interesting idea. As the others, I like the combination of low tech and high tech in this one. And I especially liked the button that indicates to 'enforcers' that they're being watched. It might be a small sign, but it might help. I think it's really powerful.

Hi Jason!I'm loving the analogue attribut of your concept, I think it's always very important to educate and inform in the physical world, as it is in the 'digital' world :) This concept reminds me of the 'Think Tank' inspiration,  http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/thinktanks/  "a custom-built teardrop trailer designed to journey into different locales in the so-called First World where it collects issues of concern to the local community...it then rolls back into the communities, this time as a mobile workstation, cooperating with community members to apply the solutions received". I thought this idea could be adapted into your concept, and create a secure and official 'hub' for the participants in rallys with this service.Educational Empowerment as you and Anne-Laure mention, is important and above all, very necessary in these times, so I think this concept hits the most crucial point for this challenge!

Thanks Ana! The ThinkTank concept should absolutely be rolled into this one. It's interesting, as concepts continue to be polished I can imagine a mobile education pod being very useful for many of the designs.

I like the low-tech aspect as well as the educational and empowerment components. The bread of crumbs is a nice one. Yet what happens if like in the little thumbling, the crumbs get eaten by the birds? This means being able to figure out "stones" (that the little thumbling used the first time) rather than crumbs. Sarah also raised an interesting issue: how will the authorities react? We have to hope that they have enough respect for the law...
Oh I really like the use of "stones" to inform the design. Thanks Anne-Laure.
Congrats on being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Thanks!!

a_z_guide_for_families_and_friends_of_de.description: A-Z Guide for Families and Friends of Detainees is an online participatory interactive book that can be used as a comprehensive guide on what to do when someone is detained.
a_z_guide_for_families_and_friends_of_de.creator: 231882454063de4d24043525f02e5700

comments.text: hm, what happened to this idea. I have a Belarusian organization at hand which work closely with families and friends of detainees and would be interested to adapt it to Belarusian realities.

Hi Amjad - did you hear the news? Your concept is being developed and prototyped as part of this weeks Make-a-thon at IDEO London! Check this out for more info http://bit.ly/y2uDQZ and be sure to weigh in over at our User Forums http://bit.ly/yt0m5d to help your idea take one step closer to reality.
And hint: be sure to check out Brief #2!

Very cool. I LOVE the fact that there's thought being given to low tech contexts (I'm online c/o an inverter at the moment - in Harare we experience power cuts of 9 hours or more). Another addition might be a short film - many people in Zimbabwe have access to DVD players but struggle to get online.For a mobile voice solution consider Freedom Fone.

Hello Amjad! Thank you for your contribution to this challenge, we really appreciate all of your hard work. Congratulations on creating a winning concept! The Amnesty team loved how comprehensive and informative the A-Z Guide idea is, great work.
Congratulations Amjad! I think this is a key concept for the supporters and their families and relatives.
Congrats Amjad! Perhaps, as a Content Editor at Amnesty, you'll be part of the team moving this idea forward? ;)
Congratulations on your winning concept Amjad!  I can't wait to see what happens with this concept.  This has the potential to be a pivotal resource...
Congratulations.
Congratulations Amjad! You have created a fundamental support idea. Looking forward to seeing it realised.

Great idea. Perhaps there could also be a network operated through a lower-tech vehicle as well for those who cannot access the internet or print.   Such as connected to a phone number that people can text to.  Critical information would need to be abbreviated, but perhaps a few key pieces of information could be coded to develop a response/information network at relatively low cost for users, but highly accessible since so many have mobile phones.  Check out: http://www.esoko.com/It's for an entirely different application, but this is a service that lets farmers know market prices for goods via texting.
That is a very good idea, thanks Sean! My only concern is a phone line service is very costly for such a project, but I'll add that too.

Like your idea Amjad.As an extension on the phone idea: Maybe a solution like Skype (out) could work to make it cheaper in use. Also person in need could text, or make a 'missed call' to an information number, and they could be called back (so the people in need of advice do not need to spend their scarce money). You could also make this into a marketing vehicle, that people can donate telephone minutes to Amnesty (maybe also left-over minutes from their mobile phone subscription).

Great great ideas Amjad! This is really good.. I agree with Martin that getting volunteers interacting with the families would be a great idea too.. I know that might not be easy but maybe partnering with Volunteer organisations and offering it as as a placement or so? I don't know at all how hard that would be, just a thought that crossed my mind. I think this is great though! :) x
Thanks for your precious contribution Gwen!

Great idea Amjad!  I like how your idea is a bundle of useful knowledge that could flow anywhere.  If you don't mind, I'd like to point out the fact that many of our concepts make a perfect match for 1 strong modular online system.  Example:  On my concept I consider that a alert should contain a package with useful information that is sent out to the network of support.  Well, the A-Z guide is juts that package.Again, congrats on a sharp solid concept!

Agreed, great ideas Amjad!Also, think they are very complementary with the ideas in http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/local-advice-wiki/ .  Two finalists concepts in this realm, really points to the importance of such a resource!

Thanks Alejandro and Vicent for your comments, that's the very point of this initiative, to share efforts and develop altogether solid concepts for human rights. Many concepts could be incorporated into each other, but the more work you develop, the bigger and harder to manage the project gets. So my idea here is to combine simplicity and harness sophisticated technology to produce a simple product high-end product.
amazing work Amjad!
Thank you Joesfine!

Amjad, I agree with Alejandro and Vincent. So many of the concepts in this challenge complement each other (not just the short-listed ones). Both this and the wiki concept need to be a part of the integrated system. People relate to information in a variety of ways so offering different ways to access information (even duplicated information) is very valuable. Great work!
Thanks Paul!

Hi Amjad,This looks really useful. It's not until someone you know is detained that you realise you don't know what is safe to do online and what isn't...and Facebook doesn't feel so safe. I hope it would be possible to make this site really secure and avoid hacking...is this possible?! Overall I definitely think the power of social media must be tapped into as you describe, to help people in similar situations connect and share strategies/experience with each other. Best of luck and I hope it comes to fruition.

Yes, I have creative ideas on making this website much more secure than facebook and other social website by implementing few creative ideas I have not included here for copyrights reasons. Thanks heaps for your comment Liz.

It's very interesting to see how a lot of the contributions target different groups of people from 1) Guards - how to elicit empathy from them 2) detainees themselves 3) friends and family of detainees. I particularly think it's particularly good that you recognized the confusion, anxiousness, and helplessness that families would feel when a loved one is detained. Perhaps this should be something that all potential detainees, activists who fear that they may be in trouble, could train and teach their families ahead of time to prepare for.
As someone who was detained earlier this year, my only concern when I was in solitary confinement was my family!

Looking from the other end, your friends in London were extremely worried about you including myself. Nobody knew what was going on with little or no information or updates, nobody knew what to doand equally what one shouldn't do. Thus, one question I would raise is about distribution. If any guides did exist, none of us knew where to find them. How do you see such a book/website being spread?

You've certainly addressed a significant need here... There may be no quick-and-easy solution to these issues, but helping the families involved cope with their struggle is commendable. Perhaps there's a way to add to point #4 by assigning a volunteer "case worker" to families that request it...
Hey Martin, thanks for your suggestion. Yet it requires big capacity to accommodate such task!
I think I can benefit from your suggestion, check how I amended the concept. Thanks
That is perfect. Information is so important in these situations, but the human touch can often have the longest-lasting impact. I'll be cheering you on to the finish line!
Thank you everyone for your suggestions. They were extremely helpful to develop the concept further to incorporate many new amazing ideas.

Great ideas, Amjad! You might want to connect to previous Inspirations which relate to your great thoughts here  eg Making Policy Public: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/making-policy-public/ To do this, hit the Update Entry button on the right of your post, scroll down to the Build Upon area. Search terms like "communication" and see what's relevant and drag posts which you think connect to yours over. This helps us connect the dots between various ideas & conversations and brings more people into your conversation (authors of posts you Build Upon will get email notifications) Fab to have you onboard and hope to be seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!
Sorry Meena for my late reply, and thanks for your great work. I think I am too late to connect previous inspirations, but I will do in the future. x

Great concept Amjad! I especially like how you've outlined both 'high-tech' and 'low-tech' versions of this idea. Welcome to OpenIDEO - we're happy to have you and your Amnesty International colleagues onboard.
Thank you very much Ashley, you are doing great job guys! x

Hi Amin,very nice idea and like Meena, I love the fact that you thought of low tech and high tech contexts, as well as  making it in local languages.To follow up on Meena's suggestion, here are a couple of inspirations you might want to build upon: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/beyond-translation-how-to-design-tools-and-campaigns-that-are-culturally-relevanthttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/avaaz-a-voicehttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/free-social-impact-technology-tools-connect-people-and-solutionshttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/global-pulsehttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/language-problem-you-have-to-prove-your-right-in-right-languagethere are many others. I thought I remembered seeing an inspiration proposing a similar service. Yet, I realized that in fact, the idea  about having a "repository" for information, tips and guidelines emerged  in comments and discussions about stories of powerlessnessSee for example: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/you-cannot-board-the-flight..-you-dont-have-enough-money../http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/fleeing-the-police/So your concept seems to answer some of the issues raised in these conversations! :-)
Hey Anne, thanks for your suggestion. They were helpful, they gave me ideas to incorporate further help to families.

Great idea Amjad. I also really like the incorporation of a low-tech version that can be downloaded/printed/disseminated. I really liked Haiyan's inspiration regarding micro loans: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/micro-loans-to-support-the-families-of-those-unlawfully-detained/  Maybe you could incorporate links to support other families going through this same process?
I already did, thank you very much.
Congrats on being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks :)

Hey Amjad, .a networking thinker!! thats great hey Anne-Laure sent me your concept cause she found that we can join forces! I also have a similar sinergy with online/offline communities,,have a look to my concept and if you dont mind we can build interesting things.Have a nice day..
Hey Nayda, I am so very sorry for my late reply, please let me know once you are online. We have only 8 hours left!
Hey Amjad, great idea. So simple and yet so necessary. I wonder how we could design this site to be easily accessible/understandable for family members with varying tech-abilities?
Thanks Christine, as explained in the concept: The book will be printed too into a soft copy and distributed worldwide. Read the last section of my concept.
Simple and efficient, great idea! Let's hope the access the this information won't be censored by governments :)
In addition to hard copy/downloads the equivalent could be provided on removable usb media perhaps through Anne-Laure Shift III Vans
Thanks heaps Sarah for the your comment, I added a section on fighting censorship.

Hi Amjad, we loved your idea of a comprehensive guide for supporters of detainees. This sounds like a really useful resource on a global level. We would love to see more refinement on the technology front in terms of how you envision the interactive platform.
I already added info on this! Thanks OpenIDEO

I find this to be a terrific idea as just another way to use the concept of networking to solve a problem.  We hear every day how your personal network can help you accomplish tasks from finding a new job to planning a wedding more effectively.  Naturally, we should look for new ways to make networking work.  This is just one of many new avenues where networking can be a benefit.

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

comments.text: Hi Calum,interesting concept which tries to take into account the fact that smart phones might not always be available.Another concept you might want to look at as it takes a similar perspective: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/hidden-bracelet-with-signal/To Meena's point about tracking devices can also be dangerous for someone who might be "at risk", you might want to think of the conditions of use and how you could avoid risks linked to tracking systems. A more general question re. tracking systems: can't we already be tracked with our smart phones? Another question about the use: who would be the users? Activists, people who might be at risks (traveling in a country politically unstable, e.g.)? thanks.

I like this idea a lot! I think this would be easier (and safer) to use than pulling a cell phone. It's interesting that it would work the same way as "I've Fallen and I Can't Get Up". If this could be made properly and sold at a sensible price, I feel like this would be a good tool for a protester to use.
Thanks Emily. I was thinking this concept of device could also be used for seniors. lol

Hi Callum, interesting idea! You might like to check out our Tips on Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking devices could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

The "larger than life" scale of the Cristo installations are what really grabs people's attention. It reminds me of the inflatable rats one sees on the street, during union strikes. http://www.laborunionreport.com/portal/2011/09/shock-laborers-union-to-pay-up-to-12-5-million-to-get-rid-of-cheese-eating-rat-seiu/

Hi Ashley, thanks for commenting!I chose to share this exactly because it got my attention for being such a secure and motivated group of people that believe in this and that formed Global Survivors Network.And it is very true what they say: that terrorists are innovators...And like OpenIDEO does with this exact platform, (and this challenge!) is bringing us a step forward in being greater innovators. comments.text: What a great example of individuals contributing their experiences to make the community smarter and safer. I checked out their website and played around with the map that's on the home page (http://voiceofkibera.org/) and what I loved was that the map doesn't just pinpoint emergencies or danger, but that it also shows celebrations, religious events and community gatherings. Great inspiration Michael.

Thx Ashley. I think Ushahidi is a great example of how technology (soft/hard) can empower communities, not only to report problems but also to gather people around a cause, a celebration. In this challenge, the sense of community building and connectivity seems important so as many voices as possible can be heard and words be read.

social_network_alarm.description: Every person connect via mobile phone to a number of peers - family members, friends, colleagues. Connection is then monitored every hour by sending a coded ping to all the mobiles in the network. When the mobile is switched off, all the peer mobiles are informed the time and the location. If the persons mobile phone does not come online again within few hours, the alarm notifies the peers about it. Could be useful, not only to detect people that are being detained, but anyone who disappears from his or her network.
social_network_alarm.creator: 5a4877c01de27cb9f01d78b5d431e648
social_network_alarm.title: Social Network Alarm

comments.text: I really like this idea. Making a list of rights easily accessible to those who may not know what their rights are would go along way for those being detained. The only issue that I see with this, going forward, is that the people that are actually detaining people unlawfully are not always concerned with the rights of their prisoners.

comments.text: Thanks guys for your inspiration which reinforces the point made by many others stories shared in the inspiration phase - see for example: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/how-do-you-want-this-story-to-end/The point you are making about the role of evidence in judging a case. It is very much aligned with the questions raised by the 12 angry men movie: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/12-angry-men-the-power-of-questioning-/On your second story about the soldier in Taiwan and how he was forced to admit the crime, you might want to check Ashwin's inspiration on why detention: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/why-detention/I guess then the question becomes how to act. a few inspirations such ashttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/avaaz-a-voice/are providing some suggestions.Increasing public awareness seems to be one way to go. It seems that you're also calling for an approach that will address the deeper problems as suggested by Christian in his inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/inverting-the-problem/Looking forward to how you would address these issues in the concepting phase,al

And if you think these Inspirations relate to what you've posted here you can add them using the Build Upon Feature (hit the Update Entry button on the right of your post) Authors of posts you choose to link to your post via Build Upon will get an email notification  so are more likely to come and join the conversation you've started here.

Hi Team Chimera (aka Rita, Kuan-Hsien, Regina and Ashwin)! Thanks for sharing these two important stories with us. I think the big takeaway is the role that evidence plays in the mainstream judicial system - and the powerful role that evidence might play in exonerating/freeing people who are detained unlawfully. As we prepare to head into Concepting, let's keep this in mind  how might we develop tools that help bring important evidence to light?
Well put on the horrible shortcomings of the death penalty.

too_many_troy_davis_where_is_justice_.title: Too many Troy Davis ~ Where is justice ?

invisible_people_giving_the_homeless_a_f.description: The Invisible People project has had a great reach so far and has given homeless people a face and a name. The story shared here is one of many.
invisible_people_giving_the_homeless_a_f.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: This is heartbroken to watch, yet the project itself is raising awareness to issues that many do not feel comfortable discussing.. Definitely something to learn from and think about for raising awareness of unlawful detention! Thanks for sharing Arjan.

This is nice, and reminds me of the Danish National TVs (2011) project called "Lseklubben Sundholm" (BookClub Sundholm.... Sundholm is the name of the 'last destination'/activation for drug addicts and homeless people )The program consisted of 1 moderator and 4 homeless people / addicts who each week, for 6 weeks, read a book and discussed it. The program was 30 minutes long, and absolutely amazing. The homeless people used their own life stories to analyze the books. So one learned about their life indirectly, and in a very dignified way (-as full human beings with an opinion and experiences to share). The program really gave the 'The Voiceless a Voice'.(Link: http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Kultur/Laeseklubber/Sundholm/Artikler/20110304145344.htm)

Oh, that sounds great! Wonderful way of portraying people differently and shift perception. Also, I think that is one of the fun things of reading, it puts your life into perspective, relative to others.

Ashley's Fire! post inspired me to think about connecting people who've been detained and people who can help... it seems like if people who could help saw themselves in detainees, they would be more likely to lend a hand. A project like this one could be so powerful in that regard... simple video clips of innocent detainees talking about their lives before the event, and then telling the story of what happened to them.

invisible_people_giving_the_homeless_a_f.title: Invisible People, giving the homeless a face

This is a great site, for all ages.....seeing that I am in fact playing one of the games :D. Tools like this have the capabilities to be extremely influential. And I would rather children playing games such as these rather than watching the gobble-d-gook I've seen on TV

an_app_for_everything.description: An app that asks for a password every three days. If you can't access your phone they'll call and ask if you're ok. You don't answer, they call your contact and get your agenda. They then have a place to start looking.
an_app_for_everything.creator: dd147ea08856879a3c60cbac45d2ea84

comments.text: Interesting idea. You could even make an additional lower tech version, in which someone sends their password by sms every three days, for places where not everybody can afford a smartphone, or where mobile data services are not available.
Yeah! Was thinking about that.

Hey Allison, welcome to OpenIDEO and cheers for your great idea! Be sure to hold on to this and re-post it as we move into Concepting - I am sure that folks in our community would love to help you build this out! In the meantime, I wonder if there are examples of current/existing apps that offer the ability to communicate an emergency like this to a person's family or friends?

innocence_project_uk.description: Innocence Network UK is a programme that uses law-school student labour to work on wrongful conviction cases. Key features why I think it is relevant to this discussion are: student activism, academic rigour and practical humanitarian goals.
innocence_project_uk.creator: 1efb90dc246807ff9a4b35505fc3b882

comments.text: Hi Vincent, This is an excellent comment and a great initiative. Its important to engage law students in human rights case work, here and also in places where extreme poverty add a futher dimension and distance between justice and those who are being unlawfully detained. The Nigerian Network of University Legal Aid Institutions in Abuja does innovative work with law students - creating legal clinics to service those living in extreme poverty and in hard-to-reach rural areas, and in inspiring law students to consider public litigation as a career. And they have had some success in this last, despite the high student fees and the low potential income in this area of law.
Very good example

This is a great idea because it gets law students involved in real cases making them aware of what is going on and provides a cheap way for people wrongfully convicted to get legal help that could lead to their proven innocence and chance at a real life. - Zack Daniels: Wells College Innovation Lab

Wow, great way to match people who very much need legal help with law students who value the practical & humanitarian legal experience.Hmm...I wonder if there's a way this could be applicable in other areas with more repressive regimes. How could legal help be provided, while also hopefully keeping those who are trying to help relatively secure?

Hi Vincent, that was exactly my thought - and could technology provide a way of helping those individuals collaborate on casework, get advice and support on casework, and perhaps also be a platform for supporting detainees and their families through co-ordinating letter writing, or provide contact routes with the regime causing the detention. So many questions! I suppose I am thinking of a sort of casework dashboard for activists whether inside repressive regimes or not.

innocence_project_uk.title: Innocence Project UK

storybook_workshops.creator: 7905b5813c35371a21bcc668945f61d5

comments.text: A similar project was done with the White Mountain Apache native american tribe in AZ. Very effective.
Very cool! Do you know where I could learn more about that?
Interesting thoughts around inclusiveness and communication, Alix.

storybook_workshops.title: Storybook Workshops

experiencing_trauma.description: Thinking about a time I felt powerless, I thought I'd share a personal story of a vacation I took as a teenager.
experiencing_trauma.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Ashley, that is such a powerful story! Thank you for sharing this. I wonder if there can be some kind of stimulation "game" where people can also experience similar feelings of a person who is being unlawfully detained feel. To raise awareness sometimes we have to evoke empathy first.. and empathy comes from life experience.

Ashley - I think you've got a couple of really key concepts here:-"having no ownership of my body"-distinct lack of control over the future-Sensory overload at the presentThis conjures for me the D-Day scene in Saving Private Ryan - The audio becomes essentially a buzz - total overload that renders any manner of function impossible.I think this sense can be extrapolated and applied beyond this very temporally finite example to the entire duration of an imprisonment.  Oh this is good; this needs thought.

Ashley, thanks for sharing this very personal experience. Sickness, physical pain in itself is always to an experience of powerlessness. Adding this to being abroad and not with your family, at a young age, is clearly adding to the stress and the sense of powerlessness. I had a few experiences where I had to go to the hospitals (for nothing as serious as yours) in foreign countries - once while being on my own - and it is indeed very debilitating. I think that the materiality and embodiment of the experience is to be taken into account - esp. when talking about detention.

experiencing_trauma.title: Experiencing Trauma

low_tech.description: It's easy to jump to new technologies, but what if the best technology for this situation is not new? The advantages: simplicity and easy adoption.
low_tech.creator: 50b2022c20fc3181890b6ab257d77398

comments.text: We could even go one step further down and not using technology itself but making use of human nature. using our senses (hearing, smelling, listening,... ) ... have to think about it ...

Simple solutions often turn out to be the best.  A small RF transmitter, powered by a hearing aid battery and using a piece of guitar string as an antenna, is used to track monarch butterfly migrations over thousands of miles of travel.  Anyone can tap into the signal if you tune to the right frequency.

Gabe, that's another great example! Keeping it simple, can definitely be best.It reminds me of an asthma researcher that used basic mobile phone technologies and attached them to inhalers to collect dynamic, geo-tagged data on when and where people used their inhalers. Researchers had never been able to collect such detailed information, the study participants didn't even need to remember to send the data in (I'll try and find a link that explains it better).

Jamie, very good point. I think it is sometimes important to step away from "new" technologies to explore what is possible. Morse is one; what about horses and people: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/social-epidemics-paul-revere-and-its-famous-nocturnal-ride/or pigeons: sorry I can't find the inspiration... :-(or a question box: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-question-box-provides-answers-in-unreachable-places/   ?Note only it can help us think about something that is simple and effective, but also in many countries, the new technologies might not be an option.
Hi Jamie, here is the other inspiration (with the pigeons' image) that I was thinking of: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/how-to-communicate-digital-content-without-the-internet/
Good eye Anne-Laure, merci !
I am totally into this! Great thinking!
Thanks!
Great thoughts which would likely lead to accessibility, Jamie!
Thanks!

low_tech.title: Low-tech

throwable_camera_ball.description: Only something a came across on Youtube. Could be adapted to peak over a wall, i thought. Possibly something for someone to "build on".
throwable_camera_ball.creator: 77ff14b2439160cb2a7244eb215b5919

comments.text: This concept would work very well with many of the S.O.S. button concepts! Instead of just sending a signal or GPS location - and having that device on your body as a potential security risk (e.g. they might be punished or killed if the captors realize they are being monitored or that authorities were notified), a small device such as this could record the visual location, along with time / date stamp, and send out a signal. Clincher 1: Once activated the ball could be thrown away from the person - say into non-involved parties - so as to not be associated with the abductee. Clincher 2: there are directions on the device which say (in multiple / customizable languages) "If found return to A.I (or relevant local authority / support network)", along with specifics on how to do that. When the 'ball' makes it to such a support entity, it could initiated many of the other concepts presented here. While this idea may seem too offbeat, or even a moonshot, I think really does have potential. Goes to show the importance of submitting ideas during the brainstorming session no matter how crazy they seem at the time.I could see protesters here in the U.S. using this, albeit for lower health stake situations.Thanks Hubert!

Hi Hubert, nice prompt for some community builds :) I wonder how we might learn from this example and apply those insights to a scenario where someone who's being detained is in an unknown location? Perhaps a camera that surveys the landscape from above to look for certain patterns, movements, or markers? Just thinking out loud....

Yes, I think if there was a way to have the detainees leave behind something visible from above or from a natural system within the city or village this could be a good idea. I am not sure such a high tech device is feasible for our situation given resources.

throwable_camera_ball.title: Throwable Camera Ball

fear_button.description: A solar powered fear button that is provided to all victims of unlawful detention
fear_button.creator: 1ca36cc962c17dd262abfabaa734a77c

comments.text: Nice one Majul! There is something about the simplicity of this that is quite appealing.And, I could see this being viable in cases where the authorities that are detaining the individuals value human rights to some degree, and care about ensuring that day-to-day jailers do not harm detainees.I wonder how we could prevent such a device being taken away by jailers through force, stealth, or threats. Perhaps it could be attached to the wrist (like a house arrest ankle monitor, but worn more accessibly like a watch: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ankle_monitor ), and also issue an alert if tampered with/removed.

Hi Majul,great idea!How often are detainees absolutely surprised to be in trouble? What I want to say is - maybe most people that know or start to fear that they might get into trouble could already get such a device early on.As Vincent says it should be somehow attached to the person.As well it should give a signal automatically before its battery is completely empty (no light for solar-panel in prison / cellar).Each person could even agree to not leave a certain zone that can be individually mapped. So when the signal does leave that zone the alarm signal is sent automatically. Like in the ankle monitor that Vincent mentions.Julian

Thanks Vincent / Julian. Sure, I think a simple wristband with just a button - where the button changes colour to show its battery level might work well. There's also the option of it getting charged by 'kinetic energy' rather than solar. In which case, any body movement would give it charge - even if someone is in solitary confinement etc situations where as Julian mentioned there may be no sun.

Hi Manjul,Very nice idea and which addresses an important element of the detainees' condition. I like Vincent's idea of having it as a watch or a bracelet... but are you allowed to keep this in jail? I also like the idea of using kinetic energy.To go back to Vincent's point about authorities needing to be supportive, it could in fact be an artifact showing an effort from the authorities of a country that they are trying to respect human rights. To show their willingness, they will join a program and will agree to have detainees wear the wrist band...

fear_button.title: Fear button

unlawfully_detained_autistic_son_separat.description: It was Night mare for autistic son Steven Neary  and father Mark, when his  stay only meant to be  a few days in a ‘positive behaviour unit’ while his father recovered from flu ended up being a year long seperaton.
unlawfully_detained_autistic_son_separat.creator: 597265f32f6c8ec9ebdfd5f1f802345c

comments.text: Shocking! Makes me think of a concept I once came across: Formal vs. Informal Bureaucracy. One as being the established power of the state/county/council, the other as some sort of media-based hidden agenda influencing decision making by either supporting or confronting formal bureaucracy (with both, positive and negative effects).  What could Joe Public (or the boy's father) do to increase pressure on the often superslow bureaucratic proceedings in an informal way?

Insightful example, Sreshta. We're looking forward to the ideas it might inspire in the upcoming Concepting phase where we'll be turning to solutions-focused responses to the many examples we've collected.  In many countries Medical Alert bracelets indicate conditions such as this.

unlawfully_detained_autistic_son_separat.title: Unlawfully Detained Autistic Son Separated From Father

hope_for_tomorrow.description:
We know all about the loss of life through terrorism and the resultant state repression. But  people in India and some other countries are doing much of the killing themselves – in the womb.
-As stated in an article
hope_for_tomorrow.creator: 597265f32f6c8ec9ebdfd5f1f802345c

comments.text: Thanks Sreshta for bringing up this very important topic. I think that beyond the powerlessness of the new born, what the video shows is the powerless of the mothers, and even the families. It also shows the importance of local contexts and cultures with this woman who in the video explained that she killed 8 baby girls because she kept having girls instead of boys. This implies raising awareness but also evolving socio-cultural structures and cultural biases. It is also important to remember as noted that these biases are often shared by people who  have migrated: http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=there-are-more-boys-than-girlsThis is a topic that have been raised with several inspirations: how to raise public awareness?Maybe highlighting the consequences for society and themselves rather than morally condemning could be an option. I remember reading about 6 years ago an article on this topic and its implications in rural China where there were many, too many bachelors. Men started sharing women among brothers and cousins... They even went to psychiatric hospitals to find wives. (sorry I've been trying to find the article but could not).

Thanks Tayfun and Anne-Laure...Yes, it is true that the basic human rights according to law that every country has is different.What is legal in one may not be in another or what is considered an atrocious in one, may be just a practice in another.When the basic right to live can be taken away, all others seem like mere mishaps.It shows the helplessness of the mother/family on losing her child. This is a way to raise awareness among people influenced by cultural/social factors.This is also a message for families to be aware and prepared in any situation and stand up for themselves to protect their loved ones.One must not be biased or let go.It reminds us to fight for our rights.

Hi Sreshta, In addition to what this story shows as you and al mentioned, I think one another aspect is the need to have customized solutions for each country and/or specific group. Unlawful detention in developed and developing countries are different. In some of them, we are talking about basic human rights (rights to live) while in other we may talk about more advanced issues. So I believe the messages to raise awareness should be adjusted for that. Secondly, depending on the "culture" of the group (by culture, I mean everything related to such group including histroy, religion, language etc.), the message should be adjusted. In one country religious references might be the right way while on other countries, it could be sports, history or something else could be the emphasis. Thank you for sharing the story as it brings such autracious practices on a tangible format where people can understand (and act if they have the motivation and ability).

Hi Tayfun, I completely agree on the importance of being aware of the local contexts and the need for developing local solutions. There are indeed huge variations between developed and developing countries, and even among various countries. This is partly what  I was trying to point to when I was writing that morally condemning people in China or India who killed baby girls might not be the solution as for them such practices are grounded in a set of understandings and values. Thanks for highlighting this important point.

hope_for_tomorrow.title: Hope For Tomorrow

what_can_we_learn_from_jack_bauer.description: In his quests to fight terrorists, Jack Bauer knew he was doing the right thing. Even if that meant unlawfully detaining suspects and torturing them. But what can we learn from that?
what_can_we_learn_from_jack_bauer.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: Check out film 'Unthinkable' http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vLufgELgjhk

Hi Arjan,nice inspiration. I immediately thought of Christian's post about inverting the problem and then realized you built upon it! :-)This being said it is a tough call. How to use something that gets people in a cathartic relationship with the hero to at the same time distance themselves and realized that maybe he is going too far. I don't know this show (I know the name of it, I know many people who watched it but I have not) but from what I understand it is built on the assumptions that there is good and bad and  that Jack Bauer is a hero. This made it then difficult to make people think about it... although you could maybe think of a follow up program or debate, maybe even sponsored by Amnesty International to start a conversation around the questions your are raising in your post.thanks,al

The show ran for 9 seasons, and the questions have come up in several interviews, but I think most of the interviewers were of the entertainment sections, so the emphasis was not on this topic. However, there have been some posts in the blogosphere. Having said that, I think shows like this can play an important role as discussion starters.

what_can_we_learn_from_jack_bauer.title: What can we learn from Jack Bauer?

comments.text: Thank you Haiyan for sharing this inspiration. This is definitely something we should spend time and effort to find a solutino for. police_officers_or_criminals_behind_badg.creator: 597265f32f6c8ec9ebdfd5f1f802345c

comments.text: Hi Srestha,your inspiration raised a theme about "who should we trust?" and a theme that emerged from several inspirations that maybe those to be watched are the authorities as they are powerful (if not almighty in some cases). Trust is an important issue in this challenge as well as ways to monitor actions of the authorities (if / when necessary) and thus to increase our sense of trust.Here are a couple of inspirations that seem to address these issues are:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/from-guilty-officer-to-whistleblower-to-friend-to-anonymous-angel-with-a-great-new-job/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/who-are-the-individuals-frequently-responsible-for-human-rights-violations-/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/hey-everyone-s-going-to-find-out-about-thishttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/wearable-video-recording-for-law-enforcement-beyond/

Indeed, Srestha  the issue of trust is a key one for us as we move forward with our solution-focused journey: http://bit.ly/amnesty_guide  Rather than concentrate on who's to blame in past cases  might we explore ways to provide information and confidence to those detained so that we avoid these situations in future? Excited to see what folks come up with in the Concpeting phase, which launches tomorrow, to support human rights and limit future examples like this

comments.text: Everyone needs a pick-me-up. I really like this idea. The support of others is what keeps us going. Sending someone a little message can really brighten their spirits. Great thoughts! This comment comes from the Wells College Innovation Lab.

Hi Emily !Thanks for commenting. You are right when you say 'the support of others is what keeps us going' it's true for so many situations we encounter through life. In this particular case, it could be a prisoner who is unlawfully detained, that might feel alone and lost: this service could hopefully give them a little strength and support.

Great inspiration, Ana. I like how you've broadened this inspiration of exchange to consider quotes, images, poems, etc. Looking forward to the multiple ideas that this may spark for the upcoming Concepting phase.

Hi Meena and thank you for commenting! Yes, I think there is a lot of potential in mixing inspirations and opening up existing ideas and letting them grow further with the help of the whole community!This inspiration is a very small step, but it could possibly add some happiness and help someone in need if implemented.

Nice inspiration Ana! I actually just checked out Emotional Bag Check for the first time this weekend but hadn't made the connection to our challenge. A great inspiration to get us all thinking about tools that connect us.

Hi Ashley! Thanks for your comment :) I came across EBG recently too, but forgot to link it somehow to possibly help people in need, let's see if it can be turned into something bigger. There are so many ways that we connect, it's very interesting to see what everyone else is inspiring too!

comments.text: Thanks Vincent for sharing. Among other things - such as public awareness, power of new media with the use of usb - this story shows the importance of history in allowing people to think about their present and their possible future. Such a book is important as it will allow people in today's China to understand the situation. It also shows that you need one person to take the risk in this case to publish the book.There is also the willingness of Zhao Ziyang to share his perspective (back to one of your comments Vincent, that it's not only about access to information, but about the possibility of having multiple perspectives). In this case, his use of his personal network and of a simple technology, tapes, is also relevant to this challenge and its focus on technology.  I can imagine than working on this book has been a key support element for him.  Last, I like the idea of the book as emerging from a distributed vocal performance. al

this_tiny_microchip_cans_save_you_.description: In Libya still there are 50,000 lost people whom they know what happened to. I think huge proportion of unlawful detainees consists by these people so I built this concept base on targeting these folks.
this_tiny_microchip_cans_save_you_.creator: 1c68bd27143c48545c24e9b2209f18af

comments.text: Using lessons learned in military applications such as shown here: http://proceedings.ndia.org/7040/11%20IFPS%20by%20Marshall.pdf technology can be used to track individuals.  Use would be for individuals most likely to be detained during protests/civil unrest to both locate individuals and document logistical movement of detainees in offending infrastructures.
Thank you rabert  for your collaborating these information was really useful I think i should quote them as a practical sample of this notion,
I especially like your idea of leveraging trusted networks, Amin.
Thanks for your motivating comments

To build on Meena's points, it might be helpful to take a look at the Tips for Concepting that we've posted for this challenge http://bit.ly/n8Xc1O. You'll see a quick discussion there of how tracking devices might actually have both positive and negative effects on detainees. How might we balance 1) our desire to keep tabs on people with 2) the potential of putting them at even greater risk if their monitoring device is discovered?

Ashley thanks for your hints. I really get your concerns, I think that good possibility, lets talk about how we can control its ramification rather that throw it out. I think first of all bearer should have control on device that lead to not only self risk control but make it a Morse device as well. lastly i think if governor  get this point that they can't hide anybody any more despite all initial possible violence, in long term that lead to a huge turning in their attitude.

this_tiny_microchip_cans_save_you_.title: This Tiny Microchip Can Save You
