from_guilty_officer_to_whistleblower_to_.creator: 36388794be2cf5f298978498ff3c64a2

comments.text: Great Inspiration from Amnesty International, Angela. (That's AI for those of you who don't know :^)

Meena I am new to OpenIdeo so just want to clarify that the 'Angel of Humanity'service at AI doesn't exsist to my knowledge. My imagination went possibly a little far here. At it's core though it's an idea that sees the other people in the process as the factors that can make a great difference to detainees well-being. Truely sorry for the confusion.
Hi Angela, well it looks like a great idea to explore during the concepting phase! :-) Looking forward to see it developed,al
Thank you, Anne-Laure. Let 's do it! :-)

from_guilty_officer_to_whistleblower_to_.title: From guilty officer to whistleblower to friend to anonymous angel with a great new job!

visualising_social_media_influence.description: What about a visualisation of all the major influencers in a particular event or conflict?
visualising_social_media_influence.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: I really like the visual aspect of this idea, visuals are innately powerful in themselves. I also like the consideration of the elements of empowerment and inclusion.

I am a student at wells college and work in the innovation lab. This is an interesting concept because it also involves a type of model, similar to prototyping, and is a new way to present information and empower activists.

This is a very interesting concept.  Empowerment is one great idea to keep people motivated and get them to post.  This idea can also show area's geographically where the word might not be getting out and thus possible ways to improve getting the word out.

Hi Haiyan, great inspiration and topic, and a very imminent one too. It reminds me of a documentary I recently went to the premiere of here in Stockholm, about the Arab uprising. It revolved around 5 young individuals who were taking center stage in the uprising by fighting for free speech and using the internet to fight injustice, despite all the danger in blogging and documenting their opinion to the world.It's very worth reading / watching into. The link is here: http://zerosilence.org/

visualising_social_media_influence.title: Visualising Social Media Influence

facebooking_as_a_crime_.description: State security forces are getting more and more nervous about attempts by citizens to use Facebook to stir up unrest an express dissenting opinions.
facebooking_as_a_crime_.creator: 1c68bd27143c48545c24e9b2209f18af

comments.text: Amin  it's really insightful to have someone join us here who was in Iran during the uprisings of 2008. Thanks for sharing these instructions which were disseminated in that particular context. There are also ways that people can participate and amplify issues using social media more anonymously. Hopefully your post will trigger folks to explore more of these strategies  which have been used widely by people in areas of extreme conflict in the context of the Arab Spring. Here's an example from Amnesty's Director of Digital Communications: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/substitute-communications-channels-in-the-event-of-an-information-crackdown/Great to have you onboard and look forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO. You may want to check out the New User Forums too: http://bit.ly/new_users

Dear MeenaThanks for your motivating comment. I read about your link before but I reckon something is totally wrong with that. Firstly, the core competency of any social network in terms of penetrations potentials is based on transparency that lead to everybody can deal with data. Secondly, if you put some code anywhere that almost every opposition community could decode its really optimistic assumption to think government or opponent forces couldnt decode it.Im talking about such a government that hacked almost 700,000 google accounts of its citizens, government such as Iran, China and even USA which are mainly target of this challenge have gradually became absolutely accomplished so I think this wouldnt a reliable strategy to beat them.
Interesting & welcome thoughts, Amin. Perhaps you'd like to add them over on the actual Inspiration post so that conversations might continue over there.

facebooking_as_a_crime_.title: Facebooking as a crime

being_positive_sky_s_the_limit.description:
So, after looking at some videos and doing some brainstorming in class we realized that you can't always free someone but you can keep their moral high by giving them positive reassurance. 
So, one of our ideas was to send positive messages through the sky using a helicopter.  Kinda like what you see sometimes on the beach with advertisements.  I know that in Columbia most people get kidnapped and aren't able to be freed right away and are hidden in the jungle so we could also just send messages over the jungle hoping they will see them.  Kind of the same idea with the radio station, just sending out messages hope their loved ones will hear them.

Wells College Innovation Lab
being_positive_sky_s_the_limit.creator: 0919fa46609df68fe18eca1085a74be2

comments.text: So after some more brainstorming we can up with some more details about our idea. First, the type of messages that would appear on the banner would be positive things, messages from families who have people missing, quotes, things happening in the news, maybe funny things.Another thing we talked about was who would sponsor the messages, and we were thinking that maybe radio stations or other companies who would be willing to help the cause.  We would fly these messages over areas that are suspected to contain prisoners.

Interesting thoughts. Perhaps you might like to extend your thinking to consider how to positively "support the supporters" as well? Check out the theme we've got on that topic near the top of the Concepting page. Looking forward to ongoing ideas around positive reassurance.

being_positive_sky_s_the_limit.title: Being positive, sky's the limit

remember_the_eric_volz_story.description: Eric Volz was the American who was operating a magazine in Nicaragua when he was arrested after being falsely accused of murder. His story shows how social media helped to get the word out and raise money to help get him freed.
remember_the_eric_volz_story.creator: b4d48bc73278bbcb7fb016e255ff2d43

comments.text: The point about social media getting the word out is a very valid one.  It can generate buzz and attract television and news stations' attention thus furthering its effectiveness.  It also helps to remind people that someone is unjustly incarcerated and provides a platform and voice for someone who other wise would have none.

Hi Sean, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know if you face any problems. You should be able to use the 'Update this' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO!

remember_the_eric_volz_story.title: Remember the Eric Volz Story?

the_sixth_sense.description: This is an amazing tool that allows you to store and share media digitally using your own gestures. This would be such a discreet way for individuals to be able to report locations and situations as to receive  help from an external source.
the_sixth_sense.creator: 03eeb3724131478a1376885494e2e4a3

comments.text: I had to post this quickly, so just to give a little bit more information on the idea behind this.....This system would allow you to turn any surface into a desktop and it would allow your hands to document the world around you. You can take pictures, map your surroundings, and document occurrences and people you interact with. This is an extremely discreet way of helping outsiders know where you are being held.

the_sixth_sense.title: The Sixth Sense

little_camera.description: A little camera that detainees who are most at risk would take and put it in their mouths if they were captured. The camera would remain inside the body until the person can retrieve the camera after it's out of the body digestive system. Once that happens the detainee can use the camera which will be connected to a website where they can broadcast live where they are.
little_camera.creator: 883df91a26e62a7a0a5108e96b83b9e6

comments.text: Interesting Evando. Keep in mind that we don't want to put detainees at more risk from getting caught with items like this. Also that we cannot presume the innocence of detainees  more that we support their rights to be legally detained, so providing them a public communication tool may not be appropriate. You might also want to to check out our Tips on Concepting: http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips  looking forward to onwards discussion & ideas from you across the challenge!

little_camera.title: Little Camera

planet_text_texting_for_good_.description: How SMS is changing the world and can help spreading the word, accessing information and connecting people
planet_text_texting_for_good_.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: Great early synthesis here Anne-Laure. Thanks for pulling this together. We came across this link today which might also be relevant for looking at the advantages and the obstacles of using SMS in global health: http://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/world/july-dec11/text_10-05.html

Glad you found this useful Ashley. Thanks also for sharing the link.It's interesting that a major point made in this article is about understanding and designing for local contexts:"The challenge is people have cell phones, but so many components come into play" from people heeding the text messages to making sure the messages have value for them, said Patty Mechael, executive director of the U.N. Foundation's mHealth Alliance. "What's relevant for Bangladesh might not be for Africa or Brazil."this point is related to another conversation we've been having about understanding the local context. see for example my attempt to synthesize some of these conversations: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/beyond-translation-how-to-design-tools-and-campaigns-that-are-culturally-relevant/Clearly issues to keep in mind when we move to the concepting phase.

planet_text_texting_for_good_.title: Planet text: texting for "good"

electronic_petition_create_your_own.description: Change.org has created a quick and simple interface to help you create your own petitions. The Start a Petition page is very user friendly and leaves room for every cause, including an illegal arrest.
electronic_petition_create_your_own.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: I like these types of electronically collecting signatures , conveniently, for any type of cause.However I feel that this service are lacking the important next steps:  to carry these lists into the chambers of congress, bureacrats meeting places, companies boardrooms. I would like to see that change.org provided more service and education on how best deliver a petition in proper order. To gain attention and recognition and awareness.I have heard that even in Sweden it is very difficult to get your petition delivered to the correct place/person/department. To get it recognized and acknowledged in the correct manner, so it becomes an official document that the government be made to take into account.Since there are some legislation on how a petition should be designed and formed to be legally recognised, there are some hurdles that is not known to most people that want to start a petition. And probably that legislation is different in different nations.

electronic_petition_create_your_own.title: Electronic Petition: Create Your Own

an_international_day_where_human_rights_.description: Similar to the concept of Peace One Day (http://goo.gl/GoJt). Create an International day for human rights that all countries recognise, where detainees can obtain support from the outside world.
an_international_day_where_human_rights_.creator: c5caf3e72f1fb436eb457053110b5745

comments.text: Great idea, Mark. Seems that there already is one: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Day so perhaps it's more about how we might promote and encourage action + impact from this existing day? Hopefully you'll be back to repost this in the upcoming Concepting phase too. Meanwhile you might like to start a discussion on what makes Peace Day successful and what they key insights are which will help others drawing inspiration form this example.

an_international_day_where_human_rights_.title: An International day where human rights are recognised globally

background_checks.description: Why does detention extend to hours?
background_checks.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: But then again, if you are very unlucky and being in the hands of sadistic officers, a detention could be made to be stretched out for very long time period, just because the officers feel like they want to put extra mental pressure on the detainee.Or it can be their idea of fun entertainment, to process other smaller tasks, before they handle yours, and therefor delay a release, even though there is no suspicion at all against you. Could even be their attempt to get bribes from the detainees.So your thoughts on efficient routes to avoid lengthy detention, are basically good, but if in wrong country will still not help you at all out of a pickle.
Exactly, my other post recants the actual reason why durations take long. But in countries with "democracy" and established IT networks, the duration of detainment should be lesser.

background_checks.title: Background checks

bread_crumbs.description: This is a concept that is still developing, but I'm posting it now in hopes that I may see what collaboration may expand upon this idea. Oddly enough, this concept is based somewhat off of the tale of Hansel and Gretel. If you think about, they were definitely suffering from some illegal detention.
bread_crumbs.creator: 03eeb3724131478a1376885494e2e4a3

comments.text: AbbeyThis is a very important concept and should be incorporated in all concepts that involve meovements of detainees and potential detainees. If we look at the fairytale there are important lessons to learn about applying the principles implied in this concept.

bread_crumbs.title: Bread Crumbs

augmented_reality_alert_system.description: There are many augmented reality apps or GPS systems that alert you when you are around a special "marker". It shows info about the landscape. What if you could have an app/geolocation SMS alert for locations of illegal detainment incidences.

comments.text: Thanks Akshataa for sharing this experiment which is indeed very relevant to the challenge. In particular, it highlights the importance of context and roles in influencing behaviors. In fact, it suggests that all is not about "human nature"... but that context, roles, uniforms matter in the way people behave (in that case, both the guards and prisoners). You might also want to check: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/hey-everyone-s-going-to-find-out-about-this/
Wow, Anne-Laure, you're really a true connector in this challenge. Amazing. Thank you.
Thanks Arjan. I just happen to remember some of the posts and notice some connections... maybe this time more than before. :-)
I love it!And @Ashkataa: you can still connect the inspirations by using the update button and then add the other inspiration to yours.

@Ashkataa: you can do what Arjan is suggesting by using the Build Upon feature once you've hit the Update Entry button on the right of your post. You can see a video about it and check out tips & tricks on the New Users forum: http://bit.ly/new_users Great to have you join us!
Thank you Al, abbey, vicent and arjan. @Arjan, yeah i shall do that...
This is one of my favorite studies researched in Sociology. Its extremely telling of human character in situations of power and submission.
Yup, a classic!
This is indeed an important inspiration. It really shows how sometimes humans can be manipulated into doing awful things and crossing their own boundaries.

_zimbardo_experiment.title: Zimbardo experiment

using_peer_to_peer_mobile_networks_to_im.description: Using peer to peer mobile networks would aid communication between those who are detained unlawfully or their families to communicate with support groups. Allowing users to communicate by using cell phones without the need for cell towers
using_peer_to_peer_mobile_networks_to_im.creator: 5985a2173f02d421f866c74433afbb2c

comments.text: Hello Jace, This is a great idea.  Have you seen this project http://www.servalproject.org/ .  This is being developed in Australia.  It uses mesh networks.  The intent is for emergencies, but could be adapted.(My first post)
Welcome Alan! the serval project sounds really interesting, very much aligned with Jace's inspiration and relevant to this challenge... It could even be an inspiration "on its own"...

Hi Alan and Jace, i have added a concept (Startegic networking using Mesh potato Networks) which is based on the technology involved in the serval project. Will acknowledge inspirations and contributions as i get the time to refine my concepts.
That is awesome!!
Thanks Paul, And thank you everyone for commenting!
Great inspiration Jace! Welcome to OpenIDEO :)
Very insightful, great inspiration!- Molly Heslin, Wells College Innovation
Thanks Alan, The serval project was actually an example I wanted to mention, although I had completely forgotten its title and URL. Thanks for the contribution!

Hi Jace, thanks for sharing and for explaining clearly.  While reading  inspirations involving social media, I thought a few times of the limitations in terms of access. Your inspiration would provide greater access.

Way to go, Jace! Really like your clear explanation of what makes inspirational to our challenge plus the tech efficiency you've outlined. And great to see a new user embracing our Build Upon feature so well.

Wow, this is  great idea. So if you are detained in an area without network coverage, a pre-recorded message can "bounce" from one phone to another until it reaches the receiver with or without a tower? I think that has huge implications.

using_peer_to_peer_mobile_networks_to_im.title: Using peer-to-peer mobile networks to improve communication with support networks

amnesty_global_shortwave_radio_channel_f.description: Amnesty can transit messages from families of detainees globally on a shortwave frequency.
amnesty_global_shortwave_radio_channel_f.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: http://www.itcertengine.com/

Hi Avi. Great idea, but radio sets nowadays don't come with short wave frequencies.How about detainees' families record their messages on mobile phones, then these messages can be played to the detainees when their spouses visit them.

Thanks festus. True but the concept that the detainees do NOT have physical or legal access to their families. The SW transmission problem cam be overcome by having local Amnesty affiliates rebroadcast the messages on AM frequencies. The original SW broadcast can also be streamed or podcast on the web for targeted (country-specific) rebroadcasting.

If you're keen to translate this into a specific solution for this challenge  we hope you'll be back when the Concpeting phase launches tomorrow to re-post it there. memories_museum_for_the_unlawful_detenti.description:
The concept of a Museum is, nowadays, something different from the one that the Louvre or the Museum of Natural History manages. Today, a museum can be a place were people interact with History and were stories can be part of that History with capital H. 
So, Why not having a place were these stories can a more diverse perspective of the unlawful detention? What if these testimonies can be told not only by words but by objects or places?
memories_museum_for_the_unlawful_detenti.creator: 26a6c41292e114f2dcef5a1563de70a5

comments.text: Great to have you back on board, Luz! And great to see you triggering conversations, as always.
Thanks Meena. I think that I have some new ideas to update this concept based on the conversation with Ann-Laure ;) I'll updating it really soon!

I love your idea Luz. Memories are crucial and this is very important to make people aware and understand... It is also important for those who share their memories as it gives them a space, a voice, and some recognition.It reminded me of the History of the world in 100 objects that was curated by the British Museum but also existed virtually and had also a series of talks on the BBC: http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/Maybe you could imagine to have exhibitions and a virtual space and a series of radio talks (by historians, sociologists, political scientists, etc.)  sponsored by the BBC or another media company. These talks are also accessible online and become part of the museum.I like the mobile nature of the museum and the fact that it can happen anywhere... I'm wondering if there could not also be the idea of a distributed museum... with "rooms", exhibitions taking place around the world.Just a thought.again, great idea! thanks for sharing.

Well, you make a good point thinking about a distributed museum. I think that it could happen because rooms can be design in order to be mobile. Anyhow, the basic idea is exhibit the memories of all these people. :D

Luz, agreed on the main point - exhibit memories. My point about the distributed museum was in line with your comment about the changes in the nature of the museum. Instead of thinking of museumS, I was thinking that this was ONE museum with rooms located and distributed in different geographies... A distributed museum for a distributed memory...
Interesting point! Yes  iscould be single space with rooms in different places.  I like that idea! :)

Hi Luz, I really like the idea of a 'Memory Museum', it's close to the heart and I'm sure will touch many people.I want to share with you a great website I came across at the 10 year celebration of 9/11 this year, by Time magazine: http://www.time.com/time/beyond911/# Don't know if you've seen it before, but they made a beautiful mosaic of video stories + text, and really simple and well designed. I know you prefer a mobile museum, but this website came to mind when I read your concept. I think a mobile one is a great idea too, maybe something like the Think Tank ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/thinktanks ) that can travel and be mobile, but in the form of a museum!Great work!
Great links! Thanks for the comment. And yes, it could be like the thinktanks. The great thing about this is that, the concept of museum could be develop in almost every form. :)

memories_museum_for_the_unlawful_detenti.title: Memories Museum for the Unlawful Detention

my_voice.description: As evidenced by many of the concepts submitted so far, video is a medium that is at the intersection of words, image, and life.  What if we could use video to spread the stories and voice of detainees in a safe and anonymous way?  Through MY VOICE we could connect protestors and detainees to a global community in an impactful, engaging way.
my_voice.creator: 3b6f421e7550395e28e091c5565ac80a

comments.text: I definitely think it is important to hear from the detainees themselves. They are the people we are trying to protect and help. I really like this concept! It's great to give a voice to those who need it!
Thanks Emily :-)

I'm drawn to the idea of masking the original tellers of the stories, which takes attention away thus lessen their danger, but at the same time, have a protestor for the same cause to deliver the message in all its humanness. It solves two problems at once, getting the story across, and elicit empathy, allowing readers to vicariously experience what the detainee must feel and has gone through. very intriguing, great idea!
Thanks Frances!

Hi Amanda,I just wanted to say I love this concept. It perfectly takes advantage of the uneven resource distribution: lots of people with stories of unlawful detention, without ways to share them, in areas with low access to technology, and lots of people who want to help and raise awareness, in areas with high access to technology. Another possible extension, particularly if a van or hub is used to collect these narratives, would be to record conversations between potential or former detainees and their families about their experiences and feelings. I think seeing these narratives re-enacted by Ambassador families would be very powerful, for viewers and Ambassadors alike. Imagine a conversation between a father and daughter about his absence during most of her childhood. This could really illuminate the impact of unlawful detention on families and communities, in addition to the stories of individual detainees.

Hi Rachel,I'm glad you enjoyed my concept.  And, more importantly, thanks so much for your suggestion!  I agree with you that adding in a level of real interaction could make the re-enactments even more impactful.  I'll definitely be incorporating your suggestion into my concept.  Look for your collaboration shout-out soon :-)

I really like this idea because of the anonymity aspect. Many of the other ideas are based on profiling the detained person, but in so many cases this will not be seen as a useful step. This idea should appeal to those human rights activists who are the link between the detained people and the wider world, who might sometimes not be able to tell all that they know, for fear of repercussions for the detainee. This idea also works in a range of other situations, such as detention of asylum seekers arriving by boat in Australia. Although some human rights lawyers claim this is unlawful, the Australian government believe it is OK to do so -- but activists here would like to share the stories of people suffering in detention. These are cases where anonymity is paramount, or the authorities may adversely review their immigration applications.  Well done  on this concept.

Thanks Julie!!  It was really important to me to find a way to balance the need to tell stories that bring humanity to them, while also finding a way to maintain anonymity.  I think this concept could be applied in a variety of situations and I'm glad it's got you thinking :)

Hi Amanda, nice concept and honored to be part of your virtual team :-).I agree that storytelling is crucial. I think the storycorps project is a great inspirations. A few inspirations you might want to build upon: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/story-telling-in-any-way-possiblehttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/fifty-people-one-question/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-encyclopedia-of-speechI agree that Amnesty International Vending machine  and the Shift III Van are great places to collect these stories. Here are two thoughts:- In some cases people might be concerned with the video and sharing their image for privacy as well as security issues. I remember seeing some videos from the Storycorps project and they were animations. Animations might take too much time but maybe there might be the way of using only audios when people don't want to be seen. - On the translation, I think that it'll be a shame to give the voice to the people and then take it away by dubbing the videos. What about subtitles?

Hi Anne-Laure,Haha, no problem!  Thanks, as always, for your suggestions.  It seems I may not have been clear about certain aspects of my concept, so let me try to clarify.The video would not be of the storyteller.  The video would be of their matched, volunteer, English-speaking counterpart.  This volunteer would be using his/her own voice (so no dubbing) but speaking the words of the original storyteller.  As this counterpart would be an English-speaking volunteer of the same age and gender of the original storyteller, I hope that it would give an added dimension to the story in terms of adding a personal element to detainees' stories; without the risk of the detainees having to appear on video themselves. I also think that by using a global community of volunteers, this might help other cultures connect with the story of detainees through having the detainees' story presented by one of their own.  To me this symbolizes a global community who would be there to speak for the detainees so their stories might safely be heard.  (Presumably, if the volunteer is English-speaking and a volunteer, they likely would be videotaping from a safe-zone at least and quite probably from another country or continent entirely!)To emphasize, though reading in their own voice, the script the volunteer would be reading would be in the detainee's own (albeit translated) words.In addition to the volunteer telling the detainee's story, I would post something completely separate from the video.  That would either be the scanned version of the original written story, pre-translation, or the original audio recording, pre-translation.  That way the platform would bring the voices, languages, and people together.  Does that make more sense?Let me know, if you would.  I may need to clarify my concept above if it's not clear...  Thanks!

A-L,I went back into the concept and tried to clarify a few things, plus add a visual aid.  Does this help with clarify my concept?  Also, as always, spot on with your inspiration recommendations!  Thanks again for your help :-)

Thanks Amanda for the clarifications. I missed quite a bit of the richness of your concept. I really like the idea of having someone "lending" their own voice to someone's else story and thus becoming their voice. I guess I still like the idea of hearing the original voice (in the original language) but it is another concept maybe :-)

No problem Anne-Laure.  I've loved how these conversations have helped my concepts evolve, thanks for your part in that!!Incorporated on the page, completely separate from the video, will be (as Jason termed it) the original artifact in the native language.  If audio, it would be presented in a Quicktime file (or something along those lines).  If in hard copy, the original letter telling the story would be scanned in and visible as a pdf.  While I wanted the safety of lending a voice, I also really wanted the story to be heard in its original form.  Hopefully this format manages to incorporate both :-)

Nicely done. I really like the idea of giving a face (and voice) to the anonymous...and the addition of the original artifact is great. It would require a little more architecture, but maybe you could add a "support the family" link with each profile?
Thanks Jason!  I think the idea of adding a support the family link is an excellent one.  I'll likely be posting an update later today and this will be one of my additions :)
I like Jason's idea of adding the "support the family link" ...
Fab build, Jason! And Amanda  we're loving that you're evolving your concept based on collaborative conversations. Way to go!
Me too!  I actually just updated my concept and I added in a section incorporating that :)

Amanda,thanks for the update. I think that the sentence "What this format signifies to me, and I hope to others, is that others are willing to speak for detainees when it would be unsafe for them to speak for themselves." really clarifies it all and synthesizes very well what makes this concept so powerful.Ambassadors, support the family and the universal symbol (Jason, you really need to find a name for it :-) ) are great additions. al

Hi Amanda!Loving your energy and your concept here.I love it for two main reasons, first that you say: "What this format signifies is that others are willing to speak for detainees when it would be unsafe for them to speak for themselves. " This is so true, and still addresses the issue of security and maintaining anonymity.Second, I love that My Voice will serve two functions, one which I find very important is the recruiting volunteers. This can potentially be a 'dangerous' job for the volunteer to do, representing someone else who is unlawfully detained, and a cause they really support. One word that springs to mind when I think of these volunteers in this case is ' Ambassadors'. They get involved with this to give voice to silenced people, so maybe you could give them a special name, so the volunteers feel even more empowered and attracted to participating in this project? Just an idea that popped up!One problem that I imagined with telling the story of an unlawfully detained person, would be how we get physical access to them if they are unreachable. But then again you also mention that we can tell the story through the eyes fo the families and friends affected, who need identical anonymous protection, so I liked that that is also a possibility. I also really like the idea of incorporating the van + info hub as possible vehicles to collect the interviews :) If the Info Hub had a bluetooth or USB connection point like I hope, that would be a way to transmit safely back into the hub and into a 'cloud' system the footage, and then the camera that filmed the story could be deleted for security purposes.We could incorporate the Universal Unlawfully Detained symbol by Jason on this campaign website too! And with regards to getting cameras to film this, there are really cheap ones out there, I put one example of a cheap Camcorder on the dispensed Vending Machine/ Info Hub items list.I really see potential in this platform and each video going viral too, as people like to share meaningful stories, so this could bring great attention to this problem.

Hi Ana!I'm glad you're enjoying my concept!  The idea to have a name for the volunteers is an excellent one!!  I will definitely be incorporating that into the concept.Also, it's funny you mention Jason's Universal Unlawfully Detained symbol.  After his post below, I began thinking of ways that it could be incorporated.  I'll probably have an update later today :)Thanks for the comments, I'm loving your energy too.  It's been fun collaborating with you!
Hey Amanda, happy we're on the same track too, it's been great exchanging ideas with you, love them :) I look forward to ure update !

Really great thinking on this one, Amanda! And we're loving the way you've help everyone trace the path of your inspiration via various collaborators and sites. Nice work  looking forward to discussion and builds on this.
Thanks for your support Meena!  I think I'm starting to get the hang of this whole concepting thing ;)  I too am looking forward to seeing the discussion and builds that spring from this.
Indeed  collaboration thrives on conversation!

my_voice.title: MY VOICE

personalize_electricity.description: By using our personal electromagnetic field to "charge" digital flares, we would be able to send out a signal to help pinpoint a location.
personalize_electricity.creator: 43160183dee0c41d5dbbda3804b27d20

comments.text: Interesting provocation here Dia! I think something like this could make a lot of sense for people who know they're at risk for detention so let's definitely remember this Inspiration as we get to Concepting. In the meantime, here's another question for you: how might this light technology be used to aid people who don't know they're at risk for detention, for people who don't suspect they could be imprisoned, and thus wouldn't know to carry this small light-enabled device? There might not be an answer for this, but I thought I'd ask to see if it sparks anything :)

Hi Ashley! If we are connected by this grid...then we would ideally be able to detect disturbances. If each person were tapped in then we would be able to notice a change in the frequency. I guess that is going a little Pandora, but that is kind of what I was thinking about-- a giant electric web that we are all plugged into. The problem I see with it being used for people that do not know that they are in danger means that it can also be used for people that want to conceal their whereabouts. hmmm, I will sleep on it tonight and see if any inspiration comes to me.

personalize_electricity.title: Personalize electricity

crowdsourcing_the_work_required_to_take_.description: A social network, connecting detainees and their families with volunteers who are willing to take up small tasks to support the detainees and their families to cope with the situation.
crowdsourcing_the_work_required_to_take_.creator: 4b0ecd5a3a5c4881c323c18fe46b2ad1

comments.text: I absolutely love this idea! Progressive action in order to keep the detained safe is what this project is all about! Great concept!Molly Heslin, Friendly neighborhood Wells College Innovation lab

Angiliki, I think it's a very good idea and it increases the chance to get people to do something: instead of asking for a huge task that might take "too much" time, you're just asking for a small commitment. Micro-tasking is indeed a nice way of phrasing it.It reminded me studies on citizen science projects where people are asked to do just a small piece of the task - in some cases, because of expertise and skills, but also sometime because of time and commitment.Commenting on Ashwin's concept: www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/secure-network-to-provide-customized-real-time-solution./I thought of a way to connect it with your concept... See if it could make sense...

Micro-tasking! Very nice addition Angeliki...and as Meena mentioned, these can include only those tasks deemed appropriate, which there should be plenty of. The "social quotient" is a nice little touch as well. I'll work on integrating it into the Support Net sketches!

Great tip on the micro-tasking angle. Angeliki  you might like to check out platforms like Samasource http://samasource.org/ & Sparked http://www.sparked.com/ as you build this Concept out. Keep up the fab discussion, guys!
I just checked Sparked and I love it :)
Great. Feel free to update your concept based on discussions here & new thoughts. Looking forward to seeing ideas evolve!

Thank you for the feedback! Yes, indeed, I assumed from the beginning that since the detention is unlawful, the detainee is innocent! So, as Meena noted, my goal should change towrads supporting the family and providing legal support so that the case is lawfully handled.@Jason : Oh nice word: micro-tasking! I think tasks should be small and clearly defined so that a volunteer can dedicate 1 or 2hrs of his time and see some direct feedback on the progress of this case and on his quotient too.

Interesting thoughts about leveraging networks, Angeliki. Keep in mind that we cannot assume the innocence or guilt of detainees  it's more that we note that their detention is unlawful. Check out our guidelines here: http://bit.ly/amnesty_guide Networks may be very helpful for providing support in various ways that champion human rights  but keep in mind that we're not saying that all detainees have done no wrong. It may be more about using networks to help with financial and legal support while innocence/guilt is lawfully determined. Perhaps you'd like to discuss and reconsider your ideas with others here  that's the joy of a flexible, collaborative platform!

crowdsourcing_the_work_required_to_take_.title: Crowdsourcing the work required to support the detainee and their families

it_could_be_you.description: Solidarity and compassion (in the sense of feeling other's situation as yours) are attributes that can really make a difference in cases of unlawful detention.
it_could_be_you.creator: a6c9b4335dc88b94628ecd5500b3d504

comments.text: Hi Felipe, "it could be you", putting yourself in the other shoes, or putting someone you love in these shoes (per your example: your son could be the unknown detained), are very strong "mindsets" as they reduce the distance between the other and you and it forces you to consider the implications. It is particularly important to increase public awareness.Yet, I could not prevent myself (sorry for playing the devil's advocate here) to also think of the NY Time article on the limits of empathy posted by Ashley: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-limits-of-empathy/The article and the discussion that followed is very relevant to your inspiration and highlight interesting questions on how to move from the emotions associated to "it could be you" to some actions (if, when possible).thanks, al

I agree that these attributes are key in making a difference in cases of unlawful detention. To somehow allow the sad reality of unlawful detention to "hit home" with people may be the best way to reach people's hearts. Without this understanding I am not sure how vast improvements can be made. That's why I think sharing someone's personal story (say, a victim of unlawful detention via book, website, video, etc.) and somehow getting people to relate it to their loved ones would be a good focal point.
Yes, "It Could Be You" is a strong message to draw support to help those in need. Reminds me of: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_they_came%E2%80%A6

it_could_be_you.title: It Could Be You

Today we thrive on technology. The Social networking media has become part of our lives. This can be achieved by an under skin micro-chip implant.
(An initiative by OpenIDEO Student Chapter @ NYU-POLY)

comments.text: Hi Swapnil,interesting concept. I like the fact that you're building upon Alejandro's idea. You might want to use the build upon function to make it clearer.I can also see a couple of inspirations and concepts that you might want to build upon and which could help you refine your concepts. For example:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/this-tiny-microchip-cans-save-you-/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/rfid-implant-or-pill-to-signal-distress-and-location/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/tattoo-electronics/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/radio-frequency-identificationhttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/cell-phone-implementI find it interesting that you have found a company developing this technology. Maybe you could elaborate (there was some discussions on price and feasibility on Avi's concept RFID implant) and provide the link to the company.The huge investment on the individual part makes it difficult to imagine implemented but maybe you can think of a way to reduce the cost and make it more accessible.thanks!

Wow! Thanks for the wonderful reply Anne and also for the Green housing :) From the links you posted I can now gradually comprehend the science behind OpenIdeo. There are so many ideas which are collaborative and symbiotic. I went through all of them and they are excellent.About the company Applied Digital Solutions, I'll try to channelize this concept to them in some way. The technology seems expensive now. I think as it progress n evolves like any other innovation it will reach its a phase where it will be available to everyone reasonably. But yes now we need to think upon reducing its cost.Regards.

Hi Swapnil, glad you found the links useful. Per OpenIDEO team tweet:Keep up with the comments on Concepts on the Amnesty Challenge  remember that collaboration thrives on conversation! #oi_amnesty:-)If you can from these various ideas start elaborating your concept as well as thinking of various ways to implement it, that'll be great.I also suggest using the build upon features to link these inspirations and concepts (as well as Alejandro's ping concept) to your concept.
Nice tip, A-L. Swapnil, you can check out how to use the Build Upon Feature over on the New Users Forum http://bit.ly/new_users
I'll surely do it, Meena. I was surprised to see this new button on the page. It's kind of cool collaborating you ideas with that of others...
Most of our features are devised with collaboration in mind  enjoy!

Hi Swapnil, interesting idea! I thought I'd share a recent link we've just posted to help guide everyone through Concepting http://bit.ly/n8Xc1O. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking devices like microchips could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. Definitely something to take a look at, and of course you're always welcome to update your concept with any additional insights or thoughts!

comments.text: Hi Iam browsing as many inspirations as I can....slowly....yup, Ideas can come from any direction.My reaction to the trailer (i haven't seen the movie... yet! )... It is our ...or anybody's definition of Alien that could be looked at. My personal philosophy.... when we are inclusive...there's no 'us vs. them' then the solution is more easily Identified. So the day we as Humans think of all humans as our own... that we all belong together, & develop a mutually respectful connection...we will achieve an Open Society...

There is a poem of Rumi. This lover that goes to the door of the beloved and he knocks at the door, and when the beloved answers, "Who's there?", he said," It is  me" and then he says, "Go away". And then he goes away and stays a long time in the world and then comes back and knocks at the door again and says,  "Who's there" and he says, "It is you" and he said, "Come in"
I loved that film! It was impossible to love that creatures but at the end .... People are strange when you're a strangerFaces look ugly when you're alone

Thank you for the information about doors song and for HBO link!

Interesting post, Tayfun. I haven't seen the film but imagine lots of our community has  so let's discuss what the key takeaways are from the film which might inspire our current challenge. It's great to see folks drawing on films, books and popular culture  this widens our exploration and hopefully will enrich our upcoming Concepting phase!

Hi Meena, well many takeaways!!  We are all actually very similar even though we may look different (including aliens and humans)Things are looking different from the other side (this happens when the main character starts becoming alien) There is more to creatures than what it looks on the surface (aliens were supposedly stupid but they were actually quite intelligently designing their way back to home with their space craft).... On a separate note, I am a little reluctant to put the these takeaways right away as it might influence people to see from my perspective (although inspiration phase is more about exploring different perspective). On the other hand, people may not get any takeaways without further explanation. In this case, I thought the trailer was sufficient. I am curious to learn your take. Thanks!!

comments.text: Fascinating, A-L. As we propose solutions in the upcoming Concepting phase, it will be useful to consider ways in which information can be shared, clarified and amplified to support human rights in the face of unlawful detention  for both the general public and those closer to detainees (friends, family & supporters) I feel the latter may be a bigger challenge and we're looking forward to ways our community might propose innovative ways of engaging and supporting these audiences as well. Could also be interesting for your class to consider both avenues  we're so excited to have the on board!

Thanks Meena. I agree with you that there are two audiences to think about in the concepting phase.Related to story telling, I saw a sound installation in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, based on story telling: http://www.nobillsstories.org/This installation involved the community in an interesting manner:Nick Yulman and the North Brooklyn Public Art Coalition (nbART) reached out to community members to record their stories, including owners of the neighborhoods long-standing businesses; neighborhood characters; and residents who revel in neighborhood quirks and legends.

comments.text: I wonder how frequently Amnesty gets reports of detained people. If it's more than once a day, the constant texting could get a little tiresome, which might keep people from signing up for the service. I like the idea of an email, maybe something that is sent out weekly, that highlights the week's activity.However, it is nice to have the immediate response, which might make people feel more involved in the situation... maybe a person could add texting to the email service by selecting certain geographic areas, reasons for detainment, etc. for which they'd like to be immediately alerted.The weekly email could also include infographics and/or illustrations as mentioned in these concepts:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/infographics-a-call-to-actionhttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-google-earth-observer/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-human-rights-graphic-narrative-platform/

Great build Alix.The idea of massive amounts of text and e-mail were the primary things that concerned me about this concept.  I turned off storm warnings from the weather channel because they alerted me too often!  I can't imagine the amount of text/e-mail you would get if you were messaged each time a person was detained.  Weekly summaries in the form of an infographic would be a nice way to be involved.  I also like the idea of being able to narrow down what kinds of detainments (what region, etc.) you would get texted information about.Nice work!
Thanks, Amanda!

I agree with Alix too! The big goal here is to make it so we are reminded periodically - not just once a year, but finding a balance is important. I'm reminded of the number of survivors listed each week on Battle Star Galactica. It wasn't annoying as it only happened at the beginning of each episode. But it was good to remember that it was changing with time. I can celebrate when detainee number goes down and think hard when it goes up.
Welcome MIT brainstormers!

heat_maps_identify_the_problem_cities_an.description:
Two types of environment: (1) developed – high technology usage and (2) underdeveloped – low technology usage.
In both environments the community effect plays a significant effect (friends, family, colleagues).
By using technology as a platform (GPS, internet connectivity, social networking) we will identify the people responsible for unlawful detentions. Not every judge is corrupt; it is usually just a few.
Creating heat maps, we will target specific cities and areas within each city (specific courts) where the complaints against unlawful detention are high or increasing significantly.
Based on significantly more heated cities/courts we will provide a platform to identify the actual officials/judges giving the sentences. By having real faces tied to the wrongdoing, the social community surrounding the corrupt official will take care of ‘punishing’ him through e.g. banishment. No person wants to live in isolation.
heat_maps_identify_the_problem_cities_an.creator: 5269c230b473de2fe12a4ef7004493c7

comments.text: Hi again,as I saw your image and your comments about old type writers, I thought of the installation by the artist Jean Shin: http://www.jeanshin.com/textile.htmYou could think of having part of the campaign being an installation made of the messages and conversations written by people who have been arrested or members of their families... I agree with Nathalie, it will be fun to brainstorm more concepts.thanks for the inspiration!al
That's an awesome take on this idea - makes me think of the scene from V for Vendetta where Natalie Portman find old letters from a previous prisoner.

Hi Anne,I love the name and the picture... Shift freedom sounds like a call because of the imperative mode... It is a call for action and change: shift.And of course "freedom' is the object... The image of the keyboard is also an interesting one: it is the keyboard, the "repertoire" with which we can write and share stories, but also with whom people who have lost their freedom can (re)-write their story...Sorry for this free association exercise! :-)I'm looking forward to seeing you exploring this idea... al
Super creative, and I think it would be a great campaign theme/title.

Thank you Arjan! What comes to mind when you hear the "SHIFT FREEDOM" name? And what kind of campaign do you think this could become? I am trying to wrap me head around just that, to get ready for the Concept Phase.

Hi Anne, this is a wonderfully creative idea! It has a nice ring to it (very memorable) and your visuals create inspiration about the type of campaign this could be. When I hear the word "shift", I think about moving over or in this case, more specifically "lending" what I have to someone else. What if those of us who experience the greatest personal and societal freedoms are able to lend them to someone who doesn't? The could be an entire campaign around providing ways (just like this challenge suggests) to impart freedom on those who are not currently in a situation which allows for it. It would be fun to brainstorm more concepts around this!

Thank you for your inputs Nathalie! I had not thought about the "lending" part of the word "Shift". My mind was more centred around "shift" as a synonym of change or transition form one state to another. But I really like your idea about how a campaign could be about lending or exchanging freedom.

shift_freedom.title: Shift - Freedom

comments.text: Hi Tomoe,interesting idea for raising awareness about issues related to unlawful awareness.There's been a lot of research on experiential learning (see for example the work of John Dewey or Piaget, but also in a more applied way the work of Simon Papert, an MIT professor http://www.papert.org/ who developed logo, a programming language, which also led to Lego Mindstorms) and how "simulations" can help people understand better some issues that might be difficult to take into account. I personally use several simulations or similar types of activities in my courses to make people think about team work, collaboration and change. There are two important things I believe: the learning taking place while doing the simulation, but also the reflection after. an interesting approach to consider in the concepting phase

why_detention.description: I think we need to know why detentions happen. Here is my theory.
why_detention.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: If we could spread the word about such techniques, perhaps we could find a way to bypass it. Perhaps design humane interrogation techniques as David Bamford said or from an innocent civilian's perspective, learn how not to break under duress by realizing that it is only due to psychological manipulation and if there is a system, it can be beat.

Ok, this is a solid essential 'Why'. Now 'How' do governments come to this tippingpoint to go for this fearfactor in society. What are the 9 steps bringing decision makers to cross the human rights bridge?If if know these other 9 psychological steps, we might be able to 'design' technology to see the the downward spiral coming and create tools for community/government to climb back up again when they realize they are halfway down already.

Step 1 - Direct Confrontation. Lead the suspect to understand that the evidence has led the police to the individual as a suspect. Offer the person an early opportunity to explain why the offense took place.Step 2 - Try to shift the blame away from the suspect to some other person or set of circumstances that prompted the suspect to commit the crime. That is, develop themes containing reasons that will justify or excuse the crime. Themes may be developed or changed to find one to which the accused is most responsive.Step 3 - Try to discourage the suspect from denying his guilt. Reid training video: "If youve let him talk and say the words I didnt do it, and the more often a person says I didnt do it, the more difficult it is to get a confession."Step 4 - At this point, the accused will often give a reason why he or she did not or could not commit the crime. Try to use this to move towards the confession.Step 5 - Reinforce sincerity to ensure that the suspect is receptive.Step 6 - The suspect will become quieter and listen. Move the theme discussion towards offering alternatives. If the suspect cries at this point, infer guilt.Step 7 - Pose the alternative question, giving two choices for what happened; one more socially acceptable than the other. The suspect is expected to choose the easier option but whichever alternative the suspect chooses, guilt is admitted. There is always a third option which is to maintain that they did not commit the crime.Step 8 - Lead the suspect to repeat the admission of guilt in front of witnesses and develop corroborating information to establish the validity of the confession.Step 9 - Document the suspect's admission and have him or her prepare a recorded statement (audio, video or written).

Hi Ashwin, thanks for posting the 9!To all readers, There are many countries in the world which do not violate human rights yet, but Amnesty recognizes patterns and can predict sooner or later human rights will be violated in 5-10 years from now. So how to help these countries get out of this pattern they are not even aware of they are in? What do we get when we flip these 9 around to get to the step 0; Step 0 : A government official decides to arrest innocent people. What needs to be done to prevent governments to violate on one point human rights. These violations sneek in when the fear among officials and citizens in a society grows. MIRRORING the above quotations, on the timeline from step -9 to -1. Could be an interesting exercise, here a first attempt;step -9 : Document local government with audio, video, written; "We respect all Human Rights"step -8 : Lead the government to show human rights are respected and let them show they can repeat the admission time and time again because they have law and NGo and technology enforcement to keep the standard high.step -7 : Pose the alternative question to government, giving two choices : one more socially acceptable than the other. there is a terror attack in the city, what happens. There is lack of work/water/food, what happens. (can be better)step -6 : The government will become quieter and listen. The gaps in their safety net to protect human rights become visible. If the government cries at this point, infer guilt. Guilt of not seeing the gaps, guilts in structural human right ensurance neglectance.step -5 : Reinforce sincerity to ensure that the suspect is receptive. step -4 : At this point, the government will often give a reason why it did not or could not commit the crime. Try to use this to move towards the confession. The confession it needs SOCIAL TECHNOLOGY to strenghten the safety net in times of a society in fear. step -3 : The government maintains in not confessing, our safety net is fine, we do not need social technology to strengthen society and prevent this way human rights violations.step -2 : The government ignores the importance of social technology, they argue there are more important topics to invest time and resources in. Other topics are blamed for possible violation of human rights. step -1 : direct confrontation. If they do not implement better social technology in their society, Amnesty International will very soon be on their doorstep to show human rights are being violated. I guess I will post it as an inspiration? Or wait for concepting phase?

Thanks Ashwin, it is a sad fact that putting enough pressure on anyone can make them say anything to make it stop. To extend the speakers point out to torture or extreme duress is not a jump. So why do governments put so much stock in information gained through techniques meant to "break" the suspect. How could we design techniques to gain information through technology and not water boarding. To change the way the investigative system works from the inside.

Thanks Ashwin for sharing this is very interesting.It reminded a story of a friend of my friends' in unlawful detention, who kept asking "what did I do?" and was told "you know you are guilty, so you'll tell us". She told my friends that she was ready to confess anything she was told... This is an extreme case but it can be more subtle as described in the interview.I found the point about the power of the "confession" to "corrupt other evidences" - to reframe our interpretation of "evidences" - particularly scary. al
Really interesting and eye-opening perspective Ashwin, thanks for sharing this!
Great point Ashwin. Know what we're up against.

do_you_trust_your_brain.description: Recent studies have found human memories to be unreliable as they are easily prone to change. Could this mean the end of eyewitness testimonies in criminal proceedings?
do_you_trust_your_brain.creator: 6d40cea9faeeb7133a34e071eaca06b2

comments.text: Here is a supportive document with some interesting information with regard to cognitive biases.http://www.scribd.com/doc/30548590/Cognitive-Biases-A-Visual-Study-Guide
Could this also mean that you can train your brain to accept a different memory?

YES! Actually, our memories are re-created every time we "think" about them. Thus, the more you think about a particular event (such as your first kiss), the more inaccurate it becomes. Additionally, scientists have successfully been able to implant "false" memories inside of people's minds during research. For example, they'd make someone believe that they didn't like pickles, when they in fact do. There is a very interested Radiolab podcast on this subject, it is called "Memory" and can be downloaded for free on Itunes

do_you_trust_your_brain.title: Do you trust your brain?

doces_detainees_one_click_emergency_supp.description:
DOCES is a one click button that would be available as a free application for PCs, facebook, mobile phones and other platforms.
The one click button is designed for activists and friends of detainees.
doces_detainees_one_click_emergency_supp.creator: 231882454063de4d24043525f02e5700

comments.text: Very interesting concept. I like the way the activist program has so much functionality. This could be really helpful. Alternatively, maybe activists should start using trusted cloud computing services, so that they do not have to erase their files on a pc, just the connection to the cloud service. Might save a lot of work, in case an activist is in danger, pushes the button, but gets out of the danger.

I agree with using the cloud services. Especially because remotely turning on a computer can be very difficult with the improper hardware. It could potentially cause a lot of set-up on the user end.I think it would be a good idea to have a server that accepts these DOCES requests, translates them, and then submits them to Facebook and Twitter. It would require some previous application preauthorization, but so would a native application. If sensitive files were stored on a cloud service, perhaps the user could request that on button press, certain files would be released to a certain recipient, or just deleted.

We like the concept of a one-stop emergency activation switch.  Our concept is similar in so far as the processes that are activated after the push of the button. Maybe we can work together toward developing in the implementation of these concepts.

Hi, this is great. It would also be useful if the 'message' being shared automatically gets translated into the what is the most widespread language in the world - english. So that users can input their message in their native language and when it does get spread out on different platforms - it is understandable by all viewers.

a_desperate_mother.description: A woman was reporting to me that her son had disappeared in her home country. She felt powerless. I was one of her final hopes and I was just as powerless to change the situation.
a_desperate_mother.creator: 01d361e7592b403163b2f14ddfd43a32

comments.text: Such type of cases are happened in plenty every where through out the world. Amnesty International is a premier organization in the field of human rights. Amnesty International should broaden its network to the gross root level through out the world. An effective organizational setup of A.I. in all countries, states and districts through out the world is only solution of worst position of human rights violations. In this regard, the use of modern technology can play a vital role.

About 5 years ago, a muslim old lady came to me and told me about disappearance of his 25 years old son. She was weeping and almost helpless because she was belonging to a very poor family. I tried to search him using my own resources. Just within 2 hours, I came to know that He was caught by the police in daylight at 4pm from the roadways station while he was going to see his married sister. I searched him in local police station but he was not there. Then I came to know through my local network that he was arrested by the police of another police station which was about 25 km far from my place. I reached there by my car and asked the Inspector of police station, he told me that the detainee was involved in robbery so police arrested him but the statement of police was wrong and detainee was innocent. He was arrested and detained unlawfully. The police were not ready to respect the basic human rights of detainee. He was brutally beaten for forced confession. At that time, I felt helpless, I returned back to district headquarter and conveyed the real things to the District magistrate and Superintendent of Police but couldn't get immediate response then I came to the office of Telecom Department to make telegrams to the higher authorities. After 48 days of unlawful detention police admitted him to the court concerned. He was in a very bad position and injured but he was verified physically fit by the government doctor. The Advocate was began to produce Bail Application ignoring his injuries and unlawful detention. I produced a separate application on behalf of his mother highlighting the facts of unlawful detention, brutal torture enclosing the proof (the copies of telegrams and faxes) and Challenged the medical report produced by the police in the court. The court was convinced and passed order of medical checkup by a panel of doctors. Finally the Police could not prove the case and he bailed out. But I am not satisfied because I could not return the tears of a poor old lady because of unlawful detention of his beloved innocent son, I could not return him the days of detention and further I could not change the cruel and inhuman face of the Police.
Thanks for sharing the story with us!

a_desperate_mother.title: A desperate mother

we_miss_you.....over.description: This concept is based on a radio broadcast I heard, which detailed the utilization of radio in Colombia to allow family members to send messages over the air to reach their loved ones who have been kidnapped.
we_miss_you.....over.creator: 03eeb3724131478a1376885494e2e4a3

comments.text: Abbey, thank you for your contribution! We liked how your concept really lends itself towards emotional support for those affected by unlawful detention. One inspiration we had looking at your idea during our final meeting was how we might use radio to broadcast Twitter streams using voice to tweet. We're hoping to prototype the concept. Thank you for this great inspiration and for your participation on OpenIDEO.

During the Arab Spring Google launched a service that enabled people to telephone in a message that would automatically be tweeted out.  This was effective at letting those offline share their stories with the online world.  More on that here:  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-12332850Your concept made me wonder if the reverse would hold value too, i.e. somehow broadcasting an audio of all tweets?  Could we create a radio station around a hashtag in which people share their stories regarding unlawful detention?  As you point out the reach of radio is greater than any other medium...
Abbey, as you set out in your explanation, this concept fits well into an integrated system and provides novel options for communication between families and detainees. Great suggestions.

A number of other tools mentioned in the concepting phase inspired this idea and can be built in. Think of the number of ways we could make all of this information accessible while still having the capability to keep an organized format.

I think you're right--multilingual tools and user-friendly maps will be really important in bringing this to life (and will be especially important for families in crisis who may not have a lot of technical literacy).

Hi Abbey, as I was looking for some information for Rashmi's concept, I found this article which uses radio to link communities and create an emergency network: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15173291

Hi Abbey, thank you for your great contribution to the Amnesty challenge. The expert panel was very excited about the simplicity of your concept and how it helps to connect those affected by unlawful detention. Would you be willing to push your idea further? A few questions to get you started: What would an accompanying website look like? How could the information thats reported on the radio turn into forms of activism? What existing radio programmes could you build off of? Thank you again for your hard work, dont forget to reach out to the OpenIDEO community for help.

Thank you very much to push this idea forward and continure to make contributions. I would like the opportunity to develop this idea and will take the time to research and develop the concept based on examples and inspirations from my fellow contributors

Abbey Congrats!! I live in Colombia, so if you need any help let me know, here is the link to Las Voces del Secuestro (the voices of kidnapping) the radio programme you mention..good luckhttp://www.lasvocesdelsecuestro.com/index.php
Thanks so much! I will definitely try and get in contact. Itd be great to do an interview and get more personal and real information from those involved

Hey Abbey,You had the same thought I did! I linked to that This American Life episode in my inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/held-hostage-by-the-jungle-by-the-law-and-by-love/I agree this is a great communication tool for detainees, great job fleshing it out here. It's a practical, low-tech solution, which can be the hardest kind to think of.

Interesting thoughts, Abbey! Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add some related Concepts & Inspirations to your Build Upon feature (such as the one's you mention above). That way the collaborators who wrote them will get an email notification and are likely to come and join the great conversation you've started here. Creativity loves company, right? :^)

we_miss_you.....over.title: We Miss You.....over (UPDATED 11.16.11)

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people
