dental_fear_powerlessness.description: As many people have experienced some level of fear & powerlessness associated with a dentist visit, thought this might be an interesting way to empathize with detainees, and consider what would help improve these situations.
dental_fear_powerlessness.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: I have to say, I think you're right to worry that such an approach would be seen to trivialise unlawful detention. (As well as annoy dentists.)  I'm really struggling to think of any useful way in which a non-horrible event has usefully been compared to a horrible one.  Dentist-related metaphors are actually pretty common ("like getting teeth pulled") but they are inevitably compared to a less horrible/traumatic event, not a more horrible one.
interesting!almost everyone has experienced, so this idea is helpful.I am thinking about this problem in serious way, far from me, but this is familiar example. really image-able^^!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

This is really interesting and insightful! The way you compare the two!I have two conflicting thoughts on "clear information" though..In one situation, when I'm at the dentists - I always want to know what he's doing before he does it, so I'm prepared. It makes me feel safer to have discussed procedures, and pain before handBut, in another situation, having information can also cause more stress and fear as there is time to dwell over the bits and pieces of information.

Arushi, your distinction between the 2 different effects about "clear information" is an interesting one... I would like to add a second distinction:  information about why the detainee is here (often times, and in many of the stories shared) it is unclear and I believe causes a lot of fear, and information about the future - what is going to happen. I guess on this one, you might argue that this creates fear but I think that overall, knowing reduces fear. to be explored... thanks for highlighting these different perceptions and impacts about information...al
Really nice work on teasing our relevant insights here Vincent. Certainly draws well on Nathan's call to consider analogous contexts: http://bit.ly/oi_analogous

Interesting analogy and great work in teasing out the similarities.Fortunately, I have no fear of the dentist as my visits are "eventless" but I know I'm lucky :-)To your point, Vincent, I agree that we all have a situation that we can relate to and that make us reflect on what is the experience of being powerless.thanks! al

dental_fear_powerlessness.title: Dental Fear & Powerlessness

take_action_on_google.description: 'Take Action on Google' utilizes the Google Map open source API technology (http://code.google.com/apis/maps/index.html) to create an interactive platform, bringing victims, supporters and the general public together into an online visual environment
take_action_on_google.creator: 96a7e2fef87e68b66d827131818268ae

comments.text: Hi Midori - did you hear the news? Your concept is being developed and prototyped as part of this weeks Make-a-thon at IDEO London! Check this out for more info http://bit.ly/y2uDQZ and be sure to weigh in over at our User Forums http://bit.ly/yt0m5d to share insights, tips or important considerations for the Make-a-thon attendees to think about as they work on your concept.
And here's a hint: be sure to check out Brief #7!

Midori! Congratulations on being a winning concept. Thank you for your extraordinary effort and going above and beyond in your research. The Amnesty team thinks this could be a great tool for creating more informationally rich campaigns. It's clear you made a huge effort, and we really appreciate your contribution. Thank you!
Congrats Midori, Anne, & the whole ICU Hub Team! Also, great job in being proactive and reaching out to Google.

Congratulations Midori et al. This is indeed a great concept and I also enjoyed reading about your brainstorming session. It was also great to have Google involved. Looking forward to seeing the prototypes and the "final" tool.

Well done Midori et al! I will be most interested to view the progress of this from concept into realisation. This has great potential to incorporate ideas and elements from some of the other concepts, even perhaps as a comprehensive integration project.

Nice job Midori, Anne, & the whole ICU Hub Team on the refinements and fully leveraging the Google Map API for visualization. Seems like, especially after the updates, that this would also mash up very well with The Detainee Support Net ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-detainee-support-net-financial-legal-moral/ ).

Agreed - as Marnie points out in ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/collaborate-with-the-un-global-pulse-project-digital-smoke-signals-/ ) all of the short-listed concepts and possibly a few others could be integrated into a cohesive system for awareness, support and action.

Upon first glance through the proposed solutions, I was drawn to the support-oriented resource networks, especially The Detainee Support Net idea, but overall, I believe that the power of meeting the general public where they are--on Google products--is too powerful to ignore to help get the word out that someone has been unlawfully detained.I agree with Paul and Vincent that an integrated system could be developed with a number of these solutions. However, for the segment of people whose attention we want that are not immediately effected, I believe the power of using a familiar Google offering can yield big gains in ease-of-understanding. This is important because this issue may feel less "sexy" than others but is obviously a very serious social challenge. For proof of the power of the public just looking to do good via Google, just listen to this amazing story:http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/402/save-the-day?act=1One piece of feedback for now is that you consider Google's perspective in whether or not they'd want to participate in a Week dedicated to the unlawfully detained. To me, it seems unlikely that they would go for this given Google's legal trouble in the past and their desire to remain in the favor of all governments. Instead of asking for their support of something that some governments might disagree with, I think you could think about pitching to Google that they allow for the easy mapping of various "social issue week" events and pilot the functionality with your idea. It's a basic tweak of your idea that gets Google looking great as an enabler while empowering the dedicated users to set the agenda.

The heat map is a wonderful idea and I think vital for raising awareness and showing the areas where this is prevalent.  Along with the full stories of some detainees, that map could perhaps be populated in a quick way as well, with locations of SMS alerts of detention (this is from another finalist, but pairs well with your idea).

Time perspective? I have recently wondered a lot about geo tagging on a map (of certain facts like photo, video clips and sound clips, statistics) But in your case, could it be relevant to also add the time notation as a means to figure out if "incidents" are rising or slowy fading in frequency?I am very inspired by dr. Hans Rosling, and his Gapminder.org and I have heard some rumours that Google are very interested in this project and its technology. I wonder if it is possible for you to try to "interview" your contacts at Google if this is true and if it gives further potential options to your concept?Also some credit must go to Morgan that I met @Sony's Open Planet Ideas-development days early this year. we together brainstormed a little bit about being able to time stamp a SMS - text message, and send it to a phone number (or my own phone number) to be delivered at a certain determined time and day in the future, as a little "time-travelling-messaging"-feature.A little thing I just came up with is if there can be useful to practically set an automatic message from "my phone" as the GPS in my phone alerts me, when I cross the border into an area that are dangerous, risky, or coming close to an area where a lot of recent detentions have just happened. And that the automatic pre-set wording in this message could be something like : "If Johan have not phoned you or sent an email to you to tell everything is alright (before you will receive this alert" he might be in some kind of danger, in this area : 591930N 18415O "

I re-read your concept and saw that you had the idea of colour-coding incident-markers depending on time of occurance. anyway, I hope that my few little last-minute sketches comes in helpful to someone... :) best of luck!
Thanks for your feedback, Johan! Time-marking would definitely be an interesting additional to the overall effect of the platform and would be worth questioning Google re feasibility.
Thank you for your ideas, Johan, the gapminder site is very interesting and definitely provides a lot of inspiration for improving the Amnesty International platform.

Perhaps Newsmap http://newsmap.jp/ would be a helpful graphical or user interface reference. This model could factor in additional data such as time, location, contact frequency, support into a constantly updating interface.

In evaluating this concept I have again considered it in the context of an integrated system. To that end it seems to me to be a major component of the system 'engine'. As such it is fairly heavily technology dependent (not necessarily costly if corporate contributions are provided on the basis of CSR). Having a broad perspective the concept fits well with a number of other, more specific, concepts,

I do love this concept. Since the whole plan is aimed at rising awareness of unlawful detention. When the whole society pays attention to the phenomenon, victims could then be helped and saved by the power of people.
Great refinement!Despite my previously stated reservations about Google the basic concept is sound and would dovetail with several other refined concepts.

Thank you Paul for your comments and feedback. Your previous comments were extremely useful when we did a SWOT analysis of the original concept, prior to going to Google to present - AND, your reservations ere something which we discussed with Google directly. I hope you agree that we found a sustainable and realistic solution for it.

Thanks Anne - I do agree and would say that many things about Google are good. In fact I make extensive use of Google maps in my prototype IDEATOR Resources site( http://www.experiment.vacau.com ) which attempts, amongst other things, to provide IDEATORS with your Geolocator concept from the Social Impact challenge.I hope that the result of this present challenge will be three or four projects that draw on the strengths of all the concepts put forward.

All of these 'support' oriented platforms should provide some resources to encouraging membership of Amnesty - I imagine for instance that the shift vans will require some volunteer Amnesty staff.Just as the stories are important to concepts like Support a Spouse they are also important to attracting other forms of support such as volunteering.
It looks better :) Otsukaresama, good job.
Great to see it all coming together. Thanks for uploading Midori!
Thank you for all your critical questions. We will be addressing them in the brainstorm in Tokyo tomorrow - and be discussing them directly with Google on Friday!

Midori, lets get together at the ICU HUB again, and do some more brainstorming about how to refine the concept - so we can tackle some of the challenges which have been raised by Paul, Marion and OpenIDEO. This is SO exciting. Brainstorming ikimashou!
Great idea, Anne. Looking forward to seeing some innovative updates here based on your collaborative brainstorming!

We are in the middle of final-exams for this term this week. But we are trying to meet up for an hour on Wednesday to develop the idea further. I am also reaching out to one of the Japanese guys a Google, who initiated the Google Peoples Search during the earth quake - to get his expert ideas on how to improve the concept. He did a great presentation at TEDxTohoku, so I hope he will have the time to help out. Lets see if time allows.

I should qualify my objections to Google as a platform for this.The revenue driven model that has overtaken the organisation has resulted in some of my objections:Personal data mining (not exclusive to Google but I object to Facebook and others for the same reason);Mining IP addresses while undertaking street mapping; andA somewhat dubious approach to literature still in copyright.If the platform was independent of Google I would feel more comfortable about it. I would have no objection to Google placing the (independent) site at the top of its rankings as a good will gesture.

The site would be immediately shut down by the offending country by blocking DNS requests to the ip. The rest of the world could see it, but I think friends and family members of the victim would never even know the site exists. DNS restrictions are routine in the mainland of China. Even poorer countries like Syria or Yemen employ smart IT people to help prevent "undesirable" information from spreading.Second, we shouldn't rely upon for-profit corporations, like Google of all people, who for example recognize Jerusalem as an Israeli territory on Google maps. Even though the rest of the world including the UN claim Jerusalem should have an international status, sort of like a Vatican City.

Just because the potential for censorship exists, doesn't mean that this idea should be scuttled. There are many ways around such censorship, such as using the Tor network or Firefox plugins like AnonymoX to hide your true IP address and thus your country of origin. It would also be useful to work with organizations like the EFF that are anti-censorship to come up with more long-term solutions.

i don't think the idea should be scuttled either, but anonymizers and firefox plugins are really only useful for the very technically inclined.. The "99%" in other censored countries do not know of the existence of such tools or the reason for their existence.
I love that I can share the concept idea on Facebook now!

Hi Midori, thanks for participating and being part of our Amnesty short list. We wonder how you might push this idea further in terms of incentivizing people to contribute to the map and how you might represent people that dont wish to be located or identified.

Conceptually find the idea of sharing stories in a universal space very appealing, but thoroughly agree with Marion that some platform other than Google (or any other commercial entity) is to be preferred. Truly philanthropic donation of server capacity put under Amnesty's control would be my choice.
Way to go, Midori and the ICU Openstormers!
Great visualization of the idea Midori!

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

making_policy_public.description: An initiative using strong communication design to to make information on policy truly public: accessible, meaningful and shared.
making_policy_public.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: This makes me ask: can pure imagery be used to convey key concepts - in order to overcome literacy and language barriers? There is huge precedence for this. For example, I think of the Teotihuacan culture in Mexico (before the Aztecs). In their city-state they had people from so many different cultures, they had to figure out how to convey important laws and practices just through the use of imagery. They accepted this challenge, I believe, in part because they valued diversity.

Interesting insight, Steve. I certainly think that imagery can be used in context of challenged literacy. I've noted a number initiatives leveraging this kind of thing when I've been involved in development work in India. In fact we use visual material a lot when conducting ethnographic studies as we tend to get much richer results than just asking questions verbally or in writing. Great to you have you commenting on challenge posts. Hopefully you might even find the time to add a Concept of your own. Would be great to have you join us as a ideator!

Hi Meena, Thanks for posting this. An excellent idea. I particularly like it because it can be used by people to draw down their rights, but also it enables police personnel to understand what those rights are.Today's (17.11.2011) photo story in the British Guardian newpaper of the African Prisons Project in Uganda illustrates how prison officers (and likely police personnel in general) are ill-informed about human rights issues - they are recruited from the military - and this exposes detainees to multiple risks and abuses throughout the period of arrest, detention and pre release.

That's a great insight, Mukta  that police, prison officers, etc could also benefit from clearer information  not just detainees and their support networks. Hoping these great thoughts get taken through to the Concepting phase!
I think this is good, it will allow people to understand their rights and act onthem

I think this is a great idea! I am interested to hear how this would be put into effect. For instance, if it was a pamphlet or something of the like, how would it be distributed.Love, EthanWCIL (Wells College Innovatioin Lab [pronounced whistle])
Fab! I love all the great activity that's being generated by the WCIL crew!

Oh... and I never intended this to be used in the context of unlawful detention as it is  as print based communication. During the Inspiration phase we gather examples of existing stuff which we can draw learnings from for the upcoming Concepting phase  the key point here being about clear communication rather than the format. Anyone can take this central inspiration in a number of directions in Concepting  we hope it morphs in many directions, in many forms ;^)

I really like this idea. Policy is often far too complex and not well explained. Clearly explained policy that is easy to access makes it easier and more useful for everyone. Also I am a student in the Wells College Innovation lab.

Hi Meena, this is indeed an important issue to keep in mind esp. if you think of the variety of countries and contexts that you mentioned in one of your other inspirations. Taking into account literacy levels and languages might also be important.

Indeed A-L  and the crew at Making Policy Public are mindful of this even in the US context. Candy Chang talks about it a bit on the link above and I like how she's used simple infographics and translations into key languages which I believe was informed by her research on streets on NY. Hoping that our community take up your relevant highlight about literacy & languages as we move into the upcoming Concepting phase.

Hi Meena, thanks for sharing this. It prompted me the thought that unlawful detention is different in different countries. I remember from my own country, Turkey, few years ago, the police's badge numbers weren't even easily detectable, so some police would commit violations and couldn't be found. There might be two ways here: either try to find a universal solution which takes account different aspects (like the ones that al mentioned) or solutions are customized on different contexts. I guess that is the real challenge!

That's an interesting insight from on the ground in Turkey, Tayfun. I love it that our community is so global & diverse. By the way  we'd love it if you feel like adding more info to your OpenIDEO profile. I've been very interested in many of your comments which sparks my curiosity on what you do for work, etc. We're always interested to explore the breadth and scope of our growing community!
Oh  and we're hoping for *both* customised, local solutions and those of a more universal, global nature. Exciting times await in Concepting!

making_policy_public.title: Making Policy Public

law_student_network.description: A formal system set up among law students around the world, that would tap into their knowledge and ideals.  They can be given legal research assignments, and send communications on behalf of detainees, while earning class credit or pro bono hours.
law_student_network.creator: 12b9dacb49b9ae47466c07204f630baa

comments.text: Loving your illustrations Margaret! We hope you'll be back tomorrow to re-post these in the soon to be launched Concepting phase where they'll get the attention they deserve. Till then we've got a few hours to go to collect examples of *existing* tools, campaigns, etc that will feed our idea-generation going forward. We'll be super pysced to see your fab illustrations and ideas in Concepting  and of course look forward to the conversations they'll trigger.
A very good base to stick on!
i feel this is a good idea because their more then one way to contract people and to get your name out there to move up in life

law_student_network.title: Law Student Network

share_your_art_around_the_world..description: UPDATED! Art sends a powerful message to an observer. Using a site in the format of Tumblr, people can submit their artwork and thoughts concerning unlawful detention. This site can allow people to take the submitted artwork and spread it around their city. We will encourage people to get out there and make these stories known. This concept comes from the Wells College Innovation Lab (Emily, CJ, Ashley, Molly, Kyle).
share_your_art_around_the_world..creator: 9bc86d2f8ca15c9a0ac3499f98b8cc2f

comments.text: Have you considered ways to promote the pop-up aspect? Maybe putting together some sort of kit that could be easily transported and quickly set-up.Though I'm a huge fan of Tumblr and the viral aspects that make it possible, having the ability to literally step into different neighborhoods gives you the opportunity to reach out to many more people of all walks of life. You never know when you're going to run into someone who can make a huge impact on your goal, and having both the physical and the virtual can help you broaden your base.Have a nice day. :)
This is a good idea!
Groovy idea, glad Ashley told me about your awesome project!
I really love this concept and think that art is a powerful medium to use in order to communicate ideas, especially because art is a language everyone can understand. Good luck!
This is a great idea for help those who were unlawfully detained.
Glad Ashely Told Me About This!! Keep up the Good work...
I really like this idea and I'm glad Ashley Waelti told me about this. Keep up the good work guys!

Nice concept. The big challenge in this is to get people to submit their art work. I think it would be a great idea to start prototyping this concept, so you can see what challenges you run into. We did a similar thing with the Small Acts of Goodness concept by Anne Riechert - http://www.openideo.com/open/impact/winning-concepts/small-act-of-goodness-/The challenges we are running into now are getting people involved and coming up with a new small act for people to do. You can see our 'prototype' on Facebook here: http://www.facebook.com/SmallActOfGoodnessand on Tumblr here:http://asmallact.tumblr.com/

Thanks a lot for your thoughts! We just made our prototype today of a pop up art gallery, and so far we have had positive feedback. It has inspired people to create their own art! I hope your work is going well!

Hi Emily!I'm a big fan and user of Tumblr myself, and I see great viral potential in using the platform correctly and to its max. So I see your concept as a great vehicle to share the importance of human rights issues and educating bloggers and the public in general. Maybe an online campaign to begin spreading the word about the Shift Freedom keyboard movement at stickers, concept by Anne : http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/shift-freedom-sticker-sign-up-campaign/ , especially to the younger audience who might be quite active on social media platforms such as Tumblr. I also love the idea about creating art and featuring it in cities around the world - again maybe here we could do this by spreading the Unlawfully Detained Symbol by Jason ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-universal-unlawfully-detained-symbol-to-spread-in-case-of-emergency/ ) together with the art piece?Your concept really brings to my mind this inspiration 'Using Art to Turn the World Around', touching on the excitement JR's idea brings, which is really reflected in ure concept! : http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/using-art-to-turn-the-world-around-/
Thank you so much for your feedback! We really tried to incorporate the ideas you gave us into making this a better project. Check out our updates and tell us what you think!

share_your_art_around_the_world..title: "The Forgotten" - Share your art around the world.

protest_playbook_portal_supporting_all_p.description: A repository of all the supporting materials, technologies and apps one needs when participating in an event that may lead to detention. This general schema is built on four generalized events in the trajectory to detainment coupled with the specific technologies presented in the inspiration phase.
protest_playbook_portal_supporting_all_p.creator: 2935218c6249f6d941ddaac700aa391d

comments.text: I really like that this is PRO-active instead of reactive, in terms of seeking justice. Well done!
Thanks Jamie! The general idea was there. I just added a few updates from all the great concepts, so I hope it's even clearer now.

Hi Jason, I love how you build upon various inspirations and thinking of the journey of the protester. I also like the low-tech option with the guide. It seems to me as a protester version of Amjad's A-Z guide which focused on detention and looked at both detainees and and families: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-z-guide-for-families-and-friends-of-detainees/Amjad's is adding the local context / language aspect that is implicit in your concept.Maybe there's a series of "A-Z guides" coming up? :-)

This reminds me of the a portal I've seen after the earthquake in DC last summer, informing the audience what to do in case of an earthquake depending on their location/activity (if they were sleeping, at the beach, driving in their car, etc.). I can't find the link, but it was very well done I think.

Really like your consideration of various phases here, Jason. You mention the Street Vendor Guides as an Inspiration. Perhaps you want to link to this post in your Build Upon items which mentions this: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/making-policy-public/
Of course! I totally thought I had...thanks Meena :0)

protest_playbook_portal_supporting_all_p.title: Protest Playbook Portal - supporting all phases of a protest

the_underground_railroad_2.0.description:
The Underground Railroad was an informal network of people working to free slaves from slavery. The success of the Railroad can be attributed to the secrecy that surrounded it. The people that made up the Railroad only knew what their job was; they were kept in the dark as to what happened before and after they played their part. This kept everyone safe. We are proposing a similar network that could be in place for victims of unlawful detainment in today's society. 

Wells College Innovation Lab (Ethan, Kelly, Anastasia, Corey, Zack)
the_underground_railroad_2.0.creator: e4634b7a252d9bb7c61a8a51a98a8158
the_underground_railroad_2.0.title: The Underground Railroad 2.0

missing_people_website.description: Missing People is a website that offers "a lifeline for the 250,000 people who run away and go missing each year. For those left behind we provide specialised support to ease the heartache and confusion, and help search for their missing loved ones"
missing_people_website.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Social networks are so prevalent nowadays, so something like this would be enticing to those going through a situation like that. You're right, emotional support for family and friends of those being detained is 100% necessary.

This would be a great way to find people coping with loss of a loved one, especially when they are detained. Being able to reach out to someone who understands your situation can be very beneficial for someone experiencing this loss. I really enjoy your thinking!

Hi Nathan,interest website. I agree with you part of the issue is indeed to support the relatives and friends. The emotional aspect (on their side) should not be forgotten. Creating a community of relatives and friends might also allow them to be stronger when it comes to support the person in detention. Moreover, as noted by Owen, such sites are also providing opportunities for knowledge sharing.al

Great addition, Nathan, and points well made re: supporting the support network. Emotional aspects can sometimes be sidelined in the quest for practical solutions. Interestingly, advice and knowledge-sharing, within the scope of what might be imagined as part of this challenge, potentially has a foot in both the emotional and practical camps.
Thanks Owen, great feedback

missing_people_website.title: Missing People website

coordinated_efforts_building_blocks_of_a.description: The Baha'is of Iran have been persecuted in Iran since the revolution.  Still today, many Baha'is are being arrested, detained for being Baha'i. The Baha'is of the world have mobilized in speaking out on their behalf in the international sphere.
coordinated_efforts_building_blocks_of_a.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: You see, these are the stories that happen, but you need someone to tell you they do. I, even with my interest sometimes in international and political issues, was not aware about this. Very good inspiration, and thank you for sharing!

coordinated_efforts_building_blocks_of_a.title: Coordinated Efforts: Building Blocks of a Social Movement

world_s_largest_3d_led_cube._inspiring_a.description: The largest outdoor information display cube is a visualization of data.  The display changes as information of unlawfully detained people is collected via various sources. - OpenIDEO Student Chapter at NYU-Poly
world_s_largest_3d_led_cube._inspiring_a.creator: ccb5c912f8b80ad1e8dd5f790d2fd8e1

comments.text: Hi Alan, this inspiration reminded me of both your and A-L's recent concepts:- A colleague of mine just showed me this light installation, at Christopher Henry Gallery, in NY: http://vimeo.com/30108920 This project uses about 4 projectors inside the object, and imagine this in a public space, maybe in the form of ure cube instead, or a bigger object like this one, possibly projecting different things on it's different side ancles? It would be so powerful and beautiful to stop and look at, in a city! The technology behind it is already available so it is very doable, only need support and funding from a public or private entity and connect it to Amnesty +  the public.Just wanted to share it as it reminded me of ure cube!

Ana that is a great idea. There are many ways to do it and I think it would depend on funding. I would like to do the LED's and the pixels as it is like multiple cubes in one that could represent people and the power behind people getting together for a cause. Here is another example of another way to do this.  I saw this at the MOMA on Sunday: http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2011/talktome/objects/133767/

Hi Alan,I like the idea of this cube. I was thinking as you mention of gathering the data from various sources- maybe you could team this cube up with my Interactive Infographic Platform data, as source to get this data from? -> http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/an-interactive-infographic-platform-fueled-by-the-whole-network-of-supporters-/Have a look at it if you haven't yet. It would be a great way to collaborate - turn my platform into a beautiful public art installation in the form of your cube, raising even more awareness to the public eye! Would be great to see the cube in big and small cities, so it reaches different audiences with different degrees of education. I'm sure public funding for this installation would be possible, it's got great meaning behind it. Great work!
Thank you Ana,That is a great idea!  I have added it as a build upon. How would a collaboration work?  I love the meaning too.

This is a neat concept Alan.  Almost functions as a type of 3D infographic which is very cool.  I am curious how the data would be organized among cubes.  Would each cube have information for only one region?  Or for a country?  Or for the world?  If more than one region, it might be interesting to be able to denote detentions by region through the use of color.  So perhaps one region has red lights and another has green.  Then, as detention trends flux across regions, you might see red lights brighten and grow and green lights dim and shrink, and then the trend might reverse and you'll see the pattern vice versa.A final thing for you to think about.  Who are you trying to impact with this imagery?  The reason I ask is because I wonder where the cubes should be displayed in order to create the most impact.  But I think that where the cube might be placed to make the most impact will likely be dependent on your intended audience (the government, the press, foreign governments, aid organizations, etc.).  Who are you trying to reach?  And where would you position the cubes to make sure you reach them?Congrats on an intriguing concept OpenIDEO student chapter NYU-Poly!  Looking forward to seeing it evolve :-)

Nice concept indeed. I like the idea of a 3D representation that could "embody" infographic data. I think Amanda's idea of having a color code to represent different regions is a great idea, which will make the idea meaningful.Re. Amanda's question of audience, I would see it in cities, aiming at increasing awareness of 1) the existence of unlawful detentions and 2) the trends (increase or decrease overall, in a region) in terms of numbers of detentions. You could imagine one nearby the entrance of the HQ of Amnesty and in other similar public spaces. To be more meaningful, you could have a short description, maybe a few pictures... The audience would be officials, authorities but also people in the street (in developed countries). Alan, is it aligned with what you had in mind?

Hi again,two projects that could be in a similar vein: www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/protect-protect/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/25/arts/design/25vide.htmlanother one which is simpler but I think makes the same point of raising awareness, being a constant reminder of things that happen in the world in terms of unlawful detention: http://nano.xerox.com/weiser/calmtech/calmtech.htmTo Alan's question about low tech: I don't think there is any low tech possible here and because of the audience and the purpose, it is not a major issue. You could assume having one of this cube, which could travel like any multimedia installation and then having it in the Another location: HQ of the UN... but it could also be somewhere central in a city...It has the strengths and limitations of installations in public spaces.

Thank you Amanda and Anne-Laure for your comments.  Amanda,Great idea. Colors are definitely possible, not expensive and a great idea.  We could use these for instance: http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1074 You could imagine the blending of the RBG colors almost like a 3D LCD screen.Anne,Yes that is what I had in mind. I also thought that it could be an organic display.  Meaning that it could change over time as the type of the infographic data changes. I.E. New types of information added. We could start out with something simple to display.  An animation of infographic data and then over time it could evolve. Imagine using this to display a 3D image of a detainee. Yes it could be displayed in cities and in public areas.  I love love the idea of this being outside the HQ of Amnesty or outside the UN. I also think the cube itself has a meaning and stands for something.  I was trying to find out more information about the meaning, but the sources I was fining on the web were not good for me to quote. ...I am still searching. For example Apple has used cubes before in their products and stores (http://images.apple.com/retail/fifthavenue/images/fifthavenue_gallery_image3.jpg). I do remember that there was a meaning behind it's use.

Hi Alan,I like the idea of this cube. I was thinking as you mention of gathering the data from various sources- maybe you could team this cube up with my Interactive Infographic Platform data, as source to get this data from? Have a look at it if you haven't yet. It would be a great way to collaborate - turn my platform into a beautiful public art installation in the form of your cube, raising even more awareness to the public eye! Would be great to see the cube in big and small cities, so it reaches different audiences with different degrees of education. I'm sure public funding for this installation would be possible, it's got great meaning behind it. Great work!

world_s_largest_3d_led_cube._inspiring_a.title: World's largest 3D LED Cube. Inspiring awareness by combining information, art and design

give_the_a_voice_shifting_stories_of_pow.description: How to provide support to the families by empowering them: giving them access to information, connecting them and providing a sense of meaning and independence
give_the_a_voice_shifting_stories_of_pow.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: This is a wonderful idea - moving from powerlessness to empowerment.  I particularly connected with the "virtual pen pal" idea.  Allowing people to connect, and build relationships with others EVERYWHERE.  How would you visualize this working?  With an interface specifically set up for this project, where people from around the world who desire to connect in this way can "meet" online?  Or use existing social media?

It's been a pleasure "working" with you too Anne-Laure!!  This is such a wonderful way to integrate some, as Jason said, "individually fantastic concepts."  It maintains the concepts' individual strengths in terms of providing these women with support, but also provides a way to empower the women by enabling them to provide a needed service to their communities.  Congrats on an excellent concept!
Thanks!

So many good things here. I really like your combination of some individually fantastic concepts into one unified support system. I especially like the way this service can empower through jobs: phone-trees, scribes, Shift van, etc. Awesome concept!

Thanks Jason for the compliment. I did try to provide a holistic view including many of the concepts that I found really relevant to the challenge. I thought that it was also important to not just help by "making charity", but also provide them with ways to be independent and build their own services. Jobs seem to be an obvious one, but this is also a way to provide localized understanding and information.

Hi Anne Laure,It's an honor to be mentioned by you as an inspiration here!I really like the way you picked up on Amanda's latest concept, that I feel addresses such an important point I hadn't read or picked up on yet here, about women and their powerlessness in certain communities.I feel there is great opportunity in tackling this problem, not just with women but DIRECT family members affected by unlawful detention. By reading your concept and remembering all the others mentioned, I imagine a networked program that creates a support system for these families. I imagine in called something like 'The Shift Power Program', and it would need support from legal identities such as the UN or Unicef, Refugee program responsible, and Amnesty of course. These official bodies could direct us fast enough to these families being affected and most urgently needing a support network. The only thing I see as a slower issue here is finding the right people to help : Where are they? How do we find them ( imagine they are in really secluded villages, where now one speaks their dialect) ? How do we influence them in a positive way ? How can we give them help/support without giving them unrealistic hopes for their personal problems to be resolved too, ex. husband coming back soon ? And how do we keep them 'supported' in our Support Program ? Of course the Van  + Vending machine would help us prolong the support system with little technology, but we would also need monitoring of the family possibly, so someone that would be close to them, a representative, maybe the Van, when it comes once a month? Just thinking out loud, I think there is great potential in creating a solid support structure around the main concepts you touch on. Great work as always A-L :)

Thanks Ana. I agree with you: the support structure could / should be for not only the wives, but families in general. I've touched upon it referring to afters schools for the kids, inspired by Amina's interview. To address your questions regarding how to connect with the communities, I think that there are many small organizations which have strong local connections with which the Shift power program (nice name) could work. It can in some cases even be organizations like Grameen Bank in Bangladesh which are very well connected in rural areas. I have the feeling, but maybe I'm wrong as I don't know the specific contexts and I haven't been in the field, that there are much more informal support structures which could potentially grow if they had some infrastructure and resources. This is what I was referring to by describing this project in Southwark, London, where the council thought that the community members will ask for more experts, "bodies" and in fact, they did not seem to need that many more people, but more resources such as a space to meet, internet access, computers... etc. Yet I agree to make this concept implementable thinking of these issues is crucial.
Great build and comprehensive collaboration!
and the collaboration makes the experience really great! :-)

give_the_a_voice_shifting_stories_of_pow.title: Give us a voice: shifting stories of powerlessness to empowerment.

cell_phone_implement.description: This is a technology where phone's receiver (where we hear) will be implemented to the inner ear and the transmitter (where we talk) will be on our teeth. So only the person with the implement will hear something
cell_phone_implement.creator: da5eea5073e27d790089f40e886490cb

comments.text: Interesting idea although it also has consequences in terms of our relationship to technology. This is in fact the questions explored by Auger and Loizeau with their prototype which was originally a student project at the RCA and presented at the Science Museum in London: http://www.auger-loizeau.com/index.php?id=7The aim of their work that they describe as "critical design" was to raise issues around technology, communication and bodies. I was wondering if you were referring to their work or if you had a more recent prototype in mind.  thanks,al

Hi al, thanks for the comment and the link.The picture is actually about their implementation but the info that I received was from howstuffworks.com and it wasn't as detailed as the link you have sent.I was just contemplating on more ideas (like sending an SMS which contains the location of the detaineed) But of course, this (maybe like facebook) very much involves privacy concerns. Thanks again for the link and detailed info

Hi Tayfun, glad you found the information helpful. In fact, I heard James presenting some of his work, this piece as well as his most recent work on robots, 2 years ago in London. He insisted that for him this was more about creating a conversation about the technology and its implications (e.g. for privacy). This work is in the vein of critical design as defined by Dunne and Raby: http://www.dunneandraby.co.uk/content/bydandr/13/0I found it interesting to reinterpret the work in this context with new potential uses... thanksal

Thank you for the new link. It now makes more sense for me as I see what they mean by "critical design". I guess some element of "critical design" is needed in all of the challenges here to shake the status quo.Thanks again

cell_phone_implement.title: Cell Phone Implement

exposing_people_who_arrested_beat_irania.description: In the aftermath of the 2009 Iranian Presidential elections protesters took to the streets. Many of them were detained and beaten by officials and others. With mobile phones people video/photographed the transgressors and exposed their faces online.
exposing_people_who_arrested_beat_irania.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: Crowdsourcing these accounts via  a "global photo blog" could really illustrate the magnitude of the problem of unlawful detention, as well.

Accountability of the parties involved is definitely important.  But I think there's an important distinction here:Individuals will be villified regardless of their motivation for performing heinous acts.  Yes, one could make a strong case that they ought to conscientiously object, but doing so can be extraordinarily hard when you're a pawn at the behest of a government, a gang, or some other organization.Methinks we need to emphasize the organization or ideology behind the acts, rather, perhaps, than the individuals.  Thoughts?

Yes. While I agree that governments and the organizational foundations need transformation. I think it might be wise to hold the individuals as agents enabling and reinforcing the dominate discourse is important. It's like the many dictatorships that enlisted people to do vile acts, like during the times of Nazi regime, Stalin, etc. The individual is always accountable for participating whether by omission or commission acts against other human beings. The deterrent of being accountable to other human beings, especially those in your social circle, humanizing the decision to abuse others--and takes it away from the dismissal excuses of "I was told to do it, and if I didn't the X would happen to me and my family". I only think this way more so after going to Iran and talking to various people part of minority groups as well as those part of the mainstream. But I agree wholeheartedly that there needs to be both systemic as well as individual change--neither is sustainable without the other. Thanks for your thoughtful response Christian. It means a lot to me.

Agree fully, Sina.  I think we're actually truly entirely in agreement.  I just think that the accountability of the individual needs to be messaged *very* tactfully as to not encourage overly negative reaction.Great post.

I think that by exposing those who act as agents of such a system, it also will affect them after the act. In their circles of violators, they might be led to believe they did the right thing, but by exposing them, they will also see that this might not be true. I think it's powerful to both take on the cause and the symptoms at the same time.

Another angle could be : Fear.I really think that some citizens could be angry at the protestors because they feel they should not protest in this area, because it could attract unwanted attention from the military, and increase the risk that they come here into our neighbourhood and possibly harm us, interrogate us, abduct us innocent bystanders or our families, that are not involved with the actual protest.So do not expose innocent bystanders that simply act irrational, expose the dictators and the evil systems instead.And if it is obvious that the aggressors are dressed in uniform and beat up a civilian, go ahead and film it and put it out online. (Rodney King 1991, and so on...)
Great example of using mobile recording & social pressure to stigmatize and dissuade human rights violators. What can be done to further facilitate these activism tactics?

sure it's not new, but am positive its new in many parts of the world.By posting their pictures and putting them under the spot light people will be creating a wave, a well noted one. not only this should be happening online but also in hard copies.In lots of place, and am just assuming, it would be hard to go through this. but this is sure a good way to go. we might think that those who are using violence as a threat are there in huge numbers, but we cannot forget that the ones who are being abused and detained, have more people who are welling to put their hands together for them if they have the right means. so i think people should be educated about the ways they can use to spread the word. Thanks Sina. this sure is intriguing :)

comments.text: Hi William, thanks for joining our conversation. Clearly in these situations there's an urgency around wanting to find/locate people who are detained unlawfully and your idea does get at that. Be sure to hold on to it as we get to the Concepting next week and if you'd like you can repost it there.In the meantime, I'd love to ask you to think about a couple of things, in the hope that it might spark some further inspiration for you and our community. There are some obvious ethical, logistical, and financial concerns that are raised with implanting microchips in newborns  so my question is, what are some existing technologies (apps, websites, microchips or others) that currently help families and communities locate their loved ones during times of crisis? What might we learn from them to help inform your potential concept and perhaps address some of the concerns I mentioned above? I'm glad you've started this conversation and I hope others join in to help you tease it out.

comments.text: This is a moving story... a story of powerlessness summed up in that quote: "I was punished when I didn't speak out and punished when I did". The point you are making about the "community", the neighbors who stay quiet is an important one.It reminds the story (I also shared while commenting on Ashley's Fire inspiration) of the story of Kitty Genovese, this woman stabbed several times in Queens in 1964 with no one coming to help her despite her calling her help, and her being heard by 38 people."For more than half an hour thirty-eight respectable, law-abiding citizens in Queens watched a killer stalk and stab a woman in three separate attacks in Kew Gardens." NY Times article written by Martin Gansberg and published on March 27.(see also Gladwell's analysis in The Tipping Point).It also brings us back to the importance of providing tools, supports for people in situations like Zoora Shah.BTW, maybe I missed it but could you share the link to the story. thanks. al
http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/somewhere-in-britain-1146250.htmlhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/1999/oct/28/gender.uk1

amnesty_observer_s_witness_box_.description:
Empathy is a quality deeply embedded in the human heart. Its undoubtedly ubiquitous in its nature and present in variable amounts within individuals around the world, irrespective of their personalities, nature, biases, opinions or codes of conduct. 
As David Brooks states in his article (Inspiration posted previously by Ashley Jablow), 'We are surrounded by people who want to make world a better place. The problem comes when we try to turn feeling into action,'
We all know that people empathize with other people in pain or suffering on a natural basis and it is very common, then why is it so difficult for all of us to 'act' upon it?
The Amnesty Observer's Witness Box tends to address this problem and focuses towards providing people a safe and anonymous 'Line Of Action' with an absolute 'Ease of Access.'
amnesty_observer_s_witness_box_.creator: 0e9b61ed7d7b30f3db82c5786cf2f1b3

comments.text: Very nice idea Rathin. Also the machine could have a button which would upload a video or a status message on the social media platforms like facebook, twitter etc. on the pages of the local residents. For this there can be a facebook or twitter application for Amnesty observer which should be added to the pages of facebook or twitter users. Whenever a button is pressed on the machine a status message or video would be posted to the walls of all the local residents where the detention is being happened. The video would be posted by the name of Amnesty. I think that would also help in generating awareness and people could take steps to prevent detention.Just giving an idea that came to my mind that could be collaborated with your concept.

The emphasis on facilitation actions of empathy is a great strenght of this idea. It enables everyone to help quickly and simply, and to keep the population alert and in tune rather than fading into apathy, denial, or blindness. These are really important strengths to have in a solution. However, my concerns are similar to Hannah's. Having these buttons out in public and stationary makes them (and those who use them) very vulnerable, and puts them at risk of surveillance and identification, and therefore, punishment. Cell phones are also easily tracked and monitored. Something that was more evasive of police and government power would be safer andmore effective. maybe some non-stationary solution other than cellphones, orsome sort of way to keep the users's annonymity.  That's a tough demand, but i think an important one to think aobut, since your idea is so valuable.Kathryn Shriver, Wells College Innovation Lab.

This is a great idea to discreetly alert the right people to suspicious activities. One thing to consider is that eventually the "wrong" people would catch on and either take these boxes away or press the button and lure the people staying on surveillance into a trap.
(From the Wells College Innovation Lab)
Interesting thoughts, Rathin  looking forward to discussion from other collaborators on this one.

Thanks Rathin. It's great to see you developing the concept that emerged from the conversation with Vincent, Meena, Ana and I around Vincent's Amnesty Observer's app. Very nice concept!I really like how you've developed the idea and complementing Vincent's app. As you mentioned, it is not always obvious to go from noticing something, having some empathy to acting and you are therefore offering (in a similar way to Vincent) an easy way to do this.I also like the scenario and your thinking about ease of use as well as issues such as safety. The Indian location is also a nice complement to Vincent's Chinese focus. :-) You're doing a great job on building not only on the apps but also Ana's Amnesty vending machine, Jason's Universal symbol of unlawful detention and existing services such as 9-1-1 and the question box. You could also link it to the universal emergency number: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/universal-emergency-number/Another concept you might also want to look at because of its one action focus: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/helpme-2013-a-single-push-pull-information-platform/

comments.text: Hi Vesna! I really like this idea. How do you imagine the public awareness campaign to take place: just through print ad with powerful messages? I really see great potential in viral videos online for this campaign. If so, maybe anyone could share each particular video story their Facebook and Twitter, one that you really feel affected by. ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/raising-empathy-animated-video-series/ ) Just a thought that came to mind! I think touching on empathy and creating an emotion in the wide public about this issue is a great way to raise awareness, especially thorough this sort of 'role reversal' you mention.
