_help_i_m_being_detained_and_i_can_t_get.description:
A simple watch can be turned into a cry for help if one is about to be detained unlawfully. With just the press of a button on said watch a message will be sent to family and friends the person deemed important enough.
Wells College Innovation Lab
_help_i_m_being_detained_and_i_can_t_get.creator: 6db89a242b266272161ffcf489e0b557

comments.text: Hello Pamela! Thank you for your contribution to this challenge. We really appreciate your hard work, not to mention your outstanding prototypes. Thank you!

Pamela,Despite my discussion with Vincent I see this as a very promising concept. I'm sure the cost issue is solvable and I see this concept fitting in to a range of alert devices that could be developed and or used in suitable situations. Its great to see Wells College getting involved - I am interested in promoting the design principles to primary and secondary schools and the general community here in Australia so I shall be watching Wells College involvement closely.

Interesting idea.The watch would literally always be on hand, and hopefully unnoticed as a tracking device.My main concern is on whether enough potential unlawful detainees (beyond high profile cases) can access/would decide to get this device, given the need to buy a separate standalone device (vs an app on an existing cell phone) at a relatively high cost (the cheapest SPOT Satellite GPS device in your provided link costs ~$100 down + $100/year subscription).

I know nothing about uploading signals to satellites so I cant comment on the practical aspects of a satellite connected watch or necklace. However I imagine that the device would have a unique id (like mac or ip addresses) so the cost of interaction could surely be negotiated down on the basis of fee per call rather than subscription.

Good point Paul. This fee per "alert" could be an option.I guess it's also true that GPS navigation devices are often bought for a one-time cost (though this is also quite significant), then rely on GPS signals (no subscription needed) to give directions based on the local device's data.So the location determination per se doesn't require any subscription. However, we still have to figure out what technology makes the most sense for the "sending" of an alert from the watch to the central communication center (or directly to family members, facebook, etc.), as well as the potential 2-way communication discussed in the concept, in terms of availability, reliability, & cost.

Yes I agree the question of appropriate sending technology is an issue. One advantage with satellite which is true for Anne-Laure's shift van too is that ownership of the infrastructure for communication is not an issue - as I imagine both mobile and PSTN may be in some countries. That's what makes me feel mesh networks connected to 'the world' through satellite have a lot of potential.
great use of an existing technology!
Nicely done!
great idea, great work!!
Nice job refining this!!!

Great idea, My worry is can this device work in remote part of the work like in Africa where lots of illegal detentions take place? If so at what cost? I 'll also like to know if there is a possibility deactivate a signal if one mistakenly activated it? Finally what are the possibilities that authorities countries like China and others have over the signal?

That is problem we haven't entirely figured out yet. Assuming it is possible to use existing satellites, it shouldn't be as expensive and should be able to send the signal just about anywhere. It would use independent satellites so it would be harder for government to have the signals, however we don't know that much about this so if you have ideas please let us know.
Nice thoughts on the panic button. But we were wondering, how would the button transmit the signal to an actual radio station that people would hear (other than the radio that is in the same room)?

It would not transmit to a radio station it would send out a unique signal that could be pickup by satellites that could then send a message out onto the internet. This is like what SPOT does for hiker but it would only send a signal if the button is presses. A link to the SPOT website is above.
We fine-tuned our idea. What do you think of the changes?

Great concept. And prototype is so cute! :)But I'm deep in thought how we can place those buttons to be both suitable for easy access and safe enough not to be pushed by accident.It could look like fire button. It usually protected by some kind of glass door which we lift up before pushing.Has anyone any ideas?
Awesome job making it to the refinement stage!
Great idea. I had thoughts on a similar idea, which would make use of independently owned satellites to transmit the messages rather than a central radio network.Great work guys!
Great concept, I'm not sure if you've seen these apps which work in a similar way?http://www.good.is/post/white-house-announces-two-new-anti-rape-apps/
Have just uploaded a concept that does something similar but with an app and a wallet card. Have put yours in as "building on" so they're linked together
What a great little prototype. Maybe next time you could take a closer pic as it looks like you've made some great effort to bring this idea to life.
Great prototyping moves guys!

_help_i_m_being_detained_and_i_can_t_get.title: "Help I'm Being Detained and I Can't Get Free"

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

technology_is_now_solving_little_daily_p.description: Mobile Internet is developing. It plays an important role in large events and also small ones.
technology_is_now_solving_little_daily_p.creator: 97b8ff32fd53531b6d32f5729d47ea1c

comments.text: Nice one, guys and welcome on board! It's indeed exciting times regarding technology can change our lives  and here at OpenIDEO we're keen to harness positive avenues for this.Tip: If you're cutting and pasting draft text into your post, put it in a text edit program first to remove formatting (if you're on a Mac you can use Text Edit) If you're keen to do this now you can hit the Update Entry button on the right of your post & make the adjustments.Looking forward to seeing more shining inspiration from Team Chimera!

Hi again, I thought that this inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/keeping-track-of-close-family-and-friends-through-mobile-apps/might be interesting for you to think more specifically about how technology  does / can "change" our life.

Thanks Team Chimera for this inspiration. The contrast between the two examples is an interesting one as it shows how technology might also support groups of relatives and friends for issues that might seem less vital but that are still important to their life.I think your point about trust is also well-taken... this is something to keep in mind in the concepting phase.

Absolutely right about Weibo, Team Chimera. In events like this, information was also unearthed & spread about corruption & "harmony" (i.e. censorship/cover-ups): http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/29/world/asia/29china.html
thanks Vincent for the link to the NY Times article...

This ties in with Anne Laure's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-dragonfly-effect/ which talks about the dragon fly effect. I think that location based services is a powerful tool not only in emergency situations but also in tools to make life easier. Thank you for sharing this!

technology_is_now_solving_little_daily_p.title: Technology is now solving little daily problems.

symbolic_protests.description: More attention captured through symbolic display of the issue to be dealt with
symbolic_protests.creator: d79986202006e7531e3aaa0d83a08f2f

comments.text: Akshathaa, thanks for sharing your thoughts. Interesting way to think of campaining.You might want to review inspirations on storytelling and art based projects (there are a few inspirations related to this).You might find the inspiration by the Disrupters' team relevant as you start thinking in the concepting phase: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/generating-public-awareness-through-street-plays/

Interesting thoughts, Akshathaa... looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to look over other Inspirations to see if there's any insights to help build your Concept further  storytelling is such an important part of awareness.

symbolic_protests.title: Symbolic protests

a_universal_unlawfully_detained_symbol_t.description: Inspired by finding low-tech solutions to issues of the unlawfully detained, this universal symbol could be used by detainees as a cry for help. This symbol would be flashed, Morse-d, carved or dropped in a bottle as a crumb of detainment...or worn as Shift Freedom Glasses!! http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/on-10th-dec-human-rights-day-exchange-your-profile-picture-for-the-shift-freedom-glasses-/ It could also serve (in the spirit of Banksy) as a tag on locations of detainment.
a_universal_unlawfully_detained_symbol_t.creator: 2935218c6249f6d941ddaac700aa391d

comments.text: Hi Jason, thanks so much for your many idea contributions. We discussed this one at length in our expert panel and felt this would be a great campaign idea for Amnesty to take up but did not strictly fit within the brief of technology. Thanks for contributing!
Understandable. I'm just happy it became a part of some really great concepts!

Hi Jason! Loving the new illustration... GREAT idea to implement the two lenses with your circular symbol and the three bars down it... I should of thought of that for the prototype I made and it would make the U.U.Symbol easier to remember + recognize. But we can always add more versions later like you said !Awesome!! I'm loving the power of the word SHIFT implemented with the glasses and your symbol. Looking forward to hear what others have to say on this idea!Thanks for the quick replies! And great work :)
Great illustration indeed. Can't wait to wear these glasses on Dec 10! :-)

Hi Jason. I just implemented your symbol of the 3 bars inside a circle here, in my Shift Freedom Glasses prototype that I finished right now. We were talking the other day about how to prototype it, i'd love to hear your feedback, and how we could design it better, as I don't consider myself a designer!Check it out: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/on-10th-dec-human-rights-day-exchange-your-profile-picture-for-the-shift-freedom-glasses-/Thanks :)

Brilliantly simple.  Unlike many other concepts yours does not assume that the detainee has access to any certain technology. The challenge of keeping awareness from perpetrators may not be easily solved, but maybe targeting awareness through social networks of groups like Amnesty can be a starting point?  As in "anyone politically active, and their friends and social networks, should know this symbol..."Does anyone know the story of how SOS became universally recognized?  I don't and wonder if there's anything to be learned.
Thanks Jennifer. I agree, investigating into the adoption of SOS would be beneficial...i was actually surprised to find out that it isn't an acronym or abbreviation of anything!

I love the concept Jason! According to Wikipedia, "SOS" was standardized in the early 1900s as the universal distress signal by the International Radiotelegraphic Convention. Interestingly, the signal does not appear to be currently recognized as the formal distress signal by any regulatory or standard-issuing body. Though I would argue it is the most widely recognized symbol of distress, in any context. I wonder if any research has been done on the informal, near-universal adoption of SOS among civilians.A couple interesting observations about SOS, perhaps to guide the formation of any universal symbol:- It can be read right-side up and upside down, making it ideal for aerial viewing- It can be delivered either visually or aurally (through Morse code, in this case)- It is not language specific.Keep up the good work!

SOS and 911 are our most universal distress calls, but are they so universal that they could be counted on in all languages, and for detainment in any given (likely remote) location? If I were detained in a place where I don't speak the language, and come across some bystander who has no idea what's going on, I'd trust that they might understand what a smiley face means over any language or symbolic statement. Maybe better than symbolic communication would be something like an easy to draw and easily recognizable anguished face.

The symbol could also be tweeted to indicate distress and add details. For example:#OIII 852,8,15,14,7,11,15,14,7,16,18, 9,19,15,14,1,22,9 http://twitter.com/#!/avisolo/status/129312815944183808#OIII is the Universal distress hashtag on Twitter852 indicates country phone code8,15,14,7,11,15,14,7,16,18, 9,19,15,14,1,22,9  is simple A1 gematria for "Hong Kong Prison Avi"The recurrent problem is how to avoid punishment being inflicted on the detainee if the message is discovered by the captors.

Avi I think adding a little cipher after a universal twitter hashtag is brilliant! Excuse my ignorance but I clicked through your link and see that several people have used #OIII - is it already in use for something? I'll be synthesizing a few of these "universals" in an update and will definitely include the twitter hashtag + code. Great idea!

I am attending Pecha Kucha in Tokyo tonight, which reminded me of a great global concept which uses symbolic numbers in a very clever and memorable way: The event starts at 20.20 (8.20 PM) and each presentation consist of 20 slides which last for 20 seconds. This made me think what we could do with your III idea.Here are some ideas: (*please build upon these!)- Create a Day of Memory on 1.11 or on 11.1.- Create a daily memory at 1.11 PM- Create an event on 11.1 where each presentation is 11 minutes- Create an exhibition about illegal detention where each image is on digital display, and is shown for 1 min 11 seconds

thanks Anne for sharing. I like the idea of symbolic numbers. I also like the idea of 111 as being the symbolic number of the unlawful detention number. It could also become the universal emergency number: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/universal-emergency-number/

Love it Anne(s)! I totally agree, we have some really cool dates coming up to launch these campaigns (including http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/on-10th-dec-human-rights-day-exchange-your-profile-picture-for-the-shift-freedom-glasses-/ )I like the idea of using 111 as the universal number, it's a shame that 1 is such a long Morse code pattern. I used i's for my example which is 2 dits...I'm sure we can come up with a clever combination
Awesome build Anne! Considering that final concepts are selected on December 2nd, there might be enough time ( a little over a month ) to pull off an inaugural "Day of Memory" on 1/11 !
LOVE IT! Great idea. So simple and so clean, so easy to remember. So easy to hide if you need to, so easy for people to recognize if they are "in the know"

Jason, as a way to spread the III universal symbol, I'm wondering if there would not be a way to collaborate with Anne's shift freedom campaign:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/shift-freedom-sticker-sign-up-campaign/Imagine a sticker on the keyboard with shift III?just a thought...al

Absolutely, I've just commented on her really wonderful design...oh wow, I just now understood your "shift III" (sorry, dense). I think that's a great idea. It could almost be a follow-up to her "Shift Freedom" keyboard campaign...Anne's campaign develops the mental framework so later the word "freedom" can be transposed in various circumstances with the yet-to-be-named universal symbol. I like!

great...sorry for the confusion with the "III". maybe the triplets could be good... or a play on word between "free" and "three" ... It could be a follow up campaign or it could be shift freedom and then the universal symbol as a trademark symbol.

I love the idea, and the concern for simplicity. But I am wondering: how can someone who is unlawfully detained get this out to someone who can interpret it? I have no real experience with being detained, but it seems to me that one challenge would be communication with the outside world, especially if you're held in a facility that is remote and/or has high walls around it. Just thinking out loud, here :)

Hi Jason!I LOVE this idea.It really focuses on the low-tech implementation to solve this challenge that is so very important: Designing the Communication on Unlawful Detention / Problems. Vincents' comment below touches on a crucial aspect - Educating : "How can we increase awareness of this symbol amongst potential detainees & bystanders?", I was inspired by the Ghana Think Tank as a possible solution/idea for this problem: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/thinktanks/ . I know it might not easily avoid detection as it is so out there in the physical world... But I like the potential of education the population about this new Symbol to the world through a 'Mobile Unit' like the think tank. You could easily distribute pamphlets and info, and also have a digital platform to share it too.

Wow, very smart idea Jason! Reminds me of Hobo Code ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hobo#Hobo_.28sign.29_code ).One thing I'm pondering. How can we increase awareness of this symbol amongst potential detainees & bystanders that could help, while also avoiding detection by the perpetrators?
Thanks Vincent! Good call on the Hobo Code and as Anne-Laure mentioned it would be nice to incorporate this same type of surreptitiousness.

Hmm...have something that's tangentially related, that I thought would be relevant to share here. Recently, there was a logo design challenge to create a universal human rights logo: http://humanrightslogo.net/ . The winning open source logo was selected from >15,000 submissions by a crowd voting process combined with a ~40 person esteemed jury that included Nobel Peace Prize Laureates (Muhammad Yunus, Aung San Suu Kyi, Jimmy Carter, Shirin Ebadi...), designers/artists (Candy Chang...), human rights activists (Ai Weiwei...), etc.
It could also be easy to write the 3 Is in braille. I really like this idea!

I love the idea of a symbol simple and easy to draw but I think the challenge is to organize a form of this symbol have some additional tools. Ai can think of sensing variables like geo location, Morse code, among others. You know what I mean? would be something simple to draw but if the person knows the fund could use to communicate and even to enter coordinates.
Wow  you're on a roll with fab, fresh ideas Jason! Good consideration of a wide range of communication channels.
Thanks!

So much of this discussion has been related to technology, but it is important to remember that technology is not (yet) universal.Thanks for this reminder - I'll try to keep thinking along those lines.

Nice idea... It will be the SOS of the unlawfully detained or like the 911 number: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/9-1-1/I can see how with time it would get adopted.One thing you might need to go with the visual is the label: SOS, 911 are powerful because they are easy to memorize and share...One question would be as mentioned by Vincent: how to make sure that the guards and other members of administration do not figure out what it means. Maybe the angry birds game of Vincent which is the cover for the amnesty observer app could be a source of inspiration on how to hide the sign:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-observer-app/
Oh I love the obfuscation idea...should definitely try to incorporate. I've also added the two images and the respective inspirations to the built upon section. Thanks Anne-Laure!

a_universal_unlawfully_detained_symbol_t.title: A Universal Unlawfully Detained Symbol - to spread in case of emergency

james_stockdale_leadership_lessons_from_.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: Amazing story Avi, thanks for sharing.

comments.text: Great stuff! Would be great if you could add a brief summary of the insights from this clip. Some of our users are on slow connections but would still like to get a sense of the Inspiration youve shared.

global_rescue.title: Global Rescue

_behind_the_bars_a_data_visualization_ca.description: Data Visualizations or Infographics have the immense power of communicating seemingly complex data into informative and memorable visuals that resonate with the individual and are easily sharable with a click.
_behind_the_bars_a_data_visualization_ca.creator: 2e5ee009c21e833dceee5d3e41bb9465

comments.text: Anna! Thank you for your hard work on this challenge. The Amnesty team really appreciated all of the insights you've added to the design process. Thank you, great work!

As the publisher of a weekly newspaper in a small town with limited resources, we would definitely publish infographics like the ones described in this concept if they were available free of charge or at a minimal price. Versions that printed well in black and white would be a major plus.

Anna this is concept an important component in raising awareness and motivation of individuals and groups. It is complementary to the emotive attraction of the stories and images. Together they provide a powerful source oi information and a basis for decisive action. Both can be adapted to low tech presentation and tailored to specific audiences yet fit neatly into an integrated technological solution too.

I like the concept a lot. I'm just curious what the call-to-action would actually be? In the case of pamphlets in-country, I like the "recourse" option - "what can you do if a family member is detained?" For the broader, more universal call-to-action, it really depends on your goal - are you going for a specific political goal like free detainees in x country, or a more global advocacy goal like fund Amnesty's existing programs? On the other hand, you could take the campaign cultural and make it more about awareness raising. In the absence of a clear theory of change, you'll probably want to tailor the message to your audience to encourage viral sharing (more details below). If you're going to go political, you've already provided a variety of options above. Once you determine what the infographic will be about, you can come up with a coherent and integrated ask. Just some food for thought: Is petitioning government officials the most productive? What would you be asking world leaders to do? Is there a list of countries you'd target and a clear metric for success for your campaign? What would people be donating to if you asked them to donate? What does "signing on to support" actually mean? Joining Amnesty?If broad cultural awareness is the most important factor to you, people tend to share when the piece of content helps tell a story about themselves to their social networks. Note the most viral campaign ever, the Swedish Hero campaign http://bit.ly/dkLMta; the recent success of http://slaveryfootprint.org/; and self-documenting craze spurred on by sites like http://daytum.com/.In this spirit, is there some way you could ask people where they live, how old they are, etc at the beginning, then have the infographic is tailored to them? One example of how this could be made more relevant to me: as a 25 year old  straight caucasian girl from America I'm % less likely to be detained compared to a 25 year old gay Nigerian man? It could be very cool interactive functionality... and sharable!

Hi Anna, great job on clarifying your concept and on the prototype.I was also thinking that infographics could be used for pamphlets to be distributed to local communities - to educate them on unlawful detention, or to explain them what to do (as an illustrated summary version of Amjad's A-Z guides). Nothing to change in your concept but more suggestions for broadening the audiences.

Agreed with Anne-Laure that you did an awesome job fleshing out this concept Anna! Also, I like her suggestion to provide info to local communities as well.Personally, though I'm definitely a believer in the power of visualization, I've been turned off by enough poorly done infographics, that "infographic" has become a buzz word that scares me.However, love how you've nailed down a concrete strategy of generating awareness/sharing, identified relevant information buckets to focus on, and mocked up some examples. You've converted me, despite my fear of that 11 letter word =P

Big Fan of info graphics!  Powerful way to tell a compelling story on many levels at one time, with lots of great ways to interact and extrapolate and scenario test and drill down for more detail and flip the perspectives around and .... Love your new key hole/face and the bars!

Hey Anna, visualizing.org is a pretty neat crowd-sourced resource. I think their visualization marathons and challenges (http://www.visualizing.org/open-challenges) are great at showing different combinations of data and highlighting an issue. Perhaps we can learn from what they do and adapt it for this challenge.
Yen, I've just checked the visualizing.org website and it is very interesting... worth exploring indeed!
Thanks, Yen. I am definitely looking at a crowd-sourced component to this.

Hi Anna, the expert panel was really impressed with the potential of this idea to create clear communications from the data and facts that Amnesty collects. How you might you envision using technology to build on this concept further?  As an initial prototype of this idea, we wonder if you or the community would be interested in taking an Amnesty report and prototyping it as a visualisation.

Thanks! Yes, I will definitely work on the prototype and flesh out the concept to incorporate technology (i.e. crowd-sourcing knowledge, resources, social sharing,  etc.... Any reports or data that you have will help me.
I'm also very open to suggestions from the community!
Prototyping a report is a great idea!  Happy to help if you need.
Hey Anna, if you find you need any help with prototyping, I'd love to get involved.
Hi Amanda - Would love any help you have to offer.

Anna,as you are collecting data for a prototype, I was thinking that a model for the use of visualization could be Nicholas Felton: http://feltron.com/He publishes an individual annual report... Amnesty could do this.There could also be intermediate versions, more like "dashboards".You could imagine using the website suggested by Yen which organized open challenges on data visualization for the first report.Check out a website created by Felton to collect and present data. It might be useful in the prototyping phase:http://daytum.com/feltron

Hi Anna,I just found this link of an interactive map. I thought it could be interesting for your project : http://www.heritage.org/research/projects/china-global-investment-tracker-interactive-mapAlso, maybe you already know it but here is a great software to create and share your own graphic maps : http://mapbox.com/all the best for the rest of your project !

Hi Anna,nice idea. I agree that infographics / data visualization is a powerful tool to inform and increase awareness.When I read your post, I also thought of the infographics I found on text messaging: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/planet-text-texting-for-good-/I also believe that there is a storytelling component in infographics which, as highlighted by many, is important.I think that it could be quite low key - billboards, pamphlets, posters, maybe even postcard. They could also be online on Amnesty's website. As you noted the data could be easy to get from Amnesty International website or from platform like Ana's infographic crowdsourcing.You could think of Ana's vending machines or the Shift III van to distribute the pamphlets / posters/ postcards.A few inspirations and concepts you might want to build upon:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/making-policy-public/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-vending-machine-info-hub/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-iii-shift-van-/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/story-telling-in-any-way-possible/As you mentioned, there are many different angles one could use to choose which data to visualize. Maybe you could try to think of somewhat more specific data you think could be highlighted. You've already started doing that but I was wondering if you had some more specific ideas. thanks!

Thanks to all! I will work on developing this concept a bit further within the next few days to address stakeholders, channel planning, partners. messaging,  as well as the insights you have provided!
Looking forward to seeing it developing! :-)
Nice one Anna  we love agile Concepts! And if you've got any questions for Amnesty that might help you & others out  ask them here: http://bit.ly/ask_amnesty

Infographics remind me of the "A3" reports that we use in machine maintenance to give a snapshot of a breakdown. In a single page, it includes the symptom, problem, solution and number of occurrences and it is a powerful tool in terms of visual impact and also compression of information in low tech situations. Also, it is easy to make it multilingual by using the same template so it reduces costs. Btw, a couple of examples:http://nicolasrapp.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/ice.jpghttp://www.deportationnation.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/sc_graphic_final2.jpgAmnesty can also include a line about feedback or calls to action. Like a phone number to call, a website to visit or an event to attend.

nice examples Ashwin and interesting analogy with the A3 reports.I agree that visuals are great because they can be more easily multilingual and in some cases, also be understood despite a low level of literacy.

Hi Anna ! Liking your thoughts on Data Visualization : "not only educate, but create awareness" as you mention yourself. Your points are definitely something we could incorporate into my Interactive Info graphic concept. I also like how you finish mentioning a low-tech version of this by creating public advertising such as billboards and flyers to inform in the physical world, what we publish online. Maybe we could also distribute these as flyers on A-L's Shigt Van ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-iii-shift-van-/ )
and flyers could also be distributed in your amnesty international vending machines! :-) http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-vending-machine-info-hub/

Hi Anna,I love your concept!  I think infographics would be valuable for the purpose you have highlighted, "to not only educate, but create awareness and provide a call to action."  I think another valuable use for the infographics you suggested, (I am particularly thinking of your suggestions regarding cell phones here) would be to use that information to inform the development of aid efforts.  For instance, if we knew how many people have used their cell phones to report human rights abuses (and why those numbers look the way they do; i.e., is the app technology not available? or is it because few people have cell phones?), we could better direct some of the efforts on OpenIDEO regarding cell phone apps etc.  Looking forward to seeing this develop using some of the suggestions below!

_behind_the_bars_a_data_visualization_ca.title: "Behind the Bars" - A Data Visualization Call-to-Action Campaign

Facebook (and other social medias) are great tools for connecting people. Facebooks groups and events features could help groups communicate and the event feature can help people congregate.
Also, Twitter is often used as a crisis notification system

comments.text: Hi Scott, welcome to OpenIDEO and cheers for your great inspiration. Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update this' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!

social_networking_opens_infinite_possibi.title: Social Networking Opens Infinite Possibilities for Communication

singapore_curry_day_a_viral_facebook_eve.description:
"You cannot cook curry at home because of the SMELL!" It started from a dispute.
"Cook and share a pot of curry" - A Facebook event page created by a group of friends in Singapore to make 21st Aug, Singapore's National Curry day.
singapore_curry_day_a_viral_facebook_eve.creator: b040eb0c0f44f11cac47de393dfb7bc8

comments.text: I, too, appreciate the way one can make a cultural statement through a simple activity like cooking.
Great example of unity, connection and amplification over a specific issue, Yanlingyian!

singapore_curry_day_a_viral_facebook_eve.title: Singapore Curry day - A viral Facebook event by the people for the country

eric_berlow_how_complexity_leads_to_simp.creator: 03eeb3724131478a1376885494e2e4a3

comments.text: Great inspiration. So, could we have a session with Amnesty (like in the oi_grameen challenge, to ask questions about this, and maybe start with drafting a diagram like Mr Berlow uses?
Happy to hear that this has been such an inspiration for you guys! Thanks for letting me be involved!

What a fab inspiration Abbey! I loved how Eric says that "simplicity often lies on the other side of complexity" and that the answers are often there if we can step back and embrace complex systems as a whole. Really relevant and inspiring for our work here.

eric_berlow_how_complexity_leads_to_simp.title: Eric Berlow: How Complexity Leads to Simplicity

helpme_2013_a_single_push_pull_informati.description: A single platform which on receiving a push or a pull trigger (#helpme) searches and  list last 5 activities from various communication platforms like social networking sites , check-in , SMS,GPS and inform or broadcast  the mapped area (based on last 5 activities) to public or predetermined organizations
helpme_2013_a_single_push_pull_informati.creator: bc92bdeedfb779dc6d95f9668712e026

comments.text: Very cool concept, and a good use of the current technology.  I believe this concept can be easily applied to our information age

This is a great concept because there are so many different online social networks out there, and to reach all of them with one single motion would be effective in reaching the maximum amount of people for the most awareness of the issue. (Wells College Innovation Lab)

This concept seems like it would be the easiest way to get a moblie "smoke signal" out to the internet world. I like this idea more than using an app on a phone. A simple message can go a long way. Great idea!
We like the multifunctionality of this approach. It is similar to an idea that we are working on although the catalyst and some of the key features differ.

Avneet,  I hope you have the patience to view the video I posted about Collaborating with the UN project Global Pulse.  They are using the concepts that you have presented to build a platform to capture "digital smoke signals".  They have an open source project called HunchWorks.  Standing on the shoulders of the Giant UN.

Nice concept Avneet. It builds nicely on various channels. I also like the simplicity of the action, which makes it easy to act. This is particularly important in the reporting phase. People might see something happening but they won't necessarily take the time (and risk) to go and report the person.
Thanks a Lot Anne.....the reporting of missing was meant for near and dear one's of the person wrongly detained.Apologies for not making it clear
Thanks for the clarification. It still does not take away the simplicity of the action. :-)
Awesome idea Avneet. A simple low-tech SMS flare, nicely done. Maybe the service could incorporate an #a-ok feature for an accidental text or change in circumstance?
Thanks A lot Jason.....a very amazing and elegant idea to curb accidental or prank triggers....will try to incorporate this.

This could be a very efficient new "9-1-1"! Really great idea Avneet. Wonder how the language issues can translate into this concept... Maybe adopting something more universal, like "SOS", would be better in this case?

Good point Sarah. SOS could be an option, or using Jason's universal symbol for unlawful detention: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-universal-unlawfully-detained-symbol-to-spread-in-case-of-emergency/
Totally agree with you this will help solve the language barrier......Thanks
Fab thoughts, Avneet! We're loving that your idea is multi-channel and considers a variety of scenarios.
Thanks a lot Meena, This is my first challenge, having  fun time learning..

helpme_2013_a_single_push_pull_informati.title: HelpMe – a single push-pull information platform

comments.text: Interesting. Especially if you think of people that have access to open spaces. It also means that non-commercial satellites who capture images of distress signals need to spread them. I have a feeling that commercial satellites are not able to pick up everything.

group_sms_messaging.description: A service like Group Me (http://groupme.com/) can be used in dangerous times to notify immediately a group of friends or family. This service accommodates 50 people on a list and can anonymize numbers.  It can be used to mobilize/coordinate too.
group_sms_messaging.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: This is a truly handy idea that has the capabilities to be utilized quickly and discreetly. My one question is its availability world wide.Is this a technology that would need to be on a "Global Phone"? Since a number of the devices offered on our cells is centralized to a certain country. Just curious, I do love the idea and how straight forward it is.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration  and for starting work at IDEO this week!

Great stuff Sina & here's a relevant discussion on GroupMe being used for emergency preparedness: http://www.paulnilsen.com/2011/09/05/using-groupme-com-for-emergency-preparedness/Bringing back fond memories of when we first noticed you posting gems like this way back on the Maternal Health challenge!

Sina, this is a great inspiration... i like the fact that it can be used in low tech environments (see the impact of mobile phones in Ghana, in the case of spreading false information... so when it comes to sharing true and important information...). It nicely speaks to the idea of networks and roles of connectors in spreading the word. Very nice!
Oh, wow. Great inspiration, Sina!
Yes, nice application of this!

a_chinese_story_liu_xiaobo_and_the_river.description: How many local Chinese are aware that Liu Xiaobo won the Nobel Peace Prize?
a_chinese_story_liu_xiaobo_and_the_river.creator: 1bb16f6763a5721942a54d77ef055adc

comments.text: I am sure there are few chinese local people heard this guy, and less people known he got the Nobel Peace Prize. Chinese government tried to block this news for political reasons, I know it sounds ridiculous. Government did not feel this Nobel Peace Prize could bring any proud to them. However, technology method like internet, still spread this news to all of the world.I have to say, facing one country's regime, there something has to be sacrifice, and commonly, would be human rights.

Absolutely, thanks for bringing this up Dan! Also, remember that it's not just censorship of information. It's also censorship of perspectives, self-censorship, and at some point, the party line is the general known & accepted line (alternative is not even considered as likely).
Vincent, excellent point on self-censorship.  Even with external controls - censorship - lifted, how might we re-inspire free speech - or blow away the dust of complacency?

Callum, thanks for the comment.  It will be interesting to see how things unfold as the middle class continues to grow and spread throughout the 2nd, 3rd, etc tier cities. China is a fascinating example - actually more similar to the U.S. than many care to see.

Dan, thanks for sharing this article with us. I hope others check it out  it's a really interesting account of how censorship can impact human rights. It also raises a thought-provoking question: how might we successfully raise citizen awareness of human rights violations  when the available news and information is censored?
Thanks Asheley.  I found the articles linked within this one also interesting.  ..you're new question has really got me thinking...
A great challenge to our community, Ashley  and one that I hope some will consider during the upcoming Concepting phase. Way to go Dan for highlighting these issues.

Hi, I completely agree this is an important question which once against reminds us that we will have to think of local contexts in many different ways. The article also shows how it is not only Liu Xiaobo but his wife, friends and relatives who are also "detained" or "restricted" in their freedom of action. Thanks Dan for sharing this article and Ashley for starting this important discussion.

a_chinese_story_liu_xiaobo_and_the_river.title: A Chinese Story: Liu Xiaobo and the River Crabs

action_tokens.description: Action Tokens bridge local community action with supporters of the unlawfully detained.  Although Action Token participants and supporters may be thousands of miles away from each other, participants can still express their concern, and supporters do not have to feel like they are alone.
action_tokens.creator: 4f5f1a586212bdf010ad856feb3e0c36

comments.text: Hi Andrea I think this is a really cool idea...it reminded me of the "wheresgeorge" website where people can track $1 bills. I think both physical and virtual tokens are great ways to implement...as you mentioned they'll provide some really interesting visualizations on a tracking site as they they travel around. Maybe you could add a "paths to release" feature to highlight successful tokens. It might also be nice to give visitors to the tracking site the ability to support&copy a token to amplify the number of paths. Nice concept!

Jason, I had not thought about virtual tokens, but I think that makes a lot of sense.  It would be a great way for friends who are not in the same physical location to share the experience of taking action.  Also, I can imagine them being dispersed via social media; perhaps a token icon on participants' Facebook pages?  I also really like the idea of highlighting tokens that are moving particularly well.  Not only would it provide helpful data, but I think it would be a great motivator for participants.
Great thinking and visualisation, Andrea!
Andrea, I do like the "pass it on" core of your idea, and am thinking that perhaps a physical token may provide additional weight & commitment vs. just a virtual ask/forward. Nice!

action_tokens.title: Action Tokens

detainee_support_parties.description: Given the desire for anonymity, perhaps introductions between law students, families, and activists could occur at one-time events, or "parties".
detainee_support_parties.creator: 7905b5813c35371a21bcc668945f61d5

comments.text: Nice one Alix.Connecting people face to face can help build relationships & trust.Security/Privacy is also key where these types of gatherings are likely to be persecuted.
Good point, Vincent. I'll think more about that.

detainee_support_parties.title: Detainee Support Parties

visible_car_sticker.description: "Support our Soldiers" stickers were sold to acknowledge the contribution of the Danish soldiers.
visible_car_sticker.creator: 046c14ccc821e094ab37859494deeacc

comments.text: I like your leap from public support of soldiers to public support of detainees. At least in the US, there have been several effective campaigns to honor those who serve in the military and their families and raise public awareness of their struggles when they return home.These campaigns overcome some similar difficulties as any campaign to connect detainees with the public would  - they are far away, you do not personally know them, the battle zone is so different from the comfort of your own home, you do not know what to do to help. One big difference is that generally soldiers are culturally praised whereas detainees may be guilty of crimes against the public.Are there other ways we can learn from "support the military campaigns"?  How can we shift the issue away from public support of detainees (who may be guilty of heinous acts) to public support of lawful and humane detainment?

visible_car_sticker.title: Visible car sticker

caller_tunes_to_spread_the_word..description: How to use an available medium to communicate a message. The caller tune is a way to spread a voice.
caller_tunes_to_spread_the_word..creator: 97b8ff32fd53531b6d32f5729d47ea1c

comments.text: Hi team Chimera, indeed an interesting idea to develop.In terms of inspiration, I remember going to a talk by Genevieve Bell (an anthropologist at Intel) where she was presenting their ethnographic studies of people use of cell phones all other the world. She was explaining how in some developed countries (she cited a specific example in Africa), people will develop a set of rings practice: ring one and then hang up, "all is fine"; ring two and then hang up means "no emergency but can you call me back"; ring 1 then ring 1 again means "i've sent you some money; you should get the transfer soon", etc. (btw I'm making up the code). It was like a morse code. This leads you then to concepting: developing ring tone for public awareness or maybe, as suggested by Meena below, to support communication between friends, families and supporters.Looking forward to more inspirations and to great concepts,al

And as we get closer to Concepting  you may want to draw inspiration from posts like this in regards to potential communications between friends, families & supporters: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/group-sms-messaging/ Bring it on, Team Chimera!

Sounds great guys, hope you'll repost it in the upcoming Concepting phase too  maybe with further development after taking in all the gems posted in the Inspiration phase. Fantastic that your group is interested in spreading the word about unlawful detention amongst the general public. And we hope you'll also consider how communication channels may help the detained themselves plus their friends, families and supporters. So much to think about  and we're excited to have your group thinking on all these issues!

caller_tunes_to_spread_the_word..title: Caller Tunes to spread the word.

medical_alert_monitoring_devices.description: Many medical devices exist, either in pendant form, bracelet, or subcutaneous (below the skin) that provide tracking and monitoring to emergency services and loved ones. These devices are particularly useful for people at risk and living alone.
medical_alert_monitoring_devices.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Very interesting thought. Maybe in the form of jewellery?
I have been thinking in terms of something that is potentially edible. This way it could not be confiscated and human waste does not always travel far, if it does its monitored in some form.

My Grandparents have this for themselves because they have gotten very old and have fallen without help before they had this. It has turned out to be very useful for them, and I think that it could be very useful in this situation as well. Great Idea!

Hi Nathan!Great inspiration and topic to come across, especially as I am very close to my family and especially concerned with my elderly family, who would greatly benefit from having a non evasive technological kind of 'alert' system for their well being at the moment. The problem is that generation isn't as digitally literate as the ones after them.I was searching some medical care apps and came across this article on The Wall Street Journal about some of the best apps out there, for senior's medical care, it's worth checking out: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704111504576060041940701926.htmlApps are one thing that means you have to have a digital equipment with you, but if you could have some kind of device linked to your brain activity, or heart function, (thinking quite into the future maybe) it would be interesting. Anyhow, great to read interest from other people on this topic!
I really like this idea. I don't think it could be used as jewelry or anything worn, as it would most likely be confiscated.

Yes, but I was thinking some sort of bracelet that has an unlock code. If the code is not used, then a message is automatically sent to the support network. The fact that it would be confiscated is the trigger for the alarm, so to speak.
Hmm...nice idea Arjan. Also have to think about concealing the existence of the alarm & code mechanism. Otherwise there may be attempts to force the person to enter the code.

Brilliant Arjan. You many not even need an unlock code, as the wearer would want it on him at all times. There would be no need to remove it ever, really. So it should be activated upon removal OR activated by the wearer (pushing a button or some such).

Yes, Vincent, and Brian. That was exactly what I was thinking about. Some sort of way that it gets activated upon removal. And code not necessarily being a PIN code, but a way of opening, or losing touch with skin, or...

It could be paired with an subcutaneous device and when they are separated it gets activated. So no code and no evidence. We could also think of shoes or clothes that could contain the 'external' device.

medical_alert_monitoring_devices.title: Medical alert / monitoring devices

evening_news_on_tv_as_thermometer.description: It is very interesting to see in what order the news headlines are presented at the beginning of the evening news. Or what story will cover the front page of the tabloids, and which important events get stuck between sports section and cartoons.
evening_news_on_tv_as_thermometer.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: This is an issue partially because of advertising dollars supporting the networks that host news programs. It is in their best interest to not always push stories that might make people feel bad or guilty about their luck in terms of geographic location. If someone is unhappy, they're unlikely to buy the new denim-styled baby diapers that are displayed during the commercials.Again, I know this is a small part of the reason, but one that eneds to be considered when looking at how to notify the world of truly important events.Have a nice day. :)

Johan, good points. And the thing is, I'm afraid, that in a way these editors have a point. In general, their viewers are more interested in the topics that are closer to home. An interesting example from recent politics in Latvia tells this story quite well, I think. Earlier this year, the then president moved to dissolve parliament, because they refused to cooperate in a corruption inquiry, and did not grant the anti-corruption agency access to the home of a member of parliament. This all happened close to the presidential election, in which the parliament choses the next president. The move was a 'career-suicide' for the president of course, and he did not get reelected. The people voted later indeed to dissolve parliament in an overwhelmingly clear vote. This all was huge news in Latvia, and had all the ingredients of being a news story of European interest: in the EU, corruption by members of parliament, a courageous president. You name it.And the mentions of his move in the European press: well, at that time there was virtually no attention. People in Europe, especially Western Europe, simply do not care that much about the former soviet republics, but more about Greece and Italy, where they go on holiday and that directly influence the value of their pay checks as also members of the Euro.And as an editor of a news show, you are evaluated by the ratings, so you show what you think the people want to see; thus creating a vicious circle.
Thanks for sharing your thoughts, concerns and insights here Johan. Really interesting questions that certainly made me pause and think!

evening_news_on_tv_as_thermometer.title: Evening news on TV as thermometer

30_days_in_jail_morgan_spurlock.description: In his documentary series, 30 Days, Morgan Spurlock gives viewers a behind-the-scenes look of his personal experience in jail. Interesting watch to create empathy for what it means to give up personal freedoms.
30_days_in_jail_morgan_spurlock.creator: b22c8efc945511851a0f7098f6bd753e

comments.text: Can not imagine what is going on in the next days in jail. But it's no doubt that is feeling powerlessness and fear.
Great inspiration Nathalie - makes me want to watch the whole episode :)
Great post!! This is the same guy who ate at McDonald's for 30 days

Having grown up in the Netherlands, there's sometimes that creeps up on my, imposed by my fellow country men (and women) that jail is not so bad. Prisons in the Netherlands tend to be on the luxurious side, and people who have never been in one tend to think it's not a real punishment. For those, it's hard to feel empathy, even if it concerns unlawfully detained people in prisons that are far less comfortable. Stories like this are hopefully changing that. Plus, you've inspired me to share something else as well!

That's interesting to hear, Arjan! It's a good point that detainment experiences can vary greatly throughout the world and that the truth behind the stereotype is often misunderstood. Glad this could inspire you to more ideas. :)

30_days_in_jail_morgan_spurlock.title: 30 Days in Jail - Morgan Spurlock

on_10th_dec_human_rights_day_exchange_yo.description: To celebrate this years International Human Rights Day, let's all switch our profile pictures on social networks with one of ourselves with the 'Shift Freedom' glasses. Calling all human rights defenders to keep their eyes open for any suspicious activities in their local communities, while also raising the awareness of unlawful detention, and the fight for  ending discrimination world wide.
on_10th_dec_human_rights_day_exchange_yo.creator: 890278307fec5590e0f5982a2de58e38

comments.text: Hello everyone!I know this concept did not reach the refinement phase, but I am still interested in making it reality.Is there anyone else out there who would also be interested in wearing the glasses on the upcoming days to 10th Dec, and if there are any further suggestions for improvement to release this idea ?  I will be replacing my profile pictures in social media for one wearing these glasses and explaining why. If you will also be joining me, let me know! Thanks :)
Love the idea! It is so easy and cheap to do, it is catchy, memorable, highly viral AND has a global reach

Hi Anne!Thanks a lot for the energy. If you have any feedback on how to propagate and share these glasses, a mix of yours Jason's and my concept, please feel free to share and help improve this concept :) Thanks.

Ana, agreed with all comments below. I love the idea and the prototype. I will definitely be wearing them on December 10. I'll also distribute them around for people to wear them... It could also be nice to be able to add the logo as a signature in any email we send that day...

Thanks A-L for the enthusiasm too, i'm really thrilled with the comments and feedback. Wow thanks... if you think we could improve this in anyway let me know, and what best way would be to share the glasses, and SPREAD the news of this campaign BEFORE the 10th Dec ?Yes... great idea! Include the logo with any digital communication had maybe from 8- 11th Dec, so it is well built upon? That is definitely something I'd like to 'stick' on me signature !If Jason and the rest of the community agree on one major U.U.Symbol for now ( the circle with the three bars through the middle) this is a great start to start planning analogue (posters maybe?) and digital communication leading up to the 10th Dec!It would be great to think of a way to measure the impact we make through adopting the usage of these Shift Freedom Glasses to spread awareness... do you have any ideas how we could measure that?:) thanks again!
Way to go on the prototype!

I just updated this concept with a prototype in the form of Downloadable Shift Freedom Glasses - incorporating Jason's Unlawful Detainee Symbol + Anne's 'Shift Freedom' name ! So this would be ready to be placed on the Amnesty Website for anyone to download prior to the 10th Dec, and exchange their profile pictures for one with you wearing these glasses!Please feel free to give feedback on my prototype and how to develop it.Thank u!

Ana you're a natural! Your design is great and I have to agree with Sarah I think the bright colors really add a nice twist. Not sure how best to share pictures so I added a sketch to the Universal Symbol concept. They reminded me of those 80s shutter glasses...takes a little bit more cutting, but we can always have multiple designs for people to download. I definitely think we can get this going for Dec. 10th!

Thanks a lot for the feedback Jason. As I just wrote to you, I love your Shift Freedom Glasses with the U.U.Symbol as the lenses..very good way to implement the symbol.Glad to hear your opinion on the color of the glasses. I think it's also interesting to offer more than one downloadable option- but it will be important to have a constant recognizable theme in them - which I imagine to be your U.U.Symbol!Excited to see where this could take us in a month's time. Thanks for the enthusiasm, really gives me energy too!
Great idea Ana! Love the prototype :) You can count on me to wear this for (or even before) December 10th!

Hi Sarah! Thanks so much for the energy!I hope we could improve the prototype with someones much better design skills than mine.. and make it more appealing! Thanks for this :) I'll be wearing them too. I look forward to hear everyone's opinion on how to develop this concept!

Actually what I like about it the most is that it's fun and quirky. Most of the times, talking about unlawful detention is very serious and grave. Making it colorful, and playing around with it in Facebook and Twitter profile pictures could help spreading the word out.On that note, I have an idea... I don't know if you've seen those default Twitter backgrounds, sometimes some of them feature a specific message (I remember mainly the red one about AIDS in Africa). What if the Shift Freedom Glasses were made into a Twitter background? It could have only one sentence (something like "To Shift Freedom, Wear These Glasses on December 10"), along with the link where the DIY glasses can be downloaded.

Yes Sarah, that is a great idea... if we could get a lot of people geared up to this day and ready to place this as their background BEFORE the 10th, it would generate a lot of awareness!I know Facebook also has that way of changing your small pictures at the top (like ure latest tagged ones) and change them into sentence or  a group of funny images that together mean something. That is also another way. I love your idea, and sounds very doable! Thanks for your feedback on the glasses, I guess it's true, the more 'approachable' we make the subject of this concept, the better received and talked about it will become!
How about both the Twitter background AND the Facebook pictures? :) I can work on a rough visual prototype for both sometime next weekend if you want.

Hi Sarah!Absolutely... the more prototypes the merrier!! so we could have two ways of spreading awareness on this day - through the profile picture and changing Twitter backgrounds + Facebook Photo tabs.I'd love to see your prototype when you have time! Write it to me here or Tweet me :)Thanks Sarah, looking forward to see this develop!

What a fun and smart concept! I love how you've built on the work of others and devised an idea that's both easy and eye-catching. Perhaps it's worth thinking about whether we could all help prototype this idea on December 10, 2011?! :)

Hi Ashley, thanks for your comment !Exactly, I really wanted to think a bit more simple here as my other concepts were a bit more complex, and harder to turn into reality unfortunately.. so this one I hope could get everyone on board (in the whole world maybe?!)ABSOLUTELY, the aim is for everyone to get involved somehow from the raising awareness of this day, to designing and creating the Glasses and the Logos to display on our profiles. I'd love if we could turn this into reality, I think it could be quite doable, with a good message incorporated behind it !
I'm loving your continued iteration on this concept - and that anyone could download and cut out their own glasses! Great work on this Ana.

Hi Ashley thank u!I hadn't had time yet to make a prototype and design some 'real' glasses so here they are, did them this afternoon! Let's see what everyone else's thought is. Glad to hear your feedback!Maybe we could design our own ones, but personalize our message on the Amnesty Website before the 10th? Like so we wouldn't be completely stuck to one message and phrase through the glasses.

Hey Ana I was just thinking a bit more about these glasses and maybe some version could be handed out pre/during protests...sort of preemptive symbols to unscrupulous detainers that wearers know their  rights??

Hi Jason! Great idea.... so it could become a peaceful universal signage to spread, together with your Universal Unlawfully Detained Symbol at these protests? I think it's great! And I really think we can create a universal and coherent communication design between Anne's Shift Freedom Keyboard concept, your Symbol, and my Glasses for the 10th of Dec ! Maybe we could think of creating a prototype for this 'connected communication' later on, taking into account everyone's suggestions + improvements? Thanks for the energy Jason!!
Love this concept Ana!  Very simple and cost-effective, but also very efficient in terms of getting the word out.  Great idea :)

Hi Amanda! Thanks for your positivity! Great pointing out the cost-effective part... hopefully everyone interested could all get involved with a very low cost involved. Excited to see what everyone else thinks and how we could turn this into reality!
Such a great idea, simple, catchy and downloadable! I'd love to see all those profile pics updated with Shift glasses. Nice work!

Hi Jason!Thanks for the heads up. You indeed capture what I most aim with this concept: Simple and Doable! The 10th of Dec is not far, and if we all design a much better pair of Glasses than I did, with a catchy color and memorable design, it's something that we could easily do next month.I was thinking maybe your logo of Unlawful Detention could be 'world premiered' on this day too, through these glasses. Maybe you have a better design suggestion as for the substitute picture? I'm going to update this concept soon with a better picture of the glasses and the tagline 'Shift Freedom' so its easier to see !Thanks :)

on_10th_dec_human_rights_day_exchange_yo.title: On 10th December Human Rights Day : wear the 'Shift Freedom' Glasses

alert_mobile_system_for_suscribes_under_.description: Subscriber pings the system every period of time.  If the subscriber stops "pinging" the system, this one sends a sequence of smart alerts to a series of organizations (previously determined).  Inspiration: interruption-based security architecture.
alert_mobile_system_for_suscribes_under_.creator: f12c7f26c1955c557591c0bac98307d8

comments.text: This is great because so many people at risk would lose technology/communication if unlawfully arrested so something that uses that loss as the alert is what we need.
Thanks Hannah!  Yes, that's it.  Been arrested means been taken off ones regular flow (daily life), so it makes sense to transfer this nature of the problem / scenario to the potential solution.

Fab idea Alejandro! Be sure to hold on to this and re-post it during the Concepting phase that starts next week. For now, you mentioned that your inspiration for this is "interruption-based security architecture"  I know I'd love to hear more about what this is, and I bet others would too. Perhaps you'll post an Inspiration that explains what this means and provides some examples? Glad to have you onboard :)
Thanks Ashley!  Sure, I'll re-post it and evolve the concept (and I'll add some examples :)  )
Awesome  can't wait to see it!

google_latitude.description: With cellphone usage increasing throughout the world, applications such as this one could be a great way for acting as a GPS device for locating individuals.
