sponsor_a_spouse.description: Create a campaign similar to "Sponsor a Child" where people can learn about spouses' individual stories and donate directly to them. By radically shifting the webpage from statistics to emotional stories, viewers will care and contribute.
sponsor_a_spouse.creator: b901fbcd2a2de371a0a72d5d5b024e7f

comments.text: Elliott, great effort on this challenge. Thank you for your hard work. The Amnesty team felt that you could really take this idea forward as an independent charity. We really appreciate your contribution, and particularly liked your Mother Teresa quote. Thank you!

I'd like to reach out to the community to help me design this further. I will take your suggestions together and recreate the concept. Here are some questions that I'm wrestling with. Please let me know your thoughts. Let's make this awesome!0. Would anyone like to help me make a mock up interface to show how the information would be portrayed? I'm not really an interface designer.1. What would be important/emotional information that we should tell about a person? How does this change if the person needs to be anonymous?2. How should we show this information? A webpage/TV ad/???  Should we show all the spouses or just one?3. Should I name the program Sponsor a Spouse or Sponsor a family - money will go to the family, but I think family is too broad?4. How can we get money to anonymous spouses if they can't tell their story?5. How can we utilize technology to make this process accessible, anonymous, safe, and reliable?6. What excites you about this project? How could it be better?7. What questions haven't I asked?

I strongly recommend anyone interested in helping with this to look into psychological numbing. This article is really great for giving a clear picture.  http://www.sas.upenn.edu/~baron/journal/7303a/jdm7303a.htm

Hey Elliot, I notice that you've posted a new prototype.  It looks great!  You posted some good questions, I'll have to think about it.  Just wanted to stop by and let you know that the web pics look great :)

Hi Elliot,I agree with Amanda and will give this more consideration.Was the web page designed to replace Amnesty's home page?If not I think it should, or at least form a substantial part of it, perhaps in conjunction with a similar 'emotional' appeal for membership.Some of the criticisms in Ashwin Gopi's concept to Shift Amnesty's Image can be applied to the existing web page. The Appeals for Action, at least the headlines, have a strong imperative, even scolding, tone giving the reader the impression that somehow they (the reader) have shirked their responsibility. Im sure I am not alone in saying that the phrasing made me emotionally disengage from the issues. Had I not been committed to reading beyond the headlines for the purpose of this challenge I probably would have disengaged from the whole website.My personal feeling, based largely on life experience rather than learning or research, is that the process of gaining commitment is comes from:1. Emotional engagement (which is where your concept and ideas excel);2. Satisfy the resulting curiosity with broad general information, giving the reader/visitor a positive overview of Amnesty's work; then 3. Gain commitment by offering the reader/visitor a choice of ways to participate in positive outcomes.By positive outcomes I include any failures that can be learning experiences on which to build better prospects of ultimate success.Once you have commitment - then you can challenge people to deeper involvement with the more intractable issues - again offering different degrees or methods of involvement - physical, financial, emotional, legal, technological, political etc.

Thanks Amanda and Paul. Originally, I had designed this section just for the donation page, but I like the idea of making this an overall theme. There should be personal stories on the front page. I also think it's important that people can just become members they don't have to pay. Maybe there are other ways people can contribute?In my own experience, I'm finding most my peers are disengaged from this issue. It feels so distant to them, so I think we are heading in a good direction! Interestingly enough, research suggests that adding broader statistics to an emotional story actually decreases a desire to donate, which is a sad fact. But I do think statistics do help with getting political policy to change, where an emotional drive may not be enough.With this suggestion, you can create commitment by forming deep relationships between readers and a spouse. I feel that no matter how many facts we tell someone, they need to witness and feel the struggle.

Thanks for the comments Elliot - I am happy to accede to research findings - I guess I was not thinking about including general information in the stories rather than:The story emotionally engages the reader -> option to donate / or get to know more about Amnesty - where positive snippets of other areas in which Amnesty is doing good things give readers more reasons to commit.My main thinking was really that the present litany of human rights breaches is more likely to turn people 'off' than 'on'. when seeking commitment to the cause. Once people are commited then you can provide them with the issues together with the good news.Amnesty has a disadvantage compared to World Vision (et al) because of the added dimension of the variety of breaches of human rights. Your concept puts Amnesty at the same level in Maslow's heirarchy as World Vision - a point of entry to involvement that almost everyone recognises.
I really like that idea Paul of referencing this problem in terms of Maslow's hierarchy.

Hi Elliott,great work on the updates.Here are my replies to your questions:0. Would anyone like to help me make a mock up interface to show how the information would be portrayed? I'm not really an interface designer.al: I wish I could but I could not even do what you did. I think that you did a great job in giving us a feel of how it will look like. 1. What would be important/emotional information that we should tell about a person? How does this change if the person needs to be anonymous?al: I agree on the weight of making these stories real, rather than anonymous (thanks for the article on psychological numbing). Yet, anonymity as you noted in some cases might be required. I like your options of having a fund for the anonymous. I guess you could also have a section explaining why some families, spouses need anonymity and if well told, this story could make it "personal". 2. How should we show this information? A webpage/TV ad/??? Should we show all the spouses or just one?al: I think having specific stories with just one spouse each time will have more impact. I guess you should have a mix of all of this but this is the job of a media strategist / planner. It depends who is your target audience. You could also use the Shift van (scenario 2) to spread the word and potentially get some donations: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-iii-shift-van-/3. Should I name the program Sponsor a Spouse or Sponsor a family - money will go to the family, but I think family is too broad?al:  Sponsor a Spouse is stronger and the alliteration is nice. The only limit would be for specific donations for education... but I guess this is still helping the spouse who has to pay for the education of her children. 4. How can we get money to anonymous spouses if they can't tell their story?al: I like your suggestions of having part of the donations to a specific spouse going to the anonymous spouses. To still make it possible for people to choose, you could have the option to say, "No I want to sponsor only this spouse" (however it is unlikely that many people will choose this. Based on research on choice and decision making, it's important to do it this way, rather than the other way round).You could also imagine having the anonymous spouse and you could create a persona with a story inspired by stories of anonymous spouses. You could have an anonymous spouse per country.5. How can we utilize technology to make this process accessible, anonymous, safe, and reliable?al: not sure about this one... potentially Lei's concept of distributed network could help.6. What excites you about this project? How could it be better?al: I think it's simple and strong. It also reminds people of the implications for the spouses and families. From what I read in many inspirations, this is a real problem (survival when the husband has disappeared) and I think your concept can help tackle it.7. What questions haven't I asked?Not sure... I'll think about it. Yet, I think you've done a great job in refining your concept.

Just wanted to reinforce Anne-Laure's comments and answers:0. Your mock-up is better than I could do - we still need that talent/skills component to the platform so we can ask particular IDEATOR opinions and assistance.1. I guess the type of information used to inspire us in this challenge is a good guide. I also think that the stories should be examples (from real life) so that donors are encouraged to sponsor 'any' spouse, rather than 'a particular' spouse. Sponsorship shouldn't be like choosing a puppy for the children for Christmas.2. For a website I wopuld suggest a rotating presentation so that perhaps stories change between sessions (not every time a potential sponsor changes pages) although the front page could lead to a gallery of stories if people do want to choose on that basis.I also think linking the story presented on the website to any advertising campaign (using a story) would provide continuity to encourage sponsorship. Agaib here it would be good to have an IDEATOR with media experience provide input.3.Sponsor a Spouse - the alliteration and sibilance give the phrase real strength.4. I think using pseudonyms in the telling of the story would be acceptable. Many sponsors will accept this and indeed allow Amnesty to choose the 'spouse' being sponsored. As for communication between sponsor and 'spouse' it would follow the same model as World Vision and other organisations.5.I think we have to trust Amnesty's judgement - I dont imagine any stories being publicised without Amnesty putting in appropriate safeguards.6. The most exciting things about this from my point of view are:a) It is a way for many people to provide support where possibly there has been none before; andb) It will help to give Amnesty a 'shifted', more positive image.7. NothingYou have done a superb job!

Great work on the concept and refinement. I wanted to comment on the naming of the project. While the alliteration is strong, it is limiting to the potential scope of your vision. Beyond spouses, we must consider children, parents, siblings, even employees or community members. It may take more oversight, but the support could be customized for the situation. Some individuals may have no ties, but deserve support which could be directed per the individual's request. I'm not sure about another project name, but maybe Sponsor a Survivor or more of an active name such as Sponsor Strength or Funding Families. Admittedly, these don't resonate as well as Sponsor a Spouse but i'd rather your vision not be limited by the name.

I agree the potential may appear limited but personally feel the name Sponsor a Spouse has huge emotional appeal (almost as great as the already taken Sponsor a Child). It is a great psychological hook and, as with sponsoring a child, those who become engaged realise that the support will not be limited to a 'spouse' per se.

Regarding #1 (important/emotional information) --- I would think that anything that helps create an empathetic bond would be critical.  Simple demographic info ("this person is also a mother, like me!"), vingnettes that capture emotions (uncertainty, fear, grief, frustration, bewilderment), might also help "draw" readers in to share in the plight of your highlighted families?

Psychology research has shown that people who have a real face and a real name to see are far more likely to make a donation than to an anonymous face behind a pseudonym. How about focusing on success stories of people that have been reunited with their loved ones, and let potential contributors know that with their funds they can increase the number of these success stories. That way you could use real names and real photos. You could also include stories about how things didn't work out with specific names/faces and let people know that more funds would have made a difference at critical moments, if you feel that sort of campaign would be helpful.

I agree that a mix of positive success stories would help create a balanced emotional appeal.  If, as Paul Reader suggests, you had a rotating presentation of stories, you could then reserve a couple for success stories, or find a way to link successful examples into the stories of families in need (a couple sentences of how a donation could help Miriam's family be like "Amireh"s, with a link to Amireh's story etc.)

Oh!  Another thought.  If you were mounting a large campaign/had the capacity for real-time updates, you could incorporate specific milestones where X amount of funds would make a critical difference (in preparation for a court date for example).  This would be at odds with the 60/40 anonymity protection clause, but I do think that when visitors are given specific donation targets (and can see how close you are to reaching them), it can be motivating to donate.  Just a thought!
Making it personal is a great way to educate and solicit reaction and action.  Getting beyond the numbers is vital, and this will go a long way toward that.
Oh, and the 60/40 split to deliver funding to those who require anonymity is just brilliant and very sensitive.

I'm curious about the reactions you heard when you asked other students about illegal detention. What misconceptions (or questions) became apparent to you that helped shape your idea?It's great to see the emphasis on human connection that results from seeing someone's face, and I think you're spot on. Instead of building a completely new platform to share brief stories about and photos of detainees, I wonder if it might be possible to create a white label version of Kiva.org's profile pages (given their visual nature)?

This concept represents an opportunity for Amnesty bring the plight of detainee families to the personal attention of prospective compassionate sponsors. It is the shopfront or (possibly literally) home page of the integrated support system behind which lie concepts like 'Take Action on Google'and 'Shift Van'. A vital component that 'shifts' Amnesty's public image to attract new support and provides a gateway to the whole range of information Amnesty brings together on detainment issues.

Wow Elliott...you and your virtual team did an excellent job on refining this concept!I admit, I didn't truly "get" your concept until now, but your updates have convinced me that you're on to something. Nice =)

Hi Elliot! Hope i'm not too late to congratulate you on your great concept reaching the refinement phase. I think it will help relieve many spouse's and families pain.After reading many of the comments below, I believe you've also refined this concept through discussing many important things. ** One think I wanted to mention about donating money, (i am working on a similar system for an idea to donate money a charity) is that people also like this to be transparent. Sometimes times we donate money to big organizations (very well respected ones) and we sometimes don't know exactly where that money will be distributed inside the organization. So my point is that it would be nice for the sponsorer to see the journey of the initial donation/sponsoring until it has reached the family/spouse. This could be done through amnesty keeping in touch with the donator, saying something like "we have received your request Ana, thank you. We will now connect you to a spouse and after that you will be informed exactly where your donation will be applied within the family. Right now, your bank will be sending the money to us in the next few days, once we have received it we will notify you via e-mail." This is just an example, and I'm not talking YET about the contact between the spouse and the donator through phone or letters, I am just talking about the journey of the donation to the family/spouse. This is just some info I've also researched on for my current project and found it valuable! Congrats again on your great research and development on this :)

Hi Elliott,Interesting idea! It seems that lots of energy goes into protesting unlawful detainment and the struggles of prisoner's families stay hidden. I like that this idea directs attention (and money) to those who are left behind. I wonder if there is a way to encourage donations over time and maintain interest in the sponsored family? I know that Support a Child campaigns sometimes send donors letters or photos of the children (as you mentioned) to build a personal connection and encourage a long-term relationship. Since anonymity is an important concern here, sponsored families could maybe send something less personal like a short note, a low-cost gift, or a non-identifying photo (of their city, for example), that still assures the donor their money is reaching a family in need.This is a particularly important element of the interaction because these families could need very long term support. Unlike Support a Child programs, which end at a certain age, families of detainees may need to be supported indefinitely, as their loved one may never be returned.With that in mind, it is worth considering if you want to establish a one donor-one sponsor relationship or if you want the donor to have a more active role in deciding where their funds go. Here are two possible models:Support a detainee's family for a year:Each donor is assigned a family when they join. The donor can pay the full yearly amount up front, or be reminded to pay each month, and get quarterly (anonymous) updates on their family. At the end of the year, the donor can continue with the same family or pick another. This will maintain interest in families that have been receiving support for a long time, since they will be getting new donors each year. Support pools for families of detainees:Donors can pick a donation plan (one-time fee of $120, monthly fee of $10, etc.) when they join and read stories of all the families that are supported by the collective fund. They can choose to donate additional funds to specific families if their stories are particularly poignant. For example, families could list opportunities for specific support, like paying for a child's education, or purchasing gifts for holidays, which donors could contribute to (like Kickstarter). Either way, all participating families are ensured adequate funds, and donors can freely allocate additional funds.

Hi, I agree with Rachel that it is important to also take into account the family. I think that sponsoring a family is indeed a good idea and I like Rachel's suggestion to create program that builds relationships, even though anonymity might be an issue in some cases. To Rachel's point about the long term element of the needs and the need to maybe think of specific needs, like education. I'm also wondering if there's not a way to think of going one step beyond this campaign so that Jess in Iran can become independent at some point (this was a point that was made in the video of Amina).

Anne-Laure,That is a great point, particularly for the families that may never have a traditional breadwinner again. Perhaps a model very similar to Kickstarter, where donors can invest in a mini-business plan for these families, or (as mentioned above) a specific child's education. With this focus, the donors are further incentivized to participate, because they get to see the money at work, providing a fresh start for these families, instead of maintaining a set standard of living.Another possible avenue, building off of Anne-Laure's focus on future independence, is a partnership with an organization that provides business opportunities for women. For example, donors could subsidize the start-up fees for a micro-franchise. This way families of detainees could benefit from a fresh start without jeopardizing anonymity.

Sorry for not coming back to the conversation earlier and thanks for adding to it Rachel. I also think that one way would be to connect to Jason's detainee support net concept:  http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-detainee-support-net-financial-legal-moral/Jason in fact suggested connecting the 2 concepts.
Thanks for pointing that out Anne-Laurie. I just connected the two concepts. In what ways can we adapt this proposal inspired by Jason's work?
Jason wrote" I can imagine the "donate" feature linking to Elliot's Sponsor a Spouse campaign ". I guess that would be one way. Check his widget: http://www.jasondgeorge.com/openIDEO/openWidget.html

I'm not sure how much you need to adapt rather than thinking of your concept as connected to his concept. My impression looking at several concepts in the refinement phase is that they all build upon each other nicely to provide answers to different parts of the problems.

Anne-Laure,You and Marnie have hit the nail on the head!I think the refinement phase has two broad aspects:1. The opportunity to literally refine a single concept as we traditionally do; but probably even more productively2. The opportunity to collaboratively integrate concepts.At present the platform is geared towards individual ownership of concepts (which reminds me that I must apologise to David Hood) It would be good if we could integrate concepts with joint or multiple attribution. This is different from your NYPoly group collaboration but potentially very valuable.I need to discuss this more somewhere else.

Hi Elliot, to second Anne-Laure response, I just wanted to illustrate the overlap and the opportunity to combine and enhance a few of our concepts. This one offers a really great support opportunity and I was excited to build on it!
Marnie has made a great attempt at highlighting connections between her concept and all concepts. This in fact inspired me to do the same. My last update. :-)

Hello Elliott, thanks for your great contribution to the Amnesty Challenge. The expert panel was excited about your idea and wonder if youd be willing to push the concept even further. For example, how would you visualise the site? How do you envision reaching out to a broad community? What elements would you build into the platform? Feel free to reach out the broader OpenIDEO community for ideas.

Hi Elliott, congragulations! I was thinking of reaching out to a broad community and beyond the usual campaining (there were a couple of interesting concepts in the concepting phase), I thought of a concept that was called adopt-a-detainee: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-adopt-a-detainee-program/ Could it be reframed into adopt/ sponsor a spouse?

Interesting thinking, Elliot. Keep in mind that anonymity is often a concern for detainees and their families. Read more in our Guiding Principles: http://bit.ly/amnesty_guide  Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

sponsor_a_spouse.title: Sponsor a Spouse: Adding a face to Illegal Detainment - Updated 11/16

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

tandem_skydiving_putting_your_life_in_so.description: Last week I did my first tandem skydive. I jumped out of a plane at 18,000 ft with an instructor attached to my back. I was utterly powerless and had to put my trust in a random stranger to do the right thing.
tandem_skydiving_putting_your_life_in_so.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Still plucking up the courage! This reminds me of change management /leadership literature and three 'tests' around change...of trust, of expertise, of jurisdiction. Leaders are subjected to these and collaborators also will not feel empowered unless they feel trusted, that they (or their expertise) are valued, and they have some authority to make or be involved in decisions. So trust and powerlessness are closely connected.
Wow, nice insights on trust. This will definitely be helpful as we think about how to design technology that people are comfortable trusting in respect to human rights & lives!
thanks Vincent, funnily enough I actually did the skydive for research for another project someone was working on - which was looking at how to build trust.

Nathan! I totally agree on the three things you mention here. I did tandem skydiving six months ago (I have to say it was not for the sake of research, but for pleasure, that was at least what I expected from the jump) and I trusted the instructor every single second.I would add, to this particular case, that knowing that the instructor has jumped X times already (which we asked, and It was some thousand times) helps a lot to trust building. It reinforces the idea of "she/he knows the perfect process". Furtheremore, when you jump you believe the instructor does not want to die, so knowing you are attached to her/him makes you think he'll do his best. Well, now I'll start thinking how to extrapolate those insights!

That's true, and I remember my instructor said he had jumped over 18,000 times, which is kind of mind boggling. I wonder if there's a role for a trusted advisor or facilitator in this process, someone who has been there, and you can trust implicitly?

Great suggestion, Nathan  I can imagine that being able to share the perspective of a former detainee would be really useful if you were being detained. Really like this insight  and how you got there from your analogous exploration of your skydiving experience.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Amazing story, and great reflection. This is one of the items on my Things I want to do once, but am actually too afraid of list.

tandem_skydiving_putting_your_life_in_so.title: Tandem Skydiving - putting your life in someone else's hands

amnesty_observer_app.description: Around the world, from the Arab Spring to Chinese Anti-Corruption Campaigns to African Crisis Mapping to Occupy Wall Street, people are using mobile phones & online social networks/media to become activists & communicate important information.
amnesty_observer_app.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Now mobile phone video has even been used to make an undercover half hour documentary (aired on TV news networks) of the situation in Syria, providing coverage despite the Syrian government's active targeting of journalists: http://www.fastcoexist.com/1679518/iphone-investigation-an-undercover-documentary-from-syria-made-using-phones

Hi Vincent, congrats on having this concept developed as part of our IDEO Make-a-thon this weekend. The team created an iPhone prototype, Activate, which accesses photo and video functions on the phone to record and send footage to a secure server.https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/21033302-ideo-make-a-thon-thanks-recapScroll down to see a shot of the phone app.

Awesome and thanks Haiyan, IDEO London, OpenIDEO, Amnesty, and of course, the Make-a-thon team @iliasbartolini, @gridinoc, Ralf Rebmann, @tristamsparks . Great to hear that this & other promising concepts are moving closer to real world impact.Would love to check out the prototype in more depth. Is the app or source code available?

Hi Vincent - did you hear the news? Your concept is being developed and prototyped as part of this weeks Make-a-thon at IDEO London! Check this out for more info http://bit.ly/y2uDQZ and be sure to weigh in over at our User Forums http://bit.ly/yt0m5d to help your idea take one step closer to reality.
And hint: be sure to check out Brief #1!

Vincent - Congratulations on having the opportunity to take this concept to the next phase. I want to invite your team to collaborate with the SecureSmartCam project which been underway for a year as a joint effort between WITNESS Labs and the Guardian Project (an open source mobile security group). We share many of your goals, and have made progress in some significant areas. Our next milestone is in two weeks, with our first alpha of our video camera app and tor-based uploader.This is a big problem set to tackle so the more the merrier, and look forward to having your creative thinking in the mix. You can learn more at: https://guardianproject.info/apps/securecam/https://github.com/guardianproject/SecureSmartCam/wiki

Hi Nathan.  Granted, I'm not really part of this conversation, but what a great offer.  The idea of a collaboration between this virtual team, Amnesty International, and WITNESS Labs is inspirational...

Awesome Nathan!From what I can gather, the Guardian Project is focused on creating a privacy/security layer & apps (protecting communications, data, etc.) that can customize Android smart phones.And the Guardian Project's partnership with Witness on an ObscuraCam app provides the anonymous obscuring of faces (as well as identifying media file metadata) that Amnesty recognizes as an important feature for processing these types of videos. Also, see there are aims to support other use cases in the future.Certainly looks like it'd be worthwhile for the Amnesty/OpenIDEO team (who are pursuing realization) to communicate with the SecureSmartCam project (Guardian Project & Witness) to determine collaboration opportunities.Thanks so much for reaching out and sharing the great open source work you & your team are doing Nathan!Very valuable for Witness, Amnesty, other humanitarian organizations, activists, & even people just looking to ensure their privacy.

Vincent! Thank you for your huge effort on this challenge (and others)! We really appreciate all of your hard work and collaboration. Congratulations on designing a winning concept. The Amnesty team particularly liked your simple but effective use of mobile technology. We're hoping to prototype the idea at a hack event. Thank you again!
Congratulations Vincent! Looking forward to seeing a prototype soon. al
Very worthy concept Vincent! Will be most interested to follow the realisation and see the end result.

Thanks everyone! Great to see so many promising ideas emerge to further human rights, and grateful for everyone's collaborative discussion to make all these concepts even stronger.Excited to see what emerges from the Random Hacks of Kindness Global Event, where Amnesty & OpenIDEO hope to take selections for prototyping!
Congrats on your winning concept Vincent!!  I can't wait to see what happens with this at Random Hacks of Kindness :-)  Onward prototyping.
Congrats Vincent. Like the others, curious to see it prototyped soon. :)
Great work! Great concept, addressing comments, refinement, and collaboration!

Vincent - your contributions across multiple challenges are all amazing.  We discussed this concept with Amnesty yesterday and all love it.  I wonder if this is something that could be prototyped fairly quickly at a Hackathon?

Thanks Tom..it really means a lot coming from you, the creative & entrepreneurial visionary who makes this all possible!And I'm excited that Amnesty loves this, giving it a good shot at being realized & supported!Yes, core elements of this concept can certainly be prototyped quickly at a Hackathon. Hopefully anticipating what emerges from the Random Hacks of Kindness Global Event!

Vincent,  you have a lot of rich content here.  sorry I have not gone through it all.  I wonder if you know about Peter Gabriel's http://witness.org/ - a human rights organization that has travelled deep into the jungles of Burma?  A potential source of inspiration and knowledge.  They have their own interactive community platform called HUB, for Human Rights activists to upload photos and videos and document Human Rights abuses.

WITNESS MISSION. - "SEE IT.  FILM IT.  CHANGE IT.  WITNESS uses video to open the eyes of the world to HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS" "WITNESS empowers people to transform personal stories of abuse into powerful tools for justice, promoting public engagement and policy change."

Hi Marnie. I actually quoted from Witness near the top of the concept, as I believe one of their videos actually helped inspire this.Thanks for nudging me on Witnesses's HUB, which I definitely had overlooked mentioning! Have now incorporated them directly into the "Integrating with/Leveraging Online Distribution" section, as well as attributing you for your build there ;).

If a picture is worth a thousand words, what is a video worth? - pricelessI really love the video concept (and your eye-con), as you can tell by my mock-up.I think it is an essential component to the solution set in this challenge, but with human rights there are some serious considerations in any implementation, as you have noted.  I'm sure the experience of the WITNESS team would prove invaluable to Amnesty.  Glad you found it useful.

Vincent I have evaluated this as quite technically dependent because I see it as a very important component in the integrated system..Extending your 'privacy' filtering argument I see filtering first by 'Amnesty' to extract any useful information (who, what, when, where) important  This would help initiate contingency plans (PACT and Detainee Support Network)), inform families, update incident reporting (Take Action on Google) and add to repository of stories and images. After that a considered decision could be made about putting the footage into the public domain. The other system elements give added purpose to the App and your 'camouflage' aspects provide important safety for the observer.
Thanks Paul! Appreciating how your comments on various concepts really illustrate how they can work synergistically as part of a broader system.

It's good to see the pricing options you're considering to be able to offer the observer app to a wider range of users. I wonder if it might be feasible to add photos or sketches of people who other users have seen committing corruption? It seems that it could be useful to use geolocation to know who's nearby and worth keeping an eye out for (of course this could also raise serious privacy concerns but could be something worth exploring).

Thanks Emily!The intent is to make the app freely available/accessible to everyone (in order to reach those in need and at risk), but to solicit voluntarily donations(from say a tourist downloading the app as a precautionary measure before traveling abroad, i.e. "donate what it's worth to you" or "donate what you can") to support Amnesty's human rights works.And absolutely, about allowing the upload/sharing of other media beyond video, as well as having location tagging for these.Have added you this concept's virtual team.

Vincent, congratulations on being shortlisted! We loved your idea of anonymously crowdsourcing evidence of human rights violations. We would challenge you to refine the concept in terms of how might this service verify the footage and overcome consent issues.For inspiration, check out the http://openleaks.org/ project which is aiming to make whistleblowing safer for individuals.

Thanks OpenIDEO and Amnesty International for the shortlisting, refinement guidance, and OpenLeaks reference!Have updated the concept to incorporate OpenLeaks, address some of your issues raised, and to gather and attribute the great builds from OpenIDEO community members. Continuing to think about further refinements.In the meantime, would really appreciate it if y'all could elaborate a bit more on what you see as the consent issues, as well as your thoughts on potential/related solutions.

Hi Vincent, great to see so much progress from you and the virtual team on this concept. The consent issues are, as you might expect, complex. As such there is no silver bullet, but they should be fed into the process to allow you and team to consider the implications and possible solutions.Imagine a situation where a human rights violation is unfolding before someone with the Observer App, resulting in the user recording and uploading the events for further scrutiny. Although not central to the events being recorded, there may well be individuals in the background whose whereabouts, actions and affiliations may inadvertently have been captured and distributed as part of the recording, without their express consent. Whilst a significantly different product, it's a problem that Google's Street View had to grapple with. Are there ways in which the team feel this can be addressed?

Hi Vincent, agreed with Owen, maybe the issue goes a little further than consent in the sense that whilst consent, depending on the context may not be strictly necessary, we always need to be asking the questions about what indirect negative impact might there be on a person as a result of our campaigning, and how might that play out, it's a delicate balance without any one size fits all solution and in an ideal sitiation we could analyse on a case by case basis.

Hi Owen & Sara. Thanks so much for your thoughtful replies to help us understand this important consent/privacy issue! Really helped clarify things for me. Agreed we need to carefully consider how to avoid inadvertent negative impacts while we try to make a positive difference. It's a tough one, especially in scenarios like the one given in the concept, where a seemingly innocent bystander may not be so innocent.From my understanding of Google Street View, it's approach to privacy is 2-fold: 1) photos taken in public places generally do not require consent, as there's no legally recognized expectation of privacy; 2) however, Google provides a "report for removal/blurring function" that allows people to report inappropriate, privacy infringing, & security compromising content (bottom left of each image). Of course, there are variations in different areas such as allowing households to put their houses on a do not show list, respecting government requests to not photograph military bases as a general rule, and banning/exit of Google Street View from areas with more stringent privacy regulations.For the "Amnesty Observer App", the anonymous blurring of content could primarily occur at the distribution partner stage (see INTEGRATING WITH/LEVERAGING EMERGING ONLINE DISTRIBUTION subheader of "My Virtual Team" updates section). Thus, after a video is uploaded, distribution partners/administrators (such as Amnesty International) can make the call about what's appropriate to show publicly, and what might need to be blurred or even never distributed at all.I have added a new subheader to the "My Virtual Team' updates section called HANDLING PRIVACY CONCERNS to take a 1st cut at addressing this issue in more detail.As always, would appreciate your, and the broader OpenIDEO community's, continued feedback & ideas on how to best handle this.

It occurs to me that there should be a web version of this app as well. Yes, being able to upload it in the moment, and delete it in the moment is powerful, but why not enable videos to be uploaded regardless of where - or how - they were recorded? I can see capturing a video and then waiting until I was miles away from the incident to upload it. The compiling process that you mentioned would be facilitated with a complimenting web component, in addition to facebook and facebook equivalents.Someone could navigate to the web page on their smart phone and upload from there if they did not have the app.What whatever form this solution takes, part of its design must be how it will coordinate with other inputs - such as the SOS button, or the witness box. (With all the comments this is getting, I'm sure it will).The impetus for this comment comes from my experience with the "spare the air" app for the iPhone, which provides a quicker way to report polluting cars in the SF Bay Area (in app text or single button call). But you can also call in such info later (when you are not driving!), or write it down on paper to call in later (they provide printed forms). That app could learn from your idea too! Namely I wish I could just zip them a photo / video of the license plate from my phone. Ironically I just scanned their web site, and they don't have an obvious entry method there...

Good point Steve! This should definitely be web (not just mobile) accessible: the upload process, as well as the post-upload compiling/distribution/etc.If you have further thoughts on coordinating with other inputs, I'm all ears =)

Awesome concept Vincent. I agree with Steve on the need for a web version. In the case of Cuba (where these detentions have been occurring regularly for over 50 years) there are very few people who have cell phones and the ones that do can't use them to access the web or email thanks to the government restrictions.

Also, it would be great if the web version had a similar "stealth" component to it. In the event that your computer gets confiscated there will be no record of you visiting the site or of the uploaded video/pics.

Absolutely. Thanks Jacqueline for helping make this concept work for as many people in as many places as possible! Already updated the concept with a web upload component, but have now also clarified that this should be secure/anonymous, and have attributed you, in the Virtual Team section of this concept.

Hi Vincent. This seems to me to be a great idea, to enable reporting to a wider community, thus minimizing the local authorities influence of the message to get through. The idea of disguising the app as another app is very important I think, and also the idea about hiding all actions of the app, upload, running program (if visible as in some android phones), further communication to other devices, etc. I was thinking if it could be possible to make an app that can imitate or install under another existing app, to make the cover of the Observer app as local and undetectable as possible? I was thinking something in the line of when installing the app, choosing which existing app in the phone it should imitate or install under, either grabbing icons and if possible some functionalities, or installing an "invisible" app to boot when activating a given app, creating a bootable app, started when starting eg Angry birds, a camera app, the existing calculator, or whatever is the most obvious choice for the individual.

Thanks Thorkild for your idea about how to further customize the app to be as covert as possible! You're definitely taking the implementation to a deeper, but potentially fruitful, level. Have integrated your builds & attributed you in the "Customizable Mock Screenshots / App Names / Icons" part of this concept's "My Virtual Team" section.

Thanks everyone for your support & many great builds!Have filled in "My Virtual Team" section to update the "Amnesty Observer App" with your brilliant insights & ideas, and to attribute your contributions =)As always, your feedback/builds are very welcome.
Habari (Swahili for hi) Vincent.Great app idea and especially for remembering that for the app to be effective and widespread, it has to be donwloadable on basic phones too.RegardsFestus
Habari & Asante Festus!

I like the idea that you can disguise the film on your phone if someone tries to look at your screen. How can a person activate that when their phone is being searched? I think this concept of getting information out there with video footage is very important. I think this can allow people to gain access to that information as soon as possible. Great thinking!
Thanks Emily. In the case of a person's phone being searched, the action of the searcher would actually automatically activate the online upload & local deletion process.
Man...I was thought its an already done app and was thinking about downloading it!! LOL...but good idea...

Lol...it's good to know that this app concept is appealing, understandable, & believable enough that you want to download it right away! We just need to make it a reality, and the downloading & positive impact can begin =)

Dear Vincent I really like your concept, Here I want share a probable situation that may happen in countries like Iran, Syria and so on. During after election demonstration in Iran in 2009, almost 20,000 from people were arrested in only first month of demonstration, some of them never came back and you can say almost all of them had cell phone. The initial strategy of government, to repress people, was based on interfering their means of communication as far as they could. SMS was off for months. Internet on mobiles as well, but they couldnt turn off the whole internet network because many of infrastructures, such as banking, transportation and almost all official carrier have been installed on the internet platform but they reduced the speed to the extent that uploading 1 minutes video took almost 30 minute. So I suppose that would be the probable scenario for next time as well.

Internet & Mobile Network shutdown is indeed a possible situation & valid point Amin. Thanks for raising. I see you've posted a related concept around this concern, so posting the link to it for you here: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/open-network-mesh-cans-be-on-when-they-turn-off-every-thing-/

Circumstances will differ from place to place: as a universal app for 'everyday' situations the likelyhood of internet and mobile network shutdowns is minimal. For other situations like general uprisings or regime 'crackdowns' the likelihood increases substantially. That's why I built a concept from Amin's for developing 'strategic' mesh networks using simple solar driven lighting as a 'cover' for installations: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/network-startegically-using-mesh-potato-networking - although I didn't do much of a job in describing it.

Hi Vincent!Great concept, and what I especially like is the possibility to protect the witness, the user of the Amnesty Observer App, as many others have already mentioned. This makes me immediately feel safer. On the other hand it also makes me think who is on the other side, looking at the content and analyzing it so that actions can be taken accordingly to stop the problem. So I guess this is also a very important point, to make the 'trust circle' is complete for the user of this App to feel empowered.It also reminds me of CNN's iReporter. I have the CNN App on my iPod which includes the iReporter function too, but I have never found an opportunity to use it yet, but I love the pioneering idea behind it:  Crowd sourcing the news! : http://ireport.cnn.com/I look forward to see how this idea could be turned into reality!Ana

Thanks Ana!Agreed that the storage/distribution/sharing system/actors on the other side is extremely important. Videos can be browseable, aggregated, and sortable by time, place, shares, votes, etc. Different organizations or individual activists/causes (like Occupy Wall Street) could set up their channels/collections of videos to be shared (think Youtube).In some cases, perhaps a trusted party (like Amnesty!) could administrate the site.However, in other cases, some kind of more distributed, peer-to-peer system that's harder to takedown/block may make more sense, perhaps in parallel. For example, in China, domestically operating social media sites must be compliant with government censorship & generally have their own internal censorship division as well. Meanwhile, prohibited foreign media sites are blocked by a countrywide firewall (though there are ways around this).
Along with Ana's question: how would the app be distributed so that the people in need of it can actually use it?Great idea, Vincent!

Hmm...good question Jamie. Thanks! I'd think mainly through pre-existing official (Amnesty & other human rights websites, app stores, phone preloads) & unofficial channels (software, movies, music, tech hardware, etc. often of uncertain IP are available both through various online channels & sold by street vendors in China).Would appreciate other's thoughts on how best to distribute such an app in different areas around the world.

I think this app is a great idea especially with the added 'cover' of a game screen - I dont know much about games these days but there used to be limited functionality demo versions available which might be adapted to the purpose.Following up with Jamie's question I had similar thoughts about how you get the app into the 'right' hands and keep it out of the 'wrong' hands. Perhaps a range of possible cover games together with a 4 key pin known to the owner to initiate it. If its too widely available and too easy to initiate then ultimately its too easy to discover too.
Awesome idea, like how you have accounted for the case where the officer finds you recording the scene.

Awesome idea Vincent. I think nowadays people don't help each other in such situations because they don't want to get themselves involved in any kind of issues. I think this idea will really motivate people to help each other.

Another brilliant idea, Vincent. The great thing about this idea is that it does not require any advanced technology or tools, all you need is a smart phone with the app installed. And anothing I really like about your proposal is that you also designed this app to protect the witness who's using it. Such protection will encourage people to take more actions without concerning the safty of himself or the family members. Greate concept, thank you!
Thanks Lei. The family/personal safety issue is a huge concern for many.

Awesome idea Vincent. I think nowadays people don't help each other in such situations because they don't want to get themselves involved in any kind of issues. I think this idea will really motivate people to help each other.
I really like this concept.  I think the more we can educate ourselves from the experiences, we can share this to others, so that prevention can be a very helpful start

Hello. I need to tell a short story to perhaps give you further ideas to, and perhaps simplify the programming of this great Application.In the stockholm (sweden) subway, a young dude saw some security guards beat up an innocent man and dragging him into a room. The dude picked up his phone and started filming. Of course another guard approached him and dragged him towards the same room. He was shouted at, and ordered to delete the film. The dude had to show the phone screen to the guards while he deleted the film. And they checked that there were no films left on his phone and memory card. He was released. (There is no knowledge what happened to the innocent man that got beat up.)But the dude walked directly to a friend, and they together used some software to rescue all deleted files on the phone. And they emailed the film to a tv reporter, and everything became public on national TV.
Thanks Johan! This is a great example of where this app would be useful. Seems like it has applications everywhere from Shanghai to Stockholm.Any chance you have a link to the news about this?

Great concept Vincent. I was thinking on similar lines for the past few days. A feeling of empathy for the detained (or the person in trouble) is very common among the ones who are the witnesses to the scene. Most of the times the witnesses are not able to help just because of the fact that they are scared to 'raise a voice against it' or that they dont want to risk in their freedom too. So providing a tool or a process through which they can contribute to the issue without getting noticed is an excellent way to get people involved for the cause. The concept addresses the perception that 'technology can be a double-edged sword' in a decent and less risky manner.A similar tool can be a discrete SOS button accessible to public at public places (airports, public hubs, etc.) may be in the form of a local phone booth or something similar which can just send a discrete message letting the right people know that something is going wrong at a paeticular location, without revealing the identity of the person who triggered the signal.
Great thoughts, Rathin. Feel free to have a go at building off Vincent's concept to create a new one if you like. You can credit him via the Build Upon feature.

Hi Rathin, great minds think alike =) Glad that our lines of thinking are resonating well.I like your springboarding to the idea of a discrete SOS button & definitely second Meena's encouragement post as it as a concept. I'm interested to see how you develop this further ;)

Just joining the discussion to say that it'll indeed be nice to see how there could be an SOS button in public places. I agree with you Rathin that a great strength of Vincent's concept is in offering a very simple way (not requiring a lot of action) and quite safe way of (re-)acting.

I 'third' that too... Regarding Rathin's idea of an SOS button! Because many people who may witness a distressed situation in an airport for instance, may not have access to their phones to document a situation or call someone... so if they could signal this problem discretely like you say, this could be a further way to fight a crime, using less technological means. Or we could possible integrate this into the Amnesty Observer App with the same symbol, e.g. I love the logo of this app resembling an iris, so maybe something like that? Or bringing in Anne's 'Shift Freedom' keyboard key! The issue with educating and informing people about this button creeps up again, but I'm sure this concept could develop further with your great idea Rathin!

Thank you everyone for the valuable inputs and thank you Vincent for this great concept. Helped a lot in directing me towards a new concept. I agree Anne Laure that its very interesting to think how an SOS button can be implemented in a public space and moreover the challenge lies in making the whole process work. It can be a design based issue too which I have started thinking upon.The beauty of Vincent's concept indeed lies in the simplicity of it and the fact that it reduces risk for the one taking an action about it. It is a known fact that any process that demands 'too much' out of people is seldom a success.Thanks Ana and Meena for the inspiration and I hope to come up with a concept built upon this soon.

Hello Everyone,Inspired by your support, I went ahead and came up with the Amnesty Observer's Witness Box.  Here is the link :http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-observer-s-witness-box-/Please go and check it whenever possible. Looking forward to your thoughts and comments.

Vincent -I believe I own an answer to your envisioned concept. You require a collective intelligence of a crowd (at the very least, one astute witness with a phone and connectivity) acknowledging corruption and human rights violations are taking place. You also require a means for monitoring the multiple, concurrent channels of social media for posting, spread and strength of message (amongst other variables).  Finally, you require a means for managing the project to ensure proper attention is given the crime worldwide.  This program exists within my company, Temetic.com.  I'd be glad to offer its utility for free to meet the needs of your envisioned concept. -Richrich.neal@temeticresearch.com

Hi Rich,thanks for your comment & offer to help!In this human rights challenge, I believe selected concepts will be moved forward by Amnesty International & OpenIDEO, who also hope to take these to RHOK (Random Hacks of Kindness) to develop.If this idea is selected, you might want to contact them directly about how to contribute to its realization.Also, it sounds like some of your thoughts may not only build on this concept, but also extend beyond video in broader ways. Perhaps you'd consider posting another concept to more fully explain the potential for social media monitoring/management to uphold human rights?

As smart phone adoption increases,  this app  could really be instrumental in spreading the word.  I think that perhaps an SMS /MMS "hotline" could also  work for people with feature phones, whereby users could just upload photos and reports via SMS. I think it would also be important for everything to be anonymized... There may be ways to work with manufacturers so that the app comes pre-bundled...

Great thoughts Anna! Will definitely be incorporating into the "How could this idea also be adapted to work in low-tech situations?" section of the concept and attributing to you during the refinement stage.

Amazing concept, Vincent. I do think that we have to come up with solutions to some of the questions in the comments, like how to give the right people access to the tool and how to avoid the upload speed problem. As for the latter, a hidden background process, named after some innocent other app, could do the trick. Maybe combined with some p2p tech.

Thanks for the support Arjan, and agreed that these are important implementation issues.And great  idea to use hidden background processes in the case of slow upload speeds!In terms of right people, it probably comes down to chosen distribution channels, awareness generating approach, and finding ways to naturally surface the most important content (all 3 of which Amnesty can be very helpful for).
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Dear Vincent I supposed it could help as well: http://www.amnesty.org/en/activism-center/activism-tools/ai-candle This is Amnesty current App to take part in international campaigns, appeals for action and petitions to:1- act for the release of prisoners of conscience2- commute death sentences3- bring torturers to justice4- stop forced evictions5- hold corporations accountable6- protect womens rights7- persuade governments to change their laws and practicesI didn't work with that app but do you think your app could be an extra function added to current app or completely a new app

Hi Amin. Thanks for pointing out this Amnesty Candle App!Indeed I think easy video recording would be a valuable functionality addition for this bundle.At the same time, I think the availability of a simple standalone Observer App is important for ease of use & security/privacy reasons, especially in repressive regimes.

Vincent,I love the scenario which allows us to understand the local context. Thanks a lot for thinking of us. It also allows you to take us through all the steps and possible scenarios showing us the potential of your idea.It makes it very easy (nearly no effort - 2 clicks with a device that she or he will have easily access to) for the user (and with very low, even null thanks to angry birds :-)) to report a situation.The low involvement of the user in the action of reporting is also in the medium - a video, not writing up something or filling in a form. To this, it adds the power of the images and their "objectivity" (we will leave aside the discussion of how objective images really are :-) )...thanks for another great concept!
Thanks Anne-Laure! Easy access is key in these situations.
Really great idea Vincent. The scenario was spot on and definitely illustrated the power of this app. I also like that it's technically the officer who is uploading the information!

This is really nice as the number of smart phones are increasing and within few years, all the phones (i.e. everyone) could accomplish such task.  I will just add on two things: 1) A camera on the ear plug will be even greater, in that case, it won't look like at all that you are filming. 2) The covert application should be any of the applications within the smartphone, therefore the officers will even suspect less (they may start seeing too many angry birds to form a pattern)

Thanks Tayfun. Agreed with you that, especially as video recording devices continue to decrease in cost & size, there will be more discreet ways to wear a video camera. And absolutely: about being being able to choose/customize different wallpaper/screenshots for the covert app in phones that can support!
Brilliant idea, Vincent (and nice storytelling skills :) ). I wonder whether there could be a non-smartphone version (working with regular phones, SMS-based).

Thanks Sarah. Yes, I think I mentioned feature phones too (or at least video-enabled ones) in the concept. Are you envisioning non-video, SMS-based too? If so, how do you see this working?Oh, also, great comments on everyone's concepts in general! You're really bringing new angles to the discussion =)

Really loving how you've painted a scenario where this Concept may be used Vincent  really helps others engage with your great idea. Wonder if the folks over at Angry Birds will see it as a form of free advertising or suit-worthy? ;^)) But seriously  lots to love on this one... looking forward to discussion & builds!

Thanks Meena! Angry Birds *should* see it as free advertising =). Anyways, I was more using that as an illustrative example that the OpenIDEO community might be able to relate to. So, any graphic/screenshot of other popular programs, such as mobile MMORPG games or text messaging, would also work fine for this purpose.Continuing on that vein, an interesting side note: Steve Jobs was also a top trending topic on Chinese Weibos, just as it was on Twitter. The world is truly becoming more global every day!

amnesty_observer_app.title: Amnesty Observer App

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

internal_monitor.description: When someone is detained anywhere, police, abroad, terrorist groups, they have every possession taken away. Therefore any monitoring or device used to communicated is eliminated. To combat this we need to design a device which is held in the body either temporary, or permanently.
internal_monitor.creator: 6448e86d7837e2feb55834a2b2581d66

comments.text: Very innovative idea presented here.  I love the idea of looking to seemingly unrelated areas for inspiration to addressing an issue.  This idea is very similar to that which pet owners use to assist on searching for a lost animal.  Whether or not this was the basis of your creativity for this,  I always promote an "outside the box" approach to brainstorming new ideas.

Interesting idea, Aex! You might like to check out our Tips on Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking devices could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

internal_monitor.title: Internal Monitor

social_media_alerts_are_sent_to_amnesty_.description: Get Facebook (or other social media) on board and motivate people at risk to write status messages regularly and register with Amnesty International. If someone at risk is writing status messages each day, everyone knows he or she is fine. Once he or she stopped writing an alert is sent to Amnesty International by Facebook.
social_media_alerts_are_sent_to_amnesty_.creator: bcf89ad8e7f736a3e01c31da59776936

comments.text: This is a great simple solution. I wonder if police would also be less likely to take people if they knew that they were very public figures and that many people would know if they went missing.I suppose many countries that condone unlawful detention probably also censor websites like Facebook, which would make this more difficult.
I thought about that as well. It doesn't need to be Facebook. We could establish a feature on the Amnesty International website to send status messages from there.

Interesting thoughts, Ines. Tip: you might want to connect your Concept to ideas which were gathered in the Inspiration phase like: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/medical-alert-monitoring-devices/ using the Build Upon feature. This helps us all join the dots between related posts and will show up on your Collaboration Map for this post. Plus you'll get more DQ points!. Hit the Update button on the right of your post, then scroll down to Build Upon. Keep up the great work!
Thank you, Meena. I went trough the inspirations and added some using the Build Upon feature.

social_media_alerts_are_sent_to_amnesty_.title: Social media alerts are sent to Amnesty International

street_plays_a_video_tool_kit_for_unlawf.description: Getting people to think about,let alone understand the complexities of unlawful detention is a difficult task.  Improvisational, scripted, and recorded. Street Plays, as an awareness  tactic and word-of-mouth driver tactic, have the power to be spontaneous, participatory and informative.  Vignettes that re-enact detention scenarios, demonstrate what to do can educate the public, but also create a location-based video archive of what a person can do if someone they know if detained.
street_plays_a_video_tool_kit_for_unlawf.creator: 6cf42ec9950da8306046a6a682ee78ec

comments.text: Street plays have been a tradition in many developing countries to spread the word on social matters.  This creates the perception of community awareness potentially reducing unlawful detention.  Great idea!
Great thoughts around low-tech community outreach.

This reminds me a lot of what my group is trying to do. We are looking to make pop-up art galleries in major cities (galleries that would be set up for a few hours and then disappear without a trace). Our project is called "The Forgotten - Share Your Art Around The World". I think this concept of performance art would be a great way to connect with people on an emotional level. Nice job!

Very nice concept and a nice complement to Anne's (virtual) street art festival: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/street-art-festival/I like the fact that you're building on a current practice and try to extend it to different contexts. I guess the practical questions would be linked to translations and also how to adjust scripts to local contexts. See for example Tayfun's concept and some of the conversations: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/is-that-part-of-our-culture/It is not impossible but it is to be taken into account.In terms of sharing it, you could imagine having it downloadable but there could also be a paper version that could be distributed in Ana's vending machine: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-vending-machine-info-hub/I can also imagine your concept combined with SACK's concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-adopt-a-detainee-program/

comments.text: I couldn't agree more Steve! Do you have a good idea how to make for instance my concept "SHIFT FREEDOM" more experiential? At the moment I think it is a little too "flat", and I think experiences can help shift peoples minds.

It is indeed powerful to include visceral activities in any educational campaign. It's hard to get past informational overload - unless that information is coming from your own experience. That kind of information sticks and bypasses the usual mental defenses.
Great inspiration as always Anne. And I highly encourage others to check out the Guerrilla Innovation site www.guerrilla-innovation.com which Anne shared with me yesterday  many gems there!

sonic_planet_the_voices_of_the_unheards.description: Inspired by many concepts about infographics, art and giving a voice, I thought of a sound design platform which could be developed for viewing on a website, but also be displayed as a multimedia installation in public spaces such as exhibition spaces or in the entrance of Amnesty International Headquarters.
sonic_planet_the_voices_of_the_unheards.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: Hey Anne-Laure,I like the way that this concept incorporates the vocal element.  And, of course, I love that it can integrate with My Vocie ;-) Glad, as always, to be part of your virtual team!I think Sarah's suggestion of combining this concept with the temporary museum is a great one.  I think the verbal elements of the stories are just as important for the museum as the visual elements.  And, the audio is much more easily portable, so from a practical perspective this is also a good fit.Kudos to you for your interesting concept!
Thanks! I've just updated the concept to include Luz's museum concept and Sarah's "mid-tech" suggestion.

Hey Anne-Laure! Great thoughts here. I like that you thought of both a low-tech and a high-tech version. Maybe a "middle-tech" could be a pop-up type of sound-enabled display/booth, that has a screen/monitor or a projector, showing the webpage directly. This could also be combined with the Street Play idea ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/street-plays-a-video-tool-kit-for-unlawful-detention/ ) or a temporary type of museum ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/memories-museum-for-the-unlawful-detention/ ) for example.

Hi Sarah, thanks for your thoughts. I agree on the middle tech options of having monitors with direct access to sonic planet. You could even imagine a set of head phones associated with it. It could then be accessible in public spaces. It is indeed related to the museum of memories. I don't know why I forgot to link this concept to it! I'll do it right now.As for the street plays a video tool kit, I did not think of it. I am not sure how it will be combined but that could be an option to think of. You could also imagine, if you think of interactive options, we could have an option where people could add a story (it might not be to come up directly as you'll need some editing).

hi Anne-Laure,A colleague of mine just shared this light installation with me, at Christopher Henry Gallery, in NY: http://vimeo.com/30108920 It reminded me of your and Alan's 'Cube' concept. It uses about 4 projectors inside the object, imagine this in a public space, with sound bites as data comes flowing in from the computers projecting the data? It would be so powerful!I'm going to share this with Alan too.

Very nice installation. Thanks for sharing. I agree with you that images and sound together can be powerful. I had experimented with a friend of mine: http://vimeo.com/3539585The only problem is funding and getting the technology to work, but you can imagine variations of this. Public spaces can also be semi-public like in the entrance of public buildings (easier also if there's sound).

Hi Anne-Laure!I really like this concept, and I told Alan in his 'Cube' concept, I would imagine this kind of installation in a public place in developed countries, to initiate conversations and trigger peoples curiosity about what is in fact going on regarding human rights abuses in the world. It's a shame we don't see more of these projects on streets in capital cities in the world for example, which can have so much power and connections to raise the necessary attention. It would be great to visualize the data transcribed from the voices on huge screens in public squares regularly, such as the ones on Times Square, and Trafalgar Square, that would really boost our awareness of this!I like how you mention the web version of this installation: sound is such a powerful medium, and more and more people (especially younger generation) crave for more engaging and meaningful experiences online, so this could be something they could also learn through and share on Social Media channels, and hopefully visit the physical installation too.Very inspiring :)

Thanks Ana for your kind feedback. I agree with you sound is very powerful and I think that combining it with visualization can help reinforcing the point. The web version allows to do it without too much cost and it can be more interactive and provide more information.

Thanks, I love you like it.The webpage is really amazing, in the way it has the power to change.krate

comments.text: The article you have posted about this murderer is a tissue of lies. For the documented facts about Ram check out the website http://www.satpalramisguilty.20m.com/also my speech SATPAL RAM: A Case Study In Anti-Racist Brainwashing.The photo was not taken after his arrest but after an incident in prison. As this is a man who has admitted throwing urine over his gaolers, you might hesitate a guess as to how this happened.The fact that Ram is back in prison where he belongs and is now no longer mentioned in politically correct circles speaks for itself.
Thanks for sharing this story Ashwin. Any chance you can post some links to your sources for this? It'll help give us all a bit more context as we try to understand Satpal's experience and story.
http://www.ncrm.org.uk/campaigns/ram.html
