decentralize_the_network_own_and_protect.description: In order to fight against unlawful detention, it's important to make sure that the key data/resource (files, pictures, videos, contact lists, etc.) is owned and shared by the end-users. We need to decentralize the current network hierarchy.
decentralize_the_network_own_and_protect.creator: dc88a3b12e2251eb1327bd6d71c40230

comments.text: Lei, congratulations on designing a winning concept! Like Tom said, the Amnesty team was enthusiastic about your idea--and felt it could really become a design principle for future prototypes. Great work and thank you!
Congratulations Lei! Let's hope that the contacts you made to get the technical support on developing forward this concept are able to give some directions to the Amnesty International Team.
Congrats Lei! Well deserved.Was sorry to hear the recent sad news, in relation to Diaspora. The startup life can be tough.
Congratulations Lei! Will look forward to seeing how Amnesty brings this into future prototyping.The concept has great potential for creating distributed data redundancy in all sorts of situations.
Congratulations on your winning concept Lei!  The idea of corporate partnership, as proposed by Tom, is an interesting one.  Looking forward to seeing this concept progress...
I enjoyed working through this with the Amnesty team yesterday very much - I wondered whether a corporate storage partner would assist, Dropbox perhaps?

Tom, there is a prototype open source version of it, Diaspora. Unfortunately, due to  some dramatic events, the co-founder that Lei met was not able to give feedback on Lei's concept. Hopefully, Diaspora can help develop this. As it is Open Source, it should also be possible to take it one step further in the specific context of this challenge.

Diaspora does seem to be up and running although not yet quite as originally envisaged. Nevertheless if it remains GPL software the potential for creating a future dedicated distributed network exists. Would be interested to see if this can be developed into a distributed equivalent of RAID with full security and data redundancy.

Hello Lei, Great concept!, Im just a little bit worried about this hierarchy of information working against the track of essential information to actually liberate the accused individual, making data hard to track could potentially make it harder for family members to track the bad guys as well?, I believe a decentralized hierarchy of information sharing could potentially deteriorate Internets saftey as well. In your proposed scenario it makes sense for information to be encrypted and hard to track, but what if the resolution of the case or proof of inocence depended on someone elses information being available and easy to track?, would like to hear your thoughts around this idea... Thanks and great work!

Hello Lei, I like the general idea taking control of our own data and being able to control how we share it, also in the scenario you used I think it makes a lot of sense to make it harder to gather information from an individual; the only thing that scares me is that this same hierarchy could work against the person being charged if his freedom depended on getting someone elses information by the authorities. I believe this concept could work against general internet security and make it harder to get the bad guys as well; could you elaborate on this concern I have?.. Thanks and good work!

Thanks Lei for the update which takes into account all comments and clarifies what a distributed network could be and how it would make our data safer. Hopefully, you can get some of the members of the Diaspora team (it was great to know that they found this concept interesting) or other computer scientists to develop this concept.

First, this is basically a good idea, except for the part, if I understand correctly, you would never store files locally. If all of your stuff is always distributed, there would be an enormous data access lag. I am not even sure I could express it properly without resorting to expletives. I am not sure how a user would have any sort of useful time for example opening a word document, if the pieces of the document are literally all over the place, further some of the crucial pieces may reside on computers which are not currently available (machines go to sleep, are moved around, or go missing forever).  You would literally never be able to access your own files unless "all the the stars were in alignment", and you might just lose all of your work into the ether.A better way to do this, and you can already do this on your own today, would be to use something like PGP, or GPG with a virtual disk locally, and encrypt that disk to a private key with a strong passphrase. No government today can derive a 256-bit or higher private key, so your local data would for all purposes be permanently destroyed.  The key itself would have to be encrypted and stored on a third party server somewhere else in a different legal jurisdiction. Then you just automate backups of your PGP/GPG virtual disk to dropbox, or bittorrent, or whatever service of your chosing - it doesn't matter, with 256 AES public key encryption, it would basically take too many CIA computers too many years to crack.  So you can already do this today, for free, it's just a matter of getting your computer set up properly.

Hi Marion, thank you for the comments. I think data encryption is definitely needed and can be done by today's technologies. And it is important if the data is store locally. And you have a great point of view interms of what we should do if the computer/server is down and we cannot access our data, I will definitely think about this issue. However, the concept here is more focusing on how can we protect our online activities. Which we don't really have the control of those data and information under current internet hierarchy. To make it more clear, here is an example, we can encrypt the file in our computer, but how about the pictures and tweets we've been posting online? Once you post it, you hand the control of these data over to a centralized system. There's no way you can stop someone to get those information if they can have the access to the centralized system (servers). Let me know if you have any more suggestions to make this concept better.  Thank you !

I don't see how you can make something even more decentralized than Twitter. The basic idea behind Twitter is you have a single destination point for messages from all sorts of locations to arrive at - how they arrive to Twitter, is in a sense already distributed and anonymized. If you want an anonymous account, use a fake name, then use a web proxy when posting your messages.

Hmm...interesting points Marlon and replies Lei.The encryption approach is definitely important for security (whether local or distributed storage).As for the lag and stars being in alignment, these are clearly issues, but, in general, I'm open to the possibility that the Diaspora team and general tech community will make breakthroughs here (after all, 10 years ago, who thought we could use Google Docs for realtime document, spreadsheet, etc. collaboration in the cloud; or download large media files through P2P filesharing).Finally, in terms of decentralization, this is not just about avoiding tracking, but also preserving information integrity in areas where repressive governments actively censor Internet sites (not just by blocking foreign social media but also ordering popular domestic social media sites to turn over, filter out, & remove various content; which is exactly what China does by blocking Twitter, and tracking and censoring people on Weibo, the local Chinese version of Twitter).

As a whole I support this concept.  It is again using what is already in use today to address a situation not normally associated with said technology.  My only concern is the "what if" that would be associated with those potential "detainers" getting ready access to this information and having a better idea of how to identify their potential victims.

Hello Lei, congratulations on your concept making it to the short list. The expert panel loved the potential of your idea to disrupt the technology landscape and social networking platforms. You might take a look at sites such as The Guardian Project (https://guardianproject.info/) for inspiration. Is there a way that users could specify who receives what information? You might want to design for allowing people to reach out to both small and large groups. Please keep pushing this idea in terms of how you think it might become a reality and definitely tap into the OpenIDEO community for technology expertise.

Really a good idea, Lei. As I understand it this is essentially like a Torrent with encryption? But does it not automatically endanger everyone participating in the network? Unless you find a way to masquerade the other "servers". But even if each server knew only a few others, the network could easily be compromised by a central authority with full control over Internet communication, could it not? Not necessarily in the sense of gaining control over encrypted data, but in identifying all people participating in hiding information from them. I guess you would have to find a way to cloak in some way the exact position of servers in addition to spread your data among them. The encryption part itself may be enough to be arrested, even if you just host a server (e.g. your home PC).

Hi Johannes, thank you for the comments. This decentralized network idea is kind of like a Torrent with encryption. However, you also mentioned threats can be created by a cntral authority with full control over the internet communitcation, and this is exactly the kind of stucture we are tying to remove, with is the centralized network. And getting rid of the centralized network is the way to limit the threats you were talking about. It will be so hard for some one (government, special agents) to collect information without authentications from all the nodes spread through the network. They don't even know where to start looking, since there is not centralized information (like a data map).

That sounds really great. My network know-how is not substantial enough to understand the details. I just assumed that either reserved ports would be a giveaway or in/outgoing traffic monitoring of a particular server would allow identification of potentially uninvolved others. However, if this can be solved it is really great protection for political minorities or similar. I even based a concept on this one (transparency-through-anonymous-media).

Hu Lei,Well done, I like a lot your scenario, especially part "what happens later."We (three of us, each with a deep experience in IT) discussed similar idea. Our cincerns:1. Access point: I doubt that many people will trust themselves
Sorry, line interrupted, continuing: 1. I doubt that many people will trust themselves and access any public place to store the data
Hi Vesna,Thank you for sharing your concerns. Since you guys have a deep experience in IT, I would love to get more detailed feedbacks from you to make this concept more practical.Lei

Sorry, hope this time will be OK. The problem is that even one case of arresting BEFORE the data will be stored is enough to undermine teh entire concept.2. Sharing data (your computer storage, power etc.) is known from the whale project and some other projects requiring bigger resources (huge computation). It seems to me very similar to "Diaspora", but it could be that I did not understand everything. It is a GREAT concept and we also believe that the solution is there, together with the tunneling concept of internet access. Still, a few problems:*to access the first node*the bigger the network, the most powerfull, the less secure*everything (software needed) could be blocked in those countries, the only possibility is to educate and motive a hige mass of people to use it before it is bannedWe will try to lean on your concept, if we come up with some additional ideas (like simple ones: encript your mail, use tor technology, use mirror sites of amnesty international etc.)Good luck,Vesna

Hi Vesna,Below are my understanding and thoughts about your concerns:1. You are right, the worst thing can happen is arresting BEFORE the data will be stored distributely and removed from local drive. I thank if we dig deeper, there will be lots of brilliant ideas emerge to address this scenario. For example - one hotkey to start sending all un-sent data out and remove them locally, I guess this quick action should be completable even facing a suddent break in and arrest.2. To access the first node - I don't quite understand the concept here, maybe you can give me an example :)3. The bigger the network... - Based on my understanding, decentralize the network is all about break the huge network into small sub-network. I agree that the bigger the network, the less secure. So it's up to you to decide how big you want your network to be to maintain the security level. 4. Everything could be blocked in thoes contries - Yes, at least right now it seems like the case. And this concept and a lot of other concepts are trying to make blocking become more and more difficult. As I mentioned, in current Centralized Network hierarchy, power totally belongs to the side who controls the server, owns the data, which in most cases, this is the government/corporate side. And the one of the results is that they can easily block the access, cuz they "build the path". To decentralize the network is the process to take the control back to end users, we will own our server, our own data, which means we will have the option to "build the path" and "change the path" as needed. And the result will be harder and harder for the government to work with corporate to block the access.Hope this will help you guys build your concepts. Cheers!Lei
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
It is such an honor for the OpenIDEO Student Chapter @ NYU-POLY!

Very interesting concept, and it really addresses the danger of having files stored locally. However... I have a question. If the files are distributed over several 'nodes', would that not endanger the others as well? The files have to be stored somewhere, and if Bob's computer gets seized, the government might be able to access the files anyway, even if they're not stored locally, but in the same way Bob can access them.Or would the files be encrypted and stored partially on random nodes, only to be accessed by 'authorized' users? If that's the case, we'd need to look at the authentication of authorized users. That is often the weakest link in information security. (I've seen examples where people stick their passwords on post-it notes on their screens.)I'm just curious to understand how this works.

Hi Arjan, you have asked some really valuable questions. Here is the answer based on my own understanding of this decentralized network concept. First of all, all the data in this network hierarchy is encrypted for sure, and the direct connection between every two nodes has to be two-way authorized. The second key element here is that when we say own your data, it includes own your log file, that's even more critical most of time then just own your files. I will use your example to explain more.Bob's computer gets seized, the government will be able to access the files only if they know the way Bob accesses the files. Then how can they find out the way Bob accesses the files? The simplest ways are check Bob's browser history/cache, check Bob's IM conversation history, check Bob's FTP connection history, etc. What if Bob's computer does not even store all this LOG FILE? The government will not be able to find any file or any contacts who's working with Bob. And this is "own your log file" means. How can Bob do this? It can be as simple as deleting all the local log files every one hour (of course, it might get more complicated when the concept gets really implemented). Hope this can give you a better idea how this works. Thank you for the questions. We can always discuss more about it if you are interested :)

Hi Lei!Wow this is a huge breakthrough. From reading your concept, if every thing proves doable regarding technology development, you seem to stand at the top of the hierarchical solution to a lot of side problems we've discussed in concepts until now. This is proven by you connecting many concepts within your own one, including my Info Hub + A-L's Shift Van, and explaining the scenarios these would be in. I'm very happy the Info Hub inspired you, and you picked up on the crucial and essencial use of the Hub - "There could be a possibility of then retrieving back into the Info Hub (via USB or Bluetooth, etc), all the documented material from the locals, anonymously." This would really solve the problem if local authorities seized the hub and accessed the data transmitted to it. I also personally like this because I'm quite pro-protecting our data, like you mention, it's everyone's job. This applies especially for the Amnesty teams working on these issues, not just victims of human rights, so it really should be a movement that we provide globally.Regarding the Diaspora development, have you and your colleagues gone far in solving the technical challenges involved in creating this decentralized network? How long till it could become reality? How much competition would this service face with companies such as Apple (iCloud), or do you imagine Diaspora being a service used more by private organizations such as NGO's or human rights organizations, needing strict data protection?Congrats again :)

Hi Ana,The Diaspora project is still in Beta version now. At current phase, the team is focusing on applying the decentralized network concept to the social network platform. My concept here is actually beyond their current scope. I believe more implementations is not that hard to achive in terms of technology shift, however, it will be much harder for people to change their mindset and using behavior. As you pointed out, this decentralized concept is against most of the current online products and services (like iCloud), which most of the people relies on in their daily life. So I think here is a great platform to showcase how to apply this technology and how it can really impact the society.I've tried to reach out to the Diaspora team to find out if they are interested in getting involved in this challenge here. And I'm also planning to contact Professor Keith Ross from NYU-POLY CS department for more input regarding the feasibility of this decentralized network concept. I will keep you guys updated. Lei
Hi Lei! That's great, please keep us posted indeed, I look forward.Keep up the great work!
very interesting, nice job
Thank you, Marsy.

Great scenario thinking  really helps others to engage and join the fab conversation you've started.Not sure what's going on with the links towards the bottom of your post. Might be good to re-add these using the Rich Text Editor above  the Description field, first by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post. Here's some tips on adding links: http://bit.ly/oi_link If you're having problems you may need to cut & paste the text in fresh, rather than working with what's there. Good luck & keep up the great ideating + collaboration!
Thanks Meena. I have fixed the links in my post.

Hi Lei,I love the idea that you're thinking about the infrastructure and some of the "security" issues that we've been discussing about several concepts. This is very much keeping in mind the reminder from the concepting tips regarding potential "risks" of technology. I could see many of the concepts suggested so far using the decentralized network you are suggesting.I hope you can get in touch with the Diaspora team to see how to develop this idea.I also like how you made your concept (and its value) clear through the scenario.al

Agreed with Anne-Laure, good job Lei in identifying how a decentralized (& hopefully cryptographically secure) system could help protect activists, freedom of expression, & information flow. Applicable to many of the social network/tech based concepts (such as Amnesty Observer App) & beyond (broader implications).

Just providing another current example to illustrate where such a concept would help protect information flow.Imagine if, in the United States, not only were the Occupy Wall Street protesters completely arrested/dispersed, but any talk about protests (even protests in another country) was censored online. This is what happens in China.Currently, "Occupy" has become a banned word in China (after official Chinese news outlets first used it to illustrate the weaknesses of the US), due to the Occupy Wall Street protests that started in the US. For example, on Weibo (China's version of Twitter), you can't find "tweets" where  "occupy" is followed by a place name, it's automatically removed. Similar bans were in affect about the Arab Spring. Often, the banning can be quite tricky: you could post something and from your account it'd appear like you had successfully "tweeted", but in reality, your "tweet" would be invisible to the public, and in trending topics/search results.Chinese social media companies actually setup internal censorship departments to comply with the government. It'd be much harder to control a decentralized social network this way.
Great example Vincent. It seems that Lei's idea of building upon a decentralized network like Diaspora could really have an impact.
Thanks Vincent for sharing another great example.

This seems like a very important subject, and I like how it increases the security of interacting with any online service. Having a "backup" of safety like this in any service or application would lower the threshold of participation for people who feel they are in danger of having their rights violated.I see a possibility for building on this what comes to sharing the data - what if Bob gets taken away in any case, and the authorities confiscate his computer etc. As I understand, the data still remains in the network. Could there be a system to grant others access to one's files, either permanently or in case of emergency? Maybe Bob's network could use the data to track him down or continue his work.

Hi Soila, I think it is totally possible to track Bob down or continue his work by using this decentralized network.For example, Bob knows his work contains a lot of sensitive data, and since every computer in this network hierarchy can be treated as a server, Bob never put any data in his own computer/server, instead his work exists among 10 different servers (his friends' servers, family member's server, etc.). And all these 10 servers can be accessed if you are authorized. In this case, all the people who work with Bob or support Bob should be authorized. So even if Bob is in danger, people who has the access to his data can still continue on his work.

Nice job Lei. The scenario definitely illustrates the place for a solution like Diaspora. Quick question would Diaspora or some other entity, like Amnesty perhaps, then host a "node" to facilitate these kinds of communications?  (looking forward to more concepts from the Student Chapter!)

Thank you Jason. Ideally, any entity (including individuls and organizatoins like Amnesty) should be able to host a "node". However, we don't want to see any specific node owns/controls too much data/information, since this is the oppsite of decentralize the network.

decentralize_the_network_own_and_protect.title: Update: Decentralize the Network, Own and Protect Your Data

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

emergency_shoes.description: As hanzel and grettel left crumbs to find their way home, a device that leave satellite signals perhaps from a special ink  or microchips might be applied in the shoes so that the user can leave marks from the place he was last seen. This shoes might include a microphone to.
emergency_shoes.creator: b25eceb864e68472a0eefe15448f9637

comments.text: I saw the Nike + sensor+ ipod, its great for my concept!!! Thanx Arjan. That is a very nice ilustration. However I think it shouldn't work with the ipod, for this purposes because that is the first thing they take away.

I was thinking along the same lines. Maybe a nice illustration for your concept is the Nike+ sensor. This is actually a sort of step counter. Not sure how it works exactly, but it has to do with pressure applied on it while running/walking. It is placed inside a shoe. Using the principle of activation through applied pressure, it could be so that if a certain sequence of tapping is applied, only then a distress signal and location are broadcast. This would mean that someone is only 'tracked' when the need is there, and not constantly.

Thank you Arjan, that is exactly what I'm saying: to be tracked and recorded only if the system is activated. However I didn't know Nike was working with sensors, very interesting tip. I'll check it out

So Lei left me thinking about the different stages and characteristics of the participants, pretty much as playing chess:-After the arrest: Lei's proposal is a defensive tactic of the group, which I agree a 100%this keeps the abusers to advance.However, their's a moment before and during the arrest that has to be thought:-Before: the only defensive tactic would be hidding your identity that an activist cannot do, because if you're fighting for good you can't hide.- During: most of the detentions of this kind are, of course, denied completely by the government. They will refuse even to know who the person is. So, if there is no prove there is no crime. Which is why I thought of a microphone that records at least the first instance of the detention. However, that is not enough for a trial or an international acusation.This brings me to the participants:International activists:- they are well organized-they have access to tecnology- well educated- they have access to social networks- they have lawyers -they have international support- they are fewerActivists:- they are not that well organized- they follow a leader- the education level varies a lot from someone very well educated to someone that is not- they are most of the participants- they have no lawyers, or not very influential lawyers- they don't have international support, a little few might have contact in the outside.- most of them won't have acces to tecnology or a network.So, both work in groups and they mix. so its about working in community and have a strategy as follows:Organization in groups of five or seven perhaps.One team leader: perhaps an intenational activist or not. This person most coordinate and educate the others. Specially keep them calm at all moments.They should be all inmediately connected by some means, I'm thinking something like a panic attack button that can be activated when they activate the mic on the shoes. So, they'll keep each other in sight but not together. At the moment of one arrest, the detainee should push the button that will alert the others , might be by a vibrating feeling and activate the mic on the shoes that will record sound inmediately in the web. The closest team member of the detainee will inmediately record visually what's happening and this will also uploaded in real time so that evidence is undeniable.

Hi Marsy, thanks for sharing your idea. I thought you might want to check out these Tips for Concepting we've put together  there's some discussion there about how tracking technologies might actually lead to negative consequences for detainees http://bit.ly/n8Xc1O. Perhaps you'll be inspired to incorporate some of these concerns into your idea? Looking forward to seeing more of you in this challenge.

Alright then, such as a radio in Colombia transmit the messages of the families to the victims of the FARC. Then the tracking devices can be eliminate and leave the microphone on the shoes so that the detainees can be able to transmitt their messages and be recorded on a web page or broadcast by radio waves if its necessary. This is because the detainees won't have access to a cellphone, that's the first thing they'll take. The detainees definately won't have access to a computer or internet. Perhaps they'll even take their watches, glasses, jewelry and clothing. So it should be something that doesn't stand up or call the attention.

Hi Marsy, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know if you face any problems. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

emergency_shoes.title: Emergency shoes

comments.text: Intriguing thoughts, Shawn. You might like to check out our Tips on Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking + monitoring could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. There are unfortunately also instances where governments and police can be part of the problem of unlawful detention in some global locations. Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

shift_freedom_sticker_sign_up_campaign.description: Create a signature or Amnesty sign-up campaign around the topic of Shift Freedom. When people sign up, they will be sent 10 cool Shift Freedom stickers which they can place on their keyboard and give to their friends
shift_freedom_sticker_sign_up_campaign.creator: 046c14ccc821e094ab37859494deeacc

comments.text: Hi Anne, love how this idea keeps the campaign topic at top-of-mind on someone's keyboard.

Agreed. Creative way to keep things top-of-mind.I wonder if there's a way to relate how often the average person presses a shift key with some stat on unlawful detention/human rights. Perhaps you could even link the counting of shift key presses(by a downloadable program from the "ShiftFreedeom.org" website) to some kind of micro donation pledge that gets totaled up to be donated say at the end of 1 day.

Nice indeed and I like all the associated symbols with "shift".I'm also wondering if it could not be associated to Jason's universal symbol "III": http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-universal-unlawfully-detained-symbol-to-spread-in-case-of-emergency/I think that the word "shift" is powerful in terms of symbolic connotations (on the keyboard and more generally) and it also has "musical" / "poetic" power (sorry I can't find the right word; by this I mean it's easy to say, to remember ("it sticks"), to combine with other words...).I like Vincent's idea of associating the shift key on the keyboard to some "action"...

That is such a great observation Haiyan. The target group of this kind of campaign probably spend a significant amount of hours a day in front of her/his keyboard. If the sticker is well designed and in a non-work-intrusive way, I think it can both bring meaning and delight to people who would place it on the keyboard. Vincent, I love your ideas about making some kind of symbolic connection between the Shift key and the overall purpose of the campaign. It makes it very actionable and as well speak to the unconscious at the same time! I will need to dig a bit more into the numbers, to see if I can see some possible connections. But ANY IDEA IS WELCOME: Lets build this concept together!Thank you Anne-Laure for the suggestion. i will definitely check out Jasons idea.

Great idea Anne. I was going trough all the ideas and this one definitly "sticked" me. It's very simple but yet very powerfull. Also I really enjoyed Vincent perspective. I also think it could be very powerfull if we could relate this kind of campaign with everyday actions, specially the inconscient ones (pressing the shift key) and by doing that, create an impact somehow.

Thank you for your feedback Tiago. It is nice to get confirmed that I am not the only one who thinks "Shift. Freedom" would be a powerful tag line for a concept. Do you have any additional ideas for how we could relate the campaign to other daily activities, apart from the actual "SHIFT" key?
Congrats on being today's onsite Featured Concept!

I definitely echo everyone's remarks. I think the execution is elegant...and a perfect mock-up! As Anne-Laure suggested it would be nice if we could come up with an equally elegant way to pair it with the universal symbol. I think the keyboard campaign is just so clean and clear, maybe we pair it in a parallel campaign?

either pair it or a follow up campaign.two other options: find a way to have the universal symbol added as a "trademark" sign... or it will just symbolize "freedom" (or lack of freedom). Maybe you could get 2 types of stickers...

Great to hear from you Jason! Hello from Japan. I will look more into your campaign and see if I can think of how the two ideas could allign to become something stronger than the two concepts standing alone. I am hoping to facilitate a "Brainstorn in a Box" event at my university in Tokyo on Wednesday, so might see some connections after that.
Hi! That sounds great, I'll do the same. Can't wait to see what your event produces!
Way to go, Anne! Engaging ideas are often simple and can be featured in everyday contexts.

Working on it. Still trying to connect a few dots here, to make the idea even more relevant, educational and top of mind! It amazes me how ideas travel and develop. It all started with a story about somebody who bought a turquoise typewriter... which took me to this fascinating typewriter restoration store in SF, with an eccentric piano player (-who I am still not sure whether he was for real or a super talented actor!)... and now the idea is getting all these amazing build-ons from all over the world. OpenIDEO is the best!

shift_freedom_sticker_sign_up_campaign.title: Shift Freedom - sticker sign up campaign

america_has_a_conscious_they_just_haven_.description:
Trash reality television dominates the American Television Culture Landscape (ATCL)...... but what if we USE this type of programming for the greater good? As I learned on Oprah's 'Life Class', we can do better :). The time for 'favors' for the one percent is over. This is not a CAUSE where your public standing and ability to generate publicity should reflect your level of SUPPORT. Certainly detainee's families have other things to worry about.

Shows like Nat Geo's 'Locked Up Abroad' or even the Dateline 'To Catch a Predator' series garner huge support from the public in ratings. What if we used the detainee and family stories for a weekly television program series that did something more than entertain? Celebrity actors and actresses could act in re-creation segments of the programming to show support. This is a huge success every year on Broadway in 24 Hour Plays.

With ties to a website the program could show how each individual can make a difference.
america_has_a_conscious_they_just_haven_.creator: e1eabac0055a442f830cdca02aec14b6

comments.text: POWER to the PEOPLE

america_has_a_conscious_they_just_haven_.title: AMERICA has a CONSCIENCE, they just haven't been sold it. Reality TV for the Greater Good.

flarecaster.description: A Flare is a short distress message that is sent via SMS text messaging system.
flarecaster.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: Very interesting inspiration Avi. Thanks for sharing It reminded me of Sarah's inspiration on 911: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/9-1-1/Flare seems to indeed solve several issues about access (to the internet), stressful situations (when you can't talk, or just don't have the time).In the video, I thought that the idea of how people can become "heroes" but also recognizing that acting sometimes can appear (or in fact be) difficult or not that easy.In fact, this is an idea that you highlighted in another inspiration:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/resistance-starts-with-saying-no/which resonated with Ashwin's inspiration:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/held-by-the-nypd/thanks again for inspiring!

I'm so happy to learn about the Flarecaster because it calms some of my fears of being in an emergency.  Sometimes I think about how I would react in an emergency and what basic instincts I would fall back on. But then I also think of the many "what if" scenarios that would require different plans of action, and I wonder if I would be able to remember these different plans in times of panic. The Flarecaster was "calming" because 1) it makes use of an existing behaviour (dialing emergency number) that is practically engrained since childhood; and 2) it addresses those "what if" scenarios, like what if I don't have a lot of time? Being unlawfully detained (+ in a foreign country, + not knowing the language, + not knowing the laws, + all the other what ifs) must be mind-bogglingly complex. So I think these two strong features of the Flarecastertaking advantage of what the user knows how to do and being flexible enough to work in all those "what if" casesare definitely things to think about. Thanks for the post, Avi!
Great feedback Yen! Sounds like you've identified a couple of key elements in the Flarecaster system  definitely things to keep in mind as we head toward Concepting!

flarecaster.title: Flarecaster

hey_everyone_s_going_to_find_out_about_t.description: How can we use signs and communication systems to prevent unlawful detention?
hey_everyone_s_going_to_find_out_about_t.creator: 59f5c563832e7d355b411c52f49bc449

comments.text: Nice one, Yen. You've raised a great insight around public status (negative vs positive) here. This could feed a number of ideas in the upcoming Concepting phase and might be be taken forward in numerous directions  perhaps even in different ways to the original inspiration of arm bands. That's the great thing about the Inspiration phase  it gives us the opportunity to share examples which may trigger associated thoughts along the way. Keep 'em coming, guys!

So funny,I just told Nate about this and he said, "I would do something wrong so I would get an armband, and show people that I'm a badass". Ha, which of course he would never do, but, it's an interesting thought.I wonder what makes people respect a punishment/embarrassment versus rebelling against it or turning it into something "cool".

So glad you picked that up, because that Helly Kitty was already Round 2. Round 1 was a plaid armband that officers liked so much that they kept them. I think it's also interesting that the design of the band with its cuteness factor and hearts represents the opposite of the negative in this scenario. It seems to identity the officers as ambassadors of compassion and friendliness, not as offenders.

Hi Yen,Interesting ideas that seems to propose some ideas to the questions raised by Christian(http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/inverting-the-problem) and Arjan (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/what-can-we-learn-from-jack-bauer/) around how can we also prevent unlawful detention to happen. Maybe making it clear to the performers that it is not OK, that they won't be protected is important. It reminds the Zimbardo's prison experiment (http://www.prisonexp.org/) where he shows the importance of "roles" and uniforms. By putting a hello-kitty band to a police officer, you're in a way destroying the power of their uniform. Thanks for the inspiration!al

hey_everyone_s_going_to_find_out_about_t.title: Hey, Everyone's Going to FInd Out About This!

fire.description: I took a self-defense class a few years ago, and in between all the training rounds, one idea really stuck with me.
fire.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Good point for consideration!

Maybe the "fire!" of unlawful detention is making human connections between people who could help and people who have been detained unlawfully. Awareness among "outsiders" that it could happen to them someday, and that you don't necessarily have to do something illegal to get locked away for life, might inspire them to act towards justice.

Alix, you're so right - it's about creating awareness and connections between people who've been detained or imprisoned and those who can help. Perhaps you're inspired to come up with your own example of a word or image to raise awareness? :)
Hmmm
This is interesting but sad. People always pay more attention when themselves are involved.

Excellent anecdote!  Interestingly I've experienced the story told in a slightly different way.  Another reason strangers are more likely to gather at the exclamation of 'fire' is for the sensationalism of it. For the same reason people slow down on the highway as they pass an accident on the other side of the median, people will rush to see a fire. They want to see something exceptional from their everyday routine; they want to be entertained.  While this notion is somewhat distasteful, and far less altruistic than we might hope, it is nevertheless a powerful and effective tool for generating an audience.  If we think about it, I believe we can all agree that the general media sensationalizes events regularly.This success in being able to draw a crowd is why the technique is suggested in self-defense.  Often when atrocious acts become public, the perpetrators are discouraged from continuing.  Taking this one step further, if enough people crowd around a burning building, a special few might just run in to pull someone out.

Really terrific insights here Gabe - I'm so glad you shared this and I am sure you're right (even though we might not want to admit it). A spectacle does draw a crowd, even when it's an unfortunate one. Thanks so much for joining the conversation :)

Thanks Ashley for sharing this perspective. It reminded me the story of Kitty Genovese, this woman stabbed several times in Queens in 1964 with no one coming to help her despite her calling her help, and her being heard by 38 people."For more than half an hour thirty-eight respectable, law-abiding citizens in Queens watched a killer stalk and stab a woman in three separate attacks in Kew Gardens." NY  Times article written by Martin Gansberg and published on March 27.Gladwell in The Tipping Point also describes this case. It is not very positive but it just shows how "help" might not be the "right word" but it also connects to the comment made by Alix about the importance of raising the awareness of outsiders...

Very interesting perspective, worth to think about. But one thing that comes to mind is the old folk-tale where Peter shouts "Wolf" a couple of times too much, so the bystanders ignore him when there actually arises the real danger of the real wolf for the villagers.
Such a great point Johan! We'd hate to be the boy who cried wolf! Definitely something to think about as we explore this Mission.
Indeed an interesting perspective but Peter and the Wolf comes easily to mind... I guess in this case, while there'd be no fire, there would be "something" that motivated the shout.

Interesting. Somehow related: in a workshop last week, I heard a story of the first things helicopter pilots are trained to do when things go wrong. They have to say 'I'm panicking'. By acknowledging that, apparently, they get a subconsious boost to do the things they should do. Or get more calm. Funny how language has a big effect.

Arjan, I've found this to be very true; acknowledging the "what's so" of a situation allows us to move past it.  I think this idea is a powerful tool for diffusing disagreements as well.  How many arguments persist/escalate because the other person feels unheard? Even if we disagree with someone, if we start our conversation reiterating her/his viewpoint, so they know we hear and understand them, effective discourse can occur.
Really nice thoughts Claire, and Arjan that's an interesting story about the pilots. Sometimes we just need to acknowledge the situation before we can move forward. Great points.

Very Witty recommendation to ourselves out of a pickle... but if the intended help does not arrive cause they see no-fire or smoke... (per city life exp, hard to convince ppl of anything) but... one sure word that causes reaction, wait for it....  "FREE"!
Interesting...hmm...perhaps it'd be fruitful to look at what kind of specific words/phrases have been effectively used to mobilize communities to rise up in protest?

fire.title: Fire!

pizzini_means_in_sicilian_a_little_piece.creator: 9617aef4427f40deea8d811371f75dc6

comments.text: I think that this is an interesting take on encrypted communication. If perhaps we could translate it into modern terms, the usage of multiple factors (GPS, nearby WiFi, Position of Celestial bodies) to find the location of a person to an accurate level.
YES! trafsorm an old practise(as Tayfun said before) in a new one.
Great analogous inspiration, Valentina! Learning from a person who's keen to hide provides great insights on our quest to help people uphold human rights.
Thanks Meena, yes right! I think if we observe from another prospective we will have many inspiration.

This is like old time encryption, all pieces are needed to figure out the message. Pieces alone may not mean much (in other words, if it is found by the detainers, it may be ignored which is great for detainee)

comments.text: Interesting article about the implications of the use of social media for activism, which raises important questions about how to handle security & anonymity.Should social media companies simply remain neutral platform providers or is there a greater social responsibility/opportunity for supporting activism?How about in cases like China, where the license to operate/ability to even be viable is quite restricted/controlled by the government (Facebook, Youtube, etc. are blocked. Domestic equivalents have internal teams to self-censor user generated content & remain on the good side of the government)? E.g. I'm acquainted with Chinese web entrepreneurs/VCs that have had promising ventures simply shut down by the government, and keep traveling IDs under multiple names, in the event they need to make a quick exit out of the country. Thanks for sharing Marty!

the_role_of_social_media_in_the_arab_spr.title: The role of social media in the Arab Spring

personal_emergency_network.creator: b2705ccf3a1876f9636bd018eec2b261

comments.text: This is awesome and has inspired my idea to utilize video journalism. Public witnesses help but lasting evidence uploaded to youtube or replayed on TV will immortalized these concepts.  Don't stop at taking pictures, record injustice in action and the upload it to a network. Create a short film and let others experience it first hand.  Brilliant idea mate!
Great idea! I think if it were paired with my inspiration (SIRI - Your Personal Assistant) it would help to get the information out even quicker.
Thanks, and yes let's combine some kind of personal alert network with your idea of a voice response!

I don't think we can be over-reliance on social networks like facebook or twitter because there are many social networks may be blocked in some countries so that make it invalidation. BUT I like the idea of creating a mobile app that sends an alert to a personal emergency network. People could send emergency news to contacts who are in the personal list. It's one fast and direct method to keep noticed. Nice.
Yes, I think you may be right about your comment on social media availability. So let's focus on the personal network.

Hi there Hubert, The Satellite Sentinel Project is an existing project that gives real time imagery of the movement of troops, civilians and conflicts in Sudan. This is joint venture between George Clooney, Google and some other anti-Genocide organizations. The satellite images provide a lot of information in terms of warehouses with armor and other stuff.. shift_amnesty_international_s_image.description: There are a lot of concepts proposing campaigns for Amnesty International where the goal is to educate people about illegal detentions. But Amnesty also has to campaign itself as an organization and remove some of the negative connotations and criticisms it faces among the public (yes it does).
shift_amnesty_international_s_image.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: Hi AshwinWell done for highlighting the challenges Amnesty faces in promoting its brand in authoritarian, 'low tech' countries. I put low tech in quotes because often most authoritarian governments ensure their populations get no access to high tech that would liberate their minds. Instead, such governments monopolise high tech so that it can aid their grip on power and minds. For example, high speed internet access will be available in government organs, but the rest of the population has to endure slow, frustrating speeds.
Also, it is easier to snoop around in a high-tech environment but it's harder to control word-of-mouth, a micro press, HAM radio or a pirate server.
Provocative discussion, guys! I like how you've under-pinned the critique with solution-oriented Concepts drawn from across our challenge.

Thanks you. I was actually wondering if it is possible to build upon concepts and inspirations from other challenges because it's a great resource. There is a treasure trove of knowledge that can be tapped-into if we could build upon it. Also, it would invite people who are "lurkers" on this challenge to participate at any point.

Great insight Ashwin and nice way to think about an actor of this challenge, the sponsor: Amnesty International. I think that many of the concepts posted can help building this positive image but it has to be done with the awareness that the image is not always negative. Maybe some of the criticisms have to be kept in mind when choosing which concepts to first start developing and implementing.Transparency as Manjul suggested as well as showing the impact are two important elements of such an effort.

I think you're right. Perhaps not all criticisms are unfounded but you have to change the perception at the source. Amnesty International has to have more appeal. Their campaigns do have visual impact (some would consider it to be gruesome) but how much effect does it have on eliciting action? It think that should be one of their goals too.

Great point, Ashwin.  I think that if the goal is to get mass engagement across a wide cross section of the global populace, the first criticism you outline is certainly true.  Divorcing yourself from the core constituents that provide the passion and "heart" behind the cause is tough. Instead of taking a tack of separation.   One way to do this is to focusing the messaging  to be more universal.  Another criticism is that do people who participate actually move the needle?  Is there a way to surface the impact that people can make at any scale of effort?  (i.e. Kickstarter meter to goal, gamin mechanics)

It's a good question. Do participants have an impact? I think they do. Imagine the benefits of an effective campaign: Will it increase the cooperation of the citizens, make them apply pressure through anonymous letters? Help them speak out against a "repeat-offender" government? Give them the confidence to do what they feel right in their conscience? Hopefully. That's the goal that the campaign designers need to work towards. Amnesty International is not only about freeing the unlawfully detained. It's about the confidence of the backing, it's about facilitating change, they're only a resource for a societal shift, but an important one.

Hi Ashwin,Great stuff! Having read the above - I can't help but think that Amnesty always has set out to tick the above boxes, but obviously en route certain aspects have become dim as compared to others - maybe the keyword here is TRANSPARENCY? An open input and output stance is what might be needed > which further leads me into thinking about what Open Ideo is doing, an open access platform that takes and gives (literally)...and someone like me feels satisfied after having spent a few hours a week posting here. Maybe a real time open access face  / stem of Amnesty is a useful step?

You're right, transparency is important to any organization, especially one that upholds human rights. There are some limitations due to security but if there are many concepts here that deal with decentralizing the network and protecting data. But I think for this concept, low tech solutions are more effective. I mean, television and print media still reach a lot of people but how do we design a communication channel around the constraint of censorship? That's where Amnesty needs to join with other organizations with more access (Red cross, for example?) to get the word across.

shift_amnesty_international_s_image.title: Shift Amnesty International's Image

_help_i_m_getting_arrested_app.description: I'm Getting Arrested is a creative Android app that was inspired by Occupy Wall Street movement. It lets you quickly notify your family, friends, and crack legal team (if you have one) of your situation with a single tap of your finger.
_help_i_m_getting_arrested_app.creator: 0a325eef3bbebf6d34d64bb12f63a8f2

comments.text: Would you be able to have access to a phone if you are arrested? When would a person be able to send this out? That would be the only reservation I would have for this app. Once you are handcuffed, I think it would be hard to gain access to a cell phone. Is there a solution for this?

I can totally see your point. I've been asking this myself, too. This is certainly not a fail proof option. It would only work with a hand in a pocket and the finger on the button. Another problem is: how do you access the app when you are, i.e. busy taking photos of the events with the same phone? There must be another way to trigger it. Maybe an "Arrest listen mode" that listens to you shouting "I'm getting arrested".
Love this idea! Maybe it can be voice activated by Miranda rights
yeah this voice source can even save and send the entire  conversation between the police and the person getting arrested..

A timely Inspiration Lars, which has been featuring quite a bit on this challenge. And as we move forward into Concepting it will be interesting to consider what we can learn from this context & app which could be transferred or changed for very different contexts (eg. war zones, ares where smartphone do not dominate, etc.)

_help_i_m_getting_arrested_app.title: 'Help I'm getting arrested' App

improving_petitioning_through_technology.description: Applying tech to petitioning can make it more accessible, effective, & powerful; even helping protect petitioners (who're petitioning against injustices like others unlawful detention) themselves from unlawful detention & other human rights abuses.
improving_petitioning_through_technology.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Though this concept wasn't selected for refinement, just wanted to update it with everyone's builds, as I: 1) believe improving petitioning through technology can have a significant impact in fighting unlawful detention, human rights abuses, & injustice; and 2) want to acknowledge people's great feedback and builds.

Thanks for Vincent sharing this and giving people a good example how to start this concenpt phase. I am a new user here so it is really helpful. The system is definitely incomplete. I am just wondering that why there is no email response system. Petitioner can use email to petition and get their respond without facing the risk of "Black jail" It is a basic system that most companies have applied. isnt it ? Technology could change the way people petition for sure. However, some fundamental issues like politics should be prior considered. People wont have much democracy in communism country like China. Some technology solutions may be prohibited within China. So media and public opinions are important to force government to face the problem and fix it.

Welcome to OpenIDEO Shawn =)You're quite right about this"Black Jail" problem being indicative of broader & more deep rooted issues. In terms of the government, agreed that the media & the public can and should play a key part in catalyzing reform.Hopefully, this concept, which makes use of technologies already being used commonly & legally in China, would be one way for people to begin to have more influence in how they are governed, while getting the needed approval by the government which has an interest in combating corruption & addressing issues in order to maintain social harmony/wellbeing.Would love to hear more of your thoughts on how to 1) increase the chance of this improved petitioning system being adopted, and 2) increase the motivation, capability, & effectiveness of the media & public to create change in general. Maybe you could even post a concept along those lines?

Hmm...just read that, in India, at least 12 people (including a policeman) so far this year were murdered after invoking the Right to Information Act (which allows any citizen to receive copies of government data/documentation within 30 days) to expose local political corruption. A greater number have been attacked, though not killed after filing applications, in some cases having their information passed to criminals: for example, one man reported being stabbed, beaten with pipes, and attacked with acid outside a local government office.Apparently, according to a Yale University doctoral field experimental study (Leonid Peisakhin and Paul Pinto, 2008), these RTI requests are pretty effective for countering corruption: in this case, slum dwellers being asked for bribes to get new ration cards. Unfortunately, this has led to violent retaliation, especially in remote areas where the local official may have a conflict of interest: revealing problems that could lead to reprimands/job loss.This India RTI issue seems related to the China Black Jail situation. Perhaps, the "Petitioning through Technology" concept may also have applicability here: allowing Indian citizens to submit RTI requests (perhaps with an anonymous option?) to a central department (through mobiles, online, RTI centers independent of the local gov, etc.) which then forwards & enforces follow-up on information requests (while excluding identifying information) to local government offices. The central RTI department would then send the copy to the requester and/or post the information to be publicly accessible (such as online).Anyways, this is just armchair theorizing. Would appreciate the perspective of our community members who have a better on-the-ground understanding of the situation in India.For reference, here's the article I came across about India RTI attacks:http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/in-india-whistleblowers-pay-with-their-lives-10202011.html

What I found shocking (not that I'm naive, but still), is the fact that local authorities rather jail people in black jails to prevent them from petitioning and being punished by the central authority for having too many complaints coming from that region, than actually solve the problems. The system itself is great, but it has become ineffective as the use is corrupted. The central government could do something here to improve the situation.Back to your concept: using technology can be very effective, but I also think a mind shift is necessary. Technology can also be subject to censorship.

Indeed Arjan, a shift is necessary (not just an individual mind shift, but a broader political/cultural one as well).The challenge is mitigating immediate problems in the current system, while also helping promote reform in the long run.In this case, it's partly a function of what gets measured/rewarded having a significant influence on what gets done (combined with the effects of absolute "local" power).On a different level, and to relate to your & my consulting experiences Arjan, this is also true in many corporations, where your incentive system can lead to people gaming the system, and information being distorted/hidden as it moves up the chain. Issue raising/whistle blowing can sometimes be stifled in these situations as well.This concept is about providing an effective alternative direct communication channel, sort of like the executive team taking individual staff members out to lunch/having an open door policy. This could be the start of organizational transformation and cultural change.

Great thoughts, as usual Vincent!One thing that strikes me in the Financial Times article is the existence of physical locations where people can go and deposit their complaints (which might be relevant for illiterate populations, but the experience can also feel... "scary" and intimidating). I wonder whether this concept could also include more "independent" type of petition bureaus, created by regular citizens/civil society (more reassuring). They could then transmit the information in the centralized system (then the access to only one computer / phone is necessary).

Thanks Sarah! That's an interesting idea to create "independent" petitioning centers.Any thoughts on a) how to certify/signal a reputable center, and b) how to ensure these centers aren't targeted by local officials/hired "Interceptors" (either by abducting people heading towards centers, or by even setting up fronts as centers themselves)?

Hi,I like the "independent" petition centers. It does make a lot of sense.Great idea Sarah!It made me think of the 'scribe office" in developing countries or the telephone ladies in Bangladesh (http://money.cnn.com/2006/12/04/news/international/yunos_telenor.fortune/index.htm)Maybe one way would be to make these independent centers integrated with other functions (scribe, post office, etc.). Yet, it does not solve the certification issue, nor the risk of having these centers being targeted?another option would be to think of mobile independent petition centers (although the two issues you raised Vincent are not completely solved). I was thinking for example of Nathan's concept of mobile training camps: http://www.openideo.com/open/how-might-we-improve-health-care-through-social-business-in-low-income-communities/concepting/mobile-training-camp-for-entrepreneurship-/

Great job Vincent, I really like the central idea: making petitions safe and reliable through technology. I just wanted to follow Anne-Laure's thread about independent mobile centers. In an environment that's clouded with "interceptors" and "silencers", it could be a really interesting idea to think about mobile units as distributed entities or cells, wherein the disruption of any one won't necessarily mean a service interruption. It doesn't address the certification, but if there were multiple mobile entities routinely changing locations (another variable that would have to be coordinated) connected to some central petition management system (assuming one gets created), they could provide service to those unable or unwilling to visit a standard location.
Jason, funny as I've just posted a concept based on the idea of a (mobile) van... not necessarily addressing the petitions but it definitely could...

Wow, y'all (Sarah, Anne-Laure, Jason) are definitely onto something! Anne-Laure's mobile van could definitely be used to help spread the word about & assist people in completing mobile/online petitions. Am linking to Anne-Laure's concept here for people to check out: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-iii-shift-van-/ . Also makes me think that pre-existing Internet Cafes (quite popular in China) could be providing petitioning services as well.Will try to attribute & incorporate everyone's great builds into the main concept text, when we reach the refinement stage (if this concept makes it to that point).

Great thoughts Vincent  and wow... that's a lot of Build Upon items! I haven't looked through all of them but was wondering if you could help me understand how some of my own Inspirations are connected here  such as http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/video-links-detainees-to-families Perhaps you'd like to broaden the discussion by explaining how some of these Inspirations relate to what you're proposing here? I'm sure many are excited to follow your train of thought.

Thanks Meena. The OpenIDEO community really generates a wealth of inspiration that mixes around in my mind and stimulates ideas! When I'm able to find the time, I always try to credit everyone who helped me learn more & develop a concept =).In the case of your inspiration that you mentioned, multiple community contributions helped me to recognize the power of video to connect people (from yours about video conference centers connecting detainees to families to comments on my post about connecting the Dalai Lama & Desmond Tutu through Google+ Hangouts). That gave me an aha moment, which made me realize that petitions from a distance, in lieu of travel, don't just have to be just text documents. Video (whether static or live) can be used to bring some of the richness and emotional impact of an in-person meeting.Hopefully, online petitions (such as through Internet Cafes that would serve the purpose of the video-conference centers in your inspiration) could help avoid unlawful detentions of petitioners before they occur, as well as support petitioners who may actually be petitioning for a family member/friend who is currently unlawfully detained!This continues to percolate in my thoughts, and actually influenced my other submitted concept as well: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-observer-app/For those interested in this line of thought, I think there's also potential for a concept supporting more grassroots (non-government run) video aggregation & sharing systems (documenting human rights abuses, creating awareness campaigns, & direct human to official video please). It hasn't quite come together in my mind, but I'd love to see someone else take a stab at it =)

Great to get a glimpse behind your thoughts Vincent ;^) Interesting that you bring up the grassroots suggestion (independent of government) as I was wondering about that when reading through your Concept. In many countries (including so called 'developed' ones!) governments sometime play a part in unlawful detention  which begs the question of whether the are the right organisations to be collecting & facilitating exchange of ideas?  Especially if they are the target of petitioning? Not sure what the answer is  but like you  am excited about the potential in ongoing discussions around such topics.

Absolutely Meena. Practically speaking, it takes a dual approach: both working through official & grassroots channels, which is why I also posted the grassroots Amnesty Observer App to complement this concept. Also, regardless of whether we develop better safeguards for helping & protecting petitioners, millions of them will continue to petition through official channels and risk unlawful detention and other human rights abuses.Also, in the case of the Chinese government, although on paper it's all centrally controlled, and often reported in the Western media as such; in reality like any large organization, there are various pockets of power. Specifically, for this concept, the central government is being petitioned about local (municipal, provincial, etc.) corruption, which it has a vested interest to combat.  For example, the mayor of Shanghai (China's commercial center) was sacked for corruption a few years back: http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2006/sep/25/china.jonathanwatts
Great insights, Vincent.

Thanks Vincent for this great concept.First of all, I did not know about black jails so this was an important piece of information. I also like the fact that you show how this system has been existing for more than 3000 years but is not successful. I can see many reasons for the flaws, but I feel like the absence of a public access might be one. What I mean is that even if you are able to file your petition (in paper format or online), it could be lost. I guess we could assume that there would be a receipt sent / provided to the petitioner. Yet, I'm wondering if there would not be a way to make sure that each petition as soon as posted would be available to all, in the "public domain".As for related projects, it reminds me of a study I read several years ago on e-government projects in India, aiming to increase efficiency, communication, access but also decrease corruption and bribery.One possible (main) limitation would be the resistance from the Chinese government but also every local actors.thanks again.

Thanks Anne-Laure! Yup, there's definitely multiple factors behind the flaws ( and I believe even larger root causes ). So, for the example in China, I'm attempting to 1st tackle areas, step-by-step (as Lei astutely mentions), where progress can most likely be made.Making everything (petitioning complaints, responses) in the "public domain" does have its merits, particularly in areas like the United States, where democracy, freedom of expression, & cultural openness are highly valued.  However, there may be large downsides to immediately going with such an approach in China: preference for criticizing in private to respectfully save face, safety of petitioner, use of censorship & sacrificing individuals for overall social harmony, etc.At the same time, I agree with you that information sharing is very important, whenever possible. Here's another concept which aims to do that: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-observer-app/

Hi Vincent, point well-taken regarding privacy issues. In fact, I think your concept addresses well the tension between publicity and privacy. On the one hand, people can post their petitions without being seen going to Beijing (and in fact, as you suggested, they can also do this anonymously). On the other hand, one can imagine that there's a way to make sure that when it's posted, it does "not disappear" - that was where I was getting at by mentioning the publicity aspect. I was also wondering if one way to think of making sure that these petitions are taken into account would not to think of different rewards and incentives. In the video, it is said that one reason for the black jail is that the government does not want to have too many complaints and petitions... what if having a great number of petitions was "good" as long as they were solved? I know this is not in the realm of your concept but I thought I'll make this point.also I love the small steps / multi-concepts approach. Looking forward to concept #3!:-)

Hmm...you do make a very good point on trying to increase accountability, even when enough public pressure is not viable. Thanks!For one thing, statistics & records of results should be built into the system (which should at least be viewable & incentivized by each official's superior). Careful thought would have to be put into what is being measured to avoid adverse incentives like you mention. Probably this requires qualitative reviews/judgements, not just quantitative measures.Also, we have to make a distinction between the "central government" vs. "local governments" that are directly penalized by the "central government" for too many petitions from their locality that reach the central level, meaning that they were previously unable to resolve these petitions/issues at the local level.

thanks for the extra piece of cultural information regarding central and local governments... indeed important to keep in mind... your concept refers to petitions to the central government, doesn't it?I'm glad my point about visibility and accountability made sense... Maybe the statistics and records function could indeed be useful.

Hi Vincent, thank you for sharing this concept. so glad that you bring the "Black Jail" issue in China to this challenge. And I do believe that the modernized petition system is one important way to turn the situation around step by step. Thanks again!

Thanks Lei! It's good to get affirmation on this from someone else who has experienced both sides of the Pacific Ocean =)Also, just wanted to say that your earlier contributions on China were huge inspirations for me, both from an ideation perspective, and in encouraging me to post on this topic, which I was hesitant to do, due to personal reasons I'm guessing you can probably relate to.Thanks again for the inspiration Lei!

improving_petitioning_through_technology.title: Improving Petitioning through Technology: Fighting "Black Jails"

lessons_on_communication_from_incarcerat.description: We have all heard of gang leaders being able to exert control on their organizations from behind bars. How are they able to do this effectively? Is there anything we can learn about how to communicate while incarcerated from them?
lessons_on_communication_from_incarcerat.creator: f61b638b9d17bc5c8d9e9df0f978a42c

comments.text: Great lateral insight, Ryan  to imagine such channels (and beyond) to be used for positive impact surrounding human rights.

Thanks Meena , I was looking for ways to break the problem down. At a high level there is a political problem (Preventing organizations from doing this in the first place) and execution problem (what to do if/when this happens). The former seems a little more nebulous, so I focused on the latter.

lessons_on_communication_from_incarcerat.title: Lessons on communication from incarcerated gang members.

findme_wrist_band.description: This discrete band can be given out to people at risk of unlawful detention. These plain black wrist bands will not attract attention and therefore would not be taken unlike a mobile phone. It has a circuit through it, so that when the band is broken a signal is sent to a remote central server noting the GPS location of the user, who can then send out local help. The bands can be linked up to friends and family so they can be notified that their loved one is in danger and may be able to track them down. The band also has a very small button which the user can press when they are in trouble if the band has not been broken.
findme_wrist_band.creator: 7c7acf679e83b20077763164e6e71b55

comments.text: Great concept. I was just considering an idea like this also that would replicate the utilization of dogtags. I feel like using these bracelets in a form of a buddy system, where someone in the immediate area would be notified, would allow those trying to help to have an eye witness according to terrain and possible access to where this individual is being held captive. It would be a way of immediately alerting someone on the ground of their need to be the eyes and ears in the immediate situation so they may contribute information.

Hi Clare, interesting idea! You might like to check out our Tips on Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking devices could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.
Great concept. It reminds me a bit of Rescue Alert: http://www.rescuealert.com/How would you ensure the button would not get pressed accidentally?

findme_wrist_band.title: FindMe Wrist Band
