comments.text: Interesting provocation, Basti. In part it brings up the issue of confidentiality  if you had been unlawfully detained, you may not want everyone to know. We discuss some of the implications of this in our Guiding Principles: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/our-guiding-principles/ But you've certainly observed something interesting here.

youtube_lessons.title: YouTube Lessons

using_free_group_text_messaging_services.description:
There are numerous websites that provide text messages to be sent to a group of people either online or with a cell phone for free.

This is by a student at the Wells College Innovation Lab.
using_free_group_text_messaging_services.creator: b2bba8bfeee65f14af78aa79d0417f5d

comments.text: Great thoughts & example! Are a lot of these services dependent on wi-fi connections? I wonder if there are examples which don't rely on this, nor smartphones? Heading into the Concepting phase, it will be good to think of solutions which are inclusive and accessible to those in various global contexts.

I am agreed with you but in order to achieve desired success, A.I. must pay full attention towards preparing its all members, supporters and activists fully Techno - savvy keeping in view the educational and technological backwardness of different areas in the world.

This is a beautiful Idea and can be helpful in certain situations, but in an emergency when we have to take immediate action against a severe violation of human right such as unlawful detention, forced evictions, forced rape, custodial death. At this time text messaging is not so relevant.

Not only is this a great idea for socializing with many friends at once to make plans, but this is a quick way to notify numerous people of things that may be of great importance if you have little time or are in a situation that requires you to get a message out fast. This could be useful in situations like team challenges, making plans with a group of friends or operations that require you to relay information to numerous people without making it obvious you sent it to ten others.

social_epidemics_paul_revere_and_its_fam.description: How information spreads? Gladwell highlightsthe importance of the information itself (its stickiness) as well as context and people involved (salespeople, information gatherers/spreaders, and connectors).
social_epidemics_paul_revere_and_its_fam.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: Great connection, Anne-Laure. What I take from this inspiration is that it is important to identify and support the connectors, so that stories and news spread in the most effective way possible, and action can be undertaken by organisations like Amnesty International.

Thanks Arjan. Indeed my point was to highlight the importance of understanding the role of people in spreading information. Gladwell in his book shows that there are 3 types of people, all important to spreading the information: connectors (these people who seem to know everyone), salesmen (persuaders, charismatic people) and mavens (information specialists). He calls it the Law of the few as he thinks that in any situation, 80% of the work is done by 20% of the people. I believe that for organizations like Amnesty International, it is indeed important to understand who are these 3 types of people. In the example of Paul Revere, he used the same technology as William Dawes -horse ridding and voice - but what makes the difference was that one was a connector, and the other not.This also reminds us that technology is never stand alone but always interpreted and embedded in a set of social and material practices.Sorry for the long reply but you got me thinking about the implications of this inspiration. Thanks! :-)

social_epidemics_paul_revere_and_its_fam.title: Social epidemics: Paul Revere and its famous nocturnal ride

I went through a couple of cases and it is indeed shocking! scary too!Regarding your second point, I think it goes along with the Zeitun's inspiration (and another one I can't recall right now) which highlighted how many of these cases are not necessarily taking place far from us. facebook_group_for_families_with_missing.description: Create a Facebook group where families who are missing family members can share their experiences, grieves, needs and ideas with a community of like minded.
facebook_group_for_families_with_missing.creator: 046c14ccc821e094ab37859494deeacc

comments.text: I think it would be one good and effective method for families who are missing a family number. At same time, Facebook users who see single little boys or girls and homeless could take pictures for them under their permission or just describe how they look like, where they see them. Users could post  information to this group also. So this is the complementary way for this concept. People who lost their families could review the information and see if their families are there.

Hi Anne!Great idea, and seems you've done good background research that supports this concept quite well. Thanks for the link on Fogg Behavior, very interesting.  With regards to the name, I was thinking it could be inspired by your inspiration from this challenge: Shift ! I also think the name shouldn't be too self explanatory or too catchy, so that we don't attract too much dangerous and undesired attention from Government officials controlling these kind of social networks for groups like this one, as I've read they keep their eyes on this kind of activity... There could be an undercover symbol and name for this! But this might make it harder for people to find, so maybe that isn't good :(  I was in China this April, and I can share my challenges of using Facebook. I did a lot of research before I went on this and there are many companies offering VPN services & IP adresses you can buy to surf the net. A lot of those websites get shut down fast, that is the problem... I used this website for it's free trial. They let you securely access any website in the world. They offer different types of subscription plans, not too expensive, and they are not limited to one computer, you can use it on more than one:  https://www.securitales.com/signup.php This could be a good solution for the Amnesty team working with managing this FB group. Of course the education issue of spreading knowledge about this group is crucial so the more people can benefit from it. Maybe with Anne-Laure's most recent concept, with a Van that travels around problematic communities, it could also be responsible for training and  educating affected families on this support network on FB.

Thank you for your very constructive advice and ideas Ana! Do you know about any other networking platform, which run by NPOs or NGOs, where the security around information sharing with third parties is higher?Maybe one could imagine the above concept running on a Amnesty powered online platform, but where the sign-up is through Facebook - to make it easy/accessible to use.

Hi, re. the security issue, I think building upon Lei's concept of distributed network will be a solution: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/decentralize-the-network-own-and-protect-your-data/Regarding spreading the word, but also getting access, indeed the Shift III Van could be an option :-)

Hi Anne!Unfortunately I don't know in particular any networking platforms for NGO's, but I am aware of one more similar to LinkedIn, mors focused on social life called A Small World: http://www.asmallworld.net/aboutI was also Googling about private social networks, and found this long list (where ASW is also listed) : http://www.techradar.com/news/internet/10-social-networks-they-don-t-want-you-to-join-673805If I find something more focused on NGO's I will certainly post them.Very true what A-L is saying, Lei's concept is super exciting, and could solve your (and everyone else's) security issues, and eventually transform this network of connected-concepts into a safe hub for us to start combating in safety, many human rights issues.

is_that_part_of_our_culture.description: Each country or culture gives emphasis to different values.  This is a word spreading campaign that shows that unlawful detention is against a cultue's specific values.
is_that_part_of_our_culture.creator: da5eea5073e27d790089f40e886490cb

comments.text: Hi Tayfun, just came across this gem of yours now! Agreed that tailoring campaigns to local cultures/values is key, not only to garner supporters (such as petition signers), but also in convincing perpetrators (who are receiving the petitions, and ultimately are in the position to end the unlawful detention).I think one thing this cultural sensitivity means is ensuring that the right language is used to relate to & persuade: i.e. terms like "rights" (human rights) & "unlawful" (unlawful detention) may not resonate that strongly in some areas, and can even be viewed as outsider impositions.For some collectivist cultures, upholding "rights" (which is an individual-centered concept) might not mean much, but maintaining "respect" (through proper behavior), "duty" (to others), 'or "responsibility" (for people's wellbeing) may hold more sway.
Vincent, thanks for your reflections on the wording of the campaigns and the concepts to build them upon.Your last point regarding the concept of "rights" is very well-taken!

Hi Vincent, You are right on the correct language. I was mainly thinking about images and concepts but the language is equally important as it has to "move" people.Thanks also for your nice comments. Always a pleasure to get quality feedback

Hi Tayfun,I was checking if you've updated the concept but it seems that you haven't had the time to develop a "Turkish version". I have to admit that I did not have much time to think about how you would implement in France, or anywhere else... Also I found it hard to do at least in the way I understood it from the two examples. I've been thinking (and informally brainstorming ) of your concept tonight and I was thinking that the HSBC campaign with the same picture but two similar interpretations could be quite relevant and powerful. This led me to this idea: why not develop a campaign around specific cases of unlawful detentions like black jails in China  http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/improving-petitioning-through-technology-fighting-black-jails-/or sexual preferences in Cameroon http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/allout.org-s-campaign-to-free-lgbt-prisoners-in-cameroon/ . You could have a campaign showing these different images with a short definition and something like "In China these are called black jails..." in a somewhat neutral tone... then the second part of the campaign, "it can also be called unlawful detention". The point here would be to say that unlawful detentions can take multiple forms but it is still unlawful. I'm not sure if this makes sense with what you had in mind but that's how it inspired me :-)

Hi al,Apologies for not responding back earlier as I am having some connectivity problems. I am writing this one from the house of a friend as I cannot connect from my home to openideo (some technical issues happening) Anyhow, I think what you are saying is great. It would show unlawful detention pictures in the wold. Let me give a shot!!!
No worries. Glad to see you back online. I'll check your new concept.

Nice idea Taifun. I like the local context aspect and how we could design the message by understanding a "cultural trait" of each national (local) culture.I can see how this works for Texas. I'm less sure what was the cultural "trait" they used in Turkey. Why do you think the campaign was successful in Turkey?If you were to think of implementing a campaign about unlawful detention in Turkey, what would be the trait that you would use to design the campaign? I'm going to try to think about something that will work for France (where I was born). Maybe others can join the conversation. Cheers,al

Thanks al for your comments,I think "trait" they used in Turkey was more for attracting attention. It has some sexual appeal to it.They were very successful for following reasons (I don't have the conversion rates of their website (i.e. how many people came in and how many signed on the petition) of but I assume it is probably 25-30% or higher which is extremely good conversion rates.1) They were able to get attention of the people2) They had a clear, simple message (it the fish are too small now, there won't be any of them in the future)3) They were able to offer something quick to do to people (a chance to sign a petition) 4) They were able to engage people by posting updates (they were trying to save 3 types of fish by legislation and had a status update about each (number of signatures, legislation promise))I have to think a little more about Turkey. I am thinking of traits such as we love eating, majority of the country is Muslim, soccer is quite big in the country (almost like a religion), there is history everywhere, etc.... I guess the specific concept for Turkey will come in few days .

Hi Tayfun (sorry for mispelling your name in my previous comment),thanks for the clarification. Maybe the idea of showing impact (your point 4) is something to keep in mind for this concept.Looking forward to seeing the version of the concept for Turkey! :-)

Don't worry about the spelling, it is the intention that counts!One more important aspect is timing of such campaign. So for example right now in Turkey, there have been very bad news where soldiers were killed and this may not be a good time to say anything about the unlawful detentions as the emotions are running high and the message should be clear enough just to reflect the issue from a humanitarian perspective (not political) Will hopefully come up with something for Turkey soon hopefully and waiting to hear your concept about France. Je suis sure que a sera interesent
I think you should plan to have the Turkey one before the France one. :-)But I'll try...

Tayfun, great job on this  I really like the idea of leveraging local culture and norms. I wonder if you or anyone else might want to build on this concept with specific campaign ideas for unlawful detention in their country? It would be interesting to see how this might develop into culturally-specific calls to action around unlawful detention.
Hi Ashley, thanks. I am planning to build upon it but no clear ideas yet! Hopefully soon
Absolutely - great ideas take time to form :)

you_cannot_board_the_flight.._you_dont_h.description: A true personal story about experiencing powerlessness, frustration, unjust laws and stereotyping law enforcers.
you_cannot_board_the_flight.._you_dont_h.creator: 0e9b61ed7d7b30f3db82c5786cf2f1b3

comments.text: This story you telling is so vivid that I could feel your frustation at the airport. I feel as if I was in your shoe. I am sorry to hear what you have been through. When we are in a new place that we don't know much about, we can feel insecure and hope everything will go alright. The feeling of helplessness when situation pop up at us will cause us to feel overwhelm, lost and confuse. No one really want to be in those kind of situations. I hope it will not happen to you again in the future.

Thanks Rathin for sharing this story which describes very well the frustration and the sense of helplessness. What I can see here is the uncertainty (about whether the law is true or not), lack of local knowledge, language and differences in power. Being able to contact your father and your family helped you not only to get the money, but also to "calm down" and feel connected. But what if you had no one to contact? or if the phones were not free and you did not have enough money to call anyone. Facial and racial biases came up again and the unfair decisions who accompanied them (when you traveled with your sister, you looked "ok").It reminds me of Vincent's story because of the context:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/fleeing-the-police/#c-1f2c201f88a63c420e2465a2d99e99d8Haiyan's idea of a number for travelers to dial seems also relevant...

a_quick_synthesis_of_inspirations_so_far.description: An overview of all 212 inspirations contributed so far...and some observations and questions for us to ponder upon as we continue to contribute more inspirations this week...
a_quick_synthesis_of_inspirations_so_far.creator: 59054561fe9b4dddd6fbec03ad0d1184

comments.text: I offer my comment with all due respect...especially to Chloe and any others who might misunderstand....no dis-respect intended.We as humans need to get away from technology.... we need to think. Think in the old fashioned way... so i feel analysis, synthesis can wait ...no need to rush. Let the patterns emerge. Many a time we may have adopted a System ( an incomplete or even flawed one) just because everyone involved thinks we need to bring a closure. Most of us don't like ambiguity....yet it is this state of Flux that offers a chance for the Creative spark... ...and so we may inadvertently have created this very system which we All are discussing now (A system where the need for Human Rights is essential and yet missing in many parts of the World).... we are trying to understand the existing system and change it for the better... That is our genuine interest... for which we are currently considering Technology as a Tool option...but  beyond technology we also need to address the mindset(s) which allow for this flawed system to existSo from my side I would like to Add... Love. yes Love... a society built on Human Values... where Technology can be employed in educating all of us not only in our civic sense of responsibility, but also in the Harmony of living in Peaceful Co-existence, Inspiring children and youth in taking civilized and value based decisions... one that teaches a sense of purpose beyond the bane, superficial, materialistic existence of all modern society. Thank you...from India... it is because of technology that I am able to participate in this discussion from India.
Good questions - thanks for the (re)focus.
Excellent mindmapping as always Chloe =)
Thanks Vincent! I appreciate your comments and encouragement as always.. :)
Very well summed up.
Very cool
Thank you! :)
nice graph

Hello OpenIDEO :-)  I did not hear the news, but that's exciting!  Thanks for notifying me.  I checked out the forums, but I'm not sure how to weigh in (just comment?), or in what way I can/should contribute.  I'm really looking forward to seeing what comes out of the Make-a-thon!!

Thanks Matt! I'm looking forward to seeing it in action as well.

Hello Amanda! Thank you for your hard work. Congratulations on designing a winning concept. The Amnesty team really appreciated on how you focused on supporting the supporters. Great work, we really appreciate your thorough effort!
Congratulations Amanda. This is a wonderful concept, which focuses on an important aspect of the challenge. It was also a great opportunity to collaborate with you! :-)

Thanks OpenIDEO and Anne-Laure!  OpenIDEO, I'm beginning to apply for summer internships (at IDEO among others), so if I could just take your compliments and forward them along, that would be lovely ;-)  Anne-Laure, I agree, this was an excellent opportunity to collaborate with you.  Looking forward to the next time!  Vibrant cities perhaps?
Congrats Amanda! Nice job addressing supporting the supporters. In regards to the internship applications, you should do that =). At the very least, you can link to your profile & contributions.

I've followed some of your inspirations on Vibrant cities and hopefully will have more time to post and comment more. I'll watch out for your concepts! :-) good luck for the summer internship but I agree with Vincent, you should definitely try.

Wonderful outcome Amanda! This was always such a worthwhile concept and I agree with Tom it should be straightforward to prototype possibly within Amnesty's existing database. I will follow its progress with great interest.
P.S. Good luck with the Internships I'm sure you will be 'snapped up' very quickly.
Congrats Amanda! Looking forward to seeing where Amnesty takes the concept.

Congratulations on this great winning concept Amanda! It's been great exchanging insights and collaborating with you on this challenge. I hope more opportunities will come, and keep us posted on where this concept goes in the future, it would be great to see it turn reality somehow :)

Thanks Amy and Ana!  I too am looking forward to seeing where this concept goes.  And Ana, I've very much enjoyed collaborating with you too.  Perhaps more to continue during Vibrant Cities?  Thanks again!
Absolutely :) The Vibrant Cities is another challenge i'm super excited about. 'See you' there!

Congratulations on this wonderful concept Amanda - we talked it through with Amnesty yesterday and all loved it.We discussed how dating sites would be a great place to look for inspiration, they enable people to find potential partners by focusing on key information only, like lifestage and language.We also discussed that this concept could be prototyped at a very small scale easily, perhaps leveraging Amnesty's existing database...

Wow, thanks Tom.  By now this concept is pretty near and dear to me, so it's nice to hear that it got such a fabulous reception yesterday.The idea of having a small-scale prototype of my concept is also pretty exciting.  I can't wait to see how this progresses...

Great concept, Amanda!For a low-tech situation in largely-affected communities, what if there were stationary "matchmakers"? When a missing person is reported, Amnesty could direct the family members to their nearest neighborhood matchmaker. Even without a database, the matchmaker could connect a grieving person with someone else who came in recently. This way, no one would have to wait for the Shift Van, and it seems easier and more anonymous than creating paper wheels.If there are very few people in a community who are affected by this problem, the Shift Van would be able to connect them with someone in another community through letter-writing, recorded audio, etc., as you've mentioned.
Thanks Alix!  I'll be incorporating your advice into my concept soon.  Welcome to my virtual team :-)
Alix, I've added in a small section to address your point.  You'll find it in the Little to No Tech section of Technology for Initiating a Match.  Thanks for your help!

I like your idea Amanda. I especially like your low-tech solutions. I think women could find huge comfort in these contacts even if these are not immediate (which is probably more an issue in our fast paced society than in other areas of the world)I was just thinking about one issue, how can it be prevented that 'the wrong people' enter into the matchmaking service and obtaining valuable, private information from partners of detainees? Maybe some kind of check or screening could be possible (although this would make the overall concept more complex). Or participants could be instructed in some way to discuss issues without providing vital, personal information.
Thanks for the feedback Willemijn!  I have addressed your point by adding in another paragraph to Update Too.  Thanks for your help.

Hi again Amanda,I have evaluated all concepts as potentially forming an integrated system for support and awareness. This concept is a vital component in providing support to families of detainees. I think of the support networks that have been springing up here in Australia for 'victims' of various circumstances and listen to the benefits that have accrued. Setting up a system to help those in far more precarious circumstances share mutual experiences is such a worthwhile goal.

Hey all this is really great! I love the decision to make it simply a matching service...no technical overhead needed to facilitate the communications, nice. You've really thought it through for all scenarios and did a great job of breaking down the resources required to launch. You mentioned a scenario in which no match is found. Maybe in these cases Amnesty could provide a "pro tem" support professional until one is found??

Thanks Jason!  That is an excellent point about the scenario in which no match is found.  I'll definitely have to incorporate that.  Great idea! FYI, I liked your prototype as well, I was checking it out earlier.  Thanks again for taking another look at my concept.  Glad to hear it's looking good to outside eyes.  I'm starting to feel too invested to be unbiased ;-)

Hi Jason, I just added another update that hopefully addresses your concerns.  I'd really appreciate it if you could take a look and let me know what you think!  See the section labeled UPDATE TOO.  Thanks for your help :)
Jason's point was well-taken and I think you did address quite well with the idea of the friend in need.
This looks really great Amanda. A Friend in Need is much cooler than my simple pro tem match. Nicely done!

Really lovely and well articulated concept, Amanda. One thing to consider will be helping people think about what types of things they may want to share (or not). From talking to people with life threatening diseases, I learned that there are different stages of acceptance and corresponding different types of conversations people are willing to have. Also, sometimes people just don't want to talk, so allowing a way for it to be ok on any given day not to be available would be great.
Thanks Amy, you make an excellent point. I'll have to think about ways this could be incorporated into my concept!

Hi Amy, I just added another update to address your concerns.  I'd really appreciate if if you could take a look and let me know what you think!  See the section labeled UPDATE TOO.  Thanks for your help :)
Hi Amanda, I just had a chance to look. I love the idea of a safe word - makes great sense!

Hi again Amanda,Great new update!Just a couple of additional thoughts:Your concept consists basically of 2 parts - the matching system and the subsequent communication system.As your update points out some things on the communication side are dependent on how immediate is the form of communication, and the 'slower' forms of communication are just as relevant as the faster ones.I have suggested to Anne-Laure (in relation to the 'information' available in the vans) that for situations where bandwidth is low a copy of the most current information could be retained either on computer hard drives or on removable media (kept up to date through things like 'off peak' or 'overnight' use of bandwidth). I have further suggested that this could be extended to your matching database, at least for those situations in which clients might be accessing facilities in vans or kiosks etc. I have my 'Moodle' database residing on a USB stick and my development but working version of the Ideator Resources site resides on the hard drive of a non-net connected pc as well as the live version on the web.Development costs in US are clearly quite high - would off-shore development be an option?Still seeing this concept as a major component in the 'family support' solutions for this challenge.

Interesting thoughts Paul, I'll have to incorporate this into the concept!  In terms of development costs, I found an article written by someone at Amnesty around the start of the challenge and they said they are planning on submitting the winning concepts to Random Hacks of Kindness, which is happening sometime in December.  So, the cost estimate I provided seems to be irrelevant... Thanks again!

I am giving a little more thought to the database design.Where people access the service from a van - the country is most likely already determined, so the list of countries should start with that one as a best guess for successful interaction.Where people are accessing it on their own or neighbour's computer the program can make a guess on the country based on the IP address of the internet service to which the computer is connected. Once again the country of the IP address could be presented at the top of the list.In that way perhaps 80% or more people would be matched to country immediately. With the question "What country are you from?" in English still above the list box - that box could be expanded to present the statement "Click here if [country name] is your country", expressed idiomatically for each of the countries in the list. Where more than one language is used e.g. (trivially) French and English for Canada the statement would appear in each language.Hopefully that might establish country and language together so the remainder of the questionnaire could be presented in the language thus chosen.A few other questions spring to mind:Will the person seeking a match be asked to rank preferred contact methods?How should the database identify the person seeking a match?(e.g. full name, unique nickname)Assuming the database (when it is big enough) finds several possible matches- who and on what basis makes the ultimate choice?Once a choice is made are the paired correspondents then quarantined from further matchings, pending outcomes of trial correspondence?Maybe I'm going too deep at the moment but I would rather ask these questions now - while I think of them.Regards,Paul

Hi Amanda, and again congrats on your concept reaching the Refinment phase. I'm really happy to see you've carefully updated and thought of various details.- If you need help or advice regarding the development of the website or creating mock-ups & designs for it, I'm happy to help as I've done some web designing for freelance in the past, and studided it at University, but I understand you've got some help already! Regarding this, it might also be worth developing the website according to WAI ( http://www.w3.org/WAI/ ) meaning that the website is accessible to everyone be it the blind or deaf through specific web coding implementation, so that everyone could cherish from this great concept, if they have a disability or can't read. So the website could read itself out for you, for example.. It's quite easy to code that. -  If these women become avid participants of your project, maybe it would be an idea to invite them to become 'ambassadors' of this project, and get them to 'recruit' more women that might be needing support, but don't yet know about this possibility. So therefore, provide infinite and a continuous support network into the future if they feel strong about it ( and if you would like that, of course) !I'll post back more ideas if I think of any thing else! Well done on the great collaborations and updates you've done :)

Hey Ana, thanks for checking in!  I am wondering if the WAI you mention is able to "speak" different languages?  I am looking for the website to have the questions available in a variety of languages.  If the questions are going to to be read, they would need to be read in a variety of languages too.In terms of prototyping, if it wouldn't be too time-consuming to create a mock-up, that would be awesome!  If it would be too much of an effort, don't worry about it.  Though it's not as pretty as I would like, I think the one I mocked up gets the point across well enough.  If you do think you'll do a mock-up let me know and I can tell you what I have in mind :DThanks Ana!!
wow! this was fast! :-) I'll check the update and prototype by tomorrow night.
Haha, yeah, had to get on it!  I have a ton of work due this week so I'm not sure how much time I'll have over the next couple of days.  Wanted to get as much done as possible over the weekend :-)
I had a similar strategy, but did only one round of changes / clarification. See my update 1 if you have time. Your feedback is always welcome. good luck with the busy week.

Assuming you haven't looked at my update yet, I actually have updated again.  I heard back from a childhood friend of mine (who's now working as a developer) and she gave me some great technical info that's now been incorporated.

Finally had a look at the updates and prototype. The prototype is useful and shows the simplicity of the technology side. I'm impressed by the work you did in terms of lining out the resources. I guess some of the issues you raised regarding safety, type of technology, etc. can only be addressed when you start prototyping for a real situation. Great job!

Thanks for taking a look A-L.  I'm glad you found the prototype useful.  In terms of outlining the resources, thankfully, I have some really diverse and wonderful friends.  My friend Heather really came through in terms of outlining the specific technical info for me and I was able to combine that with a little of my existing knowledge to get the finished product :-)  I agree that some of the issues I raised regarding safety, type of technology, etc. will likely not be able to be addressed until/if this is developed for real use.  That being said, I think the options are diverse enough that most of these challenges should be, if not avoidable, at least balance-able.  It seems I've outlined everything as best I can, so we'll see what happens!
You indeed explored and listed all, or most, options and it'll be very useful to be able to choose among all of these when thinking of a specific context. Fingers crossed!

Great update on the technology side Amanda I'm sure you are right that most technical difficulties can be overcome. I have been looking at some discussions on multi-lingual databases but most of it goes over my head - I'm used to developing pc and network based databases but only putting a toe in the water on the web.

Hi Amanda, congratulations on your idea being short-listed for the Amnesty Challenge. The expert panel was enthusiastic about your concept, Creating Connections. Would you be up for pushing the idea further? What would the technology component looks like? How would meetings or support groups be organised? Were excited to see how you build on this idea!

Wow, I am so glad to see this concept make the refinement phase!  This idea could provide such valuable emotional support to the partners of detained persons, I'm excited that it has the chance to continue on.  I am absolutely willing to develop the idea further, thanks for giving me some ideas on which directions to go.  I can't wait to get feedback from the rest of the OpenIDEO community!

Well OpenIDEO (a.k.a Meena et al.), you asked me to push my concept farther.  Be careful what you ask for :)  I think that I've doubled or tripled the information in my original concept.  Hope you enjoy!

Great start on prototype enquiry form Amanda!Was somehow imagining rather more information with what I was developing so have revised my thinking.I'm wondering if a few different approaches to presenting the first 2 or 3 questions would be a good idea eg.:a page listing all approx 200 countries, such as a simplified version of wikipedia list ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_and_capitals_in_native_languages ) perhaps with national flags; oran intelligent world map with the countries listed in native languages which would then zoom in to regions/provinces etc. - each selection being an answer to a question Im thinking of a sequence likeCountryRegion/Province Language (including dialects)After establishing a language the client can understand then present the remaining questions accordingly.And would touch screen technology help?

Paul, glad you liked the prototype!!  It's also good to know that it helped you better understand what I had in mind for my concept.Your wikipedia example of the countries with their native languages is exactly what I was going for.  I went back into my concept to clarify it a bit better.In terms of having a picture or intelligent world map, it seems like that would be much heavier on the tech side and would provide very few benefits.  The reason I say that is because the map would primarily benefit those who are illiterate.  But, an illiterate person would likely not have the internet access to get on the website themselves.  So they'd either need the help of a friend or the Shift Van.  Which means that they'd have a translator immediately available which would make providing a map for them superfluous.I don't think touch screen technology would add anything in particular, do you?  Did you have something in mind?  I think simpler is better...

Hi again AmandaSeveral thoughts going round in my head now.!. If the client is literate enough to access the website for themselves then there should be little problem in presenting it appropriately (ie. if the access is presented in a language they understand then you have the hook necessary to construct the interface.All other situations default to circumstances in which some assistance is required.2. I dont think the technology overhead for the mapping is any greater than the overhead for language - it wouldn't be like Google maps but rather a series of intelligent links.My thought about maps was related to access in places like the vans where even with limited common language one person could demonstrate how to navigate from country to region to language for their own background then invite the client to do the same for themselves - almost making a game of it. Once recognisable language is established normal interaction would take over.3. This doesn't have to be an either or situation - several interfaces could be established to suit circumstances but leading to the same basic outcome.4. I tend to agree that touchscreens are possibly of minimal benefit, but thought making the suggestion was still worthwhile.I guess I was thinking of simple interaction to break down barriers - a mouse and foreign (ie. English) keyboard might be daunting too.

In order to take this concept further maybe we need to begin to look at specifics eg. development of the website, the design for which might present as useful in other situations. So -1 - Do we have any developers in the OpenIDEO community who could put their talents to work to at least template/prototype such a site?2 - If not, or in addition, do we know people with the skills who might be happy to be involved  (see Ashwin Gopi's The Human Cloud http://www.openideo.com/open/impact/concepting/the-human-cloud/ from the Social Impact challenge)?An acquaintance of mine has a client who built a "dating site" - so I shall ask them.
Thanks for your suggestions Paul.  It would be great if your acquaintance could provide some technical expertise!!  That is an area in which I am sorely lacking.

Fab idea to see if your friend wants to get involved, Paul. And actually I've spoken to someone who worked on the dev team of a dating site before and was astounded by the learnings they had gained around effective engagement and interaction design.

Any chance you're still in touch with that person Meena? :-)  I have also asked my brother to take a look.  He has not designed a dating website, but is studying computer science, so I'm hoping he'll have some insights as well.

Amanda, I'll try to ask some of the students at NYU-Poly and I'm sure they are other people in the OpenIDEO community who have the skills. I unfortunately could not do more than a paper prototype but maybe that would also be a way to start and then videotape a scenario with the interactions and different steps involved in the process. We know the technology is out there, so to a certain extent what matters is figuring out the type of information needed and the types of interactions. I like the point you make about the fact that the metaphor is not social networking, but dating... or white pages / phone book, or an organized bulletin board. I have a question regarding the second step, when the connection is made. Meeting face-to-face would be one option, if the people don't live too far from one another, can do the trip, and if there was some security issue. Letter writing - either physical letters, or emails, or audio files, would be another one. Skype could be also an option if the connection is good enough. Phone conversations could be an option that could also be offered through the Shift van. I'm wondering if text messages could not be also a mean of communication, at least once the conversation got started. I have a clarification question regarding the use of SMS for groups. I'm not sure I understand that part of the concept.I'm also wondering (but you might not have any idea) how many women do you think would be in the database: if you want to allow for face-to-face meeting, it has to be limited to a small region.  I really like the fact that you've been thinking through all the different media.

Nice one A-L! Would be great to hook-up NYU-Poly skills up on ideas like this one. Amanda  sorry I'm no longer in touch with the person I mentioned... was a casual but enlightening connect at a conference. But am holding out great hope from A-L's offer here!
I've started spreading the word - through the students' chapter, the incubator and the grad center... I cannot do much more. Maybe Paul's client would also be able to help.

Thanks A-L!!  Text-messaging is certainly a viable option, as is Skype, I'll make sure to add those in.  I'll try to clarify my SMS portion as well.  Also, I just heard back from my brother and he has some technical info for me.  So hopefully I won't butcher it when I post my second update ;-)

Also, in answer to your question A-L, I would hope to get as many people in the database as possible.  This would be the situation in which you're most likely to find people close enough to meet in person.  But, that doesn't restrict them to face-to-face meeting.  Even if they were far enough apart that face-to-face wasn't possible, I think that the other technology options should provide enough support that they'll still be able to reap the benefits of a connection...

great regarding technical advice. I'll let you know if I get any information / contacts from the emails I sent "on your behalf" tonight. :-) btw please check my update on the shift van. I haven't included the details of creating connections, but will add them in update 2.
Okay all, Update 2 is posted.  Including a prototype!!  Thoughts?

This is such a worthwhile concept, Amanda.I envisage the matching process providing a few contacts/correspondents for each. Maybe some funds could be established to allow some of them to meet physically too. Would be great if this could result in a self-sustaining, expanding network across as well as within cultures.

Thanks Paul!  I would love for this concept to become relatively self-sustaining, and tried to design it with that in mind.  I also love that you picked up on expanding the network across and within cultures.  That is definitely the way I would like to see it progress!

Thanks Amanda. Sorry for the slow and disjointed replies, my dialup is being particularly painful with page refreshing today.I dont know how many 'vans' are envisaged but I saw them being equipped with satellite phone technology for remote situations and that van-to-van communication would be a regular thing, which might facilitate some of your connections.More directly to 'creating connections' I see this as in the second rank of Maslow's heirarchy (after food shelter and clothing). I know they will already be part of a local community but in some cases they may have become ostracised too, in these circumstances being an 'accepted' part of a wider community would (I imagine) be of some comfort. Having said that, it will be absolutely essential to address the lower rank needs first, so hopefully this concept will be integrated into a structured multi-layered solution to this challenge.

Letter writing might be the most comfortable option for correspondents in some situations, with physical delivery to begin with. After that perhaps scanning/faxing technology could be used to speed the correspondence. A gentle introduction to using other technology might follow.

Hi Amanda!!Loving this, and so happy to be inspired by you once again!You mention something so important for these women regarding the loneliness and emotional support that hasn't yet had much emphasis on. This is a great way to address this issue. It does remind me of what A-L mentions as pen pals, but also almost as a dating website, but not for dating - more to converse and connect with someone with the same interests and issues as you. It also reminds me of when I was at university and the Student Services advertised everywhere their NightLine number, so anyone could call in anonymously and talk about their personal issues, be it safety, money or student life related. It was free of charge, and you would talk to someone for as long as you needed and feel better. I really like the way you've thought of literacy here, as it could be a problem. I know some of these women might not have access to technology, maybe not even mobiles, but if we could reach them with the Info Hub and Shift Van, I'm sure we could also get a way to connect with them. It would be great if through Amnesty's or the UN's local connections, if we got in touch with local translators that know the community and villages very well, if they could start pointing us to women/families they know that are in this situation RIGHT NOW, so we could start contacting them and telling them about this 'service', or aid.Great work Amanda, your very inspiring.
Wow, thanks Ana!  It would be wonderful to see this concept achieve realization in the way that you described :)
Just posted an update.  Would love to get your thoughts re: refining! :-)

Brilliant building on insights from this clip, Amanda! I wonder if there might be a low-tech angle too? Something inspired by http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/mobile-letter-writing-workshops/ Looking forward to onwards discussion on this one!
great minds think alike: see the comment I was writing as you were posting yours :-)
Too funny  collaborative minds in sync!

Thanks for the compliment Meena!  It was really helpful for me to hear a first-hand account of someone affected by unlawful detainment, thanks for posting :)  And thanks ladies, you made it easy for me this time, I only had to post one update incorporating your suggestions :P  Which I have already posted, FYI.  Thanks to you both!

Indeed  the clip really helps us relate to some of the issues which I think we'd earlier not thought of in regards to this challenge. We were amped that you were so quick to convert those insights into a concept! And great to see you evolving you conversation here in true collaborative form.
The clip indeed really helps empathize emotionally, and not only cognitively, with some of the important consequences of unlawful detention.

Amanda, quick update. Just a thought regarding the literacy issue. I'm wondering - just to keep it as low key as possible (and in particular because speech recognition as dragon are not easy to use and require time to train the system), that we could have people in the truck writing the letters (or posting on the platform) for women who might need. From your concept, I understood that it might be in the same country. Another idea that could be an extension of this would be to revisit the old role of the scribe in the village. I personally would disagree on how the phone is much better for expressing emotions and building relationship, and how phone (voice) will allow communication at its full potential. Yet, this is another conversation, an interesting one, but not the focus here. Another option is indeed the telephone option - I'm thinking of  the project of Grameen with Telenor in Bangladesh with the telephone ladies in villages. You will still to think of a matching but you could think of ladies calling each other maybe not very often - in particular because of costs - but still the possibility will already be something. It could also create job opportunities and provide meaning to the phone lady. The more I think about it, the more I like this concept and I can see how it could be developed.

Thanks Anne-Laure!I think having scribes in the van would be an excellent idea.  And you are correct, I would like to have the paired women be as close to each other as possible, in terms of physical distance.  So yes, same country would be what I had in mind, same region would be even better.I actually agree with you that actual letter-writing can be a wonderful way to express emotion.  The reason I think phones would be a better option is not due to expressing emotion, but being able to exchange messages in a timely manner.  Say the van patrols a certain region, and maybe the roads are really bad (or nonexistent) in that region.  If I need emotional support from my partner, maybe I go write the letter, and send it with the truck.  Maybe it then takes 4 days for  the truck to get to my partner, who writes immediately to respond.  But then, maybe it takes another 4 days for the truck to get back to me.  So, in this circumstance, I may not hear back for a total of 8 days.  Maybe more if the truck breaks down, or there is some other kind of problem.  I think that many of the larger issues of emotional support could be dealt with over that kind of delay, without losing impact.  But, I do think there is something to be said for the immediacy available via phone.For instance, maybe I've had a bad day, my kids are being challenging, I'm worried about how I'll pay my bills, the safety of my husband, etc.  Maybe I'm particularly sad or angry or emotional in some other way.  With phone, I think there's something to be said for the ability to immediately reach out to somebody when you're at that low point and immediately get their support and feedback.That being said, obviously this is all theoretical, and the overall answer would be that it depends.  It depends on how far the van is traveling.  It depends on the consistency of the equipment.  It depends on the safety of the van as it travels around.  Conversely, it also depends on the consistency of phone service in the area.  The cost of accessing and using phones (as you pointed out).  Many problems could arise with either outlet, which is why I think it's valuable to have both.  That was just my initial reasoning to why I thought phones might be ideal.The idea of the telephone ladies is an interesting one!  I think the key with this concept is providing women with as many ways to reach out as possible, so that no matter what means they have access to or even simply prefer, they'll be able to reach the support they need.
Of course, then again, maybe just expressing the emotion immediately is enough.  Maybe it doesn't matter if the reply is immediate, and just the catharsis of writing down those emotions will help?

Hi Amanda,I agree with you that phone provides more immediacy and in some cases, it might matter.Yet, as you noted in your second comment, in many cases, I think it's the fact of writing down and knowing that someone will read you (and respond) that matters.Also sometime you feel less shy writing to someone you don't know about things that are personal rather than talking on the phone.However, in the end, I agree with you multiplying the communication channels is the way to go.

A-L, funny you're messaging me just now.  I actually just modified my concept to reflect that thought.  I think that the situation could be so complex that each method will have pros and cons.  Ultimately, as many methods as possible would be ideal.Plus, I took your suggestion for the scribe and substituted that for text-to-speech.  Thanks for the dialogue, hope you enjoy the revisions :-)
Nice revisions and I enjoy the dialogue. :-)
Just posted an update.  Would love to get your thoughts re: refining! :-)
A really fantastic idea Amanda. I'm a little late to the party, but I just wanted to give a thumbs up and let you+team know it was fun reading through the collaboration that ensued!

Thanks Jason!  I don't know that you could be characterized as even a little late to the party; in all fairness, the video was just added yesterday and my concept didn't come too far after that.  I think it's more that the rest of us could be characterized as early to the party :-)  Regardless, I'm glad you've enjoyed reading the collaboration that ensued.  I've certainly enjoyed participating in it!
Just posted an update.  Would love to get your thoughts re: refining! :-)

Nice concept Amanda (and glad to be once again part of your virtual team with Ana! :-)).I like your thinking about the families, in particular the wives. The III shift van could definitely spread the word but it could also provide a way for these women to have access to the high tech version.  For the low tech version, thinking of the pen pals and the role of letter writing in sharing emotions and providing support, I'm wondering if we could also think of developing a pen pals systems for these wives. A related concept is the mobile letter - writing workshop: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/mobile-letter-writing-workshops/

creating_connections_.title: UPDATE 4. Creating Connections

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

comments.text: Marnie! Thank you for your outstanding effort on this challenge. The Amnesty team really appreciated how you pulled inspiration from so many concepts. Thank you for your hard work!

http://www.corpwatch.org/ another potential source of collaboration.  They are a non-profit with the mission of "Holding Corporations Accountable", including Human Rights Violations.  Their Open API set gives anyone access to their underlying sophisticated collection of research tools and data.  currently featured on their site: "Serco, a UK company, has a contract to manage the Christmas Island Immigration Detention Centre some 1,600 miles off the West Coast of Australia, which houses thousands of asylum seekers. The detainees at the overcrowded facility are experiencing serious mental health problems that union organizers say are a result of poor training and understaffing. "
Thanks for this link Marnie as an Australian resident it is distressing to see the current attitude of both major political parties to these poor people.

Thanks for presenting such a clear overview of the inter-connectedness of so many of these concepts.Such an overview is extremely useful not only for this challenge but I suspect almost every challenge discussed.In particular it is useful as we move into the evaluation phase because it means that we dont now have to evaluate concepts in isolation but consider their contribution to an integrated system.I shall go back to the Social Impact challenge and attempt a similar integration exercise (even if it is just for my own understanding) and I am considering what sort of graphical tool could represent this. I shall see if any of my Open Source MindMapping tools can achieve this.

wow Paul, nice remarks - appreciate it.  I didn't have time to review too many of the concepts that did not make the top 16, but the top 16 selection was conducive to this type of thought convergence - so many great and divergent ideas and contributions from the community to work with.  There was total compatibility, but no redundancy.  So the first, critical part of the exercise was skillfully done by the OpenIDEO selection committee.  The power of collaboration, which I love.  wrt tools, let me know if you find any please - that would be very interesting.  paper, scissors, highlighters, tape and LOTS OF SPACE work really well.  Something about the manipulation of objects in space and time and the neuroscience of it all .... works for me anyhow :)

Hi Marnie,I tracked down the sort of tools of which I was thinking.CMapTools (as in Concept Mapping http://cmap.ihmc.us ). The creation/editing tool is open source and PC based but the maps are online and can be collaborative. This is what I produced relatively quickly in the last few days ( http://cmapspublic3.ihmc.us/rid=1K1S4SRW0-1SJ351Q-W8P/Amnesty.cmap )I haven't tried anything besides basic mapping and as I had no-one with whom to collaborate I can't comment on that aspect.
thanks so much Paul.  I will play with it.  Love cool tools, especially when mixed with old fashion color, cut and paste:)  maybe potential for furture collaborations!

Thanks Marnie. I am going to submit it to OpenIDEO as a resource for the winning 'Resources' concept arising from the Social Impact challenge. They could host a CMap server and perhaps turn virtual teams into 'real' teams. I have released the collaboration lock from the map I created so feel free to play with that one specifically (add post-its etc). Unfortunately because I only have a dial-up connection real-time collaboration is difficult for me.

Oops forgot to tell you where to find it - from Places in Cmap Tools choose (each line is a folder):IHMC pUBLIC cMAPS (3)Users (create your own folder)OpenIDEATORS Amnesty Challengehopefully you can open it and make whatever changes you like.

In evaluating this concept I have had in mind first its suggestion for collaborating with and building on work already underway in other organisations (of which the UN Global Pulse Project is a brilliant and apt example). Secondly the update of the concept shows how bringing together a number, if not all short-listed concepts, and complementary aspects of others not short-listed, forms an integrated system of support, action and the desired awareness/education outcomes.

I will be adding one more refinement to my mock up (even though I could not get the downloads to work) to reflect the update that Anna made to her data visualization and to emphasize the power in the interactive real time map as described by Ana Cecilia Santos.  The idea is that you can click on a symbol on the map and get all the stories, videos, pictures, alerts.... associated with that point of data/person.  If you have high security access you will also get all of the intelligence analysis associated with the black dots in my mock up.  The goal of the intelligence information is to help locate those detained at unknown locations, just known to be missing AND to find the source of the leadership that is responsible for the unlawful detainment.  Different scenario analysis could be performed to determine probability of any given geo-location being the real location of interest ..... the possibilities are endless.  After all, I am passionate about the possibilities.  All of the data can be used after the fact for awareness, advocacy  and fund raising campaigns.  It can also be used to analyze effectiveness of various operations for future planning.  How many people were detained in any given country unlawfully, without legal representation, what type of activity drives the most unlawful detention, how many operations were shut down over time in any given location, how long were people missing before found, what operations were the most successful, who suffered abuse, how long were people detained, how many were never found, how many were indirectly impacted by this unlawful detention .... ask and the data should be there to tell many stories to help prevent, predict and provide. Thanks Ana Cecilia Santos, Anne-Laure Fayard, Paul Reader, Jason George, Meena Kadri and OpenIDEO for your comments and insights.  It has been lots of fun!! :) Hope to see you all at another OpenIDEO challenge .....  ML
http://maps.occupy.net/ A Sample of the power of the ushahidi platform and data visualization
Great example Marnie! Thanks for sharing that.It is also kind of how i imagined my concept of the Interactive Infographic Platform. Congrats on your super concept reaching the refinement stage !
Great example Marnie! Thanks for sharing that.It is also kind of how i imagined my concept of the Interactive Infographic Platform. Congrats on your super concept reaching the refinement stage !

Yes Ana, we are on the same page for sure.  As you can see above, you were my main inspiration in the evolution of the concept.  It has been fun creating with you.  Hope we meet again in the next challenge:)  Keep an eye on the Global Pulse Team, they are doing some awesome, leading edge innovation that will set the bar very high.

hi Marnie!Thank you I am very happy I inspired you, and you really helped push my concept further by giving me important info and bringing um important questions, thank you for that once again!Regarding the Global Pulse UN project, i have just read a bit more about them on the website, I'd like ask a few more questions, as I'd like to try and get involved with them. Thanks for being so inspiring Marnie! let's collaborate more very soon :)
I can't get my downloads to work!!

Take All 16 Brilliant concepts in the refinement phase (and many not included in the refinement phase) and INTEGRATE ALL OF THE IDEAS together into a strategic architecture.  Define a list of priorities based on goals, ease of implementation, impact:effort ratio ....  Build the foundation on top of existing platforms like UNGP and add on functionality as funding becomes available and technology evolves in maturity.  Pilot.  Use Agile development methodologies.  All 16 concepts collect unique and valuable information.  Define a data architecture that builds on all of this crowdsourced design.  Build one common interface to collect from multiple sources, store, scrub, cleanse, tag, analyse, visualize .... the data, building on the work that others like UNGP have already done, open platforms like ushahidi, and the integration of the design concepts of this IDEO challenge community.
Fantastic comments Marnie!There is huge potential for collaborative integration especially in the refinement phase, as indeed there was (and still is) for the previous challenge.

Hi Marnie, I cannot agree more on how we can and should integrate all the concepts of this refinement phase. I just noticed your comment (thanks to Paul who replied to one of my comments on Elliott's sponsor a spouse concept), very similar to yours). It seems to me that all concepts are providing a perspective on the problem and potentially build upon each other.You did a great job in your update in connecting your concept with all the other concepts. In my concept, I made some connections with other concepts but not with all. I'll try to do this today before the end of refinement. al
Nicely synthesized Marnie. Hopefully some combination of concepts will materialize!

Detainee - services they may need: find them; watch over them; free them; support them emotionally, financially, legally, language translation, bring their families and supporters messages to them ...Potential Detainee - services they may need: protection; intervention with the goal of PREVENTION of unlawful detention; generation of an ALERT when they go missing and start search and rescue mission; access to information and experts; protection for their families and supporters; protection of their data (photos, videos, notes, memory ...)... Detainers - monitor them; educate them; take legal action, when necessary .... Goals:  eliminate future acts of human rights violation and protect the human rights of those currently detainedHow? Data Science and Visualization
Hi Marnie, nice listing of all the audiences your concept is addressed to. I might add also the "public" as your concept would be a great tool to increase awareness and educate.
All the data visualization samples are from gestalten DATA FLOW visualizing information in Graphic design 2

from Stephen Few's  Simple Visualization Techniques for Quantitative Analysis Traits of Meaningful Data - High Volume - Historical - insight from change thru time- Consistent - Multivariate - quantitative (measureed in numbers) and categorical (qualitative, a charactereistic described in words)- Atomic - specified down to the lowest level of detail- Clean - The quality of our analysis can never exceed the quality of our information Garbage in, garbage out - Clear - familiar terms - dimensionally structured [but with tagging, fuzzy logic, video analysis techniques, facial recognition, meta data ...this point has evolved, inho]- Richly Segmented - Of known Pedigree - [balanced with "good enough" when the need to act fast, taking risk and probability analysis into account...]

For Amnesty to collaborate with UNGP,  especially with any concepts that emerge from this challenge, seems an eminently sensible suggestion. Clearly this organisation is already leveraging existing technology for similar purposes and pursuing active technological development for situations where present technology is either too limited or too proprietary.In fact keeping in mind the efforts of UNGP on every OpenIDEO challenge intended to impact developing communities might prove fruitful. Would a link to UNGP in the forums or the coming resources component of the OpenIDEO platform be appropriate?

Hello Marnie, thank you for your great contribution to the Amnesty challenge. The expert panel has short-listed your concept for the next phase. Would you be willing to push your idea a bit further? What would a mobile version of Global Pulse look like? Dont forget to reach out to the OpenIDEO community for ideas on how you might build out your concept.
Nice one Marnie  and we're loving your "Passionate about the Possibilities" line on your profile! Very much in sync with our thinking at OpenIDEO!

Hi Marnie,thanks for sharing. It is indeed a wonderful inspiration that was shared by Meena in the inspiration phase: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/global-pulse/In the concepting phase, the idea is go see how we can be inspired by such a project to develop it for the current challenge. Do you have any ideas on how to build upon this great idea?I agree it will be great if we could spend all day on OpenIDEO! OK. back to work. :-)al

Does the Global Pulse team know about this challenge?  Since they have an open source project Hunchworks, it is not necessary to re-invent the wheel.  I look at this thru the lens of a data scientist.  I would think participating in any beta with UN GP would be inspiring.

Marnie, this is an excellent point!I suppose that people developing a concept, which could build upon the global pulse project (e.g. Ana's interactive infographics and Julian's map of freedom http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/-the-map-of-freedom-on-amnesty-international-website), should definitely contact them.

"Prepared for the United Nations Global Pulse team, the Future of Real-Time Report identifies key trends emerging around the capture and transmission of real-time information streams.Evolving data-rich technologies are providing organizations, governments and businesses with a rapid way to monitor the well-being of communities and individuals without significant infrastructure or spend. For organizations whose success is dependent on the ability to quickly recognize and react to high-risk situations, the proliferation of rapid access to good enough information is proving invaluable." The UNGP team have certainly considered groups without access to the internet.  It is all about getting information from data by finding patterns and signal in noise, even when no clear information is available; keeping the participants safe in dangerous situations; and, of course, local context in a global world.
The Global Pulse project builds on the concepts that Avneet has presented.

comments.text: Interesting concept Paul!  Sarah's suggestion for funding is an excellent one.It might also be an option to open source the animation, similar to the way Joseph Gordon Levitt has with http://hitrecord.org/  Something to consider if you'd like to minimize costs...

Thanks Amanda. Ilove the way we can share ideas and resources from othe situations and personal experience. I raised the concept as one possible way of creating awareness amongst the kids (small and large). Unlawful detention might be a subject to raise through programs like The Simpsons too - just using the broadest range of avenues available to get the message across.
How about targeting CSR departments of illustration/design firms to get this funded?
And maybe also use Sparked for volunteer designers?

Thats a great suggestion Sarah I personally dont see a lot of CSR here, I think it's probably in its infancy. Will 'look up' Sparked since I had not heard of it - might be something to interest Kathryn too (as she looks for avenues to utilise her talents).

I love that this concept uses art and collective creativity to create empathy in a really big way. I like your idea of a contest to get this thing off the ground. As a student of art, I know that art students are always enthusiastic and quite honestly, desperate to exercise what they can do and get any exposure you can. Targeting students in a contest like this might be a great way to get a lot of input, a lot of effort, and very little money into this idea. It's also a great way to start a dialogue with the emerging generation to expand empathy and keep it alive for a while.
Thanks for the encouragement and excellent suggestion to get student artists (of all media) involved.

I wonder if governments have control over television in areas that deal with illegal detention. In those areas, it would probably be difficult to get a program like this on the air.For a low-tech situation, could these illustrated stories be printed as simple folded paper "books"? There could be the same censorship problem with that, but it might be easier to produce and distribute on a smaller scale.
Good point Alix thats partly why I put print media at the head of the list.

comments.text: Hope this can make us stronger.

Look at the pictures like this remind all of us that maybe we can not prevent this kind of disaster from happening but we can come up with more efficient rescue plans and reconstruction plans to rebuild our homes...

Disasters provide an interesting source of INspiration on this challenge, Callum. It's great to see some of the posts on this challenge which point to initiatives like Ushahidi as solution-focused endeavors in the face of crisis. You can read more about here: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/14/weekinreview/14giridharadas.html What other tools & initiatives which spring up around crises might we learn from to inspire new solutions?

digital_detainment.description: To raise awareness around unlawful detention, Amnesty International will detain Facebook profiles. The profiles will be taken without cause, and detainees will not be able to communicate with their friends.
digital_detainment.creator: 2694f3a8ac12bf31dd58c006140753b5

comments.text: Very interesting idea! And it seems promising in creating a buzz! I fully support.Detaining random people's profiles may be the ideal in creating a shock and hence, interaction and awareness, as this is what happens in real life, no one volunteers to be detained. One day they are free, the next they are not.However, doing this as well may lead to other legal issues by the page owner against the campaign, so Vincent's idea of voluntary permission to detain the page sounds problem-free.Individuals with high popularity, such as those with high number of  friends or actively linked Facebook page to blogs and other social networking sites would generate higher participation. Yet, I still think the individuals should be picked at random from the world, mostly individuals that are not related to the human rights field.
Great thinking around freedoms we take for granted, Jessica!

Congrats on a very interesting idea!  The thing that concerns me is that if not enough people "like" the page in a timely manner, the "detainee" will have lost the easiest way to reach out and remind them.  It's not as effective if the person is never freed.  I wonder if there might be a way to incorporate automated amnesty-related status updates into it.  Such as,Detainment: Day 1To free Detained Person's Name from detainment, please go to www.facebook.com/... (the amnesty FB page).You could even incorporate some type of link to a real detained person's petition or something into the automated status updates.  Very neat concept :-)

Interesting idea. It builds upon current communicative practices. It reminded me of an inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-sound-of-social-media-silenceYou might also want to check the no communication day concept, which is built upon similar assumptions: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/no-communication-day-an-event-and-communication-strategy/
Creative idea Jessica! I assume the "detention without cause" would actually be voluntarily enabled by the profile owner as a way to raise awareness?

comments.text: Great inspiration.  The feeling of being lost or overwhelmed was the first thing that came to mind - and made me think about whether there is some kind of breadcrumb trail or wayfinding metaphor that would help people feel like they had a sense of where they've been or that they could reconnect to the world (the prisoner or their loved ones).

Hi Erin, Maybe a metaphor like a person who suddenly loses his/her sight tries to get used to the situation after a while by slowly learning to live with it (focusing on other senses).  Along the same line, the story of Helen Keller is always amazing.
