Think this is a great idea!!!

Nice one, Laci.Tip: Rather than using HTML code, you can use the formatting bar above the submission texts fields to add links, etc. To edit your post and remove redundant formatting, just hit the Update Entry button to the right of your post. Hope that helps : )

internet_in_a_suitcase.title: Internet-in-a-Suitcase

clothing_antenna_worn_by_potential_victi.description: The Cospas-Sarsat gives alert and location data which can help rescue (and human-rights?) organizations to assist persons in distress. Sew a cheap and batteryless radio antenna into clothing being worn by potential victims of unlawfull detention.
clothing_antenna_worn_by_potential_victi.creator: b2705ccf3a1876f9636bd018eec2b261
clothing_antenna_worn_by_potential_victi.title: Clothing antenna worn by potential victims to assist searching and finding when detained

banksy_does_it_best.description: Pros at drawing media attention to social issues, Banksy or other artists such as JR, address social and political issues to build awareness on a large scale.
banksy_does_it_best.creator: c600945efcec7d3bc6c5f55073e1c49c

comments.text: Banksy makes a mark, because he is subversive and catches the attention of the unassuming pedestrian.  His approach is visually arresting, buzzworthy and culturally relevant.

I agree, but the trick is making it culturally relevant, isn't it? I think this is a great start, but how can we translate these ideas across cultures?On the same notion, perhaps translation is not important and the "relevant" should only be determined locally...

Completely agreed on the importance of finding a way to make things culturally relevant "beyond translation". Great point Jamie and nice example of the student project. It's interesting how we take things for granted.That's a point that was also raised by Aviya about an inspiration on art and increasing public awareness: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/protect-protect/on a non-art topic, we also had a conversation about culture and how taking into account the local context was key: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/hope-for-tomorrow/

That's such a great point, Jamie. A few years back I worked on a project with students to propose ways to create awareness on health issues amongst low-income communities in Kenya. They started out by proposing a graffiti campaign. Luckily one of them pointed out that this kind of messaging would not resonate with the intended audience. How might we be inspired by Banksy's + JR's use of disruptive messaging and apply it to diverse global contexts? (sorry, I posed this comment earlier under the wrong login!)

One beautifully simple aspect of Banksy's work is its pictographishness - not unlike Public Information Symbols, which do translate across cultures. His Gaza work comes to mind immediately:http://www.streetartutopia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/cuthere.jpegand http://www.flickr.com/photos/66869048@N06/6175415949/Maybe there is some universal symbology we can use to raise awareness?

Jason, you have a good point about universal symbology. And, Anne-Laure, I liked your point about locality.I think there are two ends of a continuum, and it will be important to find the right balance:-Focus on local: This focuses on resonating with the local audience. That could happen by involving them in the process, getting their input. This would be harder to replicate, but greater likelihood for success where the problems are happening.-Focus on global: This emphasizes the universal symbology. There are a number of things that are true for everyone; the act of smiling, for instance. This strives to make the awareness easy to understand, ideally easy to access as well, and it could be replicated. The risk is that is might not seem authentic in certain areas...No matter what, there needs to be a story to tell...Meena, what did you end up doing in Kenya?
Great points, Jamie. Some of the stuff we did in Kenya is covered here: http://www.randomspecific.com/creating-waves-through-collaboration

Thanks Meena for the link, The creating waves project is fascinating! Jamie, thanks for summarizing the discussion. Very nicely done. I agree that we need to focus on both the local and the global... There is indeed a potential for universal communication... smiling seems one, just thinking of my experience of traveling. Yet, as I'm writing that I'm thinking that there are different "types of smile"... Yet the "concept" (for lack of a better word) of a smile is universal but might be enacted differently... see this very interesting video on different gestures in different cultures: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pxoB6MhmbIg&feature=relatedI also think that the distinction might have to be considered in different contexts:- when it comes to public campaigns... thinking where you are doing the campaign and who is the audience? what is your message and how you are framing it? - when it comes to designing tools and support systems: this is an understanding of the technological infrastructure as well as the needs and the local practices.
Anne-Laure, that video is awesome! It's very true, even semi-universal gestures can be manifested very differently in different countries.

Banksy made a huge impact on the street art world, and he inspired artists around the world. If a movement that was aimed specifically at highlighting social injustice, and it was successful in garnering media attention, it would more than likely cross over to other countries and cultures and other artists would be inspired to use street art to highlight their specific social injustice. I love this idea!Love, EthanWCIL (Wells College Innovatioin Lab [pronounced whistle])

banksy_does_it_best.title: Banksy Does It Best

no_ping_alert_on_.description:
The inspiration was:  interruption-based security architecture. 

The concept: Someone is detained.   He was suppose to ping the system saying "I'm OK", but he can't.  Because of this, a series of smart alarms are created.
no_ping_alert_on_.creator: f12c7f26c1955c557591c0bac98307d8

comments.text: I know this is all very late, but I Alejandro I read your idea about 'No Ping = Alert On' about a year ago, and built on it, but I never did anything with it until a couple of months ago. I realised weekend party goers face similar issues, and you could have a white label app/infrastructure that supports both use cases, and also split the costs between organizations and sponsors in both spaces. I called it 'get home safe'. Here's a video explaining my thoughts on design and architecture: http://davidrs.com/wp/video-get-home-safe-design-with-balsamiq/

Hi Alejandro - did you hear the news? Your concept is being developed and prototyped as part of this weeks Make-a-thon at IDEO London! Check this out for more info http://bit.ly/y2uDQZ and be sure to weigh in over at our User Forums http://bit.ly/yt0m5d to share insights, tips or important considerations for the Make-a-thon attendees to think about as they work on your concept. And heres a hint: be sure to check out Brief #8!
Hi Alejandro.  I think your idea is great and really taps into existing technology - mobile phones - which everyone seems to have access to, even in developing countries.

Hello Alejandro! Thank you for your great contribution, congratulations on designing a winning concept. The Amnesty team loved the simplicity of your idea and hope to prototype it at hack-day events. Thank you for your hard work!

Congrats Alejandro! Activating based on inaction is a clever approach.As this moves towards realization, would be interested to hear your thoughts on integrating this check-in activity with pre-existing behavior (such as wake up alarms/calls) in order to lower usage burden & increase sustainable adoption (see my previous comment below: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/winners-announced/no-ping-alert-on-/#c-073984661ab601dca032941c45f1c66d ).
Congratulations Alenjandro! The simplicity of the concept makes it very strong. Looking forward to seeing the prototypes coming out of the hackday events.

Great work Alejandro! Will look forward to seeing how Amnesty realises this very simple but effective concept, both from a technical standpoint and the important integration into the alert and information system.
Congratulations on your winning concept Alejandro!  Like everyone else, I'm looking forward to seeing your simple and effective concept prototyped.

Paul, Vincent, Phillip, Anne, Keith, Emily, Michael,   Thank you all for your comments and your support!   I'm sorry for not replying to each of your comments, but I barely had the time to login and send this message (crazy timing).Cheers!

Alejandro, as with other concepts, I have evaluated this simple but brilliant concept as an element of a broad integrated system. In particular I see this working as an effective alert in conjunction with Amy's PACT where the alarm generated sets in motion a predetermined response. In addition it would be useful, if possible to analyse the most recent movements of the cellphone prior to the alert.

Agreed with Philip Antrobus. The beauty of this approach is that it's based on inaction (rather than an action, which may not be possible at the needed time) to begin the alert process. Seth Cochran (and others) also made some great points on how this system can work across different technologies (whether email, automated voice calls, or otherwise).Given the high burden placed on potential detainees & their families, it's likely that only the fraction that are very worried that they are at a high risk for detention (which is probably significantly less than the total population at risk) would sign up for this service.Perhaps it'd be possible to lower this burden (and thus increase the proportion of the at risk population that signs up for & sticks with this service), by integrating this check in activity with a pre-existing behavior.For example, many people already use various systems (alarm clocks, wake up calls for travelers, etc.) to wake up each morning. So, imagine if this alert service is provided bundled with a wake-up call/alarm each morning. Subscribers reply to the call & turn off the alarm by saying or texting a predetermined code. If they don't respond, the emergency alert process begins. This also has the added benefit of motivating people to wake up at their desired times (they don't want to worry their personal networks unnecessarily, and the effort needed to enter in a code makes them less likely to fall back asleep by mistake) =P

I really like this interruption-based idea.  Not only is it a more secure architectural model than an app you have to activate before the authorities confiscate your device, having at-risk individuals reply to an SMS alert to confirm their continued safety, is potentially lower tech than a mobile app or similar.
Great concept. I like the "chain reaction" idea.

An automated SMS alert is wonderfully simple and elegant.  I like the idea of geo-tagging, in that then you could create a global heat map of incidents (this was another finalist's idea).  That map would show clearly areas where this is prevalent.  But the simplicity of the "No ping = Alert" is excellent.

Might it be possible to coordinate the frequency of pings/check-ins with the level of danger the potential detainee perceives? I'm thinking about ways the information collected from the form could be put to use...

I wanted to share some of the photos from our hackathon at Cornell. We were using the methods of Design Thinking to structure our work and it turned out to be an incredibly productive few hours.Here's a link to the photos: http://flic.kr/s/aHsjwQixwRAnd our contributions to the great idea: http://prezi.com/bcn4d3yuccl7/design-thinking/Let us know if you have any thoughts/comments/suggestions, etc.!
Marshall, thanks for supporting the idea and contributing with this great work!

Hey- I worked with the Cornell team. We picked this concept because we believe it's the most feasible way to have a real impact on a dangerous situation. Developing this would be an amazing experience and an even better opportunity for change.

Very smart approach.  I like that instead of requiring the user to activate the alert, you are requiring that the user (or their circles of support) have to regularly deactivate it.  This is more of a burden on the user and their network, but if the risk of detention is high, irregular check-in is justified.  Furthermore, it is smart that it integrates into existing devices (mobile phones).  You could move across technology platforms, depending on the environment (from SMS, to landline, to smoke signals).  This systems structure would work even if the user didn't have a mobile phone.

Thank a lot Seth!  You have a very clear vision, and great system thinking, I'm impressed!   I applauded your collaboration (Local Currency inspiration), that is an amazing example of system design and social engineering.   Could I ask you (just curiosity) what do you do for living?

Hi Alejandro,Thanks for the kind words...I'm blushing over here. As for what I do for a living, its a bit hard to briefly explain. Its a bit of a mix.  Check out my linkedin @ http://www.linkedin.com/in/sethcochran
Nice idea. However we were wondering what would happen if the victim fell asleep without typing in to say they are okay.

I guess they would wake up and send their OK signal.  There is no doubt the system will have to be design to avoid such scenario.  For example, the system should not allow the subscriber to set alarms for less than 1 day.  There are too many chances for someone to not being able to sustain a frequency of let's say 30mins or 1 hour.
Thanks Marshall and the Cornell team for adding the pictures of your great prototype!  You did amazing work in such a short amount of time!!

I like the idea, however, governments and para-government forces of countries with citizens routinely in jeopardy of detention would wise up to such techniques and eventually find ways to nullify them. All the PTB need to do is block the service, by threatening the local cell phone carriers with whatever means necessary. It would take time, but we'd be back to square one.You could enhance (or complicate) this idea by creating a hardware token which the subject would then have to carry around with them at all times. The token (could simply be an app on the cellphone) would generate a new SMS number every 30 seconds based on a fixed time algorithm that is in sync with the alert service HQ. However, even with today's advancements in phone services, I think generating new SMS numbers at random would be too costly to implement. I'm not certain on that, but would seem so.The other problem is with the users of such systems, they are prone to false alarms, especially if they are difficult to explain or understand, thus raising cost and lowering efficiency. Imagine at some point nobody would know when to believe an alert, and you would have to somehow penalize people for not following up with the system, if they had gotten careless for example.Finally, you would have to know in advance that you are a target for detention. That seems a small percentage of people, let's say "professional detainees". I'm not certain the majority of detainees know when they become a target or of the circumstances they are in jeopardy at any given point

Thanks for the comment Marlon.Before posting my inspiration and concept, I realized a lot of people where focusing on the scenario where the detention was unexpected, incommunicado, and unlawful at the same time.  But what happen in those scenarios (fairly common) where we do know somebody was detained, we do where they are, but we don't have a legal and "legitim" way to take them out?   These are the cases where the detainees need more a legal support than a "war-field" sort of support.  The No Ping=Alert ON system is designed to generate institutional alertness around a detainee or a group of detainees who's location is probably know and the identity of their detainers is probably, but even that, there aren't legal resources yet to take them off.  I decided to take way and not another way because the title of the challenge says "unlawful" detention.  Now yes, I am not saying other kind of detentions aren't described on the brief, but at least, the fact that this label was chosen for the title (and not other one) had a meaning to me.The scenarios where a person is "taken away" from their natural flow is more a agressively-changed reality scenario (like a war, a kidnap, a violent protest), and unlawful detention, to me, suggest that the main problem is not only the physical isolation and retention, but also (and probably more important) is the legal impossibility to switch that reality to its previous state.This is the reason why I also decided to update my entry with a new system layer:  Automated Legal Case Preparation, where the main idea is to help cut time on the legal fight that has to happen in order to take somebody back to their regular live.

Interesting feedback here Marlon - you've raised some really good questions about the feasibility, costs and longevity of this idea. I wonder if you or anyone else from the community has any added builds or suggestions for how Alejandro can address these issues and strengthen his concept? I'm looking forward to seeing how this develops.

Ashley, this system already exists in email form (I know of a site called Deathswitch.com). Going the email route is probably more versatile and cheaper than the SMS version because you can rotate originating email address far more cheaply than changing phone numbers.For a more fail safe version I think you want the system to call you however, not you call the system. So every 24 hours, an email arrives (each day, week or month, from a different origination DNS). The users clicks the link in the email and logs in with a strong password. Everything is cheaper with the internet version than with the SMS version. The passwords can be more secure, easier to remember and easier for the user to access and change. Also, you can change the originating email server far more easily if offending country tracks it down and attempts to block.The service itself would need to check that emails are getting through the "national firewall" from time to time for each of its user locales.  If it can't get through, it would need to figure another route to send the email. That part could get costly, but I am guessing could probably be automated, thanks to the extremely robust systems in use by email spamming industry.If the prospective dissident/detainee were being illegally tapped and "sniffed", then it is conceivable our email system could be duped because there's no easy/cheap way of introducing encryption into the mix. But they would have to do something very sneaky first, like prompt the user to change their password, and then attempt to do a man in the middle attack by capturing the https packets. However now we are in the realm of a very desperate kidnapping attempt, and not a very practical concern for the low profile, average detainee.

Hey Marlon, again you make strong points!  I like that.  Using email as an interface is a great idea.  I would say, it is to be added to the SMS interface instead of replace it.  The problem with having only an email interface is that you want users on the field, who don't have smartphones to be able to ping the system, and well, SMS is pretty much the only option for those old phones.  Makes me think also that all interfaces should be considered, not only email and SMS.  Probably, it wouldn't a bad idea to also have a web interface where the user can just type a secret code into a form and submit (no login needed).  Thanks for the feedback!
I just realized something pretty obvious that was skipping my mind: voice should be another interface.  The user could also call and dial a secret code.

Hey there. We gave it our best shot to build on this... And we'll keep editing, but thought we'd share our progress.This was created as part of a Hackathon at the Telluride House at Cornell University. We hope you can use the input.http://prezi.com/bcn4d3yuccl7/design-thinking/

Hey Marshall, thanks for the input!  Your support it's awesome!Everything is good, but there are two things that I'd like to highlight:  1)  Pattern Analysis.  Great and clear concept! thanks!  I think that level of intelligence would be necessary in order to avoid entropy in the system (and avoid as much false alarms as possible).  It would also be necessary to integrate this intelligence with the organizational level, and understand how man and machine can collaborate in this sense.2)  You integrate The NO ping = Alert ON with another system (your concept).  I think that is the best:  Understand that the best solution will be the combination of different subsystems.  If this ever comes to reality, it will absolutely necessary to keep the system as a ever evolving platform.  I hope that the guys from Amnesty International and the guys from IDEO realize that the best "digital solution" is spread all across this feed of 16 concepts (off course, without ignoring the extra help that Marshall and your colleagues are providing right now ;)  ).  I love what's happening here! thanks Open-IDEO !

The Wells College Innovation Lab has been searching ideas and we thought yours was very interesting! We began to brainstorm ideas that could possible help this or just be put out there. We came up with a walkie talkie add on for the phone that is similar to the universal emergency number. This could also be a device built into the phone already much like nextel already has for one of their phones on the market. Instead of using the number, you could press a button and talk to a call center run by interns organized by Amnesty International. If the center was run by interns it would be more economically viable for everyone since they don't need to be paid. The reason we are using this kind of technology is because it's quicker to just talk to someone instantaneously than send a text or find a number to call. (Rachel, Hannah, Forrest, Richard, Giavarna)
Thank for the comment Rachel!
sorry i actually meant to post this on another page....... but i like your idea also!

I think this app has potential for those parts of the world where interference with mobile service is unlikely, which is also those parts of the world heavily serviced by mobile phones.I dont have statistics for the percentage of the populace in other places who own mobile phones but suspect that it is lower than 80%. It seems to me that we need to divide the 'potential detainees' and their families/communities into two distinct groups: those who can normally be expected to have access to mobile phones and reliable mobile networks; and those who would normally have no mobile access.Of course there is likely to be some overlap too.Apps such as this have potential for the first group.For those not in the first group low-tech solutions are needed (and probably already used). That was one reason I raised the concept relating to second world war resistance practices as ways to monitor people at risk and send discreet messages in particular circumstances.Returning to this particular app it would be useful if the mobile network providor was to make the ping free of any costs to the subscriber. Again I would see setting up strategic local mesh networks (including clandestine networks) as either a means of communication where none presently exists or as a 'backstop' for established networks.  Such networks would only provide the first 'circle' of response but that could be better than nothing at all.

Thanks for the comment Paul (and all of you guys).I think you are right.  It is necessary create some distinction between users and scenarios as well.  There won't be one idea that suits all the angles of such a tremendously complicated problem.The idea concept certainly needs to be polished and better thought in different areas:  -  Management:  How to use as less resources as possible while generating as much impact as possible?  i think that helping Amnesty International to solve this problem has a huge symbolic value that a lot of people and institution will be willing to bet on (just for the sake of being involved).  From this assumption, many possibilities become visible:  help on volunteers for management and legal assistance, help from institutions like operators, media, labs and universities, etc, etc.   This takes me to the next point:-  Strategic Communication:  strategic in a sense of "keeping the project hidden from the enemy" and at the same time strategic on a sense of "seducing the right people/institutions to get involved".-  from a system perspective, the fact of having to build an online system for this, sets the precedent that other "online concepts" should be linked to this idea and integrated into a more robust technological solution, for example, the wiki concept and this concept should be consider as a consolidated effort.  Imaging sending the right information along with every smart alert (a ping that contains the right info in order for people to act).-  Security.  Marlon's point about security is very valid, but I can't stop thinking, once the detainee physical phenomena (whether it's about a small or a big organization) has the power to take down a technological structure.  In any case, no technology is perfect, and no system will survive to a human force that has the strength and the intelligence to solve that puzzle (how to take that system down).-  User action:  this concept is based on the fact that the human brain reacts unexpectedly during high stress situations.  Making the user generate any sort of action in order to trigger the alert seems to me way more dangerous than using the "non-action" strategy (that's my opinion anyway).- False alarms.  Marlon is completely right here.  That's the first weakness I saw on this concept.  Yet, with the same systems thinking this problem could be solved.  But that solution couldn't be thought clearly until the concept moved to a more real scenario (too many variables to be considered).  Still, I hope I'll have the time to polish that part during the upcoming days.

I tried to update my entry with this, but apparently there isn't enough space, so here it goes:Automated Legal Case Preparation: When the alert crosses the family circle and moves onto the institutional circle, it will trigger a call to a Artificial Intelligence that collects information relating the detainee and put it together in a single place.
Great break-down of your Concept, Alejandro  I especially like the way that you've used a scenario to help others engage with your ideas.
Thanks for your comment Meena!I'll keep this highlight in mind while growing this concept.

no_ping_alert_on_.title: No ping = Alert ON !  (Update Nov 10)

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

examine_your_own_world_then_give_it_a_vo.description: Oftentimes, we are unable to see the issues that exist within our own environments because we believe they are the status quo; however, when we examine and realize the inconsistencies within our own systems, we must find a way to give it a voice.
examine_your_own_world_then_give_it_a_vo.creator: d2d2b2925316fd42e7fd8e6a0db35c58

comments.text: Hi Dwight, welcome to OpenIDEO! And cheers for the resources you've listed here, including the pdf from Stanford University and Philip Zimbardo's talk. It would be great if you could add a short summary of each of those here  for community members on slow internet connections or who might not be able to read through the whole pdf but who'd love to learn from what you've shared :)

examine_your_own_world_then_give_it_a_vo.title: Examine your own world, then give it a voice.

amnesty_interactive_map.description: A lot of people know about Ai Weiwei and some of them have tried to convince China government to release  him but how many people know Majid Tavakoli and did anybody helped him to release. How can we build a platform to not only play an essential and equal role in terms of raising common awareness but also could appeal more audiences and activists by designing an interactive game.
amnesty_interactive_map.creator: 1c68bd27143c48545c24e9b2209f18af

comments.text: Dear Comrades, I made some changes and look forward to reading your comments.

I like the interactivity of this idea--that is something that makes regular people want to learn about these unlawful detainees. Moreover, it makes sure that no prisoner is lost or forgotten, even in the smallest of countries. It would be great to brainstorm ways that this idea could be adapted to low technology situations, especially for the relatives of people who have been unlawfully detained and may not have access to internet. I'm sure a map like this would be a great relief to friends and family, in addition to making other people aware of these situations. (Wells College Innovation Lab)

Interesting concept, good to see thinking about the global picture, Amnesty would not publish information that had not been verfied but I really like the concept of alerts indicating if a person or indeed a situation has not been updated or if emergency action was needed and allowing participation to be global is also great. thank you !
dear sara thanks for your kindly comment

Hi Amin, interesting thinking & great opening provocation. Anonymity can be a key issue for detainees, as we mentioned here: http://bit.ly/amnesty_guide You might want to think about how to adapt this concept with this in mind. Looking forward to developments & discussion here.

Dear Meena Thanks for your post, I agree with you. There is a subtle point here, Denying detention especially when you talk about prisoners of conscience and social activists is always governments strategy to buying more time and escaping their responsibility about detainees , and at the same time considering the structure of Amnesty, the only means they have to force some changes is awareness.  Im absolutely with you that for sure there is some cases that should be promote under anonymity condition. These may be some related suggestion: First of all the whole data bases should be built up by official Amnesty observers who can evaluate condition on each case. Secondly, you can limit the site users to Amnesty members who are almost 3,000,000, although this strategy could diminish its effectiveness and appealing more contribution.

amnesty_interactive_map.title: Amnesty interactive map

find_me_.description:
Upon being detained, before all possessions are taken away, a person could push a button on their solar powered key chain item that will send their exact location to:
Amnesty International, and three emails (of family or friends) that were registered upon purchasing the item at any airport.
find_me_.creator: 5bb0d871c77245bc2a013fda7070c352

comments.text: Interesting Andy! You might like to check out our Tips on Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking devices could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

find_me_.title: FIND ME

america_s_most_wanted.description: A top 10 list of illegal detainees -- with short descriptions of their situations -- their portraits -- and links to help.  This graphic list could be packaged for rebroadcast, on websites, radio + tv, and college campuses.
america_s_most_wanted.creator: 12b9dacb49b9ae47466c07204f630baa

comments.text: Margaret, I like the idea of highlighting individual detainees; I think that makes the stories so much more personal.  The only concern I have is with the messaging of "America's Most Wanted".  All of us involved with the current design challenge have common ground: we all know that we are talking about people who are unlawfully detained.  But what about people who only have milliseconds to process the message of "America's Most Wanted"?  I just wonder if there could be some confusion for people who will not  [for whatever reason] have the time to figure out whether your top ten are criminals or not--particularly because they are actually in jail and presumably are alleged of some sort of "crime".

Loving your illustrations Margaret! We hope you'll be back tomorrow to re-post these in the soon to be launched Concepting phase where they'll get the attention they deserve. Till then we've got a few hours to go to collect examples of *existing* tools, campaigns, etc that will feed our idea-generation going forward. comments.text: I had an experiment in such situation, I was in Iran during green movement 2008~2009 and I saw how rumors works as a rousing means in an emerging social movement. Here I mention two aspects that rumors have had most of their prosperity in those fields: firstly, an indication that has a huge influence on common life such as earthquake or information that feeds common curiosity such as superstars. I reckon the first category work with tragic schemes so more tragic you find more penetration rate. Second category works with narrative structure, so as more people know about history and context of the information (that is the meaning of being well-known) it would attract more attention.

thanks Vincent. I'll have a look at the website.I guess my point was to see if we could learn about how to spread information, whether false or true. I just thought interesting how powerful rumors can be.

comments.text: It's great to see people who want to have the stories of detainees share. I think it's important that we all learn about what they went through in order to make a change. This concept would be a great gateway into making a real change in how detainees are treated!
This is great as Wikipedia is available in many languages, this could also be in different languages and also customized for that specific group of people
Yes, that's the thought, Tayfun!
Nice one Tayfun  great point about the ability to localise content.

Hi Fabio, I really like how you've included the idea of supporting people who are affected by illegal detention by giving them a platform to connect and share stories. My question, though, is about how a site like that could offer this kind of function anonymously? Obviously putting a name or face to a personal account will help guarantee validity of the story, but at the same time, it's possible that by publishing their own account of detention, a person might actually be putting himself or his family at greater risk. If you haven't already checked it out, here's a link to our Guiding Principles page http://bit.ly/riHUU2. We've written out some ideas about Ethics and Risk that might spark something for you on this topic.

Hello, Ashley. Thank you very much for your comment, that's in deed a well observed and important issue - how to maintain the information credibility without compromising one's safety? I guess we have some possibilities, at least to start on. To put a name and picture should be quite exposing, so one possibility is to use only the first name or just the initials along with a face blurred photo or something like that. Moreover, to increase the story validity, it's essential to have trusted 'Content gatherers', who can for example sign a story validation - without sharing any private information. Maybe there is a path  to start.

_201c_wikiam_201d_the_wiki_amnesty.title: “WikiAm” - The Wiki Amnesty

Great! this could be made like a series of "cards", one for each nation/region.To know exactly what you are entitled to, and what your rights/obligations are before you expose yourself to the risk of being detained is one big step on becoming prepared.Because in some countries you have the right to remain silent, and not interrogated at all, until you get to see a lawyer or interpreter. comments.text: Nice one Francisca! I like how you've considered something that pulls various channels together like Flipboard http://flipboard.com/  The great thing about Flipboard is that it requires minimal input as it's based on pulling RSS feeds together which automate content aggregation. Though I wonder how popular Flipboard is globally? Are there other platforms like this which are becoming popular to aggregate content? Also interesting to see the way that Tumblr has mobilised conversations around Occupy Wall St. Are there learnings from there which can be drawn upon? Looking forward to onwards discussion from others on this great start you've made.

Nice concept Francisca. Meena I think you touched on a cool 2.0 version. A citizen journalism/human rights news aggregator. There are lots of automated web scrubbing applications out there. Why not launch one down that path?
Feel free to go for a whole new build, Jason. As always, looking forward to your illustrations ; )

Nice Meena! I really like the idea of a news aggregator in the vein of Flipboard for different types of media from different sources. Another one that comes to mind, is Storify (http://www.storify.com), however that's more of a tool for curation rather than more automated aggregation. Clarence House has been using it for Prince Charles' recent trip to Africa (http://storify.com/clarencehouse/day-5-tour-blog).

Hi Francisca, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know if you face any problems. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

Absolutely! I added some screenshots of the Amenesty International's Twitter feed as seen via Flipboard. I think Meena hit on a great idea of aggregating news (videos, tweets, photos, stories, etc) that's already out there. Flipboard could be just one way to aggregate and display it...

the_dharma_initiative_pattern_disruption.description: In the show "Lost" a computer required a code to be entered every 108 minutes otherwise an alarm would sound.
the_dharma_initiative_pattern_disruption.creator: a2e8d29c589841d09478b740b367aceb

comments.text: This is really great idea for various reasons: It can make the close ones of the detained person aware of the person's well being, it will push the security forces not to treat bad the detained person. Of course, these are all assuming that the code (it could be a finger print detector which detects a live finger to ensure that the person is alive) is not somehow mimicked. Great going!

Thanks, Tayfun.Initially I was thinking this could be a daily or weekly procedure of someone at home (for those most at risk for being detained) since sometimes they are taken without the knowledge of the community.  But actually having this system implemented in the prison/detention center is a great idea.  A person could even possibly write up a key to the code they would enter and give it to trusted family/UN before being detained.  If a disruption is detected, someone from Amnesty International or similar could be allowed to inspect the situation.

I think the first portion of the idea is also great because people can be taken one person at a time and that may not be noticed (could be considered individual event) but such system can show any pattern that looks suspicious

Hi Sharon, welcome to OpenIDEO, and thanks for bringing in 'Lost'  I love that show! Funny enough, your inspiration made me think of a family member of mine who lives alone and who sends a text message to her close relatives every morning. It doesn't have a message in it  it's just meant to be a confirmation that she's ok. I actually hadn't connected with that as a relevant inspiration until reading your post. Looking forward to seeing more of you in this challenge!

Hi Ashley, thanks, very happy to join into the conversation!  IDEO and what it represents has played a very large part in my life and I'm very happy that a platform like this exists to be able to contribute.  I do think in an instance as this a non-communication could be more relevant than a communication.  We tend to notice what is there faster than what is not, so if we have a clear system that detects what is missing then we may more quickly detect a person under duress.

Yep, that's a great point. The tough thing about my family member who texts is that her messages have become so routine that I almost don't notice them anymore. This could mean that if she ever fails to send a text, I might not interpret the silence as an emergency but rather a non-event that goes unnoticed. Something to think about as we head into Concepting :)

I still remember this wall where they were describing in excruciating details and illustrations torturing techniques. It made me cry and sick in my stomach, for the first time in my life I felt utterly disgusted by what "human" beings are capable of.

humanity_care_package..description: Playing on any existing human sympathies of the catpors of unlawfully detained prisoners to prevent dehumanization and rivalries among detainees that spring up due to poor conditions and ill treatment will help to keep prisoners strong throughout thier detainment and to better reassimilate into the outside world if released.
humanity_care_package..creator: 5cb10199a9320c90d14e546efb59f2bc

comments.text: Hello,I really like the basic notion of this concept.  I think that if someone were being unlawfully detained, receiving a care package like this would provide a huge emotional lift.The question that I have about this concept is similar but different to the one A-L raised below.  In your answer to her post, you talk about the challenge of, "getting [the packages] to hidden locations, prisons, and camps of unlawfully detained."  Even if you could find a way to get the care packages there, I'm wondering how you will get the detainers to give the packages to their prisoners, rather than keep the packages for themselves.  I know that this is something of a common phenomena with aid shipments, i.e.:http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/feb/06/gaza-un-aid-hamasamong other examples.  If you could find a way around this challenge, I think this would be a fabulous concept!  Unfortunately, I'm not entirely sure how to help you solve it...  Do you have any thoughts on how this might be addressed?
I've added a few things into my concept that might being to address these concerns, if you;d like to take a look, and give any feed back, we;d really appreciate it!

Hi Kathryn,I checked out what you have added to your concept and I love the segment about sending something for the guards as well as the prisoners.  You may be right in that giving something to the guards themselves may make them more empathetic to the prisoners.  At the very least, maybe if they have been given already the packages that are being sent to the prisoners, maybe they will be less likely to steal the prisoners' packages for themselves.  Good thinking with this addition! :-)

Hi, I like the way you are thinking of the detainees and take into account the importance of providing food for thought. I guess your point about making sure that the guards allow the prisoners to keep the packages is important. I can see how your concept could complement Festus' shelter and food concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/food-shelter-clothing/There might also be other ways to connect your concept with other concepts... Here are a few thoughts and questions: Maybe you want to think about what would exactly be in these packages; How you would send them? through NGOs?;  and how you would get the items to put in the package? (will people give the items or would you ask for money and then put together the packages)?

My team and I met and have gone over some things to help answer these questions:1. Contents of the packages might include:Novels, books, literature of some sort, and perhaps a flashlight or booklightWriting and drawing supplies (pencils, paper, pens, erasers)Small hygiene products (toothbrush, toothpaste, etc; little things that might help  prisoners to have a sense of normalcy and preserve self worth)Radios or music players of some sortIf possible, water or small food items, candy, or vitamins.Letters and pictures from volunteers or families of other prisoners to help createcommunication between the prisoners and the outside world, to give them hope and support and to prevent a loss of empathy and human contact.These contents are not meant to help the prisoners escape or to try and combat the harsh conditions of unlawful detainment, but to help them retain a sense of self, empathy, humanity, and communication with the outside world in order to preserve hope and encourage more just and humane living conditions. We hope that if these packages are consciously allowed and distributed to prisoners by guards or other inside captors that this will also create a dialogue of humanity and empathy between the prisoners and captors, and ultimately relieve the situation of some of its injustice. 2. the contents of these packages might come from:Donations from families that have been affected by kidnapping or other forms of unlawful detainment (this also helps to make families feel empowered and to keep communication up between prisoners and families)Donations from churches, schools, non-profit organizations, volunteer groups, etcSurplus goods/ left over / overstock items3. Distribution:How to get these packages to the prisoners is a harder question to answer, and obviously an important one to answer. Getting these packages to prisons is one thing, but getting them to hidden locations, prisons, and camps of unlawfully detained is another. We hope that since the packages are non-threatening to the captors that we might be able to rely somewhat on inside help in conjunction with volunteers from enthusiast groups, but really, we havent had much luck figuring out the specifics yet.So, were asking for help! Any ideas regarding any of this are encouraged and appreciated!-Kathryn Shriver, Juli Vibbard, Evando Nascimiento, and Kenny Sharpe of the Wells College Innovation Lab

Hi, thanks for thinking through these various points. I think it helps thinking of how your concept could be implemented.I unfortunately am not sure about the channels of delivery. It might be worth researching what is already existing today. I also would like to stress the fact (that Amanda also pointed in her comment) that you also have to trust the guards to give the packages to the prisoners.

the_infamous_guantanamo_bay.creator: 6448e86d7837e2feb55834a2b2581d66

comments.text: Hi Alex, welcome to OpenIDEO! You've raised some really insightful questions here, particularly around exploring power and how a sense of power/control can lead a person to act in ways that wouldn't be morally or socially acceptable in most cases. I also think you've hit the nail on the head when it comes to these issues being relevant both "at home" and abroad. I believe someone's mentioned it already, but if you haven't checked out Philip Zimbardo's famous Prison Experiment, it's worth looking into http://www.prisonexp.org/.

Of course the Stanford Prison experiment, I remember reading about that not so long ago, it just goes to show that power can go to anybodies head regardless of their background and they can act out of character.

Hi Alex, welcome indeed.Thanks for your post. The Zimbardo experiment also shows the importance of context and roles in "shaping" behaviors. In his experiment, roles and the attributes or artifacts linked to them were key. From the start, you were defined as a prisoner or as a guard, and very quickly (in a day or two) people started acted as a prisoner or a guard. In fact, Zimbardo has written articles linking his experiment to real case studies (prisons in the US) and also cases of prisoners in Iraq http://www.prisonexp.org/links.htm#iraqYou might also want to check the video posted by Dwight: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/examine-your-own-world-then-give-it-a-voice./

Hi all,There is a bugs bunny cartoon which actually shows how people react based on their dress (or role in the society), it is funny and also thought provoking. Going back to Ashley's last post, this cartoon is for empathy reasons but I don't have a quite clear answer how to change the code (i.e. impact behavior) but I think it is a start. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vZlyVVKW-24

That Bugs Bunny episode was spot on about uniform (or hats), there was an article or program (can't remember which) which went to show how people will be more compliant to someone dressed in a certain way, and one of the uniforms were hi-vis jackets. It made the point that they could be bought anywhere for less than a pound but made you look more official. They asked people to move from the pavement with and without the jacket and noticed a big difference to the amount of people who moved without question with the jacket on.

the_infamous_guantanamo_bay.title: The Infamous Guantanamo Bay

You can read more here: http://bit.ly/amnesty_guide Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

You're right. I might have been too solution-focused. However, I do feel, there should be a place to aggregate information to provide better help. Maybe input via digital channels in addition to others is the way to go, but collection in a safe place with an erasable memory, if necessary. I am going to look into the other suggestions for further inspiration.

Great idea Manjul! I especially like how you've focused on the community surrounding the person who's been detained. Definitely an important consideration as we design concepts for the entire Eco-System (and check http://bit.ly/nVK3C4 for more on that!)

Thanks for the comment. The eco system of support is such a nice visual depiction of the impact of unlawful detention and the support available. _virus_.creator: a93a599da7413258f509b7c0f78d9e9a

comments.text: Great link Tiago. I can imagine several of these technologies being used in the concept phase. Some specific examples I found were:AirMobs - http://viral.media.mit.edu/#3358 - This technology would allow for device and carrier independent communication in dead zones, addressing the powerlessness mentioned by Anna in http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/grand-central-whispering-gallery-/Geo.gy - http://viral.media.mit.edu/#3331 - A technology essentially for creating bit.lys for locations. I can imaging dropping a geo.gy as an alert that you've been detained in a certain location. Also reminded me of Flarecaster http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/flarecaster/Reach - http://viral.media.mit.edu/#3142 - allows users to broadcast requests or services in a geographic location. This reminded me of Haiyan's comment on http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/fleeing-the-policeand in this case users in distress could broadcast the need for a translator or perhaps legal advice.I think these could all be broken out as individual Tools of Support. I'll go ahead and create one for Reach and just link back here.Good find!

Hi Jason. Thanks for your comment and further investigation on the link. It's definitely a good resource with great projects. The AirMobs, somehow makes me reminding of the "Batman 2" (latest one) when we creates a sonar system by connecting all the cell phones to trace the "joker". :)

Fab follow-up Jason... indeed these would make really great separate Inspirations so that they get the exposure they need for this challenge. Certainly good fodder for the upcoming Concepting phase. Cheers for sharing, Tiago.
Thanks Meena! I'll go ahead and break the other two out so they don't get lost. Looking forward to the Concepting phase!

_virus_.title: "virus"

decentralized_networks_with_diaspora.description: Diaspora is a software project from NYU which takes into account personal privacy in the design of a social network. This social network securely stores your information, photos, friends. The network is distributed rather than stored in one place.
decentralized_networks_with_diaspora.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: Thanks Haiyan! This is a great inspiration. Diaspora has the potential not only to enhance the security of privacy, but also make it possible for individual (for example the human rights activists in China) to take control of the timing and direction of when and where the critical information should be spread. This project should definietly be revisited by the community when the concepting phase starts.

Nice insight Haiyan! Had heard of Diaspora, but never drew the connection between its decentralized approach, the potential for this to support secure social networking privacy, and the implications in restrictive regimes.
Thanks Haiyan for sharing. I agree with you that it opens up routes on how to develop networks that still maintain privacy.  Something to keep in mind when it comes to the concepting phase. al

decentralized_networks_with_diaspora.title: Decentralized networks with Diaspora

mobile_letter_writing_workshops.description: Letters are a concrete, powerful, and 'official' means of communication. Writing a letter means serious business. Not to mention, it's low-tech. Mobile letter-writing workshops strive to: (1) provide information (cases to write about, whom to write to, points to address, and other letter-writing tips); (2) provide materials (stationery, stamps); (3) offer "scribe" services such as speech-to-text translations and letter-writing guidance; and (4) promote letter-writing as someone everyone can partake in.
mobile_letter_writing_workshops.creator: 59f5c563832e7d355b411c52f49bc449

comments.text: This idea is really interesting.Letter Writing and books are becoming obsolete with latest technologies taking over.I think it would be great to bring them back in all the small ways we can.

Hi Yen,I love the idea and it'll be a great service to offer in the Shift van. In fact, I thought of the possibility of helping people to post on some of the online platform but letter writing is a great idea. Providing training, workshop as well as just  a "scribe" service. I agree with you that letter writing can be extremely powerful. In fact writing is "close to my heart": with one of my friends and colleagues, we've been doing research for several years on writing  and analyzing historical correspondences (we're currently working on a book). Hence, I'm particularly convinced of the power of writing, and of letter writing in particular, to allow people to express / voice out their concerns. The voice letters could be related to "my voice": http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/my-voice/As for Dragon, based on the experience of one of my students, it requires quite some training for it to be efficient. I think that having the service offered of writing / typing letters (by the people traveling with the van) and a recording device (like the question box) could already be quite efficient.The inspiration you were looking for in your virtual team: is the SACK team: http://www.openideo.com/profiles/innovators/ and their concept is http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/thinktanks/ Last I agree with Meena regarding the power of your scenario...thanks

Hi A-L,That's too bad about Dragon. A typing/writing service would definitely work and is even more low-tech. I also wonder if citizens would be willing to volunteer along with Amnesty staff to help with letter-writing (in low-risk scenarios).... just a thought after reading Amanda's MY VOICE concept. I really like the idea of building a community where individuals voice(/write) for others and by doing so become advocates themselves. In this case, if the advocate is part of the community and permanently there (vs. moving Shift Van), there's potential for long-term relationships. Just letting my brain wander a bit here, but maybe it'll go somewhere nice...Good luck with your book! I hope I'll be able to see it when it comes out.

Hi Yen,I think you could definitely think of reviving the scribe office (I remember reading an article in the NY times about how the job of scribes was dying because of cell phones... maybe here  you are offering an opportunity to revive it :-)...) and have a permanent location... In my idea of the van, I thought mobility allowed us to touch more locations but the idea was that it would be quite local and will come often (maybe once a week) and thus allow some relationship. The only thing about the local office is that it depends on the political situation as you don't want this office to be a risky place to go. I'm thinking of the black jail issue described by Vincent when people go to the petitioning center: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/improving-petitioning-through-technology-fighting-black-jails-/As for the book, we're getting there. I'd definitely let you know when it's out.

Nice concept. I think the written word is more powerful in many cases because it has a deeper emotional effect once you read several times the message. An also is really useful in low-tech situations. ;)

Luz, I agree on the emotional effect of letter writing. It is true not only for the recipient who can read the letter several times, but also for the writer who can take the time to think and express her emotions, often time being able to develop them deeper than orally.
Hey Luz  great to have you back! Yen ... you can read more about Luz on our feature here: http://ted.openideo.com/fieldnotes/openideo-team-notes/openideator-insight-luz-alba-gallo-
Thanks Meena ;) I hope I can make some time to come up with a concept :)

Great thinking, Yen! I could really engage with your idea via the scenario you outlined. And I think the Shift Van concept could be linked up to this one: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-iii-shift-van-/ Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add that post to your Build Upon feature. This will signal that there's a connection between these ideas. Also the person who wrote it will get an email notification and is likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)
Ahhhh yes, how could I have missed linking to the van? Thanks!
Great to see how it's brought A-L into the conversation. She's such a great collaborator, I knew she'd be over here in a flash via a Build Upon notification!

thanks Meena although I have to tell you that I did not come through the build upon button:-) I did not get a notification for this one but I noticed your comment and Yen's comments in the activity feed ... letter writing was the trigger this time. :-)Still I agree, building upon concepts is key to start collaboration.

a_diagnosis_of_a_life_threatening_diseas.description: Luckily this is not a personal story, but having spoken to people who have been diagnosed with life-threatening diseases (like cancer, strokes, heart attacks), there is a sudden feeling of being thrown into a world you don't know anything about.
a_diagnosis_of_a_life_threatening_diseas.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Honored to be today's featured inspiration. Very topical. In another discussion around healthcare at the office today, we talked about the overwhelming what an emotional journey a life-threatening illness can be. Sometimes you want to reach out to people, other times you want to retreat. I've seen folks use simple language to communicate to others - "today's a day I want to talk about it." "Today's not a day to talk about it." Then loved ones can know how to behave. Another great idea is this book "what can I do to help?" which helps patients tell people how to help them - generally the most helpful thing is doing small, practical things for people - not big enough that they feel in debt to you, but helpful.
Ahhh  those are also great insights for our exploration here Amy!

Amy, thanks for these insights. Indeed life-threatening illnesses are a perfect example of powerlessness. Like you, luckily, I haven't experienced this but have examples around, or I've been told stories.I think your point about how people might sometimes want to talk, at other moments don't want to talk is very insightful and has implications about finding the right balance between supporting and overwhelming, making available but not mandatory.... It is also about finding ways to signal and communicate between the person who needs support and others... Also, I agree that in general (and in particular in these stressful, difficult situations), small things - it can just be  a smile - matter. Last, and this is from personal experience (I was not the one who had the disease though), I realized that in situations where you learn about a disease, often you feel powerless and part of it, is that you don't understand what it really means, what are the risks, implications, and the lingo itself sounds scary. A friend of mine suggested taking a notebook and writing down what the doctors say and then go and some research, and then in the next discussion use some of their vocabulary, but also go back to your notes and ask specific questions. It does dramatically change the relationship as you become a member in the conversation, and you also feel like you are active and engaged. Hence providing a road map and a lexicon would be important to understand, but also to allow people get engaged (or even, just feel engaged)sorry this long comment. Thanks again for sharing these insights which, I agree Meena, are going to be useful in the concepting phase.al
Really great insights from an analogous context, Amy. Cheers for sharing this with suggestions of ways to address the pain-points.

Thanks for sharing this story Amy. From what you've written, I think much of it comes down to translation and communication as keys to restoring power and control during a crisis. Definitely something to keep considering throughout our challenge!

That's very nice Amy, and this lingo, navigator and map would be just as useful to the friends and families of who has been unlawfully detained. They are the ones left behind, operating with (more) freedom and probably knowing even less about the causes of detention and what to do in case of emergency.

a_diagnosis_of_a_life_threatening_diseas.title: A diagnosis of a life-threatening disease

demonstrate_the_strength_in_numbers_the_.description: Whether it is Gandhi's Civil Disobedience movement or the Arab Spring, the strength & effectiveness of the movement in combating human rights violation is based on the size of the people network. And the size of the network has to be demonstrated to the ruling power clearly in order to make the voices heard. Amnesty International could create a social App (Facebook App or based on Twitter, Google+, Orkut, etc) that automatically creates a detailed "People Power Report" for the specific cause (about the illegal detainee in this case). The "People Power Report" should beyond "10,000 people like this" and show detailed people network beyond the cause and a direct relative/friend or supporter of the detained person can use this to intimidate the human rights violators to release them.
demonstrate_the_strength_in_numbers_the_.creator: fe062572c347f693ac1cd073be4c8610

comments.text: Great thinking, Navaneethan! Liking how you're suggesting to leverage existing technology here  rather than attempting to reinvent the wheel.

Hmm...quite interesting Navaneethan! Thoughtful incorporation of social media & visualization could potentially increasing the effectiveness & power of petitions.One concern will be how to handle privacy/security in cases where oppressors (government, criminals, etc.) use social media information to target people.

demonstrate_the_strength_in_numbers_the_.title: Demonstrate the strength in numbers with an App (the power of the people network/social graph)

amnesty_international_kiosks.description: The Amnesty International Kiosk, located in cities around the world, share vital information with the public, many of who may not be aware of the situation with unlawful abductions throughout our world and how they can help. These kiosks share stories about unlawful abductions, success stories about people reunited with their families, the efforts of Amnesty International in righting these wrongs and preventing future abductions and imprisonments, and ways they can get involved to make a difference.
amnesty_international_kiosks.creator: 407a44fcdb9051e33802cfcbdb33c950

comments.text: Interesting concept Patricia. It could be a nice complement, something like an urban version of Ana's vending machine:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-international-vending-machine-info-hub/I agree that providing access through these kiosks in parallel with the events you mentioned could be powerful.I guess the question is what kind of information are you providing and how do you trigger people to stop and look.I can also see it connected with concepts such as:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/world-s-largest-3d-led-cube.-inspiring-awareness-by-combining-information-art-and-design/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/an-interactive-infographic-platform-fueled-by-the-whole-network-of-supporters/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/my-voice/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/sonic-planet-the-voices-of-the-unheards/these are only a few but there are a couple of other concepts (which you'll find referred to in the concepts above) which explore presentation of stories, information and data.
another concept that could also be interesting to build upon: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-power-of-media/

Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add these posts to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote the posts will get an email notification and are likely to come and join the great conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)

amnesty_international_kiosks.title: Amnesty International Kiosks

giant_rats_sniff_out_landmines_and_tuber.description: Across the world, African giant-pouched rats are replacing dogs as man’s best friend. For 15 years, Tanzania-based nonprofit APOPO has trained rats to sniff out hidden land mines or life-threatening tuberculosis.
giant_rats_sniff_out_landmines_and_tuber.creator: 4f99ee8ac0164235851400715e962db2

comments.text: Hi Roger, welcome to OpenIDEO! What I love about your inspiration is that it stretches our definition of "technology solutions". We know that the goal of our challenge is to find opportunities to use technology to support unlawful detention, but in reality, technology can mean lots of different things  mobile apps, tools, social media campaigns, and even rats! :)
Thank you Ashley! :)

giant_rats_sniff_out_landmines_and_tuber.title: Giant rats sniff out landmines, and Tuberculosis, could they sniff out unlawful detention?

geo.gy_bit.lys_for_locations_.description: Yet another cool technology from the Viral Spaces Lab, geo.gy is a location shortener service that allows users to share their locations with a "geolink" or short URL.
geo.gy_bit.lys_for_locations_.creator: 2935218c6249f6d941ddaac700aa391d

comments.text: Very handy for many contexts, Jason   including those of crisis & disaster.

geo.gy_bit.lys_for_locations_.title: geo.gy - bit.lys for locations

guardian_network.description:
An online platform that matches people at risk of being detained with peers all over the world who are able to trigger appropriate actions when they stop receiving "I'm fine" notifications from that person. Advantages of such direct person to person links would be: 
a) guardians are involved over a longer period of time and are therefore familiar with the context and risks of the person concerned, b) the person at risk has a real, personal social peer which might make for extra emotional support when anonymity and being forgotten is the biggest fear c) it does not rely on a stress signal being sent which might be impossible
and d) any means of communications (twitter/email/sms...) could be possible, depending of the case
guardian_network.creator: f35e128f5e95602abcd3f3c964c96fc1

comments.text: I am new to this site and glad I found it. I like this idea because I just completed a crowdmap to log incidents of Migrant domestic workers in the Middle East. I can see this feature being used to rescue abused workers if we can get the employment agency and the migrant country government's made it a requirement . Please see how bad things are here https://domestichelpabuse.crowdmap.com - to many life's are being lost

I agree that this concept has a lot of promise. I think having the guardian status public would also help create awareness about how many at-risk individuals are currently being prosecuted, held against their will, etc. A public forum with 1on1 guardians.

I'm thrilled how the Guardian concept focuses on building support, community, and connection in advance of any danger. In the best case scenario those at risk not only stay safe but expand their cause through the process. While private connections to guardians will be valuable, a platform for the public amalgamation of support may deter potential threat or encourage resolution. The concept could also benefit many other at-risk groups.

Interesting. I feel their is a lot of potential in a guardianship. Much like a mentor, a person has someone else they can connect with about how they are dealing with the situation. I do think it could be valuable to match people with others who have had some experience in the situation. Also a component of this could be the initial "campaign" of letting people know the site exists. Wonder if there are low-risk ways of getting the word out, maybe something like the street play concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/street-plays-a-video-tool-kit-for-unlawful-detention/) from The Disrupters.  This also reminds me a bit of http://www.patientslikeme.com/ connecting people with different health issues. The similarity lies in a balance of what information one would be willing to display publicly or privately as well as finding others with common ground.
Nice concept. I really loved the part in wich you say that people feel more emotionally attached to little things, in that way you can make people thing in a deeper way about this subject.
Am always a fan of concepts which leverage P2P goodness!
This idea is very similar to Brian Kelly's "Mobile Angels" http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/mobile-angels/
Yes, thanks, I somehow managed to miss this - very nice concept. I think at its core it is a very similar idea.

I love that it's the absence of an OK rather than a distress signal that fuels this concept. That's very important and really the only effective way I've seen to do it. My only concern is the safety of the guardians. Anything that relies on the internet i feel doesn't have a lot of potential for anonymity. Ways to keep them safe?-Kathryn, Wells College Innovation Lab

Thanks Kathryn, I agree that such a platform wouldn't be able to guarantee the anonymity of the guardians, but I wouldn't think they are at great risk. Say 5 to 10 people around the world are the guardians of a human rights activist in Yemen and monitor his wellbeing (and maybe the wellbeing of all the other guardians). Maybe I am misjudging the risks, but I cannot see how the Yemeni secret police could threaten someone in, lets say Austria not to act on a missing OK message. Things obviously change as soon support on the ground would become required...

Facebook is working on a "guardian" system for password recovery currently, you will have 5 friends you name as "guardians", and you need 3 out of 5 to reset your password for you. This could be an extended part of their "guardian" system where if your "guardians" have not heard from you collectively after a certain number of hours, they can start a search for you or alert family members who can.

guardian_network.title: Guardian network

amber_alerts_and_information_sharing.description: The Amber Alert program is a partnership between law enforcement, transportation officials, and broadcasters to share urgent information relating to child abductions. It's an interesting example of using technology to spread news + updates.
amber_alerts_and_information_sharing.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: I just logged on to add an inspiration centered around AMBER Alerts, so glad to see it already on here. Elementary School administrators and teachers utilize this system extremely well, I like the idea of targeting key stakeholders/leaders in the public and then leveraging them to get the word out.
Great minds think alike I guess :)

Hi Ashley, this is a great discussion, and it immediately reminds me of this inspiration and TED talk: "Using Art to Turn the World Around" - (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/using-art-to-turn-the-world-around-/) The power of combining 'digital' bulletins with 'analogue' ones:  through spreading messages in cities around the world on physical landmarks, which of course can propagate the digital disperse of them by taking pictures with smart phones and sharing the messages on social media networks etc etc. I think it's an interesting thread to follow. Amber Alert seems very helpful, but where I live atm - Stockholm - there isn't ANY outdoor billboard/advertising, its generally really clean (there is a law prohibiting it) and I don't drive here, so I wouldn't encounter this kind of signage on my everyday life, but im quite active online so maybe I would through sharing the messages digitally.

This is very interesting Ana Cecilia. I know Amber Alerts also use text messages and I think also email to spread their updates, but I've always found the billboards to be the most useful. Why? Because often the alerts on the signs describe a car's make, model and license so that other drivers can be on the lookout for what is presumably the abductor's car. It's a nice alignment of message and opportunity  I'm in my car, surrounded by other drivers, and have tons of potential chances to find the car mentioned in the alert. I wonder how we can learn from this to help us in our Concepting efforts?
Great idea, allows the public to no what is going on right away.
Big signs like this will definitely help get people's attention. This way, people will be more alert to what is going on around them and they are more likely to help.
Nice connection of Amber Alerts with phone trees, Ashley. You've got me thinking...=)

amber_alerts_and_information_sharing.title: Amber Alerts and Information Sharing

off_site_control_center.description: Off-site control centers can help to prevent unlawful police behavior, protect human rights and to inform the families of the detained.
off_site_control_center.creator: 5cb10199a9320c90d14e546efb59f2bc

comments.text: Nice concept. Especially in high-risk situations, this could be very helpful. Maybe with gps tracking devices for people taking part in the demonstrations.

Ah, GPS technology would be an excellent resource for this project, especially if we could find a way to utilize it that was not cumbersome or depended on short battery life. Thanks for the contribution!

Hi Kathryn, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know if you face any problems. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

off_site_control_center.title: Off-site Control Center
