automated_celestial_navigation_smartphon.description: Celestial navigation was and still is used for geolocation when GPS is unavailable. Similarly, smartphones could be equipped with an app that functions in much the same way, transmitting coordinates upon emergency.
automated_celestial_navigation_smartphon.creator: 5ca71e90ad09bc898e692ccfd9430542

comments.text: Such an interesting provocation here Jared! And way to go using the 'Build Upon' feature to highlight the work of others as well. Definitely an interesting idea to consider as we start thinking about concepts in a couple of weeks.

automated_celestial_navigation_smartphon.title: Automated Celestial Navigation Smartphone App

who_are_the_individuals_frequently_respo.description: In countries where it's clear that police officers and government officials are performing illegal arrests & detentions, tracking these individuals is arguably as important as tracking the victims themselves.
who_are_the_individuals_frequently_respo.creator: 7da92725a3ac352f038bf4b1855bdd69

comments.text: This is really great John. I really like the idea because I have been always thinking how to track the potential victims and not the potential perpetrators.The major issue was the vast scale of potential victims. Well there are many of them while there are fewer officers, so it is LOT easier to follow the officers.  If we can track the officers, we will now where they are and they will know that the Big Brothers know where they are! Not only they will act cautiously, they also cannot close their eyes when someone else behaves in certain way because we will know that they were there. Another point is the beauty of not tracking individuals. Sure, we are proposing surveillance for each individual for the sake of unlawful detention but how will we know that such surveillance won't be used for something else in the future. In the case of tracking of officers, that could be part of the job, when one leaves the job, tracking is over. One more comment from a technical perspective: besides GPS (which doesn't work well within buildings) there are other tracking tools, which are actually used in shopping, that could tell where the people have been. Thanks John again for the great inspiration.
Thanks for the support Tayfun! I've just put a little more structure around the idea with this post: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-anti-solcial-network/

who_are_the_individuals_frequently_respo.title: Who are the individuals frequently responsible for human rights violations?

check_in_updates.description: A system for political activists & people that are at risk of unlawful arrest that triggers an alert when someone doesn't check into it. An alert is sent to Amnesty international / Family / Friends.
check_in_updates.creator: 0dd6bf6a3381f25d629dcf94d5673072

comments.text: I love this concept; my question is around the ability to gain access to service in areas where kidnapping or detaining is likely.  Are there any services that allow for access to (even if it was a separate and greater charge similar to roaming) call/text/check-in, in these areas.
Thanks Jason, that is a great question. I wonder if Amnesty International can afford a satellite? ;-) Cheers!

I really like this idea. It would be a great way to keep in touch with people when they are heading to a protest. Could there be a way to inform them when a spot changes (especially when considering potential dangers)?
Thanks Emily, it will be interesting to see where this could go when built on. Cheers!

This idea covers many parts of the issue! Very nice. In response to the critiques of the activist then being constantly tracked..and that being intercepted by an oppressing force. - The unit would only need to broadcast information once, when the "necklace" is broken. That being the most important check-in. The last check-in.
Great insight Charlie, thanks for the feedback!

i really like charlies idea of the broken necklace. people in prisons have to hand off wirstwatches, necklaces etc. make these devices work as "secret" electronic tags and they will send a signal if not taken off in a special way.

Really interesting idea Shawn! Definitely something to hold on to as we move into Concepting in a couple of weeks  I bet this is something that the community would love to work with you on! In the meantime, I wonder if it's worth exploring what other mobile tools currently enable people to check in (Yelp, Foursquare etc). What might we learn from those existing examples?
Thanks Ashley, I did think I was getting a little ahead of myslef but wanted to make sure the idea got out there. I'm going to do a little digging into check-in systems we may not have heard of.
No worries - it's easy to get excited early on with ideas! And clearly the community is enjoying this too :) Can't wait to see what it becomes as a concept....

Hi Shawn,Really nice and simple thinking. You mentioned further down a bracelet or such with GPS being triggered when the person isn't checking in, and i think this part of your idea is quite necessary, because not only is it important to know that something is wrong, but  is also important to know what is wrong. i think It would be otherwise  hard for Amnesty to act without really knowing or getting some sort of indication that something illegal has happened to the person. Great work! Yass

Thanks Yass! I do agree that the GPS would be important, but I don't think it is necessary. I think about Ai Weiwei being detained, I'm sure those who arrested him have very sophisticated methods for detecting some kind of signal. Having a device on one's person may even provoke a negative response from a captor... Cheers!
Hi Shawn,Yeah, you're absolutely right. it can potentially make a bad situation worse.

Hi Shawn,like all the other comments I like the idea. I also like the idea that the silence could be the signal... indeed as some mentioned very much into the spy mode. Another old version would be you send a pigeon (with no written message) a day (I recently watched again Azur and Asmar, a children animation movie, and that's what the mother asked the 2 boys to do while they go on an adventure :-) ) to let her know that things are OK. The medical monitoring devices seem indeed an interesting route.Regarding the privacy issue, I can see the issue as I'm not a 4 squares kind of person, and maybe if you're a political activist, you don't want to localize yourself. However, there might be a way to just send a signal (like the pigeon, or the postcard, or even the simple codes that people used to do when traveling and not having enough money to call you will use a pre-arranged code (ring 3 times) to let your family that you were fine (it seems that similar codes are used in low developing countries: http://www.infodesign.com.au/uxpod/inteloutside).One might argue that it is always people to find out where you are, but then, there is no real solution.As Ashley says, I can see this developing in a nice concept.thanks for sharing,al

Hi Al, the pigions are a great idea! The privacy issue is important also, I think it really depends on the individual case and what is important to the person checking in... some people probably accept that they are being monitored all the time and it's more important to be able to broadcast their well being? Thanks for the comment!Shawn

Hi Shawn, I completely agree on the individual differences when it comes to privacy. And indeed some people, quite a lot in fact, don't mind being monitored all the time. And to a certain extent, we are all monitored.My point was more a reflection on others' comments. Maybe this is an option to think of in the concepting phase. al

This is an excellent idea. I think it could be expanded/augmented to address another problem that is vexing about unlawful detention. Amnesty International is all about shining a light on these situations. The problem is that people in places like the US, just generally don't "get" what's going on, at a systemic level OR an individual level. I think rapid publicizing of detention is important. The sooner more people know, the better. And, the more people know about the person(s) being detained, the better. Of course, there are issues of privacy--the more we know, the more "they" know. Anyways... good idea.
Thanks Clark!

I think, the likeability of this prod depends on the connection for alerting. ex. I will never own a car w/on-star, for I feel I am being watched. If u r an activist, then could u be traced eventually, and interrupted? It might work against you; maybe. Now for the sportsperson - this is great! If I want to burn a gm food crop - maybe not so good, as long as the system works indep. Food 4 Thought
I really like this idea, I was trying to think of some way to notify that someone has been imprisoned, and this seems like the best way.

I just posted about the Spot GPS, but I like that your idea doesn't require the person being detained to have anything with them. It's more like the original flight plan idea, and your teenager check-in, where it's just about the potential plan, and then a lack of follow-up. That way, people also would know where you might have been seen last. The trigger from lack of response seems really feasible in this situation.

Thanks Alix, I've been thinking about the GPS also but wondering about how these wouldn't be detected. I've started thinking about all those weird implants in people on the X-Files, but it's getting a little too creepy for me!

This could possibly be spun-off and used also for mountain climbers, kajaking vacations ? make it possible to set up an itinerary and schedule on when the user is planning to be back, and it automatically alerts a couple of friends and family (on twitter or facebook) if not connecting within set time limits. This type of "casual & luxury use" could "pay for" the users that want the function for political/safety reasons.
Yeah! Like TOMS One for One for... discovery? life?
Nice! Maybe it could be combined with a bracelet / wearable GPS triggered when there is no check-in?

Old-school-versions of this was postcards, that you sent at the beginning of your trip out into the wilderness, and of course the reliability of your postal delivery service made it not fool-proof. But I am just saying, as low-tech- and low-cost- inspiration for developing this concept further in later stages.Perhaps there can be hidden some sort of pre-determined message or code words to use in "worst-case-scenarios" if you would need to send some message to your family but are under surveillance or suspect your phone is monitored. (now I am just brainstorming scenarios like in some Agent and Spy-movies)

If you're in trouble and can't check in, people are automatically alerted...brilliant idea Shawn!And great build Johan, to spin off a version for adventurers that could generate funds to support the human rights cause!

Shawn, another take on this would be something that sends out a signal on a regular basis and when the signal stops, it sets off the 'alert message'. Again, this could be tied into the discussion of the 'medical bracelet' where de-activating it by the wearer or removal by an authority could set off the trigger.

Great idea! As weird as it sounds, your comment made me think about the movie "Speed" and Dennis Hopper's character with all the crazy ways he has for triggering bombs. I'm sure if everyone trolled action movies and the SAW series of movies there are all kinds of crazy devises to get ideas from.

Hi Shawn! Great contribution!I was thinking about the same thing! How to get the "Somehing's wrong" reaction for the family and friends of people who are at risk of unlawful detention? "Something's wrong" is when it's too silent, too absent, too... We could trigger that with a missing light in a room, a sound, something, perceivable by a neighbor, family, etc. And when it's missing, they can call the police/Amnesty.
Thanks Sarah. Your comment made me think of this light that delivers ambient information: http://www.ambientdevices.com/cat/orb/orborder.html
That's interesting! Mmm... *me thinking*

check_in_updates.title: Check-in updates

creative_network_of_public_good.description: There have been many efforts to create advertising campaigns jointly by various advertising agencies, in order that communities are awareand react to events that are against human rights. It would beinteresting to create a network with the best copywriters in the world tocontribute ideas to generate targeted messages to different media,that create a chain reaction by placing the notice for violation of theserights.
creative_network_of_public_good.creator: 7527ba4be6afdb01a2cbc9be55f2d46b

comments.text: Hi Javier! How would this network come into play with Amnesty's existing campaigns and efforts? Are you envisioning a more global collaboration with other NGOs, International Organizations, etc.?

Hello, I imagine a creative network that responds to short-term events, ie if there is a kidnapping in Colombia, immediately enter the network to make a message that responds to that fact. Recycling is not the messages that already exist but to use the creative force and use it as an immediate response to events that violate human rights.To make this network work takes three main actors:1. The advertising crativos2. LOs communication meedios3 Organizations, NGOs, Government and so on.

creative_network_of_public_good.title: Creative network of public good

the_mobile_witness.description: So nowadays cell phone has become closest witness of anything may happen for us. Being arrested the first thing that always they detach from you is your cell phone.
the_mobile_witness.creator: 1c68bd27143c48545c24e9b2209f18af

comments.text: I really liked this picture concept! )))And also the idea. Thanks for inspiration!

Hey Amin, This is a great concept and and excellent conversation to follow.I am interested to see how it is further developed and would like to help by sharing a small story.A friend of mine recently got robbed off his cell phone in a dingy place in Queens, NY. Now when the thief managed to get away with this he tried to unlock the phone which was thankfully pass code locked. Now here is the interesting part. After several wrong attempts at unlocking the phone, the thief was unaware that these false attempts triggered an app which discreetly took his picture through the front camera and emailed it to the phone's owner (my friend). Now that my friend had the picture of the thief, he went to the police and by several means and efforts by the NYPD, the thief was actually captured in a week..! Now my point here is that this brilliant application still helped the owner even after his phone was stolen. So a possible solution to your concept can be a small program in a phone which sets up a process to switch off the phone. If the owner wants to switch off the phone for personal privacy, he completes the small process (just going through a couple of steps) which only he is aware in order to switch off the phone. In this way no alerts will be sent to anybody. Now, if the phone is switched of by any other person (in this case the official who confiscates your phone) he will switch it off without going through the small 'switching off'  process (as he knows nothing about it) and this will surely trigger all kinds of alerts you proposed.This, according to me, might majorly remove the risk of a false alarm.

Dear Rathin, I really like your story and thanks for sharing, I suppose that sort of application with some manipulation could meet our purposeI think bring some of these text to the main text, some of them are absolutely useful and related
Thanks for the acknowledgement. Its always Nice to work with great minds for a good cause.
I like the picture - since we know cell phones are a major way of tracking people and events, what if we disguised them - made them harder to find or easily identify?Using micro technology perhaps?

Dear Lieselot Thanks for your collaborating, I like your idea. But I think about a mechanism that could detect your detention especially when you might be the subject of that. I think of cell phone as a permanent comrade. So it could be the first who notices your problem. At first it should be by some way enable to detect you around for example by detecting your voice around or something such as this. So if you werent around for a while it could notices as act.

Hi Amin,I like this concept - perhaps instead of tracking the individual, the location of the telephone could be tracked. There was some publicity earlier this year about Apple's "tracking" of handsets by which station they were connected to. The same is possible for Android handsets. (see https://market.android.com/details?id=ch.rrelmy.android.locationcachemap ) Today I travelled a little over a mile and connected to 7 different locations.Perhaps when a user's usual network of stations that they are connected to changes, or the telephone is no longer available, a warning could be issued to a trusted third party? This would obviously require telephony providers to be involved. I'm guessing that upon arrest/capture the sim would remain in the telephone only as long as required to grab contacts, diary events and call, message and location  details. The last station it was connected to should be logged by the telephony provider (and the phone) though. I can't help but feel that we shouldn't be looking at changing the technology, rather we should be looking at using the technology already available.
Great conversation forming here guys! Dave's last point is really interesting  perhaps it'll spark even more concepts :)

Yep  loving David's last point as well  and agree it's a fab conversations you've triggered Amin. Sometimes innovation lies in the mashup  maybe you'd be interested to check out our Tech Showcase if you haven't already: http://bit.ly/ai_tech Many channels which could be potentially leveraged there.

Thanks all, your contribution built for me another concept. I will bring it up very soon, But to add something here I should mention the situation of my country and get your proposition about that.In my country telephony provider are all involved!! But not as you expected. Almost all of them were bought by Sepah one of the most radical military forces in Iran that not only did an essential role in term of repressing demonstration in Iran after 2009 but actually blamed to do same role for Syrian people.  and unfortunately enforced by European companies such as Nokia with the latest innovations in terms of eavesdropping.  Please stay be into I think this concept with some polish would be something
Great local insights Amin. Looking forward to our onwards thoughts...

I think Amin's comment of a phone as "a permanent comrade" is the most important one here - the phone though is going to be different in nearly every case. I suspect my idea of tracking connections would run into problems with people who have a less sedentary lifestyle than myself. Also a phone being switched off for privacy's sake, or simply running out of power, could trigger a false alarm.

Amin, your latest comment is basically where I was thinking my idea would fail - vodafone's involvement in the cutting off of internet services in Egypt this year, and mobile phone manufacturer's business practices being closely tied to governmental snooping since the early '90s (echelon in europe) suggest that my idea would have serious problems in nations where the state has closer ties to the telephony providers. I look forward to your concept.

Hi Amin,I like your idea of using cell phone to notify family member and lawyer. I notice that now a day, cell phone has voice command functions. You could say something that was store within the phone memory, it can activate the corresponding software. Maybe it could be implement further into your "predefined emergency instruction". for example: when you get arrest, you could say a key sentence that activate the mechanism to preform the predefined emergency instruction. Like "Why am I arrested?", most people don't say such sentence unless something really happened to them so we don't have to be afraid of accidentally activate the software. I hope it helps you in some ways.
dear Phuc Thanks for your contribution, I think you Idea really works and I will quote  it in the main text as option for start the app

Hi Amin  I donno if you have read this concept, but this one is similar to yours http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/no-ping-alert-on-/   This concept would help you in reaching a larger part of the society as we know not everyone has a smart phone. Using automated SMS's would be one of the easiest way of communication for a detainee. And coming to your point of the cell phone being switched off, Most of the Nokia phones have enough reserve power to switch on from OFF mode when an alarm has already been preset at that time. Probably this technology could be transferred and put to use here, I donno how this could be done, but i ll keep thinking. hope this helps you

the_mobile_witness.title: The mobile witness

social_white_house.description: Any petition posted that gains 5,000 signatures in a month will get an official White House response.
social_white_house.creator: 7a5f9dd2ee07e3ea9a9265ac9109fafe

comments.text: Nice highlight Claire. At the very least, it provides one avenue for getting on the radar in the US right now. It'd be nice if petitioning systems worked effectively in more places: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_jails

Thank you, Vincent.  What an absolute tragedy that such places exist.  Growing up in America...of course there was injustice, strife, but for many of us life was pretty copasetic.  So we had nightmares about made up boogeymen, imaginary creatures...I wonder what the nightmares are like for children who grow up with Black Jails in their reality?

social_white_house.title: Social White House

app_sms_alert_system.description: Port existing elderly emergency alert system: A service where an app or SMS trigger can send location as well as fire off social media alerts that someone is in danger or at risk of disappearing.
app_sms_alert_system.creator: dad8ddbb0881cebfbe3bffd71792e86b

comments.text: Thanks Meena, ok will try to flesh this out later and post to concept phase. Cheers!

Interesting thoughts Julie  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to look over other Inspirations of *existing* tools + initiatives to see if there's any insights to help build your Concept further.

app_sms_alert_system.title: App/SMS Alert System

_even_though_i_m_free_i_am_not_.description: In Burma and across the world, former political prisoners have come together to raise awareness of the tragic plight of their colleagues still detained in jail.
_even_though_i_m_free_i_am_not_.creator: 7a0c30f4bb6da850e4a7099b62303663

comments.text: Hi David, thanks so much for sharing this video and story with us. As Meena suggested, a great example that reminds us how the stories of former and current political prisoners and other detainees are intertwined. To build on this, I heard today about Burma's recent release of 200 political prisoners http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-15269259. The article shows that it's clearly only one step toward reform, but I thought it was relevant and worth sharing here.

Thanks, Ashley. I was just a reading a similar article via Human Rights Watch. The news out of Burma has certainly made me think about how we can utilize new technologies to help enact/enforce policy and governmental reforms to help in these situations.
David, thanks for sharing. This is such a neat and powerful way to tell the story and raise the awareness for the political prisoners in Burma!

Thanks for sharing, David. A fascinating way to raise awareness on this issue in Burma and I especially like how it links people who have been freed with those who are still in prison and show their ongoing support. In the upcoming Concepting phase, I wonder how we might suggest ways in which technology could further support these former prisoners to support the human rights of their friends and family who are still detained? Looking forward to more thoughts & discussion on your post till then.

_even_though_i_m_free_i_am_not_.title: "Even Though I'm Free I Am Not"

laugh_now_one_day_we_b4_ll_be_in_charge.description: Insecure the handymen of the system
laugh_now_one_day_we_b4_ll_be_in_charge.creator: 0ddcb464310d6b58427e84cfd9888bc6

comments.text: Interesting provocation here Basti, thanks for sharing. I think the key is remembering that the people being detained and the people "doing" the detaining are all just that: people. Whatever we can do to understand the mindset, motivations, and needs of all people involved in these situations will be helpful for us as we move through this challenge.

Yes, maybe we should also switch the point of views or try to get in contact with people on the other side of the system. What are their motivations, fears, motives...I wonder what actions could make the Stanford prison experiment to have a happy end.
Indeed an interesting inspiration. Also made me think of the Stanford prison experiment (http://www.prisonexp.org/ for those not familiar with the idea).

laugh_now_one_day_we_b4_ll_be_in_charge.title: Laugh now - One day we´ll be in charge

local_advice_wiki.description: Each country is different and families and friends of detainees need to have advice that is relevant to them in their countries. In some countries it may endanger a detainee if a large public awareness campaign is launched; on the other hand in other places it can make a difference. Let's create a site with a wiki system with advice that pertains to each locale so that friends and family can know how best to act to protect their loved ones.
local_advice_wiki.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Hi Nathan - did you hear the news? Your concept is being developed and prototyped as part of this weeks Make-a-thon at IDEO London! Check this out for more info http://bit.ly/y2uDQZ and be sure to weigh in over at our User Forums http://bit.ly/yt0m5d to help your idea take one step closer to reality. And hint: be sure to check out Brief #2!
that's amazing, thanks for letting me know.

Cool concept, I followed the thread here and it looks like the latest version that came out of the Make-a-thon is this: http://hackweekend.info/ with code for it here: https://github.com/townsend51/hackweekend - its a Django project!
This is a great concept that I see as complementary to the A-Z Guide. Both would form an integral part of a comprehensive system of information for support, awareness and administrative purposes.
THanks Paul that's great advice. I'll check them out. I've been looking for a good Wiki to build this from.

Nathan! Congratulations on being a winning concept. Thank you for your contribution. The Amnesty team particularly appreciated how your idea makes use of information that Amnesty already has, not to mention this could be a hugely valuable resource. Great work!
Congrats Nathan! Leveraging Amnesty's resources & expertise, while ingeniously incorporating wiki/crowdsourcing contributions. Brilliant idea right from the start =)
Thanks Vincent & OpenIDEO! Wow, really looking forward to how this might become a working prototype.
Congratulations Nathan! I think this is a very nice idea and it can also provide great data for the A-Z guide.

There are certainly various wiki software options out there (many open source, including what powers Wikipedia) to leverage to begin prototyping, as you've started with Wikispaces.Eventually, I think it's key to find, or refine, one to maximize ease of use/accessibility for browsing, searching, & contributing (as that's currently a weakness of many of these systems), and to customize for Amnesty's goals.
Congrats Nathan!  Looking forward to seeing this move into prototyping...

Great work Nathan! Good to see this and Amjad's A-Z Guide both make it to the winning list. Looking forward to developments. I'm a bit late to contribute this but http://www.wikimatrix.org has comparisons of a number of wiki platforms - one that caught my eye was BlueSpice( http://hallowelt.biz/en/software/bluespice/ ) which seems to be open source, enterprise oriented and actively supported. No doubt Amnesty and IDEO will have some platforms in mind.

Hi Nathan!I really like this concept... I'm sure this is implicit but coupling the wiki with an analytics tool could also help Amnesty streamline their efforts and add a monitoring aspect to your concept.  For instance if the majority of page views and conversion rates are on discussion forums specific to spousal support, returned detainees, or certain regions / ethnicities, etc it would be easy for Amnesty to notice this trend and create subsequent plans of action / better understand the behavior of potential / returned detainees and their families.Great idea, and congrats on the short list!Megan
Thanks Megan, great suggestion!

Hi Nathan, congrats for your shortlisted concept! We love how youve taken the initiative to already start prototyping this concept.Our feedback to you would be how could you push the functionality of the traditional wiki to provide custom features that might be needed in this context? Could this platform also become a way to activate the network to campaign for specific cases of unlawful detention?

Great concept Nathan!  Building off Vincent's comment, it seems like it could be powerful to reach out to former detainees or their families to provide commentary as well (if they were comfortable with it of course ... but you might find one or two superusers).  Even if they promoted conflicting experiences or opinions, their perspectives would enrich the debate.
Wiki-licious thinking on this one!

Hi Nathan.  I love the basic idea for your concept.  I am wondering though, how would you suggest dealing with the potential language (I assume there are a wide range of countries/continents suffering from unlawful detainment) and literacy issues?

Amanda, great question. Maybe there could be a similar crowd translation program such as the way wikipedia or ted talks works? Not sure how that would solve the literacy issues but maybe there could be a similar program to provide audio guide versions of each country's guide?

Great concept Nathan which builds on already existing knowledge but facilitates the access, and also allows it to be updated and localized even more. Good points Amanda. It seems that as Nathan said the crowd translation program could be a solution for the translation.Regarding the literacy issue, I like the idea of the audio guide. It could be like the question box:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-question-box-provides-answers-in-unreachable-places/which could also be accessible in the amnesty international vending machine or the shift iii van. In the van, I was discussing the possibility of having people educating people / helping to go online, or read information, or fill in information. Hence, they could read the information on the wiki as well as update it.Another place where some help could be provided: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/mobile-letter-writing-workshops/Quite a few options it seems! :-)

Thanks Nathan :)  I think a crowd translation program could be an excellent way to approach the problem!  I could also see the audio guides working.  Particularly if the content is already being translated, the additional effort to do an audio recording of the original content seems minimal at that point.Also, I know that your concept details a more "best practices" approach to dealing with detainment, but it might be interesting to see it incorporate some of the more native-language/image friendly approaches detailed in some of the other concepts:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/-behind-the-bars-a-data-visualization-call-to-action-campaign/(Infographics might get an overall message across well, minimizing the translation necessary to convey a point; might be useful for countries/areas where you're having a hard time collecting crowd translations)http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-z-guide-for-families-and-friends-of-detainees/(This concept seems to have a similar theme to yours.  It might be neat to find a way to integrate your ideas, particularly since the books proposed would remain in the local language...)http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/capitalizing-on-the-power-of-knowledge/(The pamphlets in the low-tech part of this concept are what I see as particularly relevant here)Hope this gives you some food for thought!  Looking forward to seeing your concept evolve.

Nice concept Nathan. Could see how this could help build up a knowledge base from people's experiences.Given that there are likely to be different opinions & some controversy on best approaches (even within a specific region), perhaps advice could include a "discussion" section (where people share their personal tips that can be commented & voted on), as well as more authoritative sections (like "Amnesty Approved" guidelines)?
Vincent, that's a great suggestion. I'll add that in.

local_advice_wiki.title: Local Advice Wiki - AmnestyGuide

py/tuple: Technological viability: Can this concept be developed using existing technological tools and at a relatively low cost, will it work in areas with a limited technology infrastructure?
The development of this concept would require minimal technological input and/or would work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would need some specialist technological input and/or may not work in low tech areas
The development of this concept would be a large undertaking and/or may require extensive technological resource and cost
Awareness raising and information sharing: Does this concept help to raise awareness/educate people on the issues of unlawful detention?
This is a concept that, alongside being an active and functional tool, also raises awareness and educates users
This is a concept that, while being an active and functional tool, does not educate or raise awareness
This is a concept that is good at raising awareness and educating, but is not an active and functional tool
Usability: Is this concept ‘friendly’ to a diverse range of user, including those with limited literacy and technological skills?
This concept is simple to use and can be used in low literacy areas with little to no technological knowledge
This concept may necessitate the user is confident with technology, but requires only medium-level literacy skills
This is a concept that requires both a high-level of literacy and technological knowledge from the user
Maintenance and continuation: Is this a concept that could be sustained over a long period of time?
This is a concept that could be updated easily and maintained by local communities after Amnesty has left the equation
This is a concept that might need further development at a later date and/or may need Amnesty or another party’s continued involvement in order to thrive
his is a concept with a limited shelf-life and would potentially need a significant maintenance during its life-span
Scalability: Is this concept practically applicable across multiple regions without extensive adaptation; will it be pertinent to a wide group of people affected by diverse issues?
This concept is practically applicable across geographies and will be useful to a wide number of people
This concept will need to be adapted to cover different regions, but will be useful to many people
This concept will need little to no adaptation for use in different regions, but will only be useful to a limited number of people

achieving_context_through_art_engaging_t.description: How much detail do we need to be effective and not violate the privacy or endanger the individual? Art can be telling and contextually relevant while subjects are abstracted and remain open. Artists close to human rights conflict have achieved this.
achieving_context_through_art_engaging_t.creator: 634fa8caffadede3eca76b7d267b9e5b

comments.text: Brian, this is a terrific Inspiration - thanks so much for sharing Conor's work. It's amazing how images can get across so much more meaning and emotion than words.
Thanks Ashley for the thoughtful comment! Conor's work is powerful in the imagery he chooses to create a dialogue with the viewer.

achieving_context_through_art_engaging_t.title: Achieving context through art - Engaging the masses and protecting the individual.

clandestine_morse_reader.description: An app that translates Morse code into text and allows it to be shared on the web.
clandestine_morse_reader.creator: 77ff14b2439160cb2a7244eb215b5919

comments.text: Interesting, Hubert. Keep in mind that we don't want to put detainees in more risk by having them engage in activities which violate their confinement rules and could attract punishments (even though their detainment is in itself unlawful) You might want to check over our Guiding Principles which contain more info: http://bit.ly/amnesty_guide

clandestine_morse_reader.title: Clandestine Morse Reader

indian_film_star_and_icon_shahrukh_khan_.description:
This is not my personal story, but one that relates closely to this issue.
For those who don't know this actor, His Name is Shahrukh Khan and has been an extremely successful actor in the Indian film industry, being considered one of the top few.
indian_film_star_and_icon_shahrukh_khan_.creator: 0e9b61ed7d7b30f3db82c5786cf2f1b3

comments.text: Hi Rathin, thanks for sharing this story which reminded me - because of the racial stereotyping (through names) - the story posted by Nathalie: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/detainments-on-9-11-11/It is sad to hear that this has happened to some of your friends and relatives. I think you raise a good question: it happens to ShahRukh Khan  but he was able to get help because he is famous, what happens to the "common man"?You also highlight another point about how we are not necessarily aware of what we have (freedom, independence) until we are in this kind of situation deprived of it - even for a short time... It reminds me the inspiration posted by Arjan about the Karosta builder: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-karosta-prison-hotel/It also relates to the discussion started by Ashley with her post on the limits of empathy: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-limits-of-empathy/This story does raise important issues to keep in mind for this challenge! thank you.

indian_film_star_and_icon_shahrukh_khan_.title: Indian film star and icon ShahRukh Khan detained in US, send fans into a tizzy

be_a_whistleblower_for_peace.description: Falling Whistles is a social enterprise that raises awareness and inspires action to end the world's deadliest war since WWII, happening right now in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
be_a_whistleblower_for_peace.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Ashley, thank you for sharing this campaign with us. At this information boom age, people usually think how to send out information or signal from different medias is important, however, how to keep valuable information flow and not being burried is even more important. We receive hundreds thousands of information daily from different media platform, by the end of the day, how many of them we still remember and eventually trigger some pratical actions? This post is a good example of how to chose a clear symbol to really highlight the imformation which worth spread and push people to take action.
Really great point Lei - it's a campaign that grabs your attention and cuts through the clutter!

Hi Ashley, thank you for sharing this. Among all of the great things, I also love what they say in the donation section: "The world is changed by those who speak out. Put your money where your mouth is."!

Ashley, thanks sharing this inspiring project. It is a very powerful way to share a fact - about these kids the whistle - but also to make it a symbol and also a way of starting conversations. You can even think of events such as let's all blow the whistle at 6 PM Kinshasa time (similar to campaigns about energy consumption where there have been about turning off the light at xx). The question would be is what will be the impact in Congo or neighboring countries where the whistle is clearly laden with meaning.I also like the point about the positive feeling that relates nicely with your inspiration about empathy... that might be part of the answer: rather than developing empathy, feeling bad for people, a way to get people to act is to make them feel good and engaged...

Clear call to action and storytelling are very effective and important steps for this kind of advocacy that is often overlooked. Empowering the audience is key. As you pointed out, positive motivation works wonders over scare tactics.  When I worked for Prevent Child Abuse Nebraska, we found that scaring the audience into reporting abuse had the opposite effect (people were nervous to get involved) where messages that were encouraging and factual motivated the audience.

Really great input Amanda, thanks for your feedback. I was originally inspired to build on your Inspiration for the LRA Crisis Tracker, and it just so happened that Falling Whistles came to the office on the same day to present! So I just had to share the story. To add to your points, one thing that the founder said was, "If I've made you sad today, I haven't done my job." His point was that he wanted to inspire us  both to learn and to get involved, and not to scare us into caring or acting on behalf of the cause. It was a very powerful way of positioning his talk, and it worked for me!

be_a_whistleblower_for_peace.title: Be a Whistleblower for Peace

act_it_out_.description: Revise the Human Rights training methodologies in different institutions such as police, army, marine, lawyers and any association whose members are in a position that enables them to  capture or play any role during imprisonment process. Develop creative workshops through SIMULATIONS and ROLE GAMES, so these people feel and experience what it feels to be on the other side, what it feels to be captured and imprisoned without proper/ fair treatment. Use performances to perform Human Rights awareness in a practical level ! Human Rights can be felt not only read! Uphold HR plays and role games!
act_it_out_.creator: a02804e335ae62484bc73e1f77c734b9

comments.text: Great way to build empathy and awareness.

Hi Ana Julia!I really like your concept, I'm a big fan of the 'learning by doing' vehicle of education, so I think it could be well applied here if carefully planned. The important thing here is you leave the workshop or training, feeling you have learnt something, and you can possibly apply it somewhere else hopefully to stop human rights issues in your community or pass your knowledge in to someone else.Another important point is where these workshops would take place - i can imagine them being more useful and valuable to impoverished communities where many human illegalities are occurring, previously in Libya and Egypt for example. So it will be important to grab the right audience to benefit the most from these workshops. Your concept reminds me of one by Anne along the similar lines, 'The Prison Hotel Experiment' : http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-prison-hotel-experiment/
Build on it!

comments.text: I wonder if you could harness the existing technology of mobile phones which already do a very good job of keep track of where users are and have been: http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=114241860
I think that this is a great start.  By starting simple we can build many ideas!
Fab thoughts Margaret! We can imagine this prompting a number of ideas in the upcoming Concepting phase  including digital trails. Let's think broadly about what this great insight might inspire...

no_communication_day_an_event_and_commun.description: One of the most troublesome repercussions of unlawful detention is the forcible and involuntary loss of communication beyond the walls of detention. We propose a global event of “silence” designed to recreate a day in the life of a detainee, who has been deprived of communication with the outside world. “No Communication Day” will call on participants to put themselves in the shoes of the unlawfully detained and sacrifice 24-hours of digital communication. In a world, where we are reliant on digital tools to share information and communicate with others around the clock, we often take for granted the power of digital connectivity and its integration in our lives.
no_communication_day_an_event_and_commun.creator: 6cf42ec9950da8306046a6a682ee78ec

comments.text: Nice concept! It reminds me of TOMS One Day Without Shoes http://www.onedaywithoutshoes.com/ What if this also incorporated being vocally silent for as much of the day as possible. To spread the message, people could wear a tshirt that says "the reason I'm not talking is..." This could bring the issue even further into daily life, and therefore spread the message to more people.

Hi,nice concept and very well-thought through.I could not help thinking of this inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-sound-of-social-media-silence/I guess you could also build upon all the inspirations / concepts that refer to the power of social media: too many here to be listed...  I'm not thinking in terms of opposition, but in terms of interrelation: the power of your concept comes from the power of social media.It could also be good to maybe think of how to link it to the shift campaign: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/shift-freedom-sticker-sign-up-campaign/a related campaign suggested by Ana might also be interesting to check: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/on-10th-dec-human-rights-day-exchange-your-profile-picture-for-the-shift-freedom-glasses-/Check also some idea suggested by Anne in the comments of Jason's universal concept on the use of symbolic number: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-universal-unlawfully-detained-symbol-to-spread-in-case-of-emergency/Based on my own experience of forcing myself to not be online for a few days / year (when on holidays), I think it will be a very strong experience as we're all so used to communicate and be online. Imagine if some companies were agreeing to stop communication or limit it within a company (I think work could still be done, in fact maybe more than expected :-)...).
Hi again, an inspiration that you might find interesting: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/get-lost-..document-share-the-experience/
Great thinking, team!

comments.text: Thanks Lei for sharing this information. It also reminds us the importance of "context": unlawful detention and the possibility to spread the word has a very different meaning - as Arjan highlighted with his question about the "meaning" and "weight" of words - depending on who you are (race, gender, socio-economical status) but also where you live. This is something to keep in mind as we move to the concepting phase... I find interesting that there is such a website and I'm curious to know who is their audience. Through this post, you're making a connection between the OpenIDEO community and this piece of information.Food for thought! thanks a lot.

Very interesting example. How is participating on OpenIDEO regarded? Especially if topics like this turn up in the inspirations? What interests me is how language plays a role in this. And not the difference between two languages, but in the choice of words and maybe some sort of codes that evolve out of it. Your post makes me very curious. Thanks!

Hi Arjan, thanks for the comment. I personally live in NYC now, so not quite sure if people in China can participate on OpenIDEO. However, based on my experience with Chinese internet censorship policy, I don't think any website contains discussion like this topic can go through GFW without any trouble.

Great inspiration Lei. Glad you posted this, especially since these things sometimes have limited spread beyond the Chinese community (not to mention within). And yes Arjan, definitely constantly morphing code words helps to bubble things past censorship for a little while.

Hi Lei, interesting example. Any chance you can share the source for this inspiration? Adding a link to the newspaper, blog, or article that your inspiration references will be super helpful for everyone to add context and increase our understanding of what's happening around the world. You should be able to use the 'Update this' button on the right of your post and add any links directly. Let us know if you run into any trouble along the way!
Hi Ashley, thank you for the reminder. I have attached the link in my post.
Thanks so much Lei! Cheers for your great contributions so far.

_the_map_of_freedom_on_amnesty_internati.description: When someone goes missing, any data you can get helps the task of evaluating the situation, searching and finding that person. Think of it similar to the inspiration phase of IDEO. An online profile with any piece of intelligence and an individual map that shows the last steps of the missing person may give important clues. See the pieces come together and create a concept of how to help with world wide input!
_the_map_of_freedom_on_amnesty_internati.creator: 804d107d591f0722a4f1ae064ef13596

comments.text: Hi Julian,in another discussion Marnie suggested the ushahidi mapping solution http://www.ushahidi.com/ and I think it is clearly a technology that is relevant to your concept. See their first video. Also in the second video (swift the river) they present various tools, including one to make sure that the content is not duplicated. Hope this helps.al

Hi Anne-Laure,this is a great finding! Thank you!I will integrate it as soon as I have a clearer concept of where this process is going. Starting a concept is easy - keeping it going seems to be the hard part. :-)Cheers,Julian

Hi Julian,I think there is a lot of potential in this context in terms of creating a database for both the families and relatives, but also organizations working on unlawful detentions.While I can see how an individual map would look like, I'm not sure how you would organize all these (we're talking of thousands of them I guess) maps and how people can access them. Could you explain me better?Also you mentioned the Amnesty International ID: Is this something that already exist?thanksal

Hi Anne-Laure,thank you for your response!Yes, this certainly does never solve the whole issue, but it helps - as you mention - in several ways. I see it as a starting-point for a "creative process". Gather all information accessible and then start combining them to a picture of what might have happened and where to start searching / acting. Compare it to the IDEO process?! Specialists worldwide could then process the given data and draw clues. And so on.Yes, sadly I suppose its a huge number of profiles. Then, how many profiles are on facebook? I think the number of profiles is technically not an obstacle. And not everybody will have input for all profiles, but only a few for one certain profile out of their family, workplace, neighbours and such. I agree it will be hard to manage, but there should be some database of some kind, don't you think? How do they manage all these cases now. Does anybody here have input on that?The persons name would always be part of the profile.The ID is just an idea of mine to overcome confusions. Names may be difficult to say or write correct and hard to remember in several languages. A row of numbers is clear everywhere.Cheers! Julian

Hi Julian,Let me clarify my question: based on the image you had, I was not sure how the page will look like as your image was based on one individual map with quite specific information. Thanks to Arjan's comment, I was able to visualize how you could have regional maps and ways of then "zooming in". Regarding the number of profiles, my question was less about data management (all the social media platforms are able to do this), and more about the interface, the "look and feel". I was unsure how all these profiles would be put together visually. Now I can imagine it.I agree that one has always to start from somewhere and that it's an ongoing process, and that's what the concepting phase, with other IDEATORs commenting is about: trying to nurture the idea and move it to a "full concept". Even if as you suggested Amnesty International was heading the project, I believe they would need a concept as fully developed as possible in order to be able to develop and implement it. Regarding the Amnesty International ID, it's a good point but that implies that it has to be created and managed. Not impossible but to be thought of. What happens if someone disappears and this person does not have an ID? It can be created when the missing person is reported I guess. Then if a second person reports this missing person, would there be a way to associate the ID and the name so that the second person does not create a second ID for the same missing person...  cheers,al

Hi Anne-Laure,yes, I fully understand. I am still trying to find the right way of participating. I will try to learn fast as we go on.Am I the only one that can work on this particular concept? Is there a kind of "wikipedia-way" of working together on the same concept?I warmly welcome everyone to give specific ideas as comments and I will try to keep integrating them. So it will build up as a joint achievement. I will list all contributors on the bottom of the concept text - if that is ok to IDEO?!The ID. I see your point, absolutely. Then, names can be spelt wrong and again you would have two or more profiles. Everyone! Ideas how to solve this one?!Thank you very much for your support, Anne-Laure!Julian

Hi Julian,and you're doing a great job at participating and sharing your ideas.As for your question regarding the virtual team, I've seen people having a "virtual team" at the bottom of their post, mentioning people who helped them developing their ideas. Arjan, Meena and Ashley will be able to provide more information.By the way, reading Alejandro's concept:    HAMPTON INN MANHATTAN SOHOI thought it could be an interesting way to provide data into your map.As soon as the signal stops, the person could be "mapped".I'm not at all an expert but looking into google maps as well as other map technologies might be worth it to get a better understanding of the issues involved in your concept.
oops! Not sure what happened. Alejandro's concept is http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/no-ping-alert-on-/

Interesting concept Julian, and a great first contribution to OpenIDEO. I like the idea of this, and I can see how people can be plotted on a map based on region or theme. Please note that if you see some good ideas, or questions, in the comments that help you work your concept out further, you can update it at any time. Don't forget to mention the OpenIDEATORS who helped you :)

Hi Arjan,thanks for writing "how people can be plotted on a map based on regions or theme": it helped me visualize! :-). I guess that then when clicking or passing over an individual icone, we would get the individual map with the last steps... thanksal

Hi Arjan,thank you for your welcome!Yes, I will edit the concept on the way.What is the correct way of mentioning Input from others without making the concept confusing to read? I thought this is what the: "this concept is built upon" function is for?!Please give me insights on how to do things the IDEO way!!!Thank you so much!!!Julian

Interesting thoughts, Julian. What we need to be careful here is that we are not inadvertently helping out people who may not have the detainee's best interest at heart. Hoping folks will chip in here to think of ways that your idea might be developed with this in mind.

Hi Meena,yes! Input please! :-)What could be happening?-others that help could get into trouble themselves.-detainee might be put into worse condition due to these actions.-detainee might be moved far away to be safe from tracking.What else?Thank you!!!

empathy_from_the_enemy_.description: We consider family, friends, community and volunteers as resources. But why not the people who have captured you? Is there a possibility of extracting empathy from your captors? If so, how to convert it to action? What kind of action? We, Team Chimera, are sure that it is possible to do so.
empathy_from_the_enemy_.creator: 97b8ff32fd53531b6d32f5729d47ea1c

comments.text: Hi Team Chimera, this is a dense concept which takes an interesting perspective. I like the idea to consider that guards and people involved in unlawful detentions are also human beings. In the Zimbardo experiment, they found that among the guards different "types" (and behaviors) emerged and that a few guards showed empathy and were willing to help. It might be nice to go back to some of these studies to figure out what triggers this kind of behaviors and how many actually "do something".Reading your concept, I was not always sure if you were only talking about triggering empathy (and hopefully action) in the guards (to make it short) or if you were going beyond. Also when you are mentioning in the "in the walls" section,  family pictures and powerful phrases, what are you exactly envisioning? Do you believe that authorities would allow this kind of campaign within a jail or other detention centers?I am also not sure what you mean by "They must seem helpless and dependent without showing anger." Are you suggesting that all detainees should look helpless? I'm wondering if it is not often the case but I don't have any experience of detention (luckily!) and I don't know much about prisoners' behaviors (but if you go back to Zimbardo's experiment, it seems that many will in fact take the obedient prisoner's behavior). Last, I really like your section on how to go from empathy to action.I started doing some research on lack of empathy http://philosophy.csusb.edu/~tmoody/F05%20191%20lack%20of%20empathy.htmand I think you might be able to build an interesting argument.Looking forward to the development of your concept,al

Inside the walls, we believe that it's not a campaign but rather a type of behavior the individual detainee adopts and the types of conversations he has that might be helpful. It would be based on the experience of people who have been previously detained. Also we're focused on long-term detentions where eventually, frustration may lead to anger which may lead to detainees making mistakes that might complicate the process.

Thanks for the clarification re. "inside the walls". I got misled by the sentence "the detainee can use visual cues to extract sympathy from the people around them" and then your references to pictures.I like the idea of thinking of ways of making it easier for guards / authorities to report a case knowing that it might also put them at risks.

another thought linked on behaviors and empathy. I'm not an expert but I remember reading about how guards (e.g. nazis) were able to do what they did because of the dishumanization process of the camps (of carceral systems in general). This made your point very valid: if there's a way to re-humanize the prisoners in the eyes of the guards, that might help create behavioral changes or at least a decision to report a situation to organizations such as Amnesty International...
an inspiration you want to build upon: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/-zimbardo-experiment

when talking about  Amnesty International, I feel like this kind of organization should do something aiming at the guards. That could include everything that helps to soften their hearts. I don't know if the organizations have the related projects or not. But that could be a good way since this kind of organizations have more resources, channels and efficient networks to do this. The only problem I am still thinking about is how to conduct it in a technological way.

Powerful notions. Thanks for bringing up this perspective.This does not effect this challenge, however, on a similar note, it is very clear to me that the techniques outlined in Marshall Rosenberg's work on Nonviolent Communication would be instrumental to all parties involved. I say this because at the core of this work is the notion of empathy, especially in difficult situations.

Interesting thoughts, guys  and great conversation you've triggered! If you've got any questions you'd like to ask the Amnesty team to help you and others understand that challenge more deeply so you can propose relevant solutions  come ask them here: http://bit.ly/ask_amnesty
Thanks Meena :-)

Hi team ChimeraI think that empathy can be a very powerful tool in bringing more humanity to bear in a system that is possibly shaped toward suppressing just that. I certainly take great inspiration from your detailed concept and indeed Anne-Laure link to the Zimbardo experiment. My initial thinking on this can be found here: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/from-guilty-officer-to-whistleblower-to-friend-to-anonymous-angel-with-a-great-new-job/This initial idea will require a lot more thinking particularly in terms of lowering the barriers for guards/officers to take action within the walls and contacting AI, however, seems to me that we're thinking along the same forces that make humans human.I'd also would like to raise the point of what can one lose of trying ...In a way, I assume that as a detainee you will  - after the anger is ebbed away - try to build relationships with the human beings around you. In that sense, we could develop ideas on how a detainee could be made more successfull  in building that bridge with his/her guard on the one hand and how AI could make it more attractive for a guard to lower his/her guard and become an Angel of Humanity ( that's how I called them)...Let me know what you think.

I think empathy as you present it here, is a very very powerful tool. If we knew how to induce it, it could be used for various noble and evil causes - it could be used also by detainees who are guilty - why not? What makes you believe, that they would prefer to use bribery? I am referring to your disclaimer:"Disclaimer: We assume the innocence of the person since they rely on the resources of family, friends, press, government, employers, volunteers and internal motivation to extract empathy. If a person is guilty and has the support of their "organization", perhaps they will rely on other resources like bribing of higher officials, threats to lower officials and so on."Could you elaborate a bit on that?

That's a very good question. Well, we assume that if you really are guilty and the government can prove it, not even Amnesty can help you. But if you know you are guilty, you are most probably prepared and you would already know how to get out of a situation like this because you have given it prior thought. You might have mechanisms in place that trigger if you get captured. This one member of the a large French crime organization was captured in Thailand once. He had sewn diamonds into his arm which he pulled out to bribe the warden to be moved to a low-security cell and broke out. His family had already bribed airport officials to let him fly out of the country. The guilty are more prepared than the innocent and we want to give these people who have been unlawfully detained a better chance.

comments.text: S A C K, I agree 100% that school is the best, scalable, starting point for this type of knowledge. There are a variety of complementary resources already out there for teachers to use, freely available and well designed and in a variety of languages, and these can be easily built upon to address the specifics of unlawful detention
Educating young people is an interesting idea. this is an interesting idea that you could indeed develop in the concepting phase... just a few more hours to go! :-)

what_if_i_said_that_you_re_under_arrest.description: Amnesty International must deploy hundreds, if not thousands, of volunteers each year on the street in order to sign petitions and collect donations. The biggest hurdle to this marketing format is that most passerbuyers have caught on to the game.  What if Amnesty spiced up their street teams to make them police look-a-likes who suggest that innocent street-goers are under arrest - hopefully causing a slight shock reaction and later an empathetic connection for those who have actually undergone the experience. These reactions could be recorded on video and then later aired as part of a viral Amnesty International Campaign under the title "What if I said that you're under arrest?"
what_if_i_said_that_you_re_under_arrest.creator: 3763dd09f444a1ba8a52794d7da1ee3c

comments.text: Very nice, and triggering their "empathy for strangers" may even lead to higher donations! http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19580564
and full text if anyone is interested:http://www.neuroeconomicstudies.org/images/stories/documents/empathy-towards-strangers.pdf
What a great idea, Ashwin! I love it and I think I'll modify the post accordingly - fifty people really helped me understand how this could work.
Nice idea and an interesting way to create some empathy with the cause.
Great to see that you uploaded two ideas from our "Brainstorm in a Box" session. Way to go Lydia!

Love the idea! Amnesty is definitely known for campaigns that utilize mild shock to transmit their messages:http://www.moonbattery.com/World_Can't_Wait_Demonstration.jpghttp://www.creativecriminals.com/images/Amnesty3.jpgAnd it would be interesting to record and gauge the immediate and post reactions of multiple people. It can serve as an indicator of emerging patterns in opinion and to collect feedback. I think you might be interested in this:http://fiftypeopleonequestion.com/

capitalizing_on_the_power_of_knowledge.creator: 3b6f421e7550395e28e091c5565ac80a

comments.text: Hi Amanda,great effort to develop your concept. Very exciting!I like the fact that you've been trying to think of low-tech situations as I think this would be a major issue. Paper could indeed be an option... yet rather than transcripts of videos (that might be difficult to make, not necessarily very user-friendly and not necessarily adequate to literacy levels), you might want to think of options like the one described by Meena's great inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/making-policy-public/Another way of thinking of accessing your app could be a "public" (or semi-private) kiosk. See an inspiration I posted in the maternal health project inspired by the hole in the wall project in India: http://www.openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/a-village-well-of-knowledge-and-communication/

Hello Anne-Laure,Great suggestions!!  I'll have to mull this one over a bit.The problem that I see with the kiosk idea is something of a major one.  Theoretically, the videos on the app are in and of themselves probably not incriminating, in that the advice-givers could disguise themselves in some way, blur themselves out, or even talk off camera to maintain anonymity.  The challenge is that by putting this information in a kiosk, protestors would have to GO to that kiosk's location to get the information (whether video or  a pamphlet).  I can easily see detainers lying in wait to snap up people who are trying to access that information.  I'll have to see if I can think of a way around that.In regards to the pamphlet suggestion, I like that a lot.  It certainly addresses literacy and language challenges, which I thought about earlier in the concept but slipped my mind in the low-tech portion.  I'll be incorporating that into my concept, definitely.  Just have to figure out how the pamphlets would be dispersed...

Hi Amanda,good point about the kiosk. I did not think of it. More than the videos themselves (because once it's on the web, they are public anyway), I think the issue is the signaling involved in going to the kiosk.I suppose in low tech contexts, you could have posters or pamphlets.

Well, that's what collaboration is for right?  So I can think of things you didn't, and vice versa :)I am definitely going to be incorporating the idea of pamphlets or posters.  Hopefully with some nice visual aids, but we'll see what I have time for!  Check back soon...

Hi Amanda,great effort to build on this theme of knowledge is power and to take into account both the detainees and their families and friends. I also like the fact that you're thinking of various time moments (at risk and just before detention). It would be great if you could develop a bit more of what you're thinking in terms of content, and how localized it will be, also how and by whom it will be developed.While I like the integrated nature of the apps, I'm also wondering if there are not two concepts in here, based on 2 different types of knowledge: one being more of an "encyclopedic knowledge", one being more about simple location information. As both are important, it might be worth integrating but I feel it requires a bit more work on articulating the different types of knowledge and their implications in terms of features.I am also wondering if there is not a limitation in the fact that it requires smart phones, which are not necessarily accessible to people that might be detained or to their family. thanks!

Thank you so much for your comments!  You have definitely given me some food for thought.  This is my first experience with OpenIDEO, so I'm wondering... Is it typical to incorporate feedback into ideas as it comes?  Or do you leave the concept as is until Refinement?

Welcome Amanda! You can definitely update your concept using the feedback of others. This is the beauty and strength of this platform. To follow up on Ana's suggestion about concepts to look at, other concepts that might be worth checking: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-z-guide-for-families-and-friends-of-detainees/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/helpme-2013-a-single-push-pull-information-platform/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/protest-playbook-portal-supporting-all-phases-of-a-protest/As a new user, you might want to check the New User forum: http://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/20385056-introducing-the-new-users-forumLooking forward to see your concept evolve.al

Hi Amanda  welcome onboard and what a stellar start. Yep... we love it when folks update their post taking feedback from collaborators into account where they see fit. Great to see the conversation you've triggered here  keep it coming guys... collaboration loves company!
Thanks AL and Meena for the warm welcome.  AL, I'm checking out the concepts that you and Ana suggested so revisions should be coming soon!
Looking forward to them. :-)
Bring it on! (when you're good & ready ;^)
Okay ladies, I've updated my post, expanding a fair amount on the ideas I mentioned originally.  I'm looking forward to your feedback!  Thanks :D

Yey! So nice to see you so motivated Amanda, it motivates me too. I like the way you've explained things with a greater sense of a networked collective intelligence, with the integration of GPS and even as an internet browser - love that! Knowledge really is and should be, a powerful collected intelligence!

Hi Amanda, nice indeed to see you so enthusiastic and glad you found all our feedback useful. May I suggest that you also build upon some of the related concepts that have been previously posted (see some of the links) in my previous comment. It's important to acknowledge the connections but it is also a way to let these people know about your ideas and potentially get their feedback and suggestions.

Haha, I see what you mean now!  I thought you meant conceptually build upon, but I'm thinking now that you meant for me to use the "build upon" option in the concepting set-up that allows me to link my ideas to others.  New user misunderstanding.  I have now "built upon" your previous suggestions! :-)
Great! I meant it both: conceptually (which you did) and literally (which you've just done!). :-)

Hi Amanda!Very interesting concept, and by reading it I get the sense of a networked security system that is in place, as you explain it. It would be really interesting to see that work! You address different people and different phases that affected a detained person, and that is very important. It would me interesting to see how the Amnesty Observer App concept by Vincent (http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/amnesty-observer-app/#c-944747d723c31c7e6eac5f366bb4f3f4 ) could be incorporated into this network of support as one of the tools to empower people affected by unlawful detention even further! Maybe as a platform or support service, and make it bigger than a mobile application.
Thank you very much for your thoughts Ana!  I've just updated my post with additional information in response to some of the thoughts raised in this thread.  I'd love to get your feedback :-)

capitalizing_on_the_power_of_knowledge.title: Capitalizing on the Power of Knowledge

nyc_arrest.description: Have you seen this video? A ridiculously unnecessary arrest.
