amnesty_international_vending_machine_in.description: Imagine an Amnesty 'safe zone' in the form of a Vending Machine / Info Hub where a human rights affected community can access basic tools and knowledge to help them stay informed with unfolding events, and also inspiring them to document their own surroundings with basic low-tech tools.
amnesty_international_vending_machine_in.creator: 890278307fec5590e0f5982a2de58e38

comments.text: Dear Ana, thanks for your fab concept. We liked the vending machine for its ability to dispense local, relevant information in a lo-fi way. However, we didnt feel that as a physical location it would provide for the safety of the people that visited. Thanks for participating and we hope you will be part of the refinement phase!

Hi OpenIDEO team, thanks for the feedback, I really appreciate it even though it didn't make the refinement phase.I understand it could pose some danger, even if the Vending Machine is in a 'safe zone' e.g. in refugee camps. Maybe some of it's featured can now be translated into a more mobile version, with A-L's  Shift Van!Thanks again.
Congrats on this post being today's online Featured Concept!
Wow, what an honor once again, thank you very much OpenIDEO! Looking Forward to the next phases of this challenge :)

Hi Ana,I really like the low-tech nature of your idea, and how this Vending Machine/Info Hub essentially acts as an autonomous, anonymous dispenser (and collector!) of information and tools for empowerment for a huge range of environments. I think you are spot-on with regard to where the machine should be situated, in the case of unstable countries -- I can only imagine what would happen to it (and those who try to use it) in a country "governed" by violent military rule. This does lead me to wonder about something, however: how could we protect this Info Hub (or even set it up) in a place where Amnesty, or any other international non-profit/human rights organization, has difficulty establishing a presence? I'm thinking particularly of China, where it's not uncommon for anyone affiliated with an international human rights organization to be harassed, denied entry or secretly detained him/herself. How could we get something like the Info Hub to make its way into the steppes of Tibet, for example--and stay there?A stripped-down version that acts solely as a small vending machine might escape the eye of a censorious local government, but there is also the chance of its purpose being diluted when locals use it simply to replace the SIM cards on their phones for below market value. What if the certain versions of the vending machine were purposefully low-quality, built to be erected quickly and last only a day or two? Like some sort of itinerant guerilla toolkit? Sorry, I'm just thinking aloud here! This is such a rich and extendable idea.

Hi Connie and thanks for your super constructive post!I'm glad you admire the attempt for this Machine / Hub to be a low tech and like you say autonomous, although we would require good technology to build it, but not that much to maintain it hopefully. You address a super important issue that I thought of too when I wrote the concept and I think it will be a continuous path in trying to find a better solution : placing this hub in a non-protected zone. That's where we would love to reach, so we could access and give these important tools to the people really needing them. You mention a great idea, a kind of pop-up easy to build and and easy to get rid of kind of Vending Machine. Maybe it could auto-destroy itself if someone tries to bang it or break it, and all digital info delivered into it would be in the Amnesty 'cloud' computer system, so that info would not be lost, only the physical items in the machine. In my action-dreams I am imagining us delivering this small vending machine in military helicopters or planes in un-protected areas of communities, such as near bad housing areas or even near religious buildings. Of course this could scare the locals and call a lot of attention with a flying object leaving this on the ground, but maybe we could find a way to use this kind of fast delivery and fast exit route, and incorporating your idea of a lower quality machine for these purposes ! Thanks for this great discussion. Please feel free to suggest your improvements to this idea! I'm going to update it with your suggestion of a guerrilla kind of version!

Interesting idea. You can equip it also with a camera/microphone, so people can record their stories (in light of anonymity, a microphone might be better), and a scanner in which people can put documents.

Hi Arjan!Thanks for the heads up and ideas. That's exactly what I'd like with this Info Hub, for people to use items dispensed in it (Such as the Camera and Voice Recorder) and then input the recorded info back into the Hub, safely. If Lei's concept of Decentralizing the Network with Diaspora could become reality ( http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/decentralize-the-network-own-and-protect-your-data/ ) then we'd solve a lot of the security questions of what would happen to the data scanned and delivered via Bluetooth/USB back into the machine.
Nice drawings!
Hi Fia, thank you!I'm hoping to include an updated and more precise drawing after such great collaborative discussions building on here.
Hi Ana,I love the concept and it really inspired me. I have updated my concept by adding your concept as a scenario where decentralized network can be applied. Thank you! Cheers,Lei

Hi Lei, Thanks a lot, I'm really happy to be bouncing our ideas off each other. I just left my thoughts and comments on your super concepts' page! I think you implemented the scenario from this Hub perfectly, in a way that reflects my major objectives for this Info Hub. Keep up the inspiring work :)Ana

Hi Ana,I love the concept and how it provides a low-tech solution for access to data. Vending machines could be an option, a kiosk or a truck (mobile or not) could be other options for implementing it.We could even assume that in refugees camp, this could be creating a "job" for some of the refugees. It could also be a place to meet, share stories and maybe you could have once a week some legal support. Cheers,al

Hey Anne-Laure,Thanks once again for your great inputs. I think your mention of creating a 'job' out of maintaining this Vending Machine or possibly a Kiosk is a super idea! That would empower a community even further, and create some sense of ownership and respect for this 'hub'.I also like the aspect of the meeting point, I touched on it briefly with the use of the computer screen information for people to gather round, and I think by sharing stories and including legal support, we could make this even better, and reminds me of the great inspiration from the Ghana Think Tank :) Thanks Anne-Laure!

Hi Ana,I think that particularly if the vending machine is in a refugee camp, then it'll be great to be able to involve the community of the refugees. I like the idea of a hub rather than just a vending machine...I see it as a place where people could have access to services and at the same time could create connections. The Ghana Think Tank is indeed a great inspiration for your idea. The question box too. It could even be part of the vending machine...as you'll see I've built upon your idea to create a mobile version of it. :-)al

Great idea Ana! I really like the fact that it's an unmanned source of information or support...it immediately reminded me of the Question Box. I think it would be a great point of distribution for all the low-tech versions of our concepts. Nicely done!

Thanks Jason! Yes, i think anonymity is really important, and hopefully would incentivate the locals to document as much real things in their surroundings as possible, if they use the Camcorder and Voice recorders from the Vending Machine ! Yes, I like how you say we could make it a point of distribution for the low-tech versions concepts! Sounds ideal.  Absolutely, the question box really inspired my low-tech approach on this one, I tried to incorporate it into something bigger and more empowering and interactive. Let m know if u have further suggestions on improvement !Thx :)

Hey Ana,I love the new concept!  Anne-Laure and I were just discussing the other day the hazards of using a kiosk to distribute protest related information because of the vulnerability in getting to it.  The idea to have it in/near a protected area was a great one!Amanda

Hi Amanda! Thanks once again! I think I read a couple of those conversations last week that you mention. And I still think it is a risk in having it in a protected zone because I thought... well, the local governments might not allow it to go in with the medical teams, or with UN officials, they might not approve it... but it would be a way to start ! If there are any new suggestions on how to solve these kind of problems let me know ure thoughts ! Thanks for your inspiring words :)

amnesty_international_vending_machine_in.title: Amnesty International Vending Machine / Info Hub

using_art_to_turn_the_world_around_.description: Street photographer JR spreads his message of the 'untold story' by pasting photos of human faces across massive canvases around the world. His INSIDE OUT project allows the public to take part and paste individual portraits in the community.
using_art_to_turn_the_world_around_.creator: 23b8663ef5634e72e3537eb2d1facbae

comments.text: I too think that the fact that the work allows people to share their stories through their local communities is really what makes this effective. Since each community has its own culture/ideals it makes sense that it might not be standardized. It is too easy to turn your back on something that doesn't tell its own story.

Hi Aivya,reading about some inspirations on designing public campaigns, I was thinking of what could artists bring in and your inspiration is a very good answer. What's nice in this project is also that it is interactive.Thanks for sharingal
Exactly! What makes this artist so inspiring is that he creates a tool for people to distill their own personal messages to their communities

Hi Aviya, thanks for sharing the nice video. I remember reading somewhere about people having more empathy for a person rather than a group of people. I think that's why kiva.org is so successful on their mission as they are focusing on each person rather than a lum sum of people. Thanks again for this perspective
That's a great insight, Tayfun  and one that may prove very useful in the upcoming Concepting phase.
Thanks Meena, will try to keep that in mind and apply during Concepting.

using_art_to_turn_the_world_around_.title: Using Art to turn the world around

gps_watch_connect_you_with_a_wider_netwo.description: This idea builds off of the chip implants and suggests an option that a person can wear and take off at will. Creating a watch with GPS capabilities can allow someone who is unlawfully detained to be searched for. This idea comes from the Wells College Innovation Lab (CJ, Emily, Molly, Kyle, and Ashley).
gps_watch_connect_you_with_a_wider_netwo.creator: 9bc86d2f8ca15c9a0ac3499f98b8cc2f

comments.text: Hi guys, intriguing idea! You might like to check out our Tips on Concepting http://bit.ly/amnesty_tips. As you'll see there, it's good to keep in mind that tracking devices could lead to both positive and negative impacts for a detainee. Of course you're always welcome to refresh your concept with any additional insights or thoughts by using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

gps_watch_connect_you_with_a_wider_netwo.title: GPS Watch - connect you with a wider network

the_connectedness_of_co_working.description:
The CONNECTEDNESS OF CO-WORKING increases de visibility of that information (human rights violation), each and every person of the community collaborates (relatives, lawyers, Amnesty International, etc) in order to either solve or support the case.
A partnership with a Law firm will support 24/7 the questions and submitions of the community.
Integrate Infographics as the search engine of supporters and real time cases! As Google Earth says "fly anywhere". Once the supporter or the case is located you can have access(online) to the profiles of the people related, aswell as collaborating and sharing- Once you see the entired world populated with human rights violation cases you realize the importance of it.
the_connectedness_of_co_working.creator: 71c9bf1422c0de57f360e8fbd226f549

comments.text: Great video - really love the way you're communicated this concept.
Hi Nathan!..Im glad you like it...I have to thank  The back of the napkin and design thinking :) ... the simpler the better! Best regards!
Hi Nathan, I would like to invite you to have a look to the new updates of the concept: a new tech tool and a offline community center :)

Thanks for your comment on the Support Net Nayda. Yes I think your Connectedness concept would definitely fit into the legal support network. The video was a nice way to visualize the flow of information. I also thought it was a nice touch to incorporate Amnesty as a secondary stop, in order to address the issue through an independent network first. Great job!
Hi Jason, I would like to invite you to have a look to the new updates of the concept: a new tech tool and a offline community center :)
Wow Nadya! Innovative thinking & we're *loving* the video you've made to illustrate your ideas  very engaging.
Hi Meena! Thanks for your message...Thats exactly what I am into Innovation and design thinking,always taking a leap forward :)
Hi Meena, I would like to invite you to have a look to the new updates of the concept: a new tech tool and a offline community center :)

Since Anne-Laure Fayard wrote me and showed me some other concepts that can work together such as: Interactive Infographics, Capitalizing on the Power of Knowledge, The Detainee Support Net - Financial, Legal, Moral, A real time word connector and A-Z Guide for Families and Friends of Detainees ( Im sure there are more I have a look tomorrow) I have realized that everything is about Connectivity, flow of information! I came out with the idea of merging this concepts( if the authors authorize me) into a possible alliance with GOOGLE EARTH, integrating the Infographics as the search engine of supporters and real time cases! Once you see the entired world populated with human rights violation cases you realize the importance of it. I still have to develop the idea and of course, ask to the other collaborators their support and approval.

Hi Nayda!I really see potential like you say, in adding and collaborating with some of the other concepts A-L mentioned below.Maybe my Interactive Infographic Platform could be one of the tools that your co-workers use to support the unlawfully detained when they are released. I also like you mention the idea of partnering with a lawyer - this could be very helpful not only for your concept, but in implementing many of the concepts we've mentioned. Human Rights's lawyers are very well informed, and we could create a very powerful information network with their knowledge and the data that is submitted to the Interactive Infographic Platform.I'm interested in knowing how you would develop the offline possibility of this concept, maybe create a low-tech version of my Interactive Infographic too !

Good morning Ana, now that you mentioned the offline I remember the Jelly Communities around the world, if you are not familiar with the idea here is a description from one of the groups in LA: JellyLA Coworking is a complimentaryyes, FREEcommunity service! Enjoy wi-fi, communal seating, and relative quiet in professional coworking spaces around Los Angeles. Come to work aloneor colloboratewith other like-minded freelancers, small-business owners, startups, and telecommuters. Maybe we can use theirsome aspects of the Jelly community to build the offline,low-tech version of the interactive Infographic.  As they say, they have  professionals co-working in different projects, so maybe we can design the infographics in this co-working spaces and use the inside and outside of the spaces to show the results. Something like interior and exterior design of the space(office and building) with infographics, so we can expose the results to the people, also we can have a INFOGRAPHIC "art" gallery so the project is open to the public. Let me know what do you think about this. :)
Hi Ana, I would like to invite you to have a look to the new updates of the concept :)

Nayda, very nice video and I also like the holistic approach you're taking. This allows you to encompass all the different actors and "steps" involved in unlawful detention, and work that has to be done.I think it could be interesting to look at other concepts and see how yours can build upon / integrate these other concepts. Here are some that I thought could be included in the co-working concept, but I'm sure I'm missing many:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/crowdsourcing-the-work-required-to-take-these-people-out/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/an-interactive-infographic-platform-fueled-by-the-whole-network-of-supporters-/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/capitalizing-on-the-power-of-knowledge/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/the-detainee-support-net-financial-legal-moral/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-real-time-word-connector/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/food-shelter-clothing/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/a-z-guide-for-families-and-friends-of-detainees/

Anne-Laure I really appreciate your comment! I got in contact with the concepts you sent me and Im more than excited to start merging forces! as the say:" Innovation comes from the creative combination of elements!"...thanks :) ...
Hi Nayda, I'm glad you found this comment useful. As I said I think the strength of your comment is in its holistic perspective. Looking forward to see evolve and build upon others.
Hi Anne, I would like to invite you to have a look to the new updates of the concept, I really appreciate your comments :)
Guys! I have updated The Connectedness of co-working: a new tool and an offline community Center! :)

grand_central_whispering_gallery_.description: Turning a whisper into a shout!
grand_central_whispering_gallery_.creator: 2e5ee009c21e833dceee5d3e41bb9465

comments.text: I really like the idea of spreading the word by experiencing the effects of unlawful detainment. It's a bit prickly because of its potential negative affect, but if we keep in mind the idea of inspiring instead of scaring, raised by Ashley and Anna in http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/be-a-whistleblower-for-peace/ - we can probably come up with some pretty cool installations. Nice post!

great inspiration Anna. I like the idea of using the environment as a way to tell a story. The Grand Central whispering gallery is a great one... Imagine a sound installation (either in one site, or it could also be distributed) where you hear "whispers" telling stories about unlawful detentions...It made me also think of Natalie Jereminjenko's installation Live wire which communicated light and heavy traffic: http://nano.xerox.com/weiser/calmtech/calmtech.htm The idea of the cell-phone dead zone reminded me of the Simon's inspiration on the silence of the media: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/inspiration/the-sound-of-social-media-silence/al

grand_central_whispering_gallery_.title: Grand Central Whispering Gallery

raising_empathy_animated_video_series.description:
Animated videos of heartfelt interviews with family, friends, loved ones of detained individuals who can tell their story and call attention to their search/plight. 

I was inspired by this video done by StoryCorps to honor some of the families of the victims in 9-11.
raising_empathy_animated_video_series.creator: 57d2451a59165ad2a718fabf59bea971

comments.text: Not only do animations keep anonymity, but they open up these serious issues to a whole new demographic--younger people. Starting to empathize for victims from a young age will lead to a generation of people who know about these issues and want to do something. Great thinking!Hannah, Wells College Innovation Lab

Hannah, thanks for pointing that out! I didn't think of it from that perspective. Animations for me represented a very powerful tool to capture the emotions of the viewer. Like in the animated film "Up" - When I saw that in the theaters, after the first 10 minutes, there was barely a dry eye in the house.

I think the concept is great and particularly the empathetic emphasis. My suggestion for superheros or some other identifiable character (eg. Homer Simpson or a manga character in other cultures) was generated by 'unlawful detention' in mythic and fairy story context, as another way to engage the younger demographic.

I'd like to see some more about how this could be fleshed out to incorporate low-tech situations.  I think that the online media portion would be great, but wouldn't it be important to be able to place tie-ins on subway posters and billboard's?

John, thanks for the suggestion! I definitely think that it's possible to choose some quotes or even a simplified success story and adapt it to a more low-tech static environment. Great suggestion on posters and billboards. I can imagine it even being made into a smaller and more mobile form like with flyers.
This idea can also be implemented through live performance (traditional theater/puppetry, poetry readings, 'happenings', etc.), as well, which solves the problem of finding a low-tech solution.

Great thinking here, Kerry. Given the frequent need or desire for the unlawfully detained to remain anonymous, perhaps the animated angle is actually a very appropriate approach. I really like your suggestion about celebrating successful reunions. Looking forward to seeing this concept develop with discussion from others.

Hi Meena! Thanks for the comments! Animations not only will be able to help maintain anonymity but also make the story more relate-able and add to color. Often times, simple but well done illustrations/ animations can be very effective at capturing emotions.

Hi Kerry. Nicely done. Seconding Meena's comment, I too really like the inclusion of the success stories. So, along with including these animated stories with the Support Net, we should definitely include and highlight those successful release stories! Instead of a red "detained # days" we can have a bright green "released!" bar. Thanks for the spark!

raising_empathy_animated_video_series.title: Raising Empathy - Animated Video Series

avaaz_a_voice.description: Avaaz is a global web movement to bring people powered politics to decision making worldwide.  It is made of a transnational community.
avaaz_a_voice.creator: 67131570836d6305e5b632276d5514e9

comments.text: Yes, this a great example of how you can leverage the power of many internet users. Great contribution.

AllOut.org is founded by some of the same people who founded Avaaz and they're actually running a campaign right now that addresses the issue of LGBT incarceration - being jailed simply for sending a text, or just being yourself: http://allout.org/cameroon

avaaz_a_voice.title: Avaaz - a voice

video_links_detainees_to_families.description: Red Cross has been setting up call centers in detention centers in Afghanistan and beyond to connect detainees with their families via video-conference.
video_links_detainees_to_families.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Thanks Meena for this example. I think it shows the importance of thinking of connecting the detainee with their family (to make the experience more "human"as Tayfun mentioned). You could imagine that it will allow them to have access to support from lawyers or any other experts - in a similar way that in developing countries videoconferencing is used to increase access to medical expertise, see for example: http://tier.cs.berkeley.edu/drupal/healthcare

Great build, A-L! Maybe you should add something along the lines of medical videoconferencing that as a distinct Inspiration? You'll get my applause for sure. In fact it was something brought up by a number of our collaborators on the Maternal Health Challenge... but would be great to bring the correlations over to this challenge.

Hi Meena, It definitely does. Even though the detainment is unlawful, it doesn't mean that there shouldn't be any humane treatment to the detained ones.Another advantage of this approach is to cut down on unnecessary travel for the detained ones. Two weeks ago, in Turkey, a bus that carries people from jail to a trial was burned and several people unfortunately died. This could have been prevented or minimized if there was a Video Conference system where people could have given their statements over such system.
Great build on the example posted here, Tayfun. And again  it's so good to get current insights from you, highlighting the reach of our global community!

video_links_detainees_to_families.title: Video Links Detainees to Families

ai_wei_wei_detention.description: Ai Wei Wei has been known to be a bold political activist that seek to bring attention to cases of human rights violations in China.  He has made an appearance after his detention to tell of the mental pressures of detention on himself.
ai_wei_wei_detention.creator: 3de4618386a1d6d56223a3d6d36bd440

comments.text: Frances  great idea to use actual detainee insights as inspiration! Any chance you can find an English sub-titled version of this clip? If possible you could then switch the video embedded here using the Update Entry button on the right of your post.

ai_wei_wei_detention.title: Ai Wei Wei Detention

digital_remembrance_a_service_to_support.description: The Digital Remembrance is a web-based service provided by Amnesty International which allows people at risk to leave messages for his/her loved ones. If the at-risk-person is illegally detained, the account will be activated, and start sending stories/pictures/messages to the family. This will allow the illegally detained person to spread joy and happiness, even when s/he is not with her/his family.
digital_remembrance_a_service_to_support.creator: 046c14ccc821e094ab37859494deeacc

comments.text: Wonderful, sensitive concept Anne.Assisting families to preserve memories both digital and physical is always worthwhile. My father died two years ago and I am presently constructing a blog with some of the visual, audible and written memories and materials.Even while people are still alive helping families preserve momentos is appropriate.

Thank you Paul for your nice comments and for sharing your own experience. Do you use a particular program / blog which is designed for this kind digital remembrance? I also wonder if there were any feature in the blog  you use, which you really appreciate, or a feature which you think would make the blog even more useful?

Nice concept, Anne. I agree on the role of providing people a chance to have a shared digital diary... letters indeed played a role: it was receiving them, writing them, but also keeping them. You could imagine like a shared blog. It reminds me of 2 concepts, which while different touch upon this idea of writing, relationships and memories:http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/memories-museum-for-the-unlawful-detention/http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/mobile-letter-writing-workshops/The only restriction I see is that this would work only for activists who know they are at risk. It is important to take them into account and design for them. From a lot of stories collected in the inspiration phases and from the Q&A, it seems to me that there are many cases where people are unlawfully detained who did not expect to be detained. Again, it does not take away the strength of your concept.

digital_remembrance_a_service_to_support.title: Digital Remembrance  - a service to support the families left behind

secure_network_to_provide_customized_rea.description: There can be no one solution to help a detained person. Why not a network to provide effective solutions that are customized to meet their specific needs in real-time? We also need to keep the information secure to prevent backlash of technology by completely owning it. This is built from the first "Open IDEO student chapter @ NYU Poly" meeting ever!
secure_network_to_provide_customized_rea.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: Great concept.
networking and databasing are good examples of how we can help prevent unlawful detention and this concept is a great example of that
Yes, it's better to be prepared and the first step is awareness.

Hi Ashwin,congratulations indeed on your first OpenIDEO student chapter brainstorming!I really like your systemic / holistic approach to the challenge and your attempt to build upon and integrate various concepts.Here are a few thoughts:- developing a few scenarios or at least short situations could be help clarifying the different situations, actors and resources involved.In a way, your concept is nearly too dense to see its whole breadth.- Before detention: I guess that Amnesty International has probably some (most) of this information and maybe already some analysis and profiling. If they don't, you might want to think of the resources needed in doing this.-I'm unclear who are potentially the people who are at risk. Who would go and do the questionnaire? - I like your idea of thinking of various of people resources, including OpenIDEO members.- Could you explain a bit more what you see "during detention"? I think I understand but it'll be great if you could clarify.thanks!al

It's not only about the people in risk, I believe that everyone must have a profile. One good way would be include it as an app on Facebook or by other forms of marketing. The more people Amnesty can collect information from, the more effective the potential solutions would be. Probably combine it with something like 50 people, one question or Alan's idea of interactive art to spread the word about this program.

Thanks Ashwin. I understand that the more data, the better. I was just wondering why people who don't think at risk will go and create a profile. Maybe there's a way to show them the "benefits" through a campaign.
I think so too :-)

A Scenario depicting what happens before and during detention: Meet Bob. Bob has heard of the Amnesty International program to help people who have been illegally detained (we need a catchier name) through one of the marketing channels that we have to select. So he signs up for it and fills in the questionnaire which analyses his "Risk" (His type of employment, travelling and so forth) and "Resources" (Friends, Family, Employer) most of which can be directly imported through Facebook. So time goes by and if Bob gets detained during his travels, an alert will go off (inactivity on a social network, cell-phone based panic button or any other mechanism that could have been selected beforehand). His family and friends can get contacted that he has been missing and help them initiate the formal process for release. Meanwhile in the background, the Amnesty International system will generate data based on previously stored information that matches the case. It contacts interested people in the "Support Network" which includes Volunteers, Lawyers, Members of the Press and even Open IDEO members who can work on a real-time solution customized to Bob's unique situation. Even if a person does not belong to the platform and if they receive information about his or her illegal detainment, this same Support Network can work with the family to provide assistance. Thus, when Bob is released, it will be due to the collective effort of many people who care. And according to the Medici Effect the most effective solutions are born from a group with unique skills and backgrounds. To support the whole network in a secure manner, Amnesty can work with DIASPORA to create a solution that they can own and completely control in order to protect everyone, their employees, volunteers and members.

thanks Ashwin for this updated scenario. It helps clarify the concept, but also to come up with more questions :-)Here is one: why does Bob sign up for the program? He's volunteering to help - e.g. be part of the network suggested by Angelikihttp://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/crowdsourcing-the-work-required-to-take-these-people-out/- or he feels potentially at risk.I understand that even as a volunteer you would feel in the questionnaire but I'm trying to understand better the first step for signing up (both cases seem possible). Just a comment as a non-facebook user (yes this species still exists! :-) ), don't assume that everyone is on facebook and offer other ways of giving / getting the information. I like the way you're building up on the infrastructure solution suggested by Lei.

Well, Facebook was only one example of a marketing tool to a wide audience. And Bob signs up for it because he believes that he may be at risk in a foreign country or if he knows he'll be attending a demonstration or he may do it for fun in the beginning and then take it seriously and in any case, it'll only take a short while. He may or may not become a volunteer. Or he may come to know about the service by reading about it somewhere. Or through word of mouth or a flyer or a mobile add or the TV.
thanks for the clarifications. I understand better your potential users, i.e. people who feel at risk. It thought so but just wanted to make sure.thanks, al

Hi Ashwin, I find really interesting and useful your 'risks and resources' approach! Yes, indeed, there could be a systematic methods to handle unlawful detention and we can only find out through research. But imagine a network with people who feel at risk (leftists, activists, anarchists, etc) in a country without democratic values; would it be possible? Would it be safe?Imagine that in such country, one person of this network is unlawfully detained and his personal computer is investigated. Wouldn't that put all the people in his network at risk?

That's why I added the other concept from our Student Chapter here: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/decentralize-the-network-own-and-protect-your-data which explains how we can use Diaspora, a project from NYU Courant by completely owning and protecting the data by making sure that it is not stored anywhere. The comments especially make the application clear. It's really a great concept and has untold possibilities.
Congrats on hosting the first OpenIDEO student chapter meeting @ NYU Poly, Ashwin!
Thank you Meena, couldn't done it without Ashley and you!

Hi Ashwin. I definitely like the idea of an intelligent Amnesty-engine crunching success story data in order to suggest resources. I see you mentioned Diaspora for the secure network the engine would run over, so can I suggest adding the development of the Comparison Engine that makes the intelligent decisions to your resources section? It seems like an important part that shouldn't be overlooked. Nice job!
Yeah, but I imagined that it would only exist to serve the real resources - people. Bu you're right, such a system, if created, would definitely be a great resource.
we have similar thoughts... Great!!!
I know, there are a lot of similarly themed concepts this time. A lot of network-related solutions. That's good, more people to work with!
Nice. I really like how you propose data mining opportunities to help create solutions and try to quickly resolve any unlawful detention. This could also empower lawyers, maybe, to offer assistance.
Yes, data mining can be applied hand in hand with the support network. It's more of a support system by itself for the people working for a person's release.

secure_network_to_provide_customized_rea.title: Secure network to provide Customized Real-time solution.

nightwatch.description:
Nightwatch would be a website where people can post where and when they are protesting, if they or anyone they know are detained, an a place where they can share their stories and pictures.  
Wells College Innovation class
Pamela Badian-Pessot
Alyssa Acquaviva
Ryan Huggins
Marissa Burns
Pat O'Callaghan
nightwatch.creator: 6db89a242b266272161ffcf489e0b557

comments.text: Nice one, guys! It's been interesting to note how Tumblr & social media have helped fuel Occupy Wall St protests. Are there further learnings from there which could help flesh out this Concept? Are there aspects which are working there which are more suited to a switched-on internet savvy audience  which might be adapted for contexts elsewhere? Looking forward to discussion on this.

Hi Pamela, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know if you face any problems. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

nightwatch.title: Nightwatch
